fields.headline: Nationwide loan index's credibility questioned in fresh Halifax spat
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Halifax and Nationwide's mortgage feud entered a new phase yesterday, with the latest spat focusing on Nationwide's house price index - the results of which are pored over by millions of homeowners and buyers every month.
fields.body:
Halifax and Nationwide's mortgage feud entered a new phase yesterday, with the latest spat focusing on Nationwide's house price index - the results of which are pored over by millions of homeowners and buyers every month.

Mortgage brokers claim Nationwide's home loan sales have fallen sharply since it changed its pricing structure two months ago.

Halifax said yesterday that people should be aware that because the house price index is based on new mortgages going through the system, if lending is down this will have an impact.

Halifax's claims were bolstered by comments yesterday by the leading mortgage broker Charcol, which said Nationwide will need to "make some adjustments" to its price index to reflect the fact that it is selling fewer mortgages via brokers and more through its branch network, which has a southern bias.

Both companies' comments were angrily denied by Nationwide, however.

A spokesman poured scorn on Halifax's own price index, saying it had been "all over the place" in recent months.

The two lenders have clashed several times in the past over house prices, and two months ago they engaged in a tussle over the changes they had made to their mortgage pricing.

After both cut their main home loan rates, Nationwide's chief executive, Brian Davis, accused the Halifax of disseminating "misinformation" after it claimed to offer a better deal to borrowers. Nationwide's monthly house price index is considered a leading barometer of the property market.

But one industry source said: "If their lending is going into free fall, as some say it is, it will have an effect on the figures that are produced."

The greatest impact will be on Nationwide's regional house price breakdown, said a Halifax spokesman.

If there are not enough mortgages going through in a particular region, "there will come a stage when it is not possible to present those figures because they are not statistically robust enough".

The Halifax spokesman also claimed that since late February, Nationwide had not appeared in any of the mortgage "best buy" tables.

Nationwide confirmed that sales of mortgages through brokers were down "a little bit" as a result of its decision to pull out of offering highly competitive discounted rate deals to new borrowers.

Mortgage business through its branches had improved, however.

But the spokesman said this "makes absolutely no difference to the house price index".

Nationwide had seen a sharp increase in remortgage business, and 40% of this was coming from Halifax and Bradford & Bingley, which owns Charcol, he added.

"It is certainly interesting that it is Halifax and Charcol that are flagging up what they see as potential issues when it is their customers who are coming though our doors," said the spokesman.

"We are totally committed to the pricing strategy. It is based on a philosophy of fairness and transparency."

webTitle: Salesman sacked after failing personality test

fields.headline: 'Failure' turns his back on B&Q
fields.standfirst:
Star salesman sacked after personality test says he will shun any job offer from store chain

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Star salesman sacked after personality test says he will shun any job offer from store chain.
fields.byline: Paul Kelso  and  Faisal al Yafai
fields.body:
A B&Q employee who was offered a promotion only to be sacked because he had failed a psychometric personality test has said he will turn the company down if it offers him his job back.

Carl Filer, 18, from Ferndown, Dorset, was a salesman at B&Q's Bournemouth store where he was regarded as a star employee and within a week had been asked to become a supervisor. But Mr Filer was taken on before the results of the 50-question telephone test relating to his work and personal life had been returned. Yesterday B&Q said management at the store were at fault for offering him the job before the results were known, but its representatives would be willing to meet Mr Filer and might offer to re-employ him.

Mr Filer said: "How could I go back and work for a company like that? I would never be able to trust them. You would never know whether they were about to sack you again for no reason.

"The only thing I will accept from B&Q is an apology and compensation."

Mr Filer may have a case for wrongful dismissal if he was not told that his employment was conditional on the test, but as he had worked there for only a week any compensation would be "minuscule", according to the TUC.

Usdaw, the retail trade union with more than 310,000 members, condemned the dismissal. B&Q does not recognise unions, to which its attitude was described as "not supportive".

"The ridiculous thing about this case is that the guy is obviously good at his job and has proved it but the test says he's unsuitable," a spokesman said. "It simply makes a nonsense of psychometric testing. The idea that it's a foolproof and accurate way of selecting employees is simply wrong.

"When we talk to employers they stress the need for flexibility in the workforce, for split shifts and short-term contracts, but when it comes to these decisions they are totally rigid. Retail is a people business and if he's a good people person then this decision is a nonsense."

Personality tests such as the one Mr Filer failed are becoming more common as employers seek quickly and cheaply to identify the most promising applicants.

According to the Industrial Society there are around 5,000 tests used in the selection of more than 50% of managers. Even for technical jobs where professional qualifications are relevant, psychometric testing is used in 37% of cases.

Theo Blackwell, a policy specialist at the Industrial Society, said the tests were a valid part of the selection process: "They can be a useful tool for achieving balance in the workforce and choosing the right employee. Tests are no substitute for human judgment."

Jill Garrett, a spokeswoman for Gallup which designed the B&Q test Mr Filer took, said: "The tests are carefully designed mainly as pre-face to face screeners. They are a much valued way of sorting who will be successful in a role, rather than CVs."

Carl Filer took the B&Q test over the phone, responding to 50 statements by pressing keys 1 to 5, with 5 expressing strong agreement and 1 strong disagreement. Here are some of his responses:

I am an over-achiever. (1)

I hate to have other people know mistakes I have made. (2)

I will report fellow employees who take merchandise that does not belong to them. (4)

Most people will steal if they think they won't get caught. (5)

Unfinished work really bothers me. (3)

I would be good as a customer adviser because even though I don't know an answer I could always make it up. (1)

Advising customers on home improvements will soon be very boring unless I can expect an early promotion. (1)

I simply do not miss work because of illness. (3)

My word is my bond. (4)

fields.headline: Women enjoy greater financial freedom
fields.standfirst: A major survey reveals that females are gaining ground in most areas - except pensions. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: A major survey reveals that females are gaining ground in most areas - except pensions. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
Women are more financially independent than at any time in the past the Financial Services Authority said this week, but added that in one area, pensions, they still badly trail men.

Only 22% of women have a pension, compared with 40% of men, the FSA found. But it found that in nearly all other types of financial products women have caught up with, or overtaken, men. 79% of women have a bank current account, only a shade below men at 83%. When it comes to savings accounts more women - 59% - have an account than men, 57%.

Women appear to save more even though they typically earn less: hourly earnings for women are still a fifth below the average £10.20 per hour earned by men.

The FSA's consumer relations director Christine Farnish said: "The good news in the report is that growing numbers of women of working age are financially independent, with fewer differences between men and women in the ownership of financial products.

"The bad news is that pension ownership is still significantly lower among women than men. There is no escaping the fact that some women, particularly those at or approaching retirement age, will remain disadvantaged."

The report, produced jointly by the FSA, the Treasury and the Cabinet Office, was produced in recognition of the fact that women are increasingly likely to have their own financial needs.

The proportion of women who are economically active rose from 56% in 1971 to 73% in 2000, while the decline of marriage and the increase in divorce or separation has led to an increasing number of women heading up family households.

Researchers found that women are generally more cautious, more careful and more traditional than men in handling finances. Women also have a greater preference for face-to-face advice than men, and are less likely to hop between different financial institutions.

But trite conclusions about women and money are avoided by the report; it recognises that age, employment, ethnic origin and social background are all more important than gender in itself. For example, 31% of Bangladeshi women in the survey owned no financial products, compared to just 5% of white women and 4% of white men.

The significant gender difference on financial products is pensions. Among men, 29% hold an occupational pension, compared with only 18% of women, while 12% of men hold a personal pension compared to 5% of women.

"Partly this is because marital status has a significant impact on pension ownership for women in a way that it doesn't for men. Being part of a couple suppressed pension ownership among women, with less than one in three married or cohabiting women having a pension, compared with one-half of cohabiting and two-fifths of married men," says the report.

The pension gap is a serious issue for women; their old age now lasts on average five years longer than men.

Marriage breakdown has a more dramatic impact on the financial situation of women than men, the report says.

 Women and personal finance; the reality of the gender gap, is available on the FSA website or can be ordered from the FSA Publications line on 0845 608 2372.

But if you are reading this article, you are unlikely to do much about it, because you're probably a man. The survey found that while one in three men regularly read the financial pages of newspapers, only one if five women do so.

fields.headline: Pick best funds for £10,000 top prize
fields.standfirst: If you can guess which five investments will see the biggest gains over the next year, you will win, says Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: If you can guess which five investments will see the biggest gains over the next year, you will win, says Patrick Collinson.
fields.body:
Ever fancied yourself as a City expert, able to second-guess investment markets and pick the shares of the future? Now you have the chance to prove yourself - and pick up a £10,000 cash prize - in the Guardian/Barnardo's Investment Challenge.

All you have to do is select which five funds of the 52 listed below will grow most rapidly over the next 12 months, starting on May 1. To help you, Jobs & Money this week profiles the funds' investment strategy and performance figures.

Each of the funds has pledged a £50 per month investment to benefit children's charity Barnardo's, so you won't be the only winner. To enter, call our hotline on 0906-753-4414 by April 30.

webTitle: War images that will help healing process

fields.headline: War images that will help healing process
fields.standfirst: An exhibition and auction to commemorate the fall of Saigon will fund a photojournalism workshop in Vietnam, says Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: An exhibition and auction to commemorate the fall of Saigon will fund a photojournalism workshop in Vietnam, says Stewart Dalby.
fields.body:
April 30 is the 26th anniversary of the fall of Saigon, marking the end of the last of the Indochina Wars. These wars, which lasted from 1945 until 1975, were among the longest in modern history. In some ways, they were also the most traumatic.

Images For Indochina, an exhibition and auction to raise funds for the work of the Indochina Media Memorial Foundation, is a very worthwhile commemorative event. It takes place on April 18 to April 26 with an auction on the final day at 7pm. It will be held at The Freedom Forum, Stanhope House, Stanhope Place, London W2.

There will be more than 205 pieces at the show, the work of 83 photographers, some of them illustrious names and others unsung Vietnamese and Cambodian ones.

Not every print is from the last Vietnam war. There is a photograph by Roger Fenton of the Crimea war donated by Lord Macdonald of Tradeston. However, the bulk of the pieces cover the 1946 to 1975 period. All the photographs have been donated for sale at the auction.

British photographer and author Tim Page conceived the IMMF in 1991. He wanted to do something to mark the lives and deaths of more than 300 media colleagues from two dozen countries, killed or missing while covering all sides of the wars in Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos through the 30 years until 1975.

The conflicts in Indochina highlighted the role of the media in what was widely acknowledged to be the first televisual war. For the journalists involved in IMMF, which include Sandy Gall and Jon Swain in the UK, the memory of lost colleagues has provoked a desire to support the development of good practice in journalism in the region where this piece of history unfolded.

It has often been said that journalists exploit the misery of war for venal ends. The foreign journalist had the choice of getting on an aircraft and going home. The Vietnamese never had that option. While 48,000 Americans and civilians died, 2m Vietnamese people were killed.

This November, the IMMF, in co-operation with the Vietnam Association of Photographic Artists, will hold an eight-day workshop on photo-journalism in Ho Chi Minh City (the former Saigon). Five experienced western photojournalists will work with 25 young Vietnamese ones. This exhibition and auction are to raise funds for that workshop.

A televisual war it may have been, but somehow the most enduring images of the wars are still photographs. One example is the picture of police chief Colonel Loan shooting a bound Vietcong suspect in the head at point blank range. There was television coverage, but the photograph by Eddie Adams had greater impact.

Another is of course the picture of the naked girl fleeing a napalm attack in 1972. Huynh Cong 'Nick' Ut won a Pulitzer Prize for this.

The wars went on so long that the show is like a roll call of famous war correspondents. Robert Capa, who made his name in the Spanish civil war and died in Vietnam in 1954, is there. So too is Larry Burrows, who was killed in Laos in 1970. Don McCullin, who is still alive, also has a picture in the show.

Estimates start at £50 and go up to £2,000 for an Eve Arnold photograph. It is hoped that the sale will raise at least £50,000.

 For further information telephone trustee Chris Peterson on 020-7330-7547, mobile 0778-524-4115.

fields.headline: Red card for green test failures
fields.standfirst: Co-op Bank is rejecting loan applications from companies which do not fulfil its policies on the environment, writes Tony Levene
fields.trailText: Co-op Bank is rejecting loan applications from companies which do not fulfil its policies on the environment, writes Tony Levene.
fields.body:
Co-op Bank is turning away one in five loan applications from businesses because they fail to pass the bank's ethical and environmental screens, it revealed this week.

Britain's biggest bank to embrace social responsibility - the blanket term for green and ethical investment crite ria - refuses to provide facilities to companies which do not live up to its policies on the environment and other social issues - even if they are creditworthy.

And those hurdles could rise still higher. Later this year, the bank's 2m personal customers will be asked whether the ethical criteria should change.

"Ethical issues are not static," says ethical policy manager Barry Clavin. "People are now less concerned with hunting and the fur trade -both these battles have been largely won - and they have moved onto GM food, not an issue when we last polled ac count holders, and labour conditions and human rights where the emphasis is now moving on to companies rather than concentrating on governments."

Companies involved in greenhouse gas emission and other forms of climate change are also set to be targetted by the Co-op.

On Thursday, holders of some 920m shares in BP Amoco, Britain's biggest company, voted for a Greenpeace resolution backed by World Wildlife Fund and Sane (Shareholders Against New oil Exploration). This called on the company to take seriously the threats of climate change on fossil fuel investments.

"It needs to protect future financial earnings by investing in renewable energy sources," says Greenpeace campaigner Stephanie Dunmore.

Around one in 14 BP shares backed the Greenpeace move - less than supported a green resolution a year ago. But the BP board upped the stakes by making the resolution a vote of confidence in itself. This scared off some investors.

Greenpeace itself had few votes - proxies from sup porters. But the bulk of its following came from UK socially responsible funds that aim for positive engagement with firms rather than shunning shares.

Co-op Bank believes its stance takes over where mainstream ethical investment and unit trusts stop. "Those funds cover the biggest companies. Some of those are our customers but most of the 150,000 business accounts are small and medium-sized firms. We're applying ethics to that area of the economy," says Clavin.

Co-op screens new customers - firstly with a questionnaire which asks about activities.

This is self certifying. Businesses that could fail are then subjected to further screenings. A farmer, for instance, might have to show involvement in organic rather than factory farming.

Other high risk firms include those in engineering, where some small firms might have links either to armaments or to processes that pollute, and in chemicals.

Recent companies to be turned down for loans or accounts include one responsible for stripping South American rainforests and a communications company that sold surveillance material to China and Indonesia.

The Co-op customer consultation will be completed in the autumn.

fields.headline: A sensual yet innocent Otello
fields.standfirst:
Otello
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Otello
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Jose Cura is an artist you either love or loathe - but he's impossible to ignore. The Argentinian tenor-cum-heart-throb is back at Covent Garden as Verdi's Otello, breathing new life into Elijah Moshinsky's well-worn production, and his performance, predictably, is unlike anything we've experienced in the opera before. His Otello is a beguiling creature, at once sensual and innocent. There's little intimation of the glittering warrior. His first appearance - bounding down the gangplank of his ship, dishevelled, shirt open to the waist, pectorals bulging - suggests sexual rather than military conquest. In what follows, you're sometimes left wondering how the man attained the position of political responsibility that he holds.

Where Cura scores high, however, is in the erotic blatancy of his depiction of Otello's desire for Desdemona, which remains unquenchable even after Iago's insinuations have done their work. Calling her a whore, he sexually attacks her. Before he wakes her to kill her, he lets the shadow of his hand run over her crotch, while the murder itself carries disturbing implications of rape. Vocally, he's beautiful, virile and athletic, if occasionally unsubtle, not always employing the wide range of tone colour he uses elsewhere.

He is pitted against the equally formidable Iago of Alexandru Agache. Physically, Agache is stolid, unprepossessing, very much "honest Iago" rather than some malevolent force. The danger lies in the seditious, velvety beauty of his voice, which seduces as well as poisons. His description of Cassio's imagined nocturnal fantasies have a luscious, prurient obscenity. It's not surprising that Otello is so easily duped.

Amanda Roocroft's Desdemona isn't quite in their league, however. She suggests a girlish, shatterable fragility that sits uneasily with the score. Verdi and his librettist Boito excised from Shakespeare much of the knowing bawdry that characterises Desdemona, replacing it with music of tremendous dignity and self-assurance. Roocroft, however, remains drippy and waif-like, while her voice doesn't always have the necessary weight to allow Verdi's lines to flow with the ease that they should.

The casting elsewhere is luxurious - Kurt Streit (no less) as Cassio, gorgeously vapid, and conveying just enough sexual charisma to give genuine grounds for suspicion. In the pit, Daniele Gatti drives the score hard, at times too much so. There's plenty of electricity, nervous energy and dramatic fire, but he's unyielding in places; the act one love scene in particular seems markedly lacking in tenderness.

 In rep until May 3. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

The Argentinian tenor-cum-heart-throb is back at Covent Garden as Verdi's Otello, breathing new life into Elijah Moshinsky's well-worn production, and his performance, predictably, is unlike anything we've experienced in the opera before. fields.headline: Damage make the girls swoon
fields.standfirst:
Damage
Ocean
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Damage
Ocean
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Damage's newly released album Since You've Been Gone has been described as "exceptional" by their label, but it's not quite enough to divert attention from the fact that this R&B boy band are better known for their friends than their music (unless you happen to be a fierce Lolita who swoons over main fox Jade Jones, as many of this crowd were). It was Damage who discovered Craig David, while Jones is familiar to tabloid readers as Mr Baby Spice.

The album contains a duet by Baby and Jones that proved an unexpected high point at this gig. The Spice Girl skipped out of the wings, drowning in white wool and determinedly loved-up, but the ensuing routine wasn't nearly the act of gross Kylie-and-Jasonness it threatened to be. In fact, they made a sweet couple, pirouetting in an intricate mating dance that climaxed with her hurtling into his arms to thunderous applause.

The real business of the evening, though, was stirring the ladies into a polite frenzy through a carefully calibrated mix of sauce and soul. Even if the soul was lite, it was staggeringly accomplished by the usual boyband standards. Damage are to Westlife what the Beatles were to Herman's Hermits: the pinnacle of the genre. This isn't apparent on their records, but give them a stage, shiny black shirts and the encouragement of a crowd who'd love to swallow them whole, and they shine.

Their voices meshed and bent notes with luxurious ease on an unplugged version of Eric Clapton's Wonderful Tonight. They decamped to separate corners of the stage for a glowing After the Love Has Gone. Inevitably, their own material was less spot-on, and after a few tepid bedroom jams such as Forever, in which Bald Damage and Afro Damage promised to "be loving you till forever", your eyes strayed to the pert tushes offered for inspection. Each time they did a collective shimmy, the squeal monitor inched further into the red until the girls had wailed themselves sick.

This was a successful night all round, and left one even less charitably inclined toward the talentless nobodies who comprise the majority of boy and girl groups. This uplifting, mildly sexy show argued that it doesn't have to be that way.

fields.headline: Ed Jones battles his bandmates
fields.standfirst:
Ed Jones
Bonington Theatre
Nottingham
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Ed Jones
Bonington Theatre
Nottingham
Rating: ****
fields.body:
British saxophonist Ed Jones either likes to spoil himself or enjoys making his own job infinitely harder. For his latest tour he has chosen to work with members of the Jonathan Gee quartet, one of the most exciting and accomplished instrumental groups in the country. As a result, he was under constant threat of being upstaged, and sometimes looked a bit scared at having to take a solo.

His cohorts' technical ability was not their most alarming characteristic. Pianist Gee and drummer Winston Clifford communicate almost telepathically, instantaneously translating each other's musical ideas to their own instruments. They stared at each other from opposite sides of the stage, egging each other on, while Jones, bassist Jeff Gasgoine and Finnish trumpet virtuoso Mika Myllari were caught in the crossfire, sometimes looking slightly overwhelmed.

The band stuck mainly to Jones originals, all of which were rooted in driving Art Blakey-style hard bop, and most of which featured some crisp but under-deployed ensemble writing. The closely tangled harmonies of Premonition and the tightly controlled counterpoint of Kickstart were so engrossing that it was quite frustrating to watch the soloists queuing up for their turn in the spotlight - although with the quality of musicianship on offer, it would be churlish to complain too much.

Myllari favoured short, glowing phrases while Jones threw the kitchen sink into his solos, plundering every register of the instrument and constructing dizzyingly long legato runs, his tone tender and elegiac. Gee proved himself a master of repetition, either hammering out bluesy single notes or reiterating complex chord sequences until they subtly began to evolve. Like Clifford, he adopted both a light touch and an idiosyncratic approach, at one point reaching inside the piano to stroke the strings while the drummer used his hands to beat out a samba rhythm.

However, Clifford's most delightful contribution came during the encore, when he stepped out from behind his drums and indulged in some miraculously accomplished scat singing. Sensing defeat, Jones didn't even try to follow that.

fields.headline: Pension funds' worst year since 1974
fields.standfirst:
70 leading managers record first-quarter losses

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Only one of more than 70 big pension fund managers avoided losses for its investors during the past three months, it emerged yesterday - the worst performance for the industry since 1974.
fields.body:
Only one of more than 70 big pension fund managers avoided losses for its investors during the past three months, it emerged yesterday - the worst performance for the industry since 1974.

The only fund to produce a positive return in the three months to the end of March was managed by the J Rothschild insurance group, which rose 6.1% in comparison with a 8.4% fall in the FTSE all-share index during the period.

The much followed league tables from performance measurement group Combined Actuarial Performance Services - or Caps - showed the difference in fortunes for two of the most high-profile fund management groups, Phillips & Drew and Nicola Horlick's SG fund management.

P&D is claiming fourth and fifth position after almost three years languishing towards the bottom of table after its arch-bear - the now retired Tony Dye - called the downturn in the market four years too soon.

P&D's strategy now appears vindicated as the markets turn down, and it claims to have recovered all the ground it lost for investors over the previous two-and-a-half years.

If its performance is measured over 12 months rather than three, it is ranked first and second, and is the only manager to have produced a positive return for pensioners over the longer period.

"We've continued to stick with our guns," said Matthew Stempt of P&D.

"We've avoided the stocks which were overvalued".

Meanwhile, SG - whose prominence in terms of its public profile is assured by "superwoman" Ms Horlick - finds its funds are ranked just seven places from bottom at the end of the quarter.

Keith Percy, the head of SG, admitted that the three months had been "disappointing", but took heart from the long term performance of the operation he set up with Mr Horlick three years ago.

Reflecting how suddenly the stock markets have altered in recent months, the small but once top performing fund management group Fuji was consigned to bottom place in the tables.

Some of the fund management groups which have traditionally dominated the industry - Schroders, Gartmore, Merrill Lynch, formerly known as Mercury Asset Mangement, and Deutsche, which used to be known as Morgan Grenfell - endured mixed results.

Schroders was 24th, Gartmore 65th, Merrill Lynch 51st, 53rd and 18th while Deutsche was 52nd.

J Rothschild which was ranked first, took second and third place but also 58th.

The poor performance in the first three months by the industry in general contributed to last year's difficult period for fund managers.

Caps said it was the fifth quarter in succession to show a negative return.

The Caps measurement figures are important because they are used by the big pension fund groups to try to win new business from leading pension fund groups.

The fund management groups try to avoid too close a scrutiny of quarter by quarter results because they argue that it is performance over the long term that matters.

webTitle: Poor advice that led to more than £1,000 wasted in premiums

fields.headline: Poor advice that led to more than £1,000 wasted in premiums
fields.standfirst: Tania Shishkin was sold permanent health insurance - but her company already had her covered. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: Tania Shishkin was sold permanent health insurance - but her company already had her covered. Tony Levene reports.
fields.body:
When high profile independent financial advice firm Holden Meehan sold Londoner Tania Shishkin an insurance policy six years ago, she was grateful for the protection it offered.

But earlier this year, Ms Shishkin was shocked to discover that the £1,100 she had paid in premiums was completely unnecessary, as she had been covered under her company scheme for the entire period.

And when she demanded compensation from Holden Meehan, the firm ignored her protests, despite the fact that it had earned £209 commission from the sale.

She also found that she had slipped through a regulatory loophole, leaving her unable to complain of mis-selling either to the IFA or the ombudsman. But this week Jobs & Money stepped in, and the firm has now offered Ms Shishkin compensation.

In 1994, Ms Shishkin, an art editor with a medical magazine, needed a mortgage. She went to Amanda Davidson, a director of Holden Meehan, which focuses on ethical investment advice.

"I was 33 at the time. I had a two-year-old child and I chose this firm on the recommendation of a work colleague. It was my first ever mortgage," she says.

Ms Davidson helped her select a home loan and a life insurance policy to back it. Ms Shishkin remains happy with the loan and cover advice.

"Then she asked me whether I had considered how I would keep up my mortgage payments if I fell seriously ill. She recommended that I think about taking out a permanent health insurance (PHI) policy," says Ms Shishkin.

PHI pays out a proportion of the monthly wage if the holder cannot work through illness after a preset period - anything from a month to a year - until the holder's retirement date, if necessary. The payout is usually fixed at 50% of the monthly salary.

"I had never heard of PHI but since I had a child and was not given to any kind of financial risk, I decided to sign up just in case," she adds. Ms Davidson recommended a £14.57 a month plan with Permanent Insurance, a specialist in this area.

But discussing insurance with a colleague recently, she discovered that she had PHI built into her company pension plan. Because PHI is geared to her salary, she could only claim once.

"I had wasted money which I can't afford to lose now that I have two children and work part-time," Ms Shishkin says.

She contacted Permanent which refunded half the premiums, keeping the balance because they had been at risk - any payments would have to be split 50/50 with the company scheme.

But Holden Meehan refused to pay back the remaining 50%. Compliance officer John Ferguson wrote: "The factfind you signed states that other than a pension and death in service life cover, there are no other employer provided benefits."

Ms Shishkin says: "Their line is that I should have known about the PHI. But that was a big assumption. You pay financial advisers to prompt you on these things."

It was made clear she could take her complaint no further. Mr Ferguson wrote: "This type of product is largely unregulated and will almost certainly be outside the jurisdiction of the ombudsman."

The Financial Ombudsman Service agrees. It says that PHI sales by an IFA fall outside the Personal Investment Authority regulatory remit as there is no investment element.

Other advisers say avoiding duplication of personal and company schemes is an essential part of financial planning. IFA James Higgins of Chamberlain de Broe says: "You can't expect clients to know these things - that's our job. Checking on possible workplace PHI before selling a policy is fundamental."

Jobs & Money contacted Holden Meehan. It has now decided to compensate Ms Shishkin. Director Mark Dear says: "Based upon the discussions held at the time with Miss Shishkin and her answers we recommended PHI. If we had known that Miss Shishkin was insured by her employers then we would not have made this recommendation.

"In view of this misunderstanding and to finalise this matter we shall pay Ms Shishkin 50% of the premiums paid as an 'ex-gratia' payment. This is based upon no admittance of liability, but as an act of good faith toward a client."

webTitle: Theatre review: Love in a Wood

fields.headline: Love in a Wood
fields.standfirst:
Swan
Stratford-upon-Avon
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Swan
Stratford-upon-Avon
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Fluttering fans and frippery are out in Restoration comedy - emotional reality is in. Tim Supple's bare-walled, stripped-down production of Wycherley's first play is commendably austere, but it is, if anything, let down by its author. In accurately diagnosing Wycherley's sexual cynicism, Supple also exposes his convoluted plotting.

"How," Harley Granville-Barker once asked, "could an audience both be clever enough to understand the story and stupid enough to be interested in it when they did?" Even if that's a bit harsh, it has a grain of truth. The main plot hinges on nocturnal malarkey in St James's Park and the predatory Ranger's pursuit of his masked mistress, Lydia, to the home of one Christina, by whom he is instantly smitten. But Christina's eavesdropping lover, Valentine, immediately assumes he has been betrayed. If only the twerpish Valentine would come out of hiding, he could resolve the whole imbroglio in a second; instead it rattles on for a couple of acts.

Wycherley was no great plotter; his real strength, like that of Ben Jonson, lies in his documentary observation. He paints a vicious portrait of post-plague and fire 1671 London where "park-time" is a code-word for sexual cruising, where the men are rapacious and the women venal. The best scene shows the puritanical Alderman Gripe seducing the youthful Lucy with the connivance of both her mother and a bawd. Carol Macready's serenely maternal pimp places her hand next to Lucy's mouth as if demanding money in exchange for kisses; and any idea that Lucy is a helpless innocent is banished by her lewd cry to Paul Bentall's supposed dancing master: "I don't see your fiddle, sir; where is your little kit?"

At times Supple makes Wycherley's brutal realism look even harsher than it already is: he not only has Lucy rend her dress to prove sexual assault but later shows Ranger hurling his disguised mistress to the ground with intent to rape. Indeed, Robert Bowman's beefy predator sometimes suggests that he's more a Queens Park than a St James's Park Ranger. But, in a strong ensemble, there is good work from Diana Kent as a voracious husband-hunter plagued with beauty spots, from Amanda Drew as the sexually tenacious Lydia and from Louis Hilyer as a manic coxcomb.

No lost masterpiece has been uncovered. But Supple brings out Wycherley's moral bleakness and confirms that Restoration comedy, which sees sex as a mix of naked appetite and financial gain and marriage as a form of inhuman bondage, is ultimately no laughing matter.

 In rep until October 12. Box office: 01789 403403.

webTitle: Cannavaro, Cocu and Rivaldo top my bill for Alex finale

fields.headline: Cannavaro, Cocu and Rivaldo top my bill for Alex finale
fields.trailText: There are three signings who could help Sir Alex Ferguson retire at the end of next season with the European Cup. The bad news for the accountants at Old Trafford is that it will cost at least £50m.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson is desperate to retire at the end of next season with the European Cup - and to my mind there are three signings who could help Manchester United achieve that. The bad news for the accountants at Old Trafford is that it will cost at least £50m.

Given the chance to take any player in Europe, I'd plump for Luis Figo. But there isn't a cat in hell's chance of getting him from Real Madrid and, because Zinedine Zidane and Andri Shevchenko are also probably out of reach, I've picked a trio Alex might just be able to land.

At the back I'd go for Fabio Cannavaro of Parma. United were let down by their defending in Munich and Cannavaro epitomises what Italian defenders are all about. I'd love to see him alongside Jaap Stam.

Although Wes Brown has great pace and potential he struggled in Germany and at the moment I'm not sure he's aggressive enough in terms of doing the ugly things. He doesn't yet intimidate opponents like Tony Adams, Martin Keown and Steve Bould did at Arsenal in the famous five. Cannavaro has that aura and attitude which says "thou shalt not pass".

At Euro 2000, particularly in the semi-final against Holland, he and Alessandro Nesta were blocking down shots, stopping crosses and doing the ugly business.

It is possible Brown would be a better bread-and-butter defender if he was in a struggling team. He may be more used to playing from the halfway line forward in the Premiership, particularly at home. By and large United attack teams and it may come as a surprise when he is put under pressure more.

But it is not just at the back that United have struggled in Europe. They haven't scored enough goals against the top sides, particularly away, and I think they've got to try to get a fantasy player.

Rivaldo would be perfect. I put him ahead of Alessandro del Piero as the ideal man to play off the main striker. I have a feeling Barcelona would be a decent club to target because I think players there will be moved out.

United certainly need somebody to do the job Dwight Yorke did for them two years ago when he was full of adrenalin and life. The move from Aston Villa suited him down the ground and he was playing like a kid with a new toy. He plays like a kid with other new toys now.

His movement in Munich wasn't as good as it should have been and there's a lot of talk of him moving. It may well be that players like Yorke or Nicky Butt would have to help finance the deals I'm talking about. David Beckham might even choose to go abroad, which would be a blow for United.

The money is presumably there to buy Ruud van Nistelrooy and I'd be surprised if he wasn't at Old Trafford next year. But the jury is still out on him and the players I'm talking about have done it.

Obviously with Rivaldo, Alex would have to weigh up whether the signing would damage his squad. Apart from Eric Cantona, who was idolised by the lads who grew up at United, the foreign players have always integrated rather than simply coming in and taking over.

Alex would have to feel Rivaldo could do the same and also consider the wages. The Brazilian would have to be paid miles more than even Roy Keane, and there are others in the camp who might turn round and say: "I know we want to win the European Cup but I'm as valuable as he is." Then you can get a few little seeds, so it is a fine line.

The third man on my list, Barcelona's Philip Cocu, might not be seen as a star in England but he's a tremendous all-round player. He's got something of everything and gets my vote ahead of his Holland team-mate Edgar Davids.

Cocu's a great passer, has a good shot and could almost be another Bryan Robson. He may not be quite so prolific a goalscorer but he's tremendous in the air arriving in the box and has a lot of those ingredients.

He's more than capable of contesting midfield and is so versatile that he can not only fill virtually any position but play it as a world player. That he would be a perfect left wing-back is handy because, if were Alex, I would look at the possibility of playing 3-5-2, particularly in Europe.

In the Champions League I think teams need a lot of bodies in midfield. It's not a question of blocking the game up and ball winning but the best sides make sure they have a lot of midfielders who can deal with the ball and move it around. That's why Steve McManaman flourishes at Madrid.

United at their best trust themselves and play that way with a midfield four but they seem more cautious than the fearless side who won the European Cup in 1999 and may need a tactical reappraisal.

What they don't need is a huge clear-out. But to move on to the next level new faces are required. Just before the treble season Alex bought Stam and Yorke, which seemed to kick-start everybody. That's the sort of thing he has do again.

fields.headline: Sea fever
fields.standfirst: Milly continues her action-packed journey across New Zealand with an energetic horse-ride and a cruise of Milford Sound's fjords, but a scary experience in a sea-kayak persuades her to start taking things easy
fields.trailText: Week 20: Queenstown to Milford Sound Milly continues her action-packed journey across New Zealand with an energetic horse-ride and a cruise of Milford Sound's fjords, but a scary experience in a sea-kayak persuades her to start taking things easy
fields.body:
The first day after skydiving I'd been determined to choose one of Queenstown's less adrenalin-heavy activities as a way of winding down. The great thing about this town is that there's so much going on we only had to book activities on the morning or the night before we wanted to do them, and our hostel reception was always able to do this for us. So, with no effort or pre-planning, we decided to go horse-riding for a couple of hours that afternoon.

At 1pm a van, smelling strongly of horses, picked us up from outside the hostel and drove us an hour out of Queenstown to Glenorchy, a picturesque, farm-oriented area. There were just four of us trekking that afternoon, and we were all at the "been on a horse a couple of times eight years ago" stage, which made it even better. We were each allocated a horse and, although I was a little disturbed by the size of mine, I soon got used to the relaxing feel of being in a saddle as our horses ambled along the road one behind another.

The start of the ride was peaceful enough, but the second we went off-road, everything changed. At one point we were allowed to run our horses uphill which was a wonderful feeling with the wind rushing past our ears - although not for Josh, whose horse had decided that any speed faster than a walk was a bad idea. The afternoon ended with a few unexpected dramas - one of the horses got temperamental and kicked both Josh's and my horse, which put them on edge for the rest of the journey. On several occasions I nearly fell off, so I was quite relieved to get on to firm ground again! That's one tip for anyone going on a horse trek: unless you're particularly experienced, only book a short ride. After over two hours I was very sore indeed.

On Friday, a combination of extreme stiffness and the money-vacuum that is Queenstown meant Josh and I spent the day quietly wandering through the woods by the lake. This was our last day in Queenstown before heading for Milford Sound and we decided to make it a relaxing one. In the afternoon we saw Dungeons & Dragons at the cinema - my advice is: don't bother. It was laughably bad. As it was Good Friday, the Queenstown nightlife was alive and kicking - more so than normal - and we left the place on a fun note.  

On Saturday we took an early bus to Milford Sound. We'd been desperately keen to hire a car and do the trip ourselves but age discrimination (you have to be over 21) meant that this was not to be. There was nothing wrong with the bus as such, but in retrospect I would definitely recommend hiring a car if you're old enough - Milford is very isolated, and a vehicle would have given us added freedom to explore at leisure. Ah well.

Thrown in with our bus-ride was a cruise of the fjords, which we took straight after we arrived in Milford. I think the worst thing was the realisation that some people were going to finish this cruise then head straight off to Queenstown again. What a waste. Admittedly we saw some lovely scenery - the fast-flowing waterfalls down the mountains are a pretty spectacular sight -  but I how can you feel the character of a place if you spend the whole day on various vehicles? I'd certainly recommend staying at least a night if you have time.  

After our cruise we had a 40-minute, heavily burdened walk to the lodge, due to some dodgy advice from a tourist information lady. When we arrived I realised how absolutely freezing the place is. Luckily we were able to hire duvets as neither me or Josh owned a sleeping bag, but there was still the outside run to the toilets and shower to contend with. The lodge did have a little shop and restauraunt but we'd brought our own groceries which meant we enjoyed the culinary delights of jacket potatoes with cheese and beans. The evening was largely spent in the warm communal lounge - where my pack of cards came in extremely handy. The electricity generator switched off at 11pm - unsurprisingly, not much happened after that!  

On Easter Sunday we'd booked an afternoon's sea-kayaking on the Sound, but it wasn't until the afternoon, so in the morning we walked round the little town - and little was the operative word. This place exists almost solely for tourism. We headed to another spectacular waterfall and the site of two small graves, one commemorating a recent air accident of several youngsters, before returning to the lodge for our kayak pick-up. We'd booked with Rosco's Kayaking, which was run by a guy named Horey. Following the leaflet's advice we'd tried to bring all the right gear, but we needn't have bothered - Horey provided everything except your underwear.

There were eight of us plus Horey in four double-kayaks. The weather was rainy and misty which was to be expected as Milford is one of the wettest places in the world - it rains for 50% of the year. Due to this the water became rougher the further out we paddled - and it was then that something horrible happened. Me and Josh had been having a few teething problems (basically we made terrible kayak partners), and suddenly a spell of bad waves completely broke my water confidence, which was still low from Coogee. I had an attack of water phobia, which was unlike anything I've felt before - I couldn't stop shaking in my kayak and I actually felt nauseous. In the end, the two of us headed for shore again while the others continued, and Horey said we could transfer to the morning ride the next day, when the water is much calmer. To be honest, that's the one we probably should have done in the first place, but I couldn't help feeling embarrassed. It was incredibly frustrating, as I've always enjoyed water activities in the past. Has anybody else experienced something like this? What's the cure?

Later that evening as I was stirring some beans in the kitchen, I noticed a large antenna wriggling at me, poking out from under the lid of an enormous saucepan. Several men were busy cooking live crayfish and the box of them still wriggling at me feet was a pretty unusual sight. There were many fishers at the lodge who would drive their boats down every morning, and this was part of their catch. One of the men gave me a piece of smoked blue cod to try and it was absolutely delicious. I promised to buy myself a beginners' cookbook when I returned to Australia.  

Our last day in Milford was slightly frustrating as we had to wait until 3pm to catch a bus. It gave us time to wander in the opposite direction besides the river and enjoy the stunning visuals combined with the unusual sight of blue skies and sun. It also gave us the chance to be eaten by flies again. Two bits of advice - either have a decent, strong repellent that's 100% deet (though don't get it near your mouth or you'll foam, as I found out in the Blue Mountains) or become a smoker, as they won't go near cigarettes. That evening we returned to our hostel in Queenstown with the intention of an overnight stop, but were alarmed to discover that all buses to Christchurch were full the next day - apparently it was a late Easter rush. So, we had to revise our plans and book another night in Queenstown - not exactly what we'd intended, but at least it was a great town to be stuck in.  

On the Tuesday we woke late, and treated ourself to lunch and a bottle of wine at Old Man Rock cafe, where we sat outside andwatched the world go by - a lovely way to spend an afternoon. After that, under the influence of alcohol, we decided to go shopping (a bad thing), then spent the rest of the day enjoying the place. Maybe another day there wasn't such a bad thing.  

The next day we finally managed to move on, with an eight-hour bus ride to Christchurch. Again it was frustrating not to be driving, as we passed some beautiful places where we'd have loved to have got out, but it wasn't to be. In Christchurch we were met by a friend of Josh's - that evening we were to have the luxury of staying in a house!! The family were incredibly hospitable and made us a huge dinner. We chatted on various topics: travel (they advised us not to go to Greymouth), university (how bad student debt is in New Zealand), even politics (theirs are far funnier than ours). Before I left Australia I felt like I was leaving my home, but now I feel I could stay so much longer in this beautiful, friendly country. But that's travelling for you.   Until next week (when I'll be adjusting to Australian living again),   Milly

fields.headline: Spurs struggle for numbers again
fields.trailText: Arsenal v Everton
fields.body:
Arsenal v Everton

Arsenal will be without the injured Ray Parlour, Lauren Etame, Nwankwo Kanu, Silvinho and Dennis Bergkamp. Parlour faces tests to see whether his back problem has been caused by a trapped nerve or a virus while Bergkamp has had a setback in his recovery from an achilles injury. Silvinho is still nursing the calf injury that kept him out against Valencia. Everton will give fitness tests to Richard Gough (calf), Dave Unsworth (achilles), Duncan Ferguson and Steve Watson (both groin strains). They will have the young defenders Peter Clarke and Tony Hibbert in their squad, and one is expected to start.

Aston Villa v Southampton

Villa get their captain Gareth Southgate back after a knee injury. He will take over from the suspended Alpay Ozalan. Juan Pablo Angel is again on international duty with Colombia. Southampton will test the fitness of Dan Petrescu (groin) but should have Marian Pahars (back) and Chris Marsden (thigh) back in the squad.

Bradford City v Derby County


Bradford will be without their centre-back David Wetherall for the last four weeks of the campaign after he suffered a recurrence of a groin injury. Gary Locke (hand) is also out. Jamie Lawrence returns to the squad and if selected will play with a protective covering to protect his broken hand. Derby will be without their captain Darryl Powell after he suffered a knee injury in the defeat of Leicester. Adam Murray is his likely replacement in midfield. Craig Burley (hamstring), Branko Strupar (pelvis) and Taribo West (international duty with Nigeria) are again ruled out.

Chelsea v Charlton Athletic

Albert Ferrer (calf), Jody Morris (ankle) and Frank Leboeuf (groin) are all back in training after injury, but are not expected to feature in the Chelsea team. Charlton, though, should be able to welcome a trio of first-team players back in the former Chelsea midfielder Graham Stuart (back), the England full-back Chris Powell (thigh) and the Bulgaria full-back Radostin Kishishev (rested).

Ipswich Town v Coventry City

Ipswich have central defender John McGreal fit again after he missed the 2-1 victory at Middlesbrough with a virus. Fabian Wilnis faces a late fitness test on an ankle injury, but James Scowcroft will definitely miss out because of a groin strain. Coventry are likely to keep the team that beat Sunderland as they look to make it four wins from five.

Leicester City v Middlesbrough

Gerry Taggart returns to the Leicester team after recovering from a knee injury and takes over as captain from Matt Elliott, who will miss the remaining four games of the season with a groin problem. Middlesbrough have a shortage of fit central defenders: Gianluca Festa is out and Colin Cooper (hip) and Steve Vickers (dead leg) will need fitness tests.

Manchester United v Manchester City

David Beckham is back, but the rest of United's team is a little hard to guess at. Informed sources say that Nicky Butt, Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke may be under threat. City will be without Danny Tiatto (suspended) but will have Gerard Wiekens recovered from a foot injury and Paul Dickov available after his three-match suspension for his red card at Everton was quashed.

Sunderland v Newcastle United

Sunderland striker Niall Quinn could return to the starting line-up after being used only as a substitute at Coventry on Monday, while Michael Gray has recovered from a neck problem and midfielders Gavin McCann and Don Hutchison have shaken off knocks. Rob Lee is a major doubt for Newcastle with a niggling knee injury, but Nolberto Solano is available after delaying his departure to join up with the Peru World Cup squad, Warren Barton (achilles), Andy Griffin (groin) and Shola Ameobi (shoulder) should all be fit and Aaron Hughes will return after being rested for Monday's 2-1 win over West Ham.

West Ham United v Leeds United

West Ham wait for reports on the fitness of their forwards Frederic Kanoute (hip) and Paolo Di Canio (Achilles). Di Canio is expected to be fit, and the Australian defender Hayden Foxe is available after his World Cup outings against the likes of American Samoa. Leeds are likely to bring back Robbie Keane, who is ineligible for the Champions League, in order to rest Alan Smith or Mark Viduka.

Sunday

Liverpool v Tottenham Hotspur

Gerard Houllier is likely to rotate his squad, possibly resting Emile Heskey in order to reunite Robbie Fowler with Michael Owen up front and reintroducing Igor Biscan, who is ineligible for European competition, to the midfield. Spurs have more bad news: joining Sol Campbell, Steffen Freund, Darren Anderton, Chris Armstrong and Ben Thatcher on the injured list are Ledley King (face) and Chris Perry (knee). Les Ferdinand (hamstring) and Steffen Iversen (concussion) will probably not be risked. So Sergei Rebrov and Stephen Clemence will probably play despite picking up knocks against Chelsea.

Fabian Wilnis faces a late fitness test on an ankle injury, but James Scowcroft will definitely miss out because of a groin strain. Coventry are likely to keep the team that beat Sunderland as they look to make it four wins from five. Leicester City v Middlesbrough Gerry Taggart returns to the Leicester team after recovering from a knee injury and takes over as captain from Matt Elliott, who will miss the remaining four games of the season with a groin problem. Middlesbrough have a shortage of fit central defenders: Gianluca Festa is out and Colin Cooper (hip) and Steve Vickers (dead leg) will need fitness tests. Manchester United v Manchester City David Beckham is back, but the rest of United's team is a little hard to guess at. Informed sources say that Nicky Butt, Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke may be under threat. City will be without Danny Tiatto (suspended) but will have Gerard Wiekens recovered from a foot injury and Paul Dickov available after his three-match suspension for his red card at Everton was quashed. Sunderland v Newcastle United Sunderland striker Niall Quinn could return to the starting line-up after being used only as a substitute at Coventry on Monday, while Michael Gray has recovered from a neck problem and midfielders Gavin McCann and Don Hutchison have shaken off knocks. Rob Lee is a major doubt for Newcastle with a niggling knee injury, but Nolberto Solano is available after delaying his departure to join up with the Peru World Cup squad, Warren Barton (achilles), Andy Griffin (groin) and Shola Ameobi (shoulder) should all be fit and Aaron Hughes will return after being rested for Monday's 2-1 win over West Ham. West Ham United v Leeds United West Ham wait for reports on the fitness of their forwards Frederic Kanoute (hip) and Paolo Di Canio (Achilles). Di Canio is expected to be fit, and the Australian defender Hayden Foxe is available after his World Cup outings against the likes of American Samoa. Leeds are likely to bring back Robbie Keane, who is ineligible for the Champions League, in order to rest Alan Smith or Mark Viduka. Sunday Liverpool v Tottenham Hotspur Gerard Houllier is likely to rotate his squad, possibly resting Emile Heskey in order to reunite Robbie Fowler with Michael Owen up front and reintroducing Igor Biscan, who is ineligible for European competition, to the midfield. Spurs have more bad news: joining Sol Campbell, Steffen Freund, Darren Anderton, Chris Armstrong and Ben Thatcher on the injured list are Ledley King (face) and Chris Perry (knee). Les Ferdinand (hamstring) and Steffen Iversen (concussion) will probably not be risked. So Sergei Rebrov and Stephen Clemence will probably play despite picking up knocks against Chelsea.

fields.headline: Dorothy Millar
fields.standfirst: Bacteriologist and campaigner for the poor in Scotland and the developing countries
fields.trailText: Bacteriologist and campaigner for the poor in Scotland and the developing countries.
fields.body:
The bacteriologist Dorothy Millar, who has died aged 60 of a pulmonary embolism, was a respected author and researcher on human skin conditions and a member of the Royal College of Pathologists. She was also a radical Christian and advocate for the poor.

Millar was born in Calcutta, the daughter of Scottish missionaries. After her parents returned to Scotland, she was educated in Edinburgh and then in New Zealand, where her father had taken up a post at Otago University, Dunedin. It was at this time that her interest in Maori culture began to develop, along with a questioning of western social values.

Her initial post-doctoral work as a bacteriologist was with the distinguished New Zealand scientist Molly Marples, an international authority on the ecology of human skin. With Marples, Millar became involved in research projects in the Pacific islands where exotic fungi carried ringworm and athlete's foot. Together they set up a reference laboratory for identification of these species, and found previously unknown types of parasitic fungus in the Cook Islands. It was while working with families in these islands that she became drawn to the Maoris' strong awareness of community and their sense of the sacred.

She returned to England in 1967 and, three years later, while working at St John's Hospital for Diseases of the Skin, in London, she co-authored with Prof Bill Noble, a seminal work, Microbiology of the Human Skin, one of a series of Major Problems in Dermatology under the general authorship of Arthur Rook. In 1974, her research work and numerous publications brought her membership of the Royal College of Pathologists.

In 1973, she had married the Rev Dr Peter Millar, then a parish minister in the east end of Glasgow. Dorothy was working at Glasgow University and at the Royal Infirmary in the pathology laboratory, continuing her work on the human skin.

While her research continued to grow, she also became increasingly involved with community issues facing families in the parish, which then suffered from social deprivation. Working with local groups, she pushed for better housing and health care. This experience deepened her commitment to work for justice, which she saw as an essential component of the Christian gospel.

During these years, she was among the early voices in Britain raised on behalf of reducing debt in the developing countries. She ran regular workshops and liaised with both Christian Aid and Oxfam on Third World issues.

In 1976, with her husband, she was appointed to the Church of South India, and during the next 12 years, her sari-clad figure became a familiar sight in many of the villages of Tamil Nadu and in the poorer areas of Chennai (then Madras). Her commitments and concerns in south India ranged through community health to the rights of women. Many of the projects which she helped establish, including care for the elderly and day care centres for young children, were both visionary and pioneering. Above all she remained a companion of the poor, who valued her wisdom and everyday spirituality.

Like her friend, the Benedictine monk Bede Griffiths, she said she discovered in India "the other half of her soul", but never in a self-enclosed sense. In many parts of the world her authoritative but compassionate voice on matters of development and international aid was valued by those who, like herself, were appalled at the increasing gulf between the poor and the rich in the modern world.

She was an advocate of the poor, and lived alongside those for whom she spoke. She was not an admirer of huge aid schemes, which often, in her opinion, further disempowered the exploited and rode roughshod over local culture.

After her return to Britain in 1989, her campaigning work increased, and perhaps especially so during her time as a staff member of the Iona Community, when her husband was warden of Iona Abbey. Through her writing and speaking, she became an inspirational person for the thousands of people who were seeking to become more aware of global issues, and her first-hand experience of the developing world gave depth to her words.

In the last year of her life, she travelled all over Australia, working on behalf of the Wellspring Community, an ecumenical Christian community inspired by the Iona Community's vision of an engaged Christianity committed to justice and reconciliation. In Australia, she worked for Aboriginal rights and her home in a poor part of Sydney was a place of welcome for many who were on the edge of society. She continued to write and reflect on how cultures remain true to their own identity, yet live within the pluralities of modernity.

She is survived by her husband Peter and their children Eldon, Tim and Sulekha.

 Dorothy Ann Millar, bacteriologist and campaigner, born August 29 1940; died March 9 2001

webTitle: Comment: the next crucial area of medical research

fields.headline: The next frontier
fields.standfirst: Special report: ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Is the United States about to fall behind Britain in a crucial area of medical research? It's certainly possible.
fields.body:
Is the United States about to fall behind Britain in a crucial area of medical research? It's certainly possible. Research on human embryonic stem cells is legal in the UK. Scientists are allowed to derive these cells from so called surplus embryos, unwanted after IVF treatment.

They are also allowed to do therapeutic cloning - using the same technique that created Dolly the sheep to produce a cloned embryo and then deriving embryonic stem cells that are an immunological match for a patient.

Across the Atlantic, therapeutic cloning is not even being discussed. Indeed, it would be politically impossible to do so. But even research using stem cells derived from surplus embryos faces a rather uncertain future.

The British government has promised to ban human reproductive cloning by law to avert fears of a slide from therapeutic cloning down the proverbial slippery slope to the creation of human clones.

In the US too, several members of Congress are now drafting legislation to ban human reproductive cloning, and President Bush has promised to sign the law when it reaches his desk. But the situation involving stem cells is much more complex.

The president has a dilemma. On one side are the pro-life activists who did so much to put him into office. On the other are the pharmaceutical companies. They want the US to maintain its leadership in this very important area of biomedicine.

B ush has asked his secretary of health and human services, Tommy Thompson, to review the guidelines that permit federally funded research. Meanwhile, he is looking hopefully at the potential of a kind of stem cell which is non-controversial: the adult stem cell.

Perhaps science can make his political problem just go away. There have been promising advances in re- directing adult stem cells to become something nature never intended - blood into nerve, for example. Recently, scientists working with fat sucked out of patients during liposuction were able to isolate stem cells which, in a laboratory dish, gave rise to cells that make muscle, bone and cartilage and also to cells that made more of themselves. There is growing clamour in the US for the abandonment of embryonic stem cell research and a focus instead on adult stem cells. But no matter how appealing the prospect of deriving spare parts from spare tyres may be, the promise of adult stem cell research is just that - a promise. It must not divert us from a full exploration of all varieties of stem cells.

Embryonic cells have the potential to develop into all basic tissue types. They could provide a potentially limitless source of tissue for transplantation. Adult stem cells, on the other hand seem to have disadvantages such as low number and poor accessibility.

It was in 1994, after President Clinton banned the use of federal funds to create embryos for research purposes, that Congress went even further, extending the ban to research on surplus embryos.

To get round that ban, proponents came up with a legal sleight of hand. As long as someone not federally funded has derived the cells from the embryo, research into the stem cells themselves may go forward. Pro-life opponents quickly marshalled their usual arguments and many politicians would have capitulated on the spot.

But this particular battle had equally impassioned opponents. Appearing on the scene were the patients' lobbies representing all manner of chronic conditions - from diabetes to Parkinson's to cancer. They wanted to be cured. And they knew that in order fully to explore the promise of stem cell research, both federal funding and embryonic stem cells were required. Even 99-year-old Senator Thurmond deserted his conservative colleagues and joined their cause.

President Clinton enthusiastically supported the aims of the research and guide-lines were drafted to ensure that it was conducted according to the highest legal and ethical standards. But they can be rescinded and funding of the research halted without consulting Congress. Merely by an executive order signed by President Bush. And that is the fear.

 The author is a lawyer and bioethicist. She is writer in residence at the Science Museum, London. Her anthology, The Cloning Sourcebook, is published next month by Oxford University Press.

fields.headline: Sweet smell of success
fields.standfirst: Aromatherapy works for some
fields.trailText: Josef Ilmberger, Eva Heuberger and colleagues from universities in Munich and Vienna, noting that scientific research lags behind the claims made for alternative or complementary therapies, looked at whether people do become more alert after sniffing those piquant aromas of the kind wafting from those little bottles you can buy in Body Shop.
fields.body:
Josef Ilmberger, Eva Heuberger and colleagues from universities in Munich and Vienna, noting that scientific research lags behind the claims made for alternative or complementary therapies, looked at whether people do become more alert after sniffing those piquant aromas of the kind wafting from those little bottles you can buy in Body Shop.

Peppermint, jasmine and menthol smell good. Water smells of nothing. But water turned out to be just as (in)effective as the sniffs in raising the attention span of the volunteers assessed in the research. In a blind trial they did not know what liquid was being dripped on their surgical masks and the sniffers turned out to be indistinguishable.

That is not quite the same as saying aromatherapy does not work. As the current New Scientist reports, there is a strong psychological element in our response. Volunteers who (after the event) said their scents were strong and pleasant did seem to have reacted differently. As the researchers put it, there were "complex correlations between subjective evaluations of substances and objective performance". Meaning aromatherapy may work if you believe it will work. Further research is to be done on what are called essential oils, assessing the effect of rubbing them on the skin, but the interim conclusion should satisfy both sceptics and sniffing's true believers. It has always been in the mind.

Complementary or alternative medicine does not "work" if enough people believe in it; simply that there is feedback between belief and behaviour and probably also autonomous bodily functions. And we do not know much about it, certainly not enough to dismiss all non-standard therapies out of hand as quackery. Advertising of aromatherapy should reflect such ambiguity; prices too. But if inhaling the scent of ylang-ylang does it for you, good luck - as long as you are extremely cautious in claiming it will do the same for your neighbour.

webTitle: Leader: Drug giants forced to bow to people power

fields.headline: A victory for the poor
fields.standfirst:
Drug giants forced to bow to people power

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Celebration will not be confined to South Africa. Yesterday's climbdown by the 39 international drug companies that have been trying to stop South Africa from importing or producing cheaper generic copies of essential patented drugs is a huge victory for health campaigners and human rights activists round the globe.
fields.body:
Celebration will not be confined to South Africa. Yesterday's climbdown by the 39 international drug companies that have been trying to stop South Africa from importing or producing cheaper generic copies of essential patented drugs is a huge victory for health campaigners and human rights activists round the globe.

Who said the giant multinational companies were invincible? As South Africa's health minister noted in the wake of the drug companies dropping their lawsuit: "This is a victory not just for South Africa but for Africa and the whole of the developing world."

One irony of the three-year lawsuit was that the South African government, which has so successfully fought for the right to import or produce cheaper Aids drugs, initially had no wish to use them. That is all in the past, though the leading South African Aids groups rightly reminded ministers yesterday that "the difficult job starts now ... getting additional resources to start implementing an appropriate treatment plan".

International attention now switches to Brazil, which is due to be brought before a World Trade Organisation tribunal for breaching drug patent laws by the US government. No developing state has done more to curb the HIV/Aids epidemic. It has invested heavily in preventive programmes, but crucially has also achieved free access to drugs through generic manufacture. This has enabled Brazil to cut its death rate from Aids in half and stabilise the spread of the disease. It is in even more need of international support for pioneering a programme that can be copied by other developing states. The case is driven by two US companies, Merck and Pfizer, putting profits before people. Hopefully, after the industry's humiliation in South Africa, they will think again.

The industry has always had a two-tier pricing system. But prices for poor countries were still too high. South Africa has resolved that problem. Prices have been slashed. The industry's opposition to generic production is understandable, but such production is permissible under WTO rules. There can be few more "exceptional circumstances" than Aids - the most lethal plague since the Black Death. What is needed now is resources. There is no shortage of ideas. One of the most practicable is the World Bank's proposal for an trust fund built up over 10 years. What is needed now is not more talk, but immediate action.

webTitle: Comment: GlaxoSmithKline explain S Africa climbdown

fields.headline: We have a deal
fields.standfirst:
A drug company boss explains the climbdown in South Africa

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: A drug company boss explains the climbdown in South Africa.
fields.body:
The settlement of the court case in South Africa has to be welcomed by all sides. The terms of the settlement meet the goals of both industry and the South African government and will enable us to work together in addressing the healthcare needs of South Africa.

No one would deny that the barriers which prevent patient access to medicines in the developing world must be broken down. The pharmaceutical industry has a fundamental long-term role to play in this, through the discovery and development of innovative medicines to combat diseases not yet eradicated. Effective intellectual property protection underpins this continued research and development.

It has been widely commented that the court case was about the industry using its patents to block access to medicines and to keep up high prices. Nothing could be further from the truth. Even now, non patented medicines are not available in Africa.

The key concern for the industry was that the South African legislation was vague and ambiguous and in particular, the law appeared to give the government freedom to override patents of any medicine at their discretion. This would have undermined the industry's ability to provide new and better medicines.

Under the terms of the settlement the South African government has confirmed that its new law will be implemented in a way compliant with the international Trade-Related Intellectual Property Rights Agreement (Trips). In doing so, it has af firmed the need for strong intellectual property protection consistent with international agreements and the underlying importance of intellectual property protection as an incentive to innovation. Put simply, intellectual property is not an obstacle to access.

Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, who played a key role in bringing about yesterday's settlement, said only a few weeks ago: "Intellectual property protection is key to bringing forward new medicines, vaccines and diagnostics urgently needed for the health of the world's poorest people. The United Nations fully supports the Trips agreement - including the safeguards incorporated within it."

In this context the settlement agreed with the South African government has to be embraced by the industry. The opportunity to input on the regulations that will implement the act and the government's willingness to consult with the industry on this are further significant steps towards a new spirit of partnership and cooperation.

In the heated debate around the court case it has been difficult to convey the overwhelming truth that the most significant barriers to comprehensive treatment for HIV/Aids in the developing world are lack of funding and public healthcare infrastructure. Now is the time for everyone who has a role to play in alleviating the human and economic tragedy of HIV/Aids in southern Africa to come together in the spirit of partnership exemplified by the settlement of the court case. GlaxoSmithKline - by providing heavily discounted Aids medicines and being the only company with experimental vaccines in Aids and malaria already being tested in people - will continue to give its full commitment to this endeavour.

 Jean-Pierre Garnier is chief executive of GlaxoSmithKline.
