It has been widely commented that the court case was about the industry using its patents to block access to medicines and to keep up high prices. Nothing could be further from the truth. Even now, non patented medicines are not available in Africa. The key concern for the industry was that the South African legislation was vague and ambiguous and in particular, the law appeared to give the government freedom to override patents of any medicine at their discretion. This would have undermined the industry's ability to provide new and better medicines. Under the terms of the settlement the South African government has confirmed that its new law will be implemented in a way compliant with the international Trade-Related Intellectual Property Rights Agreement (Trips). In doing so, it has af firmed the need for strong intellectual property protection consistent with international agreements and the underlying importance of intellectual property protection as an incentive to innovation. Put simply, intellectual property is not an obstacle to access. Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, who played a key role in bringing about yesterday's settlement, said only a few weeks ago: "Intellectual property protection is key to bringing forward new medicines, vaccines and diagnostics urgently needed for the health of the world's poorest people. The United Nations fully supports the Trips agreement - including the safeguards incorporated within it." In this context the settlement agreed with the South African government has to be embraced by the industry. The opportunity to input on the regulations that will implement the act and the government's willingness to consult with the industry on this are further significant steps towards a new spirit of partnership and cooperation. In the heated debate around the court case it has been difficult to convey the overwhelming truth that the most significant barriers to comprehensive treatment for HIV/Aids in the developing world are lack of funding and public healthcare infrastructure. Now is the time for everyone who has a role to play in alleviating the human and economic tragedy of HIV/Aids in southern Africa to come together in the spirit of partnership exemplified by the settlement of the court case. GlaxoSmithKline - by providing heavily discounted Aids medicines and being the only company with experimental vaccines in Aids and malaria already being tested in people - will continue to give its full commitment to this endeavour.  Jean-Pierre Garnier is chief executive of GlaxoSmithKline. fields.headline: Sex on the brain
fields.trailText: A Taiwan university is to inaugurate the country's first sexology programme and debt is forcing New Zealand students into prostitution, writes David Cohen in this week's press roundup.
fields.body:
Many education writers around the world this past week had sex on the brain, which, as Malcolm Muggeridge used to point out, isn't necessarily the most comfortable place to have it.

The Sydney Morning Herald in Australia reported on the controversy among a number of local high school groups surrounding an adaptation of Romeo and Juliet, retitled R&J, which opens next week at the Sydney Opera House. The famous love story will be told through the eyes of four Australian schoolboys, two of whom get to act out the kissing scenes together. "The characters in the play are heterosexual but their sexual awakening occurs with each other," said the play's director, John O'Hare, of the Bell Shakespeare Company. "A lot of people have experiences like this in their adolescent years - it's all part of the Australian experience."

Taiwan will inaugurate its first sexology programme at a post-secondary institution later this year, according to the island's newspapers. Shu Te University hopes its new offerings will improve local knowledge of sexual matters in Taiwan, the region's statistical leader when it comes to divorce. Lin Yen-chin, the head of the university's new Graduate Institute of Sexology, said she is not planning to start a sexual revolution by opening the institute but simply wants to teach people the lustier concepts and knowledge of sex. As she told the Straits Times, "If a married person fails to ask his or her better half to spice up their sex life, frustrations will build up and eventually ruin their marriage."

A number of newspapers in New Zealand carried reports on a study conducted by the country's Christchurch School of Medicine that found as many as 35% of the nation's sex industry workers are tertiary educated. Mounting student debt is a likely reason for this apparently high number, according to an item published today in the Evening Post of Wellington, where the article was teased from the front page with a somewhat tasteless photograph of a man and young woman in what appeared to be the final stages of romantic congress. In New Zealand, from where Britain took much of its user-pays philosophy for higher education, students must now shoulder a growing percentage of their own tuition costs, leading, over recent months, to a succession of hard luck stories relating to their plight being reported in the national news media.

With regard to sex in Southern Africa, the Financial Gazette in Harare offered a sad but lurid editorial analysis of the campus violence that erupted last week between students and riot police at the University of Zimbabwe, leaving one undergraduate dead and at least a dozen more injured. The protests were triggered by the suicide of a pregnant female student who was understood to have been involved with an older man paying her for sex - an all-too familiar problem at the country's national university, the paper noted, and blamed not only the recent violence but the high incidence of Aids among female students at the university on downtown "sugar daddies" preying on poorer young women.

"Take a group of middle-aged men with libidos that can only be matched by the weight of their wallets," it said. "Add hundreds of poverty-stricken male university students, some of whom can no longer afford a proper daily meal. Spice it with equally poor female students at the mercy of (these) sugar daddies and...the result is pure dynamite."

The anniversary of the Columbine massacre of April 20, 1999, which claimed the lives of 12 students and one teacher, provoked articles in several leading American newspapers, all of which continue to describe the killings as the worst of their kind in US history. (Not so. In 1927, a 55-year-old school board official detonated three bombs in a schoolhouse in Bath, Michigan, killing 45 people.)

In an editorial headlined "Inaction and Ineptitude", the Denver Post said that, were it not for the "mendacious conduct" of local law enforcement and school officials, whom, it claimed, had ample warning of what was likely to take place at the Colorado high school, then there might yet be no tragedy to commemorate. "Enough of partial disclosure, obfuscation and dissembling about Columbine!" it said, calling for a grand jury investigation of the still shrouded chain of events before and after the homicidal rampage. "Even if no one is indicted, a grand jury, with its tremendous subpoena powers, will be able to get closer to the truth of the matter than any other forum."

In a related op-ed piece, the same paper offered a terse item written by Steven Shelton, editor of the Countryside Companion, a local community paper. During the past week, he wrote, his publication has received a number of plainly "psychotic" press releases from schools in the region organising media events around the Columbine shootings - this despite the stated wish of the bereaved families that no such exhibitions be held. One of the organisers of such an event had said in a press release that his own institution's commemoration was a "simple remembrance...intended to honour the victims' families wishes that no formal event be held this year", causing Mr Shelton to ask whether the author of this disingenuous announcement didn't have "pounded suet for brains. Why on earth would they strive so to keep a tragic event that took place under their stewardship before the media?" Why indeed.

webTitle: Rage over money from home for spies Burgess and Maclean

fields.headline: Rage over money from home for spies Burgess and Maclean
fields.trailText: Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean - two members of Britain's notorious Cambridge spy ring - were allowed to receive money from Britain after they fled to Moscow in 1951 because they were "non-residents" and had not been convicted of any offence, documents released yesterday show.
fields.body:
Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean - two members of Britain's notorious Cambridge spy ring - were allowed to receive money from Britain after they fled to Moscow in 1951 because they were "non-residents" and had not been convicted of any offence, documents released yesterday show.

A row blew up after MPs discovered that the two men were allowed to have money forwarded from their British bank accounts in spite of exchange controls.

MPs were bombarded with letters from their constituents complaining that the two "traitors" were given privileged treatment, drawing on their private incomes so they could buy western goods in Russia.

"It seems that treason pays", ministers were told.

Anxious Treasury officials intervened. "Non-resident status is not in itself a privilege", they told the chancellor, Selwyn Lloyd, in 1962, when Burgess and Maclean wanted money.

Blocking the money, officials said, "could only have been imposed out of political spite ... We have to remember both that Burgess and Maclean have not been convicted, let alone of an exchange control offence ..."

Harold Macmillan, the prime minister, was described by officials as taking the view that "it would not be right to punish people of whom we do not approve", though there was "certainly no cause to feel any special tenderness for the interests of Burgess and Maclean".

Furthermore, Treasury officials warned, to reveal or even discuss personal finances in the context of exchange controls "might develop into an embarrassing precedent for other private individuals".

The papers show that the mother of the Eton-educated Burgess had set up a family trust fund of £60,000 in savings bonds. Officials also noted that Burgess left £2,000 to Kim Philby, another member of the spy ring, who kept the money for his family in Britain after he, too, fled to Moscow.

No figures are given for Maclean, the son of a former Liberal MP, though his American wife was said to have £22,000 in securities.

The last thing the establishment wanted was a trial of Burgess or Maclean, two homosexuals whose friendships included many prominent figures.

Philby was given immunity from prosecution - though he fled to Moscow in 1963 - as was Anthony Blunt, keeper of the Queen's pictures and another member of the Cambridge ring.

Burgess died in 1984 and Maclean in 1983.

webTitle: Comment: why Britain is outlawing human cloning

fields.headline: Resurrecting Fido
fields.standfirst:
Britain is officially outlawing human cloning in order to roar ahead with other embryo experiments

Special report: ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Britain is officially outlawing human cloning in order to roar ahead with other embryo experiments.
fields.body:
A frozen tissue mountain, or at least a sizeable mound, is accumulating in the American west, as grieving pet owners send off scraps of flesh from Fido or Cuddles to be turned into an embryo and stored in liquid nitrogen. Human cloning may be officially outlawed and still the province of fringe cults or maverick researchers, but the promise of pet cloning can be yours on production of a credit card.

After the cloning of laboratory and farm animals, it is the logical next step and potentially an enormously profitable one. There are an estimated 100m cats and dogs in North America and about 10% die every year. You only need a tiny percentage of owners, rich and/or desperate enough to yearn to recreate those happier days, to generate a sizeable industry.

Already there are several web-based firms, such as Canine Cryobank, who will sent you a tissue or blood harvesting kit for about $200 and then charge you another $300 or $400 to turn that into embryos. (Handy tip: if a much loved pet dies before you can take a sample, don't despair. Providing you keep the body in the fridge, but not frozen, tissue will remain viable for up to seven days.)

DNA from the tissue is then inserted into a denucleated egg, probably taken from a spayed bitch, and allowed to divide until there is a clutch of embryonic cells, which are then frozen. You then pay 100 or so dollars a year for storage until the biotech breakthrough, always just around the corner, that will allow cloning to take place on an industrial scale. As yet no one has officially cloned a pet, but theoretical prices go from $25,000, through $250,000 to $1m.

Breakthroughs aside, the immediate success of pet cloning depends on papering over an image problem, not unlike the one facing chocolate manufacturers at the moment. The hard sell concentrates on two scenes: sad loss of faithful companion followed by joyous resurrection. What that ignores is life on the embryo plantations. Literally dozens of largely nameless and unloved bitches will be indentured to a lifetime of medical interventions in order to bring Fido back.

Cloning is a terribly wasteful technique. More than 277 embryos were implanted before Dolly the sheep emerged. The rest fell at one of the many hurdles, and cloning dogs, because of their physiology, is much harder. At Texas A&M University, a leading cloning centre, 60 bitches were used to try, unsuccessfully, to clone a single dog - Missy, belonging to an anonymous benefactor who had donated $2.3m to the university in 1998.

The toll on the worker dogs comes firstly from having their ovaries harvested by cutting open the stomach and sucking them out with a glass pipette. Then further operations are necessary to implant the fertilised eggs, which mostly result in miscarriages or still births. The large number of worker dogs are needed because once a de-nucleated egg and the pet's DNA have fused and started dividing, it can't be stored but must be implanted immediately into a receptive female. However, while sheep have a regular fertility cycle of 18 days, dogs ovulate twice a year at random. So you need the numbers to have any chance of finding an ovulating bitch.

But even if the hit rate can be improved, and research scientists are eternally optimistic especially where funding is involved, a new problem is emerging that means the reincarnated Rover may not be quite what you expected. Evidence is now coming in that successful clones are prey to a much higher incidence of genetic problems, some of which don't emerge until quite late in life.

One researcher in Hawaii, for instance, has reported that a proportion of cloned mice develop severe obesity problems at a human-equivalent age of about 30. Cloned cows are often born with enlarged hearts or lungs that do not develop properly. Several scientists think that these problems are inherent in cloning. When the egg reprogrammes the donor's DNA so that it returns to its embryonic state, it's doing in a few hours something that normally takes months or years as sperm and eggs develop. The result is random genetic errors.

While some pet owners' sentimentality may be sufficiently selective to ignore the toll on other animals taken by cloning, the possibility that resurrected Fido will blow up like a balloon some years down the line will be far harder to overlook. If the commercial cloners have to start indemnifying themselves against such potential disasters, the whole project may look distinctly less attractive.

One idea about pet cloning is that it is part of a hidden agenda. It is a way of softening us up for human cloning. It domesticates the process, so that once you have cloned a much loved labrador, doing the same for another family member won't seem so alien. That certainly seems to be the message of an extraordinary website, launched earlier this month. CloneConsult promises to provide a clone of a medium weight pet - 10lb to 99lb - for $1m and a human clone for $2m, both to be delivered within two years. The options even have shopping baskets above them and they do, of course, take credit cards.

On the other hand pet cloning, once its realities sink in, may finish off the whole oversold notion of human cloning once and for all. Then when they pull the plug on the frozen tissue, it can probably be recycled into pet food.

jburne@blueyonder.co.uk

webTitle: ANC urged to deliver Aids drugs

fields.headline: ANC urged to deliver Aids drugs
fields.standfirst:
As pharmaceutical firms cave in, South Africans call on the state to exploit the victory and distribute medicines.

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: As pharmaceutical firms cave in, South Africans call on the state to exploit the victory and distribute medicines.
fields.body:
Within hours of the world's biggest pharmaceutical companies abandoning their court case against South African legislation aimed at getting cheaper medicines to the poor, the battleground shifted to the government's plans for implementing the law.

Moments after the industry's lawyers told the high court in Pretoria yesterday that the companies had unconditionally dropped their case, hundreds of spectators in the gallery ululated and sang. Many were HIV-positive and greeted the court victory as a new lease of life.

But although the health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, greeted the companies' humiliating climbdown by saying the legal battle reminded her of the struggle against apartheid, she upset the government's allies by adding that the act will not be used to ensure the widespread distribution of anti-retroviral drugs against Aids.

The government has repeatedly argued that whatever the perception overseas, the case was about access not to Aids drugs but to a broad range of medicines, including antibiotics, anti-malarial drugs and some treatments that deal with opportunistic infections caused by HIV.

But the government may come to see its legal victory as a hollow one, because large numbers of people - one-in-nine of the population are HIV-positive - regarded the court battle as primarily a struggle for drugs to combat the pandemic.

Aids rights groups at the forefront in pressing the industry to abandon its case, such as the Treatment Action Campaign (TAC), and foreign campaigners such as Oxfam and Médecins sans Frontières have long seen the legislation as removing one of the government's main arguments in justification of its reluctance to distribute anti-retrovirals in the public health service: cost.

"Every South African can be proud we stood firm against the most powerful lobby in the world, the drug companies. But now another struggle begins," said TAC's leader, Zackie Achmat.

"The government told the court under oath that anti-retrovirals are effective against Aids. The difficult job starts now, to ensure our government mobilises the resources it has to implement an appropriate treatment plan for Aids.

"We will use the law to protect people's lives. Within months to years we will have anti-retrovirals in our public health service."

Kevin Watkins, of Oxfam, who said that as a veteran of lost causes it was good to finally win one, agreed.

"If the government doesn't grasp the opportunity all we have fought for will be lost. The next battle starts here," he said.

Aids rights groups intend to begin by suing pharmaceutical companies which have offered cheap anti-retroviral drugs to South Africa's public but not its private sector.

Given the government's continued refusal to buy anti-retrovirals, the only access to them in South Africa is in the private sector, where they remain extremely expensive.

"People who want to access anti-retrovirals can go to the private sector," Dr Tshabalala-Msimang said yesterday.

Aids rights groups say they will turn their campaign on the government if it does not change its attitude towards anti-retrovirals.

The health minister argues that doubts remain about the effectiveness and safety of anti-retrovirals, and that South Africa lacks the extensive infrastructure of clinics and doctors required to distribute the drugs widely.

"It is erroneous to believe that South Africa doesn't give treatment to people with HIV or Aids," she said.

"We treat pneumonia, meningitis, skin diseases and thrush. Just because we don't provide anti-retrovirals, it is not correct to say we don't treat people with HIV or full-blown Aids."

But most people who are HIV-positive want drugs that keep Aids at bay, not just those that treat opportunistic infections. And critics say that with more than half the population living in urban areas and within striking distance of big hospitals, the importation of much cheaper anti-retrovirals could benefit large numbers of people.

The South African trade union confederation, which is a close but increasingly critical ally of the ruling African National Congress, said yesterday that if the government still could not afford anti-retrovirals then the country's biggest employers - particularly the mining companies - should use the new law to supply drugs direct to their HIV-positive workers.

The drug companies secured no changes in the law during their talks with the government before they abandoned the case.

But they did receive a restatement of South Africa's commitment to adhere to the international patent laws, which permit the government to import generic drugs or brand names bought from a cheaper source deal with health emergencies.

Dr Tshabalala-Msimang said the breakthrough in the negotiations came when the pharmaceutical companies realised that they could not win the legal case at the high court and approached the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, to smooth the way for a settlement.

The government has repeatedly argued that whatever the perception overseas, the case was about access not to Aids drugs but to a broad range of medicines, including antibiotics, anti-malarial drugs and some treatments that deal with opportunistic infections caused by HIV. But the government may come to see its legal victory as a hollow one, because large numbers of people - one-in-nine of the population are HIV-positive - regarded the court battle as primarily a struggle for drugs to combat the pandemic. Aids rights groups at the forefront in pressing the industry to abandon its case, such as the Treatment Action Campaign (TAC), and foreign campaigners such as Oxfam and Médecins sans Frontières have long seen the legislation as removing one of the government's main arguments in justification of its reluctance to distribute anti-retrovirals in the public health service: cost. "Every South African can be proud we stood firm against the most powerful lobby in the world, the drug companies. But now another struggle begins," said TAC's leader, Zackie Achmat. "The government told the court under oath that anti-retrovirals are effective against Aids. The difficult job starts now, to ensure our government mobilises the resources it has to implement an appropriate treatment plan for Aids. "We will use the law to protect people's lives. Within months to years we will have anti-retrovirals in our public health service." Kevin Watkins, of Oxfam, who said that as a veteran of lost causes it was good to finally win one, agreed. "If the government doesn't grasp the opportunity all we have fought for will be lost. The next battle starts here," he said. Aids rights groups intend to begin by suing pharmaceutical companies which have offered cheap anti-retroviral drugs to South Africa's public but not its private sector. Given the government's continued refusal to buy anti-retrovirals, the only access to them in South Africa is in the private sector, where they remain extremely expensive. "People who want to access anti-retrovirals can go to the private sector," Dr Tshabalala-Msimang said yesterday. Aids rights groups say they will turn their campaign on the government if it does not change its attitude towards anti-retrovirals. The health minister argues that doubts remain about the effectiveness and safety of anti-retrovirals, and that South Africa lacks the extensive infrastructure of clinics and doctors required to distribute the drugs widely. "It is erroneous to believe that South Africa doesn't give treatment to people with HIV or Aids," she said. "We treat pneumonia, meningitis, skin diseases and thrush. Just because we don't provide anti-retrovirals, it is not correct to say we don't treat people with HIV or full-blown Aids." But most people who are HIV-positive want drugs that keep Aids at bay, not just those that treat opportunistic infections. And critics say that with more than half the population living in urban areas and within striking distance of big hospitals, the importation of much cheaper anti-retrovirals could benefit large numbers of people. The South African trade union confederation, which is a close but increasingly critical ally of the ruling African National Congress, said yesterday that if the government still could not afford anti-retrovirals then the country's biggest employers - particularly the mining companies - should use the new law to supply drugs direct to their HIV-positive workers. The drug companies secured no changes in the law during their talks with the government before they abandoned the case. But they did receive a restatement of South Africa's commitment to adhere to the international patent laws, which permit the government to import generic drugs or brand names bought from a cheaper source deal with health emergencies. Dr Tshabalala-Msimang said the breakthrough in the negotiations came when the pharmaceutical companies realised that they could not win the legal case at the high court and approached the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, to smooth the way for a settlement.

webTitle: Gas masks put Britain's dogs of war off the scent

fields.headline: Gas masks put Britain's dogs of war off the scent
fields.trailText: Final proof, if it was needed, that the English care more about their dogs than perhaps anything else was provided yesterday by the release of confidential state papers showing that secret trials were carried out during the second world war to develop gas masks for the army's war dogs.
fields.body:
Final proof, if it was needed, that the English care more about their dogs than perhaps anything else was provided yesterday by the release of confidential state papers showing that secret trials were carried out during the second world war to develop gas masks for the army's war dogs.

After six months scientists succeeded in developing a mask which was comfortable for the dogs to wear. However, the trials revealed one significant catch - the dogs could not smell anything while wearing the masks, rendering them useless for 90% of their tasks on the battlefield.

The War Office's chemical weapons research station at Porton Down, Wiltshire, strove from April to October 1944 to protect dogs against gas on the battlefield. The War Office said the masks were needed "in view of the increasing use of dogs for essential duties".

The dogs, mostly alsatians, retrievers and collies, had been in use since early 1943 to patrol vulnerable points and on messenger duties with troops in the frontline. They worked in pairs, mostly at night, and relied almost entirely on their sense of smell.

A respirator was developed with a level of protection equal to that of "the human light respirator". It consisted of a rubberised canvas mask with a filter attached to the dog with a body harness. The War Dog Training School chose not to attach the mask to the dog's collar on the grounds that that was used for message carrying.

When the masks were tried on 120 army dogs most fitted quite well, but War Office papers show that the dogs could not carry the masks on their backs because "of the difficulty of getting through obstacles (hedges, barbed wire, etc)" and so it was decided that the respirator should be carried by their handlers.

The school at Northaw, Hertfordshire, reported that although the masked dogs were "all quite comfortable" walking and sitting while on patrol, when asked to do anything else they were useless: "Completely confused when asked to work on a/c of the intake of air coming from under the chin, no direct scent can reach the nose, and it appears that if it did the container filter would be faulty. If the filter was removed the dog knew there was someone about, but could get no sense of direction," said the report, which has remained secret for more than 50 years. "Conclusion: Masks invaluable in gas attack when dogs remain out of work, walking or sitting. No value at all for working in."

webTitle: War on superbugs enlists genetic codes

fields.headline: War on superbugs enlists genetic codes
fields.standfirst: Special report: ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Scientists hope to strike back against superbugs by unravelling the genetic codes of two of the feared organisms that have built up resistance to antibiotics.
fields.body:
Scientists hope to strike back against superbugs by unravelling the genetic codes of two of the feared organisms that have built up resistance to antibiotics.

Researchers in Japan have decoded the sequences that make up the DNA of two drug-resisting strains of staphylococcus aureus. One, methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), has become endemic in hospitals, where it infects patients who have had operations, and the other, VRSA, has developed resistance to the "last resort" antibiotic vancomycin, until recently an effective treatment against MRSA. Scientists must find new ways of fighting such bugs, including through vaccines, because even new antibiotics appear soon to lose their edge against the bugs.

The researchers from Juntendo University, Tokyo, outline their work in today's edition of the Lancet.

They found 70 new genes which could affect the bugs' infectious power and be targets for new drugs. They also found that the genes had been acquired from other living things, and that critical antibiotic-resistant genes can spread between different strains of S. aureus and between different species.

webTitle: Welsh school children infected with TB

fields.headline: Welsh school children infected with TB
fields.trailText: Eight children have caught tuberculosis at a school in south Wales,  two days after public health officials confirmed 18 more pupils had been diagnosed with TB at a school in Leicester.
fields.body:
Eight children have caught tuberculosis at a school in south Wales, the school's headmaster confirmed today.

The pupils, from Duffryn High School in Newport, are all aged between 14 and 15-years-old.

The news came two days after public health officials confirmed 18 more pupils had been diagnosed with TB at a school in Leicester, in an outbreak which is believed to be the worst in Britain for 20 years.

The disease was initially diagnosed in one pupil in year 10. The whole year was then screened and seven other pupils were found to have contracted the disease.

Gwent Health Authority is to carry out a mass screening programme among the 1,100 pupils at the school.

But the headmaster, David Snashall, said: "The school will remain open as normal. The chances of cross infection now are extremely low."

There have been 50 cases detected with connections to Crown Hills Community College in Leicester. Some 40 students have also shown early signs of TB and have been put on antibiotics, Leicestershire Health Authority said earlier this week.

The Welsh cases emerged on the same day health managers in Gloucestershire said more than a thousand former hospital patients are to be tested for TB after a nurse contracted the infectious disease.

Some 1,300 patients who were in contact with the health care worker at Cheltenham General Hospital over the last year are to be offered tests to see if they have picked up the infection.

Officials said that although the chances of her passing on the disease were rare, they were taking precautionary measures to protect patients.

fields.headline: The Human Genome Project
fields.trailText:
Professor Robert Plomin, Behavioural Geneticist, Institute of Psychiatry, London
The pace of discoveries in genetics now makes your head spin, but it's a no-brainer to think of the most exciting advance: the sequencing of the human genome. It's been incredibly exciting.
fields.body:
Professor Robert Plomin, Behavioural Geneticist, Institute of Psychiatry, London
The pace of discoveries in genetics now makes your head spin, but it's a no-brainer to think of the most exciting advance: the sequencing of the human genome. It's been incredibly exciting.

Some people say there is a lot of hype around about the genome, but it is hard to think of anything that's had such a general impact on the way we do science. It will have a huge impact on every area of people's lives.

A lot of people don't realise that it won't just affect medical diagnosis and treatment - it's not just about disease, it also affects our understanding of behaviour.

The Human Genome Project identified the order of the three billion letters of DNA in the human genome. These are what make us different from each other, what help to cause behavioural problems like mental illness and learning disabilities, as well as normal variations in behaviour like personality and mental abilities.

The sequencing of the genome gives us the chance to find the specific DNA letters responsible for this widespread genetic influence.

It will be possible to pinpoint how heredity unfolds in development as it interacts with the environment. It offers the hope of predicting who will have problems and to help these individuals before their worlds come tumbling down.

The genome is the DNA sequence that includes about 30,000 genes, but these are codes for many thousands of proteins making up all that we are, which has led researchers to the next step in understanding how genes work: looking at the proteins that are coded by genes. It is a much bigger task and one that will be a long time in the works.

Links
The Human Genome Project
Institute of Psychiatry, London

Compiled by Joe Plomin

webTitle: Britain waves goodbye to sea power

fields.headline: Britain waves goodbye to novel form of sea power drowned in red tape
fields.trailText: The first commercial version of a revolutionary British power station which generates electricity from the tides is to be built in Iceland because of red tape holding up planning permission in the UK.
fields.body:
The first commercial version of a revolutionary British power station which generates electricity from the tides is to be built in Iceland because of red tape holding up planning permission in the UK.

John Hassard, co-founder of RVco, the firm developing the system, said it had planned to build the two megawatt station on the coast of Britain until the firm found out that it could take two years to get the go-ahead from up to 14 agencies.

With the Icelanders, all it took was a phone call. "One woman was in charge of planning permission, the environmental impact study, the national grid ... she said: 'Can we help you? We have money.'"

Two British wave power firms, Wavegen and Ocean Power Delivery, are also considering moving part of their research overseas because of lack of support at home.

Dr Hassard, a scientist based at Imperial College where the technology behind RVco was invented, said that the government - fearful Britain would lose the tidal and wave power race as it lost out to Denmark over viable wind power - was now taking steps to help fledgling firms test their machines in home waters. It was unfortunate that this had not been done earlier.

RVco's power stations will use a device called the Rochester Venturi, a cross between a wing and a funnel, which is placed underwater and channels tidal flows.

As it passes through the device, the water decreases in pressure, sucking more water into pipes. This high pressure water drives on-shore turbines to generate electricity.

The advantage of the system, invented by Dr Hassard's co-founder and Imperial colleague Geoff Rochester, is that unlike other wave and tidal devices it does not have any moving parts immersed in the sea. Because it is below the surface, it is not subject to storms.

Dr Hassard said the price of electricity generated would ultimately be competitive with cheap gas power stations. If only the 10 best sites in the UK were used, venturis could generate one fifth of the electricity Britain uses each year.

RVco is building a miniature version of its system near Grimsby, but only because a private owner made a stretch of riverbank available.

Last month the energy minister, Peter Hain, admitted before a parliamentary committee that the government's ambitious targets for renewable energy - that it should make up 10% of Britain's electricity supply by the end of the decade - were in danger of getting bogged down in bureaucracy.

He described planning de lays as "a serious problem, both in the sheer bureaucracy and the associated costs that have to be waded through." In February the government announced it was considering a "one stop shop" for planning permission for offshore wind farms.

But there has still been no decision on the long-awaited announcement of a dedicated stretch of coast to be set aside for companies to test wave and tidal power technologies.

Dr Hassard said he hoped the government would designate a site on the Pentland Firth, the stormy sea strait between Orkney and the north coast of Scotland.

Richard Yemm, of Ocean Power Delivery, a wave power firm based in Edinburgh, said it received regular offers from the Danes to install testbeds in their country.

The firm was seriously considering an offer from a Dutch company to carry out joint tests in Portugal.

webTitle: The dos and don'ts of postgrad teaching

fields.headline: The dos and don'ts of postgrad teaching
fields.trailText: As the number of postgraduate teachers continues to grow, so has the controversy surrounding their employment.
fields.body:
While lecturers rarely receive any formal training as teachers, it is often expected that those applying for their first post will have had some teaching experience. This experience is usually secured by a period of postgraduate teaching.

Generally, postgraduate teachers are PhD students who are invited by their department to run a number of undergraduate classes and mark assignments. This work is often viewed as casual employment. It is unusual for a postgraduate teacher to be recruited through formal advertisements, and they are paid on an hourly basis. While the majority of lectures in Britain's universities are still given by lecturers, postgraduates now carry out up to a half of all seminar teaching.

And, as the number of postgraduate teachers continues to grow, so has the controversy surrounding their employment. Many complain that they are under-supported, underrepresented and underpaid. Nonetheless, postgraduate teaching remains an important step on the path to becoming a professional academic, and one that many PhD students value.

Andy Charlwood, a postgraduate teacher at the London School of Economics, says that there are a number of benefits to becoming a postgraduate teacher. "Having teaching experience does make it easier to get a job in academia. And if you teach an undergraduate course for your department, it gives you a broad overview of your subject. Also, it's a way of generating an income without having to do something completely separate to what you're studying."

General secretary of the National Postgraduate Committee, James Groves, says that postgraduate teaching can be one of the most rewarding aspects of postgraduate study. He says, "I would encourage postgraduates to take up a teaching role if given the opportunity. There are problems surrounding contracts and pay, but they are getting better. It is important to stress, though, that it is important for them to realise how much work they are taking on. Because they are paid hourly, rates of pay often look quite generous, but when postgraduates look at all the hours they spend preparing and marking, they can very soon find themselves working for the minimum wage.

"It's important that students don't take on so much teaching that it effects their own academic work."

Because so many postgraduates are keen to take on teaching, and others complain of poor working conditions, we have compiled a top ten list of the dos and don'ts of postgraduate teaching.

Do:

 Ask for training. If it is not offered, go to your department. If your department cannot help you, try going to the university's personnel office.

 Consider joining a union. The major lecturing unions are now beginning to recognise the need for representation among postgraduate teachers, and they should be able to provide insurance cover to indemnify you against legal liability.

 Ask for a contract which clearly outlines what you are expected to do, how much you are to be paid and if you are entitled to sick and holiday pay. If your department canêt help you, try going to the university's personnel department.

 Build a strong working relationship with the lecturer who is running the course you are teaching on. It is important that you can go to them with any difficulties regarding the subject or your teaching duties.

 Plan lessons and make sure you understand the subject you are teaching thoroughly.

Don't:

 Take on more work than you can cope with. If you are only paid for contact hours, do not think they are your only commitment. One contact hour usually takes about three hours preparation.

 Start work without a written job description.

 Undermine your own ability to teach. If you approach a class by telling them that you are "only a postgraduate" you are unlikely to inspire their enthusiasm or confidence. Be confident.

 Take on a pastoral role unless your contract explicitly requires it of you. If students come to you with personal problems, refer them to their personal tutor or another appropriate member of staff.

 Be pressurised into teaching if you do not want to. Postgraduates have no contractual obligation to teach.

Helpful links
The National Postgraduate Committee (NPC) is the representative body for postgraduates in the UK. Made up of student representatives from educational institutions with postgraduate students, the NPC aims to promote the interests of postgraduates studying in the UK, while remaining politically non-aligned. Their website provides guidelines for the employment of postgraduate students as teachers, which may prove useful when negotiating with your employer.

The Association of University Teachers (AUT) is a trade union and professional association representing academic and related staff in the universities, higher education colleges and research institutions of the UK. Postgraduate teachers are included in their membership and they have compiled an employment charter for postgraduate teachers in association with the NUS and the NPC.

NATFHE is the largest trade union and professional association for lecturers, trainers, researchers and managers working in further and higher education in the UK. They offer a years free membership to postgraduate students.

The National Union of Students (NUS) has developed links with the AUT and the NPC on the issue of postgraduate teaching, and is currently in negotiations with NATFE. Postgraduates have accesses to their universit's student union, as do any other students. The NUS have recently extended their support for postgraduate students by updating all local branches on the issues which might arise in connection with postgraduate teachers and how they may be supported.

It is important that you can go to them with any difficulties regarding the subject or your teaching duties.  Plan lessons and make sure you understand the subject you are teaching thoroughly. Don't:  Take on more work than you can cope with. If you are only paid for contact hours, do not think they are your only commitment. One contact hour usually takes about three hours preparation.  Start work without a written job description.  Undermine your own ability to teach. If you approach a class by telling them that you are "only a postgraduate" you are unlikely to inspire their enthusiasm or confidence. Postgraduates have no contractual obligation to teach. Helpful links The National Postgraduate Committee (NPC) is the representative body for postgraduates in the UK. Their website provides guidelines for the employment of postgraduate students as teachers, which may prove useful when negotiating with your employer. The Association of University Teachers (AUT) is a trade union and professional association representing academic and related staff in the universities, higher education colleges and research institutions of the UK. Postgraduate teachers are included in their membership and they have compiled an employment charter for postgraduate teachers in association with the NUS and the NPC. NATFHE is the largest trade union and professional association for lecturers, trainers, researchers and managers working in further and higher education in the UK. They offer a years free membership to postgraduate students. The National Union of Students (NUS) has developed links with the AUT and the NPC on the issue of postgraduate teaching, and is currently in negotiations with NATFE. Postgraduates have accesses to their universit's student union, as do any other students. The NUS have recently extended their support for postgraduate students by updating all local branches on the issues which might arise in connection with postgraduate teachers and how they may be supported.

webTitle: The seven ages of a scientist

fields.headline: The seven ages of a scientist

fields.body:
I want to talk about someone I have never met. His name is Alex. I want to talk about Alex because I want to discuss how knowledge is passed on from age to age, from generation to generation, from person to person. I want to talk about people, and, in particular, scientists. I want to talk about Alex's career as a scientist.

Francis Bacon argued that knowledge is power. Today, most people in the west potentially have that power. They have it because of the accessible and comprehensive education developed over the last century. But with such empowerment comes social morality.

It also follows that knowledge is only useful if it is first recorded and then passed on to the next and future generations. This is true if we are talking about the Holocaust, the Easter Rising or the BSE crisis. The knowledge surrounding these events should constantly be sifted, assessed and judged in the context of other, new material. As we learn more, we have to go back and reappraise the evidence, the historical event, the scientific hypothesis.

Who does this? In todayÕs world of specialisation we rely on policeman to police, on teachers to teach and nurses to nurse. But we also need professionals whose contribution to the community is to assess and re-assess existing and new knowledge. Their work must be free of political and religious constraints. They must have the academic freedom that is the hallmark of our universities. Above all, they must exercise that freedom with responsibility. Therefore, the moral power of knowledge lies in people, not in books or machines.

I would like to develop this theme by plotting the scientific career of Alex and examining the seven ages of a scientist.

Stage one: the infant
Alex is born. What chances does he have of becoming a scientist? To begin with it depends where he is born. If Alex was born in the USA he would be 25 times more likely to get a first degree than if he was born in China. You can argue that this is an issue of education and opportunity in developing countries. But the point I want to make is that the economic reality is that we can afford to give Alex more opportunity to gain this knowledge, and become a scientist.

But do we give all people an equal opportunity? Although more and more students are going to university, if Alex was born in the UK, into a family whose father was a senior civil servant, he would be eight times more likely to go into higher education than if his father was a refuse collector.

What if Alex was a woman? Thankfully, in much of the developed world, an equal number of women and men are now studying for first degrees. Having said this, there are still gender inequalities in some subjects. In Ireland, as in the UK, the same proportion of women and men go on to higher education in the natural sciences but, in engineering, more than eight out of ten students are men. Why is this? Why donÕt we have more women engineers? Is it because of the lack of role models, their schooling, or institutional discrimination?

There are, of course, many other examples of social and gender inequalities that may inhibit, or increase, AlexÕs early education. Although the causes of these inequalities are complex, it is a sobering thought that by accident of birth the success of AlexÕs career is partly pre-determined.

Stage two: the schoolboy
This brings us on to science education in schools. But first, some of the statistics on education amaze me.

For example, nearly half of those born in Ireland in the 30's left education after primary school, compared with just over 7% of those born in the 60's. The number of people with scientific or technological qualifications doubled from about 80,000 in 1986 to almost 160,000 in 1996. As a result, Ireland now has by far the highest proportion of science and technology graduates, as a percentage of total employment, of all the OECD countries.

This is a notable achievement and one that Ireland has every right to be proud of. ItÕs also clear that this is at least assisting - if not driving - the prolonged period of economic growth the country has experienced in recent years.

Such facts point to the apparent success of yesteryear's science education. But I question this. When you look at the level of popular debate that we witness in the UK - on genetically modified foods, gene therapy, complementary medicine, and so on - it seems clear to me that science education was a failure for a very large number of people. It almost seems that some people became scientists, irrespective of their teachers. Yet teachers have a moral responsibility to give knowledge and understanding of their subject to all their students. If this is not done, then we can expect the sort of ill-informed debate that has typified much of the discussion on, for example, the use of genetics in healthcare. A debate often based on ignorance, prejudice and fear, a debate that has alienated and marginalised perhaps a majority of people, who have now become afraid of science.

So what accounts for this failure? Some of the responsibility for this must surely lie within the universities. They train the teachers, who teach the pupils. They are, after all, the guardians of knowledge. Perhaps the way forwards is for us - the university, the academic, the scientist - to participate more in science education. When I was a working scientist, I went to the local primary school with two vials of blood - one the blood of a child with leukemia and the other without. IÕd put them down on the table and start talking to the children about what they were made of - about cells, tissue and blood. TheyÕd be listening to me - or at least IÕd hope they were listening to me - and look at the blood. The blood was a lot more interesting than me: they could relate to it, it was part of them. The blood then began to settle, and it became obvious which vial was which and, in this way, the children began to understand what leukemia was and why it made people ill. They began to respect their own complexity. Some began to dream, I like to think, of becoming a scientist.

Universities have to inspire tomorrowÕs teachers. Inspired teachers inspire pupils, which in turn instills the motivation and desire for new knowledge. To do this, teachers need confidence in the subject matter and, in this context, I find it disturbing that there are more schools that teach physics than there are trained physicists coming out of the university system.

I raise these points as only a few months ago the UKÕs Council for Science and Technology published a report on science teachers. I was as surprised as the council was by one particular finding: the confidence of science teachers in their own subject was lower when teaching older classes, than when teaching the younger 11-13-year-old pupils. If teachers are not confident in what they teach, how can we expect pupils to have confidence in what theyÕre being taught?

Despite all this, letÕs assume that Alex beats the systems, gets a degree and still wants to become a scientist. To me he has become a lover.

Stage three: the lover
The lover for me signifies the PhD student and that first post-doctoral job.

Many of us my fellow professors have witnessed the endless hours of work, often in poor conditions for a disgraceful amount of money, that Alex would be expected to do if he embarks on a PhD. He will put up with this as he is in love. He loves the work. He loves the pursuit of knowledge. He loves the creativity that goes with his research. One could argue that Alex is blinded by that love.

If Alex is blinded by that love, who is providing the vision? We are - and I wonder if our vision needs questioning? Are PhDs necessary? Maybe, with todayÕs technology driven science, PhDs are an outdated form of research training. How many PhD students should we be training? Maybe we should double stipends and halve the number of students.

Europe leads North America and Asia in the number of science and technology doctoral degrees awarded. In 1995, science PhDs awarded by European institutions totalled 45,000, about 60% higher than in North America and almost three times as many as recorded for Asian countries.Yet North America is still the powerhouse for academic research. They produce 40% of scientific papers and are the inventors on 30% of patents.

I donÕt know what accounts for this difference in success, although I suspect that culture has a major role to play, but I do believe these issues need to be debated. To try and promote this debate the Wellcome Trust recently published two reports evaluating our PhD Research Training. From this survey, itÕs clear that students embark on a PhD because they value independence, the open academic environment and the challenge. Yet this initial enthusiasm is often sadly, but quickly, tempered when reality strikes. One student said: "The things that put me off are the career paths. If I was massively ambitious then I wouldnÕt stay in the same lab, IÕd be off to the States. Also the insecurity - thereÕs a lot of short-term contracts. If I ever wanted to start a family it doesnÕt feel like it would fit within the whole thing".

Even so, some still remain in love. One student said: "I have no desire to do anything else. I canÕt believe someone pays you to do this."

Let us assume that, like this last student, Alex completes his PhD and commences his first-post doc job. HeÕd be about 25 years old - probably carrying a large personal debt - and itÕs taken 20 years of education to give him the knowledge that heÕs going to require as a scientist. He is very much in the ascendancy of his chosen career. Alex has become a repository of existing knowledge, and is busy acquiring new knowledge. He has progressed from the pupil to the teacher to the policy maker. He has embarked on potentially the most satisfying but demanding part of his career. He has moved into the fourth age - that of the soldier.

Stage four: the soldier
This age, to me, is the defining time in AlexÕs career. Not least because he will have to face a number of issues and to reach a number of decisions.

For our Wellcome Trust PhD students, there was a progressive decrease in the proportions who remained in academic research after graduating. Three years after completing a PhD, just under two thirds remained in academia, and by five years less than half remained in universities.

We need to have a far better understanding of these career movements. Where are these people going? Are these highly trained scientists leaving science altogether? If many of the best young people leave our academic systems, who is going to train the next generation? As a society, we have a moral duty to ensure a constant influx of some of our best minds into the university system. People who will articulate complex ethical problems, consider the morality and power of new knowledge and assess its impact on society

With these thoughts in mind we have to find ways of retaining some of our best young people in the university sector. Governments, here and in the UK, have to make some difficult decisions quickly. In the UK, for example, a recent independent report suggested that academic salaries need to be increased by as much as 20% to 30%, simply to get them to where they were 20 to 30 years ago.

More astounding is the realisation that if Alex was a woman she would be earning - in the UK at least - on average, and at every level of the university system, 20% less than her male counterparts. In Ireland, a similar situation exists. Last year, an article in the Sunday Tribune reported a 20% earnings gap between men and women for the whole Irish workforce.

One of the most unshakable memories of a trip I made to Ireland last year was the lack of female scientists. And those I did manage to meet were not happy. They had concerns about the amount of money they were paid. They were unhappy about the lack of family friendly employment practices. They were unhappy about the fact that only six out of every 100 professors in Ireland was a woman.

LetÕs not kid ourselves. This is due to institutional discrimination. And itÕs not a problem exclusive to Ireland - the UK is similar. If universities are to compete with other sectors of employment, we have to offer a modern working environment. One that rewards staff, provides flexible working arrangements and, above all, provides everyone with an equal opportunity to succeed in their chosen career.

But everyone has a role to play in valuing universities and in promoting academic careers . During the course of my life, I am sure that the esteem and standing of academics has declined, along with other professions such as nursing, teaching and even the clergy. Maybe society thinks these jobs are easy. Or that theyÕre not really necessary. How wrong they are - on all accounts.

In short, Alex faces many hurdles as he soldiers his way through the forth age of a scientific career. If successful, he will become the leader of a lab - in Shakespearean parlance, the Justice.

Stage five: the Justice
Alex is likely to be on the verge of becoming a professor. He has applied for numerous grants over the past five years and, on the whole, been quite successful. His publication output is near its peak. His role, as principal investigator on these grants, has been to motivate and train around five or six post-doctorate students, some of them themselves quite senior. He has, I expect, begun to realise that these post-docs are the ones who are actually pushing the frontiers of knowledge and are the real driving force of scientific discovery. To begin with he finds this insight difficult, but he soon understands that he in effect has become a manager - a manager of resources, people and ideas.

And when you think about it, management training is a responsibility the university has sadly neglected. Yet, it is essential that we manage our most precious resource - people - and ensure that they, in turn, have the skills required to manage others.

This issue has been explored by the Research Careers Initiative in the UK. They have found that although some universities have begun to provide some management training, individual academics are often reluctant to embark on such training programmes. We need to convince these people that they have a responsibility to manage their research staff and their students. Alex needs to realise that his own success is absolutely dependent on his success as a manager. His success in encouraging, inspiring and motivating his younger staff. His success in moving on to the sixth age.

Stage six: the slippered pantaloon
Alex is now likely to become a Head of Department and, if successful, to go on and become a dean, a vice-chancellor or perhaps a chief scientific adviser. He is, undoubtedly, at the peak of his career.

However, as he reaches that peak, he will have less and less time to do what he does best. Increasingly, he will have to deal with the administrative matters of his department, university and discipline. A recent survey on grant application behavior commissioned by the Trust shows that, in term time, about a third of AlexÕs time would be taken up with administration and management, a third with teaching and a third with research. To emphasise an earlier point, it is notable that of the three activities predominating Alex's time, he has only received formal training for one - research.

Stage seven: second childishness
Today, as we live longer and healthier lives, this period has become known as the third age. Academics, like the rest of society, are living longer and healthier but are, on the whole, retiring early.

Or are they? In fact, it is not actually unusual for scientists to continue their academic work beyond retirement. Only last month, the Wellcome Trust awarded a project grant to Max Perutz, an 86-year-old past winner of the Nobel Prize, who will collaborate with Alan Ferscht at Cambridge University. They will determine the X-ray crystal structure of a protein implicated in a neuro-degenerative disorder called Mechedo-Joseph disease. Perhaps this is an example to us all.

And that ends our passage through AlexÕs career, from cradle to grave. Perhaps I have painted too negative a picture of academic careers as we begin the new millennium. I have, quite deliberately, pointed out a succession of hurdles that Alex will have to negotiate in his career. Some of these are entirely just - a successful career should be based on healthy competition with equality of opportunity.

But we academics must remember, as we enter the new millennium, that just as Alex has to compete for research funds, for promotion, we have to compete with other careers. We have to persuade the youngest members of our society that an academic career is an attractive option, that being an academic, within our university system, can be rewarding, both intellectually and financially. By investing in people, we can ensure not only that knowledge is passed on from person to person, but we can be more confident that this knowledge can and will be used for the betterment of mankind - without prejudice, without fear, without ignorance. Only then will we see the real benefits of a knowledge based society. And only then will we really achieve the moral power of knowledge.

I have, quite deliberately, pointed out a succession of hurdles that Alex will have to negotiate in his career. Some of these are entirely just - a successful career should be based on healthy competition with equality of opportunity. But we academics must remember, as we enter the new millennium, that just as Alex has to compete for research funds, for promotion, we have to compete with other careers. We have to persuade the youngest members of our society that an academic career is an attractive option, that being an academic, within our university system, can be rewarding, both intellectually and financially. By investing in people, we can ensure not only that knowledge is passed on from person to person, but we can be more confident that this knowledge can and will be used for the betterment of mankind - without prejudice, without fear, without ignorance. Only then will we see the real benefits of a knowledge based society. And only then will we really achieve the moral power of knowledge.

fields.headline: Nasa's 5,000mph prototype
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: US space scientists have unveiled the prototype of a plane that will someday streak across America from coast to coast in 30 minutes, using oxygen from the air as its fuel.
fields.byline: Dan Whitcomb  at Edwards air force base, California
fields.body:
US space scientists have unveiled the prototype of a plane that will someday streak across America from coast to coast in 30 minutes, using oxygen from the air as its fuel.

They called the small black X-43A prototype a breakthrough in aviation as historic as the Wright Brothers' first flight.

On its maiden flight next month, they said, it will fly at seven times the speed of sound - nearly 5,000mph - shattering the record for a jet engine unsupported by rocket power.

Although the unmanned prototype will be launched from a B-52 bomber, a version will eventually take off and land on its own, making way for cheaper space missions, a new generation in commercial travel, and military aircraft that fly too fast for an adversary to shoot them down.

"This is aviation history," the project manager, Joel Sitz, said. "We are doing research for an operating vehicle that will fly 60 years from now."

The prototype will fly unassisted for a few seconds before crashing into the Pacific, burying its secrets.
Reuters

fields.headline: Shortcuts
fields.trailText: Oversubscribed: Jackie O | Overexposed: Post-it notes | Overheard: "Glamouflage" | Pretend you know all about: Tiger
fields.body:
Oversubscribed: Jackie O

Oh, to have blossomed at the start of the 60s, when the happy clash of social change and technological advancement caused everyone suddenly to be fabulous. It was then that a president's wife in fake Chanel became an untouchable style icon, whose name has become synonymous with a certain look (hide-all-emotion sunglasses, an expression of stoicism in the face of philandering etc). Once again, her influence is reaching fever pitch - on the recent catwalk run, all Marc Jacobs' various autumn/winter shows had a Jackie O touch about them.

More pressing is the retrospective of her clothes about to open at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, which has provoked endless articles about her ever-so-fascinating style.

We're with Karl Lagerfeld on this one - the Jackie O show was allegedly scheduled only after he pulled out of a planned Chanel exhibition. Of the Metropolitan, he is dismissive. "It's perfect. They call it the Necropolitan Museum," says Lagerfeld, as unforthcoming as ever.

Overexposed: Post-it notes

You know the lost Post-it note, the one that always goes missing with that vital number scrawled on it? Not any more, thanks to Tom Ford at Gucci. In his autumn/winter collection, Ford had killer dresses that strangely resembled the sticky office essential. Now the hunt through the bin for the rogue note will be a thing of the past - all you have to do is stick the yellow flap on your person. Not only will you have instant, cutting-edge chic (especially since Ford's does not go on sale until late summer), but no one in the office will ever shout at you again for forgetting that fantastic idea you had for the brainstorming meeting in five minutes. Meanwhile, fashionistas will wonder how you got hold of the Gucci look so quickly and will assume you have a fantastically well-connected job.

Gucci's violet number looked best, so if you're on a budget, just pop down to Office World and buy a bumper pack of Post-its, plus a few felt-tip pens. Hey presto: cheap chic and perfect workwear. Who says fashion isn't practical?

Overheard: "Glamouflage"

1. Missy Elliott's characteristic take on the military look - sequin-bedecked camouflage (not much cop when hiding in the jungle). 2. The guilty concealment of your copy of Glamour (in your handbag, naturally).

Pretend you know all about: Tiger

With the current vogue for label regeneration, there is always an element of humour at work. (Pringle, ha ha! Who'd wear that? Oh. Us.) So how should you respond to the reinvention of Tiger of Sweden, the second most popular label in its homeland, founded in 1903 by Markus Scharzmann and Hjalmar Nordstrom? Roll around on the floor, obviously.

But wait. Tiger, a menswear label that has just opened its first UK store in Covent Garden, has some fine products on offer. Its pale blue jeans are right on the mark - skinny, fitted, but also rugged, with great three-pleat stitching on the back pockets. Next to them on the shelves are cute summer T-shirts and V-necked sweaters, and in a few months' time, head there for some immaculately cut chunky coats fit to brave a Scandinavian winter.

The man behind this rebirth is CEO Roger Tjernberg, but perhaps more telling is the unofficial help given to the label by Wallpaper*'s Tyler Brlé, a lover of all things Swedish. Expect to see Tiger denim falling off some impossibly beautiful, buffed models in his magazine's photo shoots any day now.

fields.headline: Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council
fields.trailText:
Funding body
Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council (PPARC)
fields.body:
Funding body
Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council (PPARC)

People to know
Chairman: Dr Robert Hawley CBE, FRSE, FEng
Chief Executive: Professor Ian Halliday FRSE, PPARC
Mr Tony Brenton, Foreign and Commonwealth Office
Professor Roger Davies, University of Durham
Mr Robert Foster, Department of Trade and Industry
Dr Sue Ion CEng FIM FEng, British Nuclear Fuels Plc
Professor Andy Lawrence, University of Edinburgh
Professor Dewi Lewis CPhys FInstP, Nycomed Amersham
Professor Keith Mason, Mullard Space Science Laboratory
Professor John Pendry FRS, Imperial College, London
Professor Ian Ritchie
Professor Chris Sachrajda FRS, University of Southampton
Professor David Saxon FRSE, Glasgow University

Click here for more council members.

Aims
To pursue a programme of high quality basic research in astronomy, planetary science and particle physics. This programme should further the understanding of fundamental questions; train high quality scientists and engineers; increase the industry's competitiveness; attract future generations of scientists and engineers and stimulate the public's interest.

Background
The PPARC was established in 1994 as part of the reorganisation of the Research Councils announced in the government's White Paper on science, engineering and technology, "Realising our Potential". The council funds UK research, education and public understanding in its four broad areas of science - particle physics, astronomy, cosmology and space science. The council's administrative headquarters are in Swindon. The PPARC also has three scientific sites: the UKATC in Edinburgh, the ING in La Palma and the JAC in Hawaii.

Information on astronomy programmes.
Information on particle physics programmes.

Budget breakdown and top ten beneficiaries

Organisation Number of awards UK£ Value
Manchester University 19 £23,092,300
University College London 51 £22,975,262
Cambridge University 45 £21,375,380
Oxford University 34 £16,985,754
Edinburgh University 21 £14,625,120
Durham University 24 £13,708,290
Leicester University 19 £13,142,655
Imperial College 20 £12,100,519
Open University 9 £10,618,852
Queen Mary and Westfield College 23 £10,037,830

503 grants with a total value of £225,571,104 (GBP.)

Future issues and priorities
The council focuses on the following programme areas: Particle Physics, Astronomy and Astrophysics, Solar System Science.

The distinction between research areas can be a fine one. Applicants who are in doubt as to whether their activities are appropriate to PPARC should consult well in advance of the closing date for applications.

Grants
The PPARC currently support 503 grants worth £225,571,104 (GBP). Their maintenance grants are £8,500 for London applicants and £6,800 for those applying outside of London. For more information on research grants click here.

Postgraduate studentships

Standard Research Studentships
Purpose: Research studentships normally leading to the award of a PhD are tenable for up to three years, and are awarded to postgraduate students for training in the methods of research. Studentships are allocated to Departments of Higher Education Institutions within Great Britain. Standard research studentships may be converted to CASE studentships.
Success rate: Approximately 175 were awarded last year.
Deadline: Closing Date: 1 October 2001
Standeard Research Studentships

CASE Studentships
Purpose: These Cooperative Awards in Science and Engineering (CASE) are designed to give students experience outside a purely academic environment. CASE awards provide for a research student's training on a project which involves the joint supervision of the student by a member of staff at an academic institution and an employee of a UK industrial firm or an organisation in the public service.
Funding: During the period of the award, the student is required to spend a period on the premises of the cooperating body. For a three year award, the minimum is three months and pro-rata for shorter awards, subject to a minimum of two months. Students holding CASE awards will receive £350 pa in addition to the basic maintenance allowance. The cooperating body is required to make financial contributions to both the student and the project. It must include an annual contribution to the academic institution towards the cost of the project: £1,435 for 2000/2001; all additional expenses, such as the cost of travel and accommodation incurred as a direct result of attendance at the premises of the cooperating body; and an annual contribution to the student: minimum £2,560 for 2000/2001. In the event of a cooperating body withdrawing from the CASE arrangement, PPARC will continue to pay the CASE addition of £350 pa to the student.
Success rate: Last year approximately ten were awarded.
Deadline: Closing Date: 1 October 2001
CASE Studentships

CASE-Plus Studentships
Purpose: CASE-Plus extends the CASE scheme to help students become more effective in promoting technology transfer, should their chosen career path take them into either academic research or industry. The main difference from CASE is that the student spends a fourth year working full-time on the premises of the cooperating body as an employee.
Funding: During this additional year, the student is employed by the sponsor company, at a salary equivalent to that of a new PPARC postdoctoral fellow. PPARC will contribute 50% of the salary costs incurred by the cooperating body (up to a maximum PPARC contribution of £12,000).
Eligibility: Existing CASE studentships may be converted to CASE-Plus at any time up to the end of the second year.
Success rate: The PPARC awarded approximately three of these studentships last year.
Deadline: Closing Date: 1 October 2001
CASE-plus Studentships
Other types of research studentships

Gemini Studentships
Purpose: This scheme enables students from Argentina, Brazil and Chile to study for an astronomy PhD in Great Britain. It is aimed at fostering greater collaboration at the grass roots level and at increasing the number of astronomers in these countries prior to the Gemini telescopes becoming operational.
Succes rate: PPARC will make up to three awards per annum, one to each of the participating countries.
Funding: PPARC provides a maintenance allowance to the student and a contribution to the institution in respect of the student's tuition fees up to the equivalent of the UK fee rate.

Spanish Studentships (IAC)
Purpose: PPARC has an agreement with the Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias (IAC), Tenerife, Spain, to support a maximum of two IAC students at any one time to study for an astronomy PhD in Great Britain. The Spanish Studentships scheme operates in a similar way to the Gemini scheme.

Conversion of awards
Conversion from Standard Research to CASE
Awards which have been made as standard research studentships may be converted to CASE studentships at any time after the student is in their post. The duration of the award will not be extended in consequence.

Conversion from CASE to CASE-Plus
Awards which have been made as CASE studentships may be converted to CASE-Plus at any time up to the end of the second year.

Graduate Schools Programme: Personal career workshops for PhD students
Purpose: To enable research students to take control of their future and to achieve their full potential by broadening their view of career opportunities and developing personal and communication skills.
Places: PPARC funds a limited number of places each year to enable its students to attend the Joint Research Councils Graduate Schools.

Short courses and summer schools
Each year PPARC funds the following well-established Short courses and summer schools:

Introductory course in astronomy for new research students

Introductory course in solar terrestrial physics
Advanced course in solar terrestrial physics
British Universities summer school in theoretical elementary particle physics CLRC summer school in elementary particle physics
The venues for the above vary from year to year. Full details are announced at the appropriate time by the host university.

Short stays in European Centres
European Fifth Framework Programme
Offers the opportunity for postgraduate students under 35 years of age, enrolled on a PhD studentship, to spend between three months and one academic year at a recognised Marie Curie Training Site. Marie Curie Training Sites are research groups which have successfully applied to the European Commission to host short stays of young researchers.

Awards must be taken up in a Marie Curie Training Site in a country other than that of the student's nationality and of his or her recent centre of activity. The period of training at the Training Site must be recognised as an integral part of the student's doctoral studies, as certified by the institution awarding the degree. Full details of Marie Curie Research Training grants are given on the European Commission CORDIS website.

Fellowships
Information on fellowships

PPARC operates three fellowship schemes - postdoctoral, advanced and senior research fellowships - and these can be divided into two distinct categories.

Firstly, there are postdoctoral and advanced fellowships which are intended for researchers who do not have a permanent academic position but wish to pursue a long term research career. They offer the opportunity to pursue new and diverse areas of research at a chosen UK institution. There are 23 awarded in total each year. For more information click here.

Secondly, there are senior research fellowships which are intended for researchers who currently hold a permanent academic position but would like the opportunity to devote themselves to full-time personal research free of restrictions imposed by their normal employment. For more information click here. Fellowships normally begin on 1 October and PPARC expects all fellowships to be taken up by the following 31 March.
