fields.headline: Dot.coms click with charities
fields.standfirst: The IT sector, which lags behind other industries in the corporate giving stakes, is trying to catch up with innovative new schemes to get dot.coms involved in charity work. Liza Ramrayka reports
fields.trailText: The IT sector, which lags behind other industries in the corporate giving stakes, is trying to catch up with innovative new schemes to get dot.coms involved in charity work. Liza Ramrayka reports.
fields.body:
Getting business to give more time and money to charity is a perennial problem but current projects initiated by the IT sector show a novel approach to solving this dilemma.

Despite dot.com boom and bust and the relative youth of the sector, technology-related companies are behind some of the most innovative moves to get business to give back to the community.

A good example of this is the recently launched HighTech Women Skills Bank for Society project, which aims to bring together voluntary organisations and technology companies to share time and skills. Ideas include mentoring, secondments and employee involvement schemes.

The project was set up by HighTech Women, a 1,400-member network for women working in technology and related sectors.

Based on the idea of "doing good and doing well", HighTech Women already encourages its members - who range from CEOs to students - to mentor and share career advice. The skills bank will act as a brokerage service between individuals or their companies, and the voluntary sector.

HighTech Women managing director Lucy Marcus says a recent survey of members found that many were concerned about corporate social responsibility.

"The message came through loud and clear that they feel that 'doing good and doing well' is a powerful way to achieve balance, no matter where they are in their careers," says Ms Marcus.

"Their experiences with mentoring others and giving back to the community have been among the most satisfying and energising things they do."

This ethos echoes government thinking. The Department of Trade and Industry is urging all areas of business to support literacy, numeracy and community investment projects as part of its corporate social responsibility programme.

Suggestions for action include staff secondments, allowing local groups to share company facilities and acting as business brokers to attract project funding.

IT start-ups are among the supporters of a national foundation designed to provide all British children over the age of four with a laptop by 2006.

BenefisU, Bladerunner, Businesshr and Chalkscape have pledged donations to the fund, which will work with charities and schools to promote e-learning. It is funded by a £5m government grant and £1m from Microsoft.

Bridging the digital divide is the focus of a new project by AOL UK. The company has teamed up with youth development charity Fairbridge to help disadvantaged young people to develop basic web design and IT skills.

The aim is to improve their access to future education and job opportunities. AOL UK staff will work with young people to teach them about computers and the internet.

Charlie Ward, project co-ordinator at Fairbridge, says the initiative will boost young people's skills and confidence. "The majority have not had any previous access to computers or the internet," he says. "This project will enable them to enter the information age on an equal footing with their peers."

The IT sector lags behind other industries in the corporate giving stakes. Latest research by the Directory of Social Change shows IT companies contributed a mere £3m to charities last year, compared to the £60m given by the banking sector and £21m from the oil and gas industries.

One man on a mission to change this is Shaun Orpen, Microsoft director and newly appointed member of the NSPCC's corporate development board.

His task is to encourage others in the IT sector to help raise £5m for the charity's Full Stop campaign.

Mr Orpen says IT companies are "incredibly willing" to share their time and skills with voluntary groups but have yet to fulfil this potential. "I'd like to see the IT industry in the UK rise to this challenge," he adds.

fields.headline: Labour pick new theme song
fields.trailText: Party strategists play pop pickers for successor to Things Can Only Get Better
fields.body:
The Labour party have finally made one of the most difficult decisions of the pre-election phoney war - they've chosen a successor to their 1997 them song "Things Can Only Get Better."

As originally revealed on Guardian Unlimited, the party's Millbank strategists have plumped for easy-listening popsters The Lighthouse Family to get the party going at rallies and hustings around the country.

Their 1996 hit "Lifted" beat off stiff competition from dance band Primal Scream to get the New Labour seal of approval.

A spokesman for the party said: ""We are in politics to make life better for the people of Britain." "We are lifting Britain up and taking it to a better future. With the voters' backing, we can carry on with the job."

However, former Labour supporter and red wedge activist Billy Bragg immediately slated the song as "watered-down Conservatism".

Bragg, who announced this week he would be supporting the Liberal Democrats at the next election, said: "I think so much of New Labour is about presentation rather than detail. They are hoping we won't listen to the verse and just hear the chorus - it's style over content. "At least the last one (Things Can Only Get Better) had a bit of optimism about it.

"I would have preferred something a bit edgier. I think it is very bland," he added.

The band, who comprise Paul Tucker and Tunde Baiyewu, said they were flattered to be chosen by the Labour party, and added: "Lifted is a song about being optimistic about the future. It's a song about people and about life."

When the single was originally released in 1995 it only charted at number 61, but later went on to sell more than 250,000 copies.

A Conservative party spokesman said: ""If Labour think they can hide their failure to deliver on their promises to the people of Britain, then they have got another thing coming."

The Tories have already chosen Wombles composer Mike Batt to compose a song called "Heartland" for their election campaign, and the Liberal Democrats will use a cover of the Stephen Gately song "New Beginning" at their rallies.

fields.headline: Jail terms for vote-rigging councillors
fields.trailText: Two councillors were today jailed for what is believed to be the country's largest vote-rigging conspiracy.
fields.body:
Two councillors were today jailed for what is believed to be the country's largest vote-rigging conspiracy.

Conservative Isaac Leibowitz, 36, and Zev Lieberman, 29, a Liberal Democrat, were jailed for six months and four months respectively for the fraud, which may have cost Labour overall power in the local elections in Hackney, north-east London, two years ago.

Sentencing them at Wood Green crown court, judge Jeremy Connor acknowledged that both Liebowitz and Lieberman were highly respected in their workplaces and communities and men of "good character". But their "enthusiasm for public office" led to their downfall.

He went on: "The sad thing is that the evidence has shown that the enthusiasm for public office in order to do good things led to agreement for the commission of these offences, defrauding the returning officer and causing a violation of the election process.

"No doubt that arose from a clear intention to elect particular councillors, but fraud it was and fraud it was proved to be."

fields.headline: Meningitis alert follows Hajj pilgrims
fields.standfirst: Meningitis Trust hotline: 0845 6000 800.
fields.trailText: Health officials have issued a nationwide alert after the deaths of seven people in England and Wales from a strain of meningitis caught at the annual Hajj pilgrimage to Mecca.
fields.body:
Health officials have issued a nationwide alert after the deaths of seven people in England and Wales from a strain of meningitis caught at the annual Hajj pilgrimage to Mecca.

The Department of Health has issued an urgent message to all GPs and health authorities urging them to be vigilant for signs of the disease. So far 29 people in England and Wales have fallen ill with the W135 meningococcal infection and seven have died since last month's pilgrimage. It is a strain of meningitis not found in this country but prevalent in Saudi Arabia.

All the British victims had either been on the pilgrimage or had been in contact with people who had travelled to Mecca for the event. It is not known where the people are from or whether they are children or adults.

More than 20,000 British Muslims are believed to have travelled to Mecca for the annual pilgrimage this year. Pilgrims are offered a vaccine against the strain but health officials said uptake prior to the event this year had been low.

The Department of Health issued an electronic warning on its NHS-wide electronic Epinet system on April 13 after the Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre alerted it to the cases.

Symptoms of the W135 strain are the same as other forms of meningitis, with people suffering high temperatures, vomiting and aversion to bright lights.

fields.headline: Police criticise Kellogg's crime adverts
fields.trailText:
<B<8.30am: Police chiefs have condemned a Kellogg's advertising campaign designed to look like a police appeal for witnesses, writes Julia Day.
Talk about it
fields.body:
Police chiefs have condemned a new Kellogg's advertising campaign which is designed to look like a police appeal for witnesses.

And a complaint about the advert has already been registered with the Advertising Standards Authority.

The adverts, promoting a new Kellogg's product called Real Fruit Winders looks like an appeal for witnesses to an attack complete with police tape and the all too familiar sign.

New Scotland Yard said it was inappropriate imitation of their appeals campaigns.

"Our witness appeal posters are not a registered design but this is something we not be at all happy with. It would confuse people," said a spokesman.

"If it really does look like one of our posters then I would like to go to Kellogg's about it."

A spokesman for the ASA said all adverts must make it clear what is being advertised or they could be misleading.

Kellogg's was unavailable for comment.

fields.headline: Ground-breaking show ditched
fields.trailText: Right to Reply presenter Roger Bolton said today was a black day for viewers, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Roger Bolton, the presenter of Right to Reply, said today was a black day for viewers after Channel 4 announced it was axing the programme after more than 18 years.

"I have had a good run," said Mr Bolton. "But it is not the programme or the presenter that is important - it is the principle of Channel 4 being accountable to its audience.

"There is now no programme on British television in which programme-makers can be held accountable."

When it launched, Right to Reply represented the only opportunity viewers had to challenge programme-makers face-to-face.

The station was determined to hold itself accountable, even to the point of ensuring that the complainant had the last say on the programme.

It was a ground-breaking approach on many levels.

ITV had no right to reply show and the BBC paid only lip service to the notion that licence payers opinions counted.

Viewers who bothered to challenge the corporation were derided by patronising programmes such as Points of View, which was presented by Barry Took or Anne Robinson.

The alternative was the great black hole that was the BBC's "duty log". For a while the corporation made an attempt to rival Right to Reply with its own version presented by Sue Lawley.

Right to Reply, however, was different - it was half an hour long and given a key slot after the station's most popular show, Brookside.

And in a first for a TV station, viewers were invited into the studios for a face-to-face discussion with programme-makers, with heavyweight TV names on hand to guard against intimidation.

The first presenter was the Granada TV boss, Gus Macdonald, now Lord Macdonald.

Other presenters included Linda Agran, Sheena McDonald, Brian Hayes, Rory McGrath and Roger Bolton.

There was also the pioneering Right to Reply "video box" for those who couldn't make it to London, giving the programme a refreshing regional imprint.

As one TV critic said, it gave viewers an opportunity to "question and criticise the programmes that were transmitted and the smooth bastards who were responsible for making them".

And for the first time it gave viewers the opportunity to complain about programmes on any channel - something unheard of at the BBC.

Tonight's show, which will includes a discussion on the BBC's Son of God documentary series, will be the last

"I think they should have changed the presenter or the format if they felt it was tired," said Mr Bolton, "but doing away with it with no plans to replace it is a great shame.

"It is to their great credit that they have had the programme for so long, especially when the BBC so half-heartedly gave viewers a right to reply."

webTitle: New laws to trap crime bosses

fields.headline: New laws to trap crime bosses
fields.standfirst: 'Untouchable' criminal masterminds could be targeted by US-style anti-mafia initiative
fields.trailText: 'Untouchable' criminal masterminds could be targeted by US-style anti-mafia initiative.
fields.body:
The government is considering introducing powerful new conspiracy laws to tackle up to 200 master criminals who are effectively untouchable because current legislation does not give the police enough powers to tackle them.

Senior police officers have urged the Home Office to pursue initiatives similar to the anti-racketeering act in the US, which was credited with crushing the mafia .

The Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organisations Act (Rico) allowed federal agents to target the organising entity behind a crime, "not merely the act" itself. By concentrating on the conspiracy behind a crime, investigators were able to target mafia bosses as well as their footsoldiers.

Sir David Phillips, chairman of the Association of Chief Police Officer's policing committee, has supported the use of laws modelled on Rico in private advice to the Home Office, believing they could prove an essential crime-fighting tool.

The Guardian has learned the Home Office is now circulating a classified consultation paper titled the Prosecution of Organised Criminal Conspiracy to gauge reaction to Rico- style laws from agenciessuch as customs and excise and the crown prosecution service, before deciding what to do.

Concern in Whitehall that a premier league of criminals is prospering with impunity was bolstered last year with the findings of a confidential UK threat assessment report, compiled by the national criminal intelligence service (NCIS).

An abridged version of the report was given to the media but the full document was only presented to ministers.

An investigation into organised crime published in today's Economist newspaper claims to have uncovered further confidential details about the extent of criminality in the UK.

The Economist says it has seen classified NCIS documents that refer to a group of 150 "core nominals" - intelligence-speak for crime bosses - and around 750 lieutenants who work for them. It says the number of such criminals increases by a third every year.

NCIS yesterday denied that these figures were part of its confidential threat assessment report. Nevertheless, it has warned repeatedly about the increasing threat of organised crime in areas like drugs smuggling, illegal arms sales, and immigration rackets.

The willingness of the Home Office to consider new powers for the police became apparent yesterday when it emerged that a leading criminologist, Professor Michael Levi of Cardiff University, was asked to prepare a paper on methods used by other countries to tackle organised crime. His report highlighted the effectiveness of Rico laws in the US, but also questioned whether such laws would work in the UK.

Sir David Phillips, the chief constable of Kent, has advocated the use of similar laws to Lord Justice Auld, who is preparing a report on root and branch reform of the criminal justice system.

"The bottom line is this," said a Home Office spokes man. "We want to prosecute these top criminals and make them 'touchable'. _ At the moment, there is no real consensus on Rico-style laws, though the police are generally positive. We hope to publish the findings of the consultation later this year."

Last month the home secretary, Jack Straw, unveiled a new law to use civil powers to confiscate ill-gotten fortunes worth £220m. The draft proceeds of crime bill, to be introduced later this year, would set up a criminal assets recovery agency charged with the task of hunting down cash, houses, cars and other wealth accumulated through criminal activity.

webTitle: 'No go for whites' in race hotspot

fields.headline: 'No go for whites' in race hotspot
fields.standfirst:
Community leaders in Oldham dispute police claims over attacks by Asian gangs

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Community leaders in Oldham dispute police claims over attacks by Asian gangs.
fields.byline: Jeevan Vasagar, David Ward, Abigail Etim  and Matt Keating
fields.body:
A rash of attacks by Asian gangs gave rise to claims yesterday that streets in Oldham had become no go zones for whites. The Greater Manchester town has been dubbed Britain's worst racial battleground after police revealed that of 572 racist crimes recorded there last year, 60% of the alleged victims were white.

Schoolboy Wayne Cross was one of the most recent victims. The 16-year-old white teenager was punched and stamped on by a gang of 12 Asian youths, who left him with a broken cheekbone and severe cuts. The attack only stopped when a passing taxi driver came to his rescue, and his family believe he had a lucky escape.

On the Glodwick estate, where the majority of residents are of Pakistani origin, the BBC yesterday claimed whites were being warned to keep out. One Asian youth told Radio 4's Today programme: "There are signs all around saying whites enter at your risk. It's a matter of revenge. It's about giving as good as you can take."

Scepticism

The claims of no go areas were greeted with scepticism yesterday by police and community leaders and also by some young people. But there was evidence of a simmering distrust between the police and young Asian men - of a generation who are both physically stronger and cockier than their immigrant parents.

One youth smoking a carrot-sized joint outside Abdul's takeaway in Glodwick said: "The police are the main cause of it really. When they come to make an arrest here, they will come in force. There is no need for 10 or more of them to turn up in a van at the first sign of trouble."

A local police officer reciprocated the ill-feeling yesterday. Told that Asian locals thought claims of no go zones were empty rumours, Superintendent Dick Crawshaw replied: "You must have spoken to the only 12 people in the area who can read and write."

Asian community leaders hotly dispute the police figures on racial crime. Councillor and magistrate Riaz Ahmed said that Asian people under-reported attacks.

The problems were being caused by hot-headed youths who believed they were standing up for themselves in a way their parents had been too fearful to do. "Young people are saying we don't have to take all the stuff our parents and grandparents did. But I think that violence is the wrong way to do it. It only creates more racism."

Today's vigilantes were children when the National Front marched through Oldham in 1987. "Our parents stayed at home and kept us in all day. They were really afraid," one youth recalled. "But some Asian lads growing up now can be quite rough when provoked by racist groups."

Now the British National Party believes Oldham is fertile ground for votes and recruitment; its leader, Nick Griffin, is standing for one of Oldham West at the general election, and local BNP activist Mick Treacy is standing for Oldham East.

"If you are in the wrong place at the wrong time, you are going to get beaten up," Mr Treacy said. "I have no qualms against Asians or people of any colour. It's a matter of the country losing its identity."

Tensions bubbled over a few weeks ago when a caller to the local paper claimed the National Front was to march again on March 31. In the event, no application to march was received from the NF, which said it did not intend to campaign in the area at the general election."It was a stunt to whip up the town," say police. It worked - 1,000 Asian residents and members of anti-racist groups went ahead with their own demonstration.

That night, according to local sources, there was a fight between BNP supporters and Asian youths. Someone smashed the windows of a local pub, The Trap, where earlier that day a group of mainly white football fans were ejected by the landlord.

'Ignore them'

One resident, a 27-year-old Asian man, told the Guardian he had urged other young men to avoid a confrontation. "We said it hadn't done any good, and that the best thing with the BNP was to ignore them." The council believes Oldham's problems are no different from those in other poor urban areas with a high ethnic minority population. There is a suspicion that the media is only interested because a majority of victims appear to be white.

Ruth Fairhurst, an assistant director responsible for race relations at Oldham council, said: "We do have a particularly young ethnic minority population. Sixty-six per cent of the ethnic minority population are under 24, compared with 34% of the white population. We're talking about inner, urban areas, and three of the areas are among the most disadvantaged in the country."

fields.bodyText: A rash of attacks by Asian gangs gave rise to claims yesterday that streets in Oldham had become no go zones for whites. The Greater Manchester town has been dubbed Britain's worst racial battleground after police revealed that of 572 racist crimes recorded there last year, 60% of the alleged victims were white. Schoolboy Wayne Cross was one of the most recent victims. The 16-year-old white teenager was punched and stamped on by a gang of 12 Asian youths, who left him with a broken cheekbone and severe cuts. The attack only stopped when a passing taxi driver came to his rescue, and his family believe he had a lucky escape. On the Glodwick estate, where the majority of residents are of Pakistani origin, the BBC yesterday claimed whites were being warned to keep out. One Asian youth told Radio 4's Today programme: "There are signs all around saying whites enter at your risk. It's a matter of revenge. It's about giving as good as you can take." Scepticism The claims of no go areas were greeted with scepticism yesterday by police and community leaders and also by some young people. But there was evidence of a simmering distrust between the police and young Asian men - of a generation who are both physically stronger and cockier than their immigrant parents. One youth smoking a carrot-sized joint outside Abdul's takeaway in Glodwick said: "The police are the main cause of it really. When they come to make an arrest here, they will come in force. There is no need for 10 or more of them to turn up in a van at the first sign of trouble." A local police officer reciprocated the ill-feeling yesterday. Told that Asian locals thought claims of no go zones were empty rumours, Superintendent Dick Crawshaw replied: "You must have spoken to the only 12 people in the area who can read and write." Asian community leaders hotly dispute the police figures on racial crime. Councillor and magistrate Riaz Ahmed said that Asian people under-reported attacks. The problems were being caused by hot-headed youths who believed they were standing up for themselves in a way their parents had been too fearful to do. "Young people are saying we don't have to take all the stuff our parents and grandparents did. But I think that violence is the wrong way to do it. It only creates more racism." Today's vigilantes were children when the National Front marched through Oldham in 1987. "Our parents stayed at home and kept us in all day. They were really afraid," one youth recalled. "But some Asian lads growing up now can be quite rough when provoked by racist groups." Now the British National Party believes Oldham is fertile ground for votes and recruitment; its leader, Nick Griffin, is standing for one of Oldham West at the general election, and local BNP activist Mick Treacy is standing for Oldham East. "If you are in the wrong place at the wrong time, you are going to get beaten up," Mr Treacy said. "I have no qualms against Asians or people of any colour. It's a matter of the country losing its identity." Tensions bubbled over a few weeks ago when a caller to the local paper claimed the National Front was to march again on March 31. In the event, no application to march was received from the NF, which said it did not intend to campaign in the area at the general election."It was a stunt to whip up the town," say police. It worked - 1,000 Asian residents and members of anti-racist groups went ahead with their own demonstration. That night, according to local sources, there was a fight between BNP supporters and Asian youths. Someone smashed the windows of a local pub, The Trap, where earlier that day a group of mainly white football fans were ejected by the landlord. 'Ignore them' One resident, a 27-year-old Asian man, told the Guardian he had urged other young men to avoid a confrontation. "We said it hadn't done any good, and that the best thing with the BNP was to ignore them." The council believes Oldham's problems are no different from those in other poor urban areas with a high ethnic minority population. There is a suspicion that the media is only interested because a majority of victims appear to be white. Ruth Fairhurst, an assistant director responsible for race relations at Oldham council, said: "We do have a particularly young ethnic minority population. Sixty-six per cent of the ethnic minority population are under 24, compared with 34% of the white population. We're talking about inner, urban areas, and three of the areas are among the most disadvantaged in the country." The overall unemployment figure in Oldham is 4%. But joblessness runs at 16% among the Pakistani community, and at 25% among the Bangladeshi community. Oldham has its racial faultlines, but they are not set in stone - the taxi driver who rescued Wayne Cross was Asian.

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: the Tories and race

fields.headline: Old-fashioned racism and a Britain that never was
fields.standfirst:
Race is a subterranean river running through Tory party motivations

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The spectacle of the Tories trying not to talk about race is like Basil Fawlty trying not to talk about the war.
fields.body:
The spectacle of the Tories trying not to talk about race is like Basil Fawlty trying not to talk about the war. They can't help it. The harder they try not to mention it, the more they talk about it. Why should party chairman Michael Ancram need to write letters to all his candidates telling them not to? Why does it still keep bursting out all over? There are deep reasons. Race is a subterranean river running through many fundamental Conservative thoughts, feelings and ideals. Decent Tories will deny it, tolerance is their hallmark, they will say. Yet those who instinctively yearn for a better yesterday believe in a golden age when people knew their place under one culture and, by implication, one colour too.

So William Hague struck a profoundly traditional Tory note with his "Let me take you to a foreign land" speech. When John Townend MP accused immigrants of undermining Britain's "homogenous Anglo-Saxon society", it was an authentic Tory cry of anguish. Yesterday, Tory MP Sir Richard Body delivered an embarrassing new book "England for the English" right into the eye of the storm, arguing that multiculturalism is a threat to England's future. This is not just a reprise of crude Powellite race and miscenegation fears. It is not exactly race-hate. It is that old war cry for an England always in danger, always lost because it never was. Sir Richard's vision of English culture melds with his presidency of the Wodehouse Society and breeder of Gloucester Old Spots - the Empress of Blandings. His is an old English fantasy world, an imaginary heritage destroyed by modernism and outsiders.

The Conservative party's racism resides not in their MPs' usually careful public words, nor in the maverick MPs who still blurt it out or print nasty leaflets at elections. It runs deeper, an old-fashioned racism ingrained in the aged sinews of that decaying party. Only visit the bar of Conservative clubs up and down the land to hear the unthinking racial suppositions so long banned from broadcasting and public discourse that it might wrongly be thought extinct. That casual, instinctive racism is a 1950s flashback, so uncool in an Ali G world where all the hip kids talk Brixton. But there it still is, perched on the bar stools at gatherings of small businessmen, poured out of silver pots at coffee mornings of Conservative Associations, the mind-set of that rump 30% that will be forever Tory. Maybe its cruder emanations are dying out in this party whose average age is 65 - yet you can still hear it in different tones among public school pupils as well as among the England football fans.

At first William Hague set his mind against all such stuff in favour of modernism - that awkward coconut at the Notting Hill carnival was his better impulse. It only made his later return to party roots the more disappointing, but drowning politicians clutch at anything. However the reason runs deeper than that. Conservative core beliefs are rooted in an idea of Britishness or Englishness, that has race as a permanent leitmotif. The things Tories exist to conserve are a nationalist culture and history that declares Britain was and is always best. Such nationalism leads inevitably to spurious notions of ancient racial superiority, the Bull Dog Breed and all that. The anti-Europeanism which is the Tories' most sincere and passionate cause has old conservative racist origins.

Yesterday, in a blistering speech, Robin Cook hit back at this poisoned view of British identity, rubbishing the "myths of our island race" as a "pitiful misreading of British history". The British, he said, are not a race but a gathering of countless races, most not indigenous to these islands. It was a well-written attack on a false British identity and a false vision of the future. His words chimed with the work of modern historians, Norman Davies' "The Isles" in particular, which dispels the Victorian and Edwardian fantasy history those over the age of 40 were reared on. History teaching was imbued with ideas of ancient racial superiority which offered a moral justification for the empire. Our Island Story and such nursery histories were stirring polemics, propaganda to shape a national identity out of an artificial racial notions. Just as the code word "cosmopolitan" used to cloak Tory fear of Jews, now "multicultural" represents to them the double threat of black and European influence. Foreigners have always been the enemy.

Springing to William Hague's defence yesterday, Andrew Lansley, shadow cabinet office minister, said: "When William was talking about the threat to Britishness and the sense of a foreign land, he wasn't talking about race, he wasn't talking about immigration or asylum. He was talking about policy in relation to Europe." And that is partly true: he was doing both. For the two are inextricably intertwined - a perpetual war to conserve the nation against outsiders.

The coming referendum will be awash with fantasies about national identity - a modern versus an old vision of Britishness, a racial versus a multicultural view of identity. Two ideologies about who we are and where we are going will fight to the death. The pro-Europeans will shudder with horror at living isolated in a British nationalist, little Englander future. With equal repugnance, the Europhobes fear a multicultural pot melting down everything of value - Shakespeare, the bible, PG Wodehouse - in exchange for globalised pap, pan-European homogeneity stamping out our individuality. To them a European future does threaten the end of history as they always dreamt it.

A few months ago the Runnymede Trust was ridiculed for a long and thoughtful report which dared to suggest that the very word British had racial connotations. Interestingly this same report also said - though it was barely reported in the furore - that Britain has the best race relations in Europe and Gurbux Singh of the Commission for Racial Equality agrees. Neo-nazis are not a significant force here. Quarter of a century of race relations laws have had a remarkably good effect. Thre is much still to do: Asians are still 16 times more likely to be victims of racial violence, Afro-Caribbeans and Asians are still three times more likely to be unemployed. But race is largely a no-go area in politics. Straw's unpleasant references to "bogus" asylum seekers and Hague's "foreign land" are small beer beside the rise of neo-nazis elsewhere - even in Sweden.

This curious spasm of soul-searching about national identity needs to be laid to rest as soon as possible with the Euro-referendum. Defining national identity is a futile endeavour. Modern citizens have onion-like multiple identities, peeling back myriad skins depending on circumstance. The essence of conservatism is an instinct to tie things down, make borders, live within boundaries. Progressives have always been the far horizon internationalists.

fields.headline: Shortlists, Sponsors, and Supporters
fields.trailText: THEY'VE ALL VOTE-TED
fields.body:
THEY'VE ALL VOTE-TED

Voting to decide who has won the Football Writers' Association's footballer of the year award is a lengthy process. Forms are dispatched in the middle of the season and, with the efficiency you'd expect from top journalists, are immediately completed and sent back. After a couple of months, a crack team of sub-editors will have deciphered the drunken, illegible ramblings and shaped them into something presentable to the public. Sadly, this process doesn't seem to have worked properly this year, because it appears Teddy Sheringham has come out as the winner.

To be fair, you may vaguely remember Sheringham doing a couple of good things at the start of the season, so you can't say he's not earned it! "It's an honour to receive this award bearing in mind the illustrious names who have won it in previous years," he smiled this morning with reference to past greats like Stanley Matthews and, erm, thingummy. "Although I'm very down and disappointed at the moment after going out of Europe on Wednesday night, this is a very special personal highlight in my career," he continued, his grin slipping into a full-on grimace.

But, completely knackering the impact of the aforementioned award, the Professional Footballers' Association then got in on the back-slapping act by announcing the shortlist for their very own gong. The six players who could become player of the year are: Sheringham, Roy Keane, Ryan Giggs, Thierry Henry, Emile Heskey, Marcus Stewart, Not David Beckham and Not Patrick Vieira. Meanwhile, the kiddie version will be contested by Heskey, Wes Brown, Michael Carrick, Joe Cole, Steve "Steven" Gerrard and Alan Smith. Whoever gets that wins a date with a cast member of Hollyoaks.

LOOKING AFTER FOOTBALL COMES SO EASI-LEE

Who said Uefa are a bunch of out-of-touch bureaucrats with a penchant for pi$$ing the good of football up a large wall marked "big business"? Not the Fiver, that's for sure. And it's not because we're writing this from our Uefa-sponsored chateau in the Swiss Alps while young Heidi massages a carefully selected choice of essential oils, diluted in a Sandalwood base, all over our stress-free bodies. Oh no. It's all because European football's rulers are - cue gasps of amazement - out doing their bit for the good of the game!

Today, Uefa spokesman Mike Lee followed up yesterday's announcement that the bloated Big Cup might go on the footballing equivalent of the Geri Halliwell diet by revealing not one but three initiatives. First off, Comrade Lee appealed to the common man by urging Europe's top clubs to consider a salary cap. "There's a need for a debate with European football and Uefa has indicated a willingness to start and sponsor that debate," he said, shaking a wad of Euros at bemused bystanders. And though he didn't commit Uefa to a formal policy, Mike did warn: "Unless we are alive and alert to these issues then inevitably the bubble will burst. The consequences of that could be severe, not necessarily for the top clubs but for many other parts of the professional game."

With the issue of salary caps out of the way, Mike moved on to initiative two: revamping Euro Vase. "[Euro Vase] needs a separate look," he twittered. "We can see the merit of reform." Which sounds good, but Uefa's plan unfortunately seems to be to create the bastard child of Big Cup. "There is a certain amount of pressure for a league format which we think has some merit to it," he admitted, sending the Fiver into a Euro-Vase-Key-Group-Stage-34 depression. "How you do that and how many group stages you have, if you have group stages, are all open questions. But within Uefa this review and consultation process is a genuine one."

At this point the Fiver slumped into a management-baloney-speak-induced coma. When we woke up, Lee was still busy, announcing Uefa's intention to chase up the £8m they claim sports marketing firm ISL Worldwide owes them. "They owe us money and we would like that back, thank you very much!" Lee grunted. Are there any limits to this man's determination?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"You need a proven goalscorer at international level. We had one with Alan Shearer and Michael Owen is the natural man to step into his shoes. Michael is more than a natural finisher, he has also got an eye for creating goals. Apart from being a natural scorer he has the ability to play with his head up and see who is in the right position and create for others" - Glenn "Michael Owen is not a natural finisher" Hoddle puts the "backtrack" in "complete backtrack".

BANNED STAND

Yay! It's Friday afternoon! So, to get you in the party mood, let's have a fun chat with everybody's favourite administrator, councillor Barry Brotherton of the Trafford Metropolitan Borough Council. You will of course remember him as the pen-pushing jobsworth who threatened to close down parts of Old Trafford unless everyone sat down and shut their faces - although the Fiver couldn't recall him at all and had to ask around before we remembered who he was.

Bazzer has decided that now United have clanked hilariously out of Big Cup, there's no need to enforce restrictions at either of United's two Premiership games against Manchester City and erm, sorry, we can't be bothered to consult the fixture list. Instead, he's going to sit down with United over the summer and try to sort something out, although still with a view to turfing out recalcitrant supporters. Or to put it another way, working out a way to punish people who are enjoying themselves.

"We want more specific ticketing arrangements so that even for European matches the club can identify any fans who stand persistently," he announced, in a dramatic fashion that reminded the Fiver of great orators like Nye Bevan, Martin Luther King and Benito Mussolini. "We are also going to have a more thorough risk assessment of the risk of standing in various parts of the ground. We will also be taking legal advice about what are our legal responsibilities," he promised. Why he's going to all this trouble nobody knows. As Roy Keane pointed out the other day, the good times at Old Trafford are officially over - so who's going to become excited enough to get up off their buns?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Frederic Kanoute has denied stories suggesting he is about to sign for Juventus in a £12m deal. "People around me talk about my departure - but not me," said Kanoute. "It's often in the media and everything like that, but I've never spoken to anyone about leaving West Ham, so that's it."

A list of all the players Manchester United are supposedly interested in: Ruud van Nistelrooy, Rivaldo, Gaizka Mendieta, Lilian Thuram, Kieron Dyer, Emmanuel Petit, Atlanta midfielder Christian Doni, Pavel Nedved and Boca Juniors midfielder Juan Roman Riquelme.

Ipswich want Chelsea striker Eidur Gudjohnsen if they qualify for Europe.

Middlesbrough are preparing a £2.4m bid for Rangers defender Lorenzo Amoruso.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Hundreds of fans packed Glasgow Cathedral today to witness the funeral of Jim Baxter, who died of liver cancer last weekend.

Manchester United have agreed a coaching link-up with Norwegian side Oslo East. Under the terms of the three-year deal, Oslo East will scout for United in Norway.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5.30pm)

Sideshow Bob Wilson listens to the monotone drawl of the voiceover man and shakes his head sadly. "I used to sound like that all the time when I was a contender."

Sky Sports 3: Hold The Back Page (11pm)

Still, at least he doesn't have as ridiculous a hairstyle as Wooly Woolnough, he thought, before running his hand through his wiry thatch and heel-clicking off down the street.

fields.headline: Who are Westminster's Top 10 groovers?
fields.trailText: Hippest MPs singled out by club magazine Mixmag
fields.body:
Think of DJs, environmental protestors and pot smokers and the House of Commons is probably not the setting that springs to mind. Nor would one expect members to concern themselves with Mixmag, the dance music and clubbing magazine, which has just published a top ten list of Westminster's leading movers and groovers.

Mo Mowlam, Tony Banks and Conservative party chief executive, David "Rizla" Prior are included in the list, which also recognises politicians for their interest in issues relating to the club scene such as soft-drug use, environmental issues, or simply for being a bit of a live wire.

While clubs such as Fabric or Cream are more naturally the venue for younger professionals, former club-scene regulars such as Labour backbencher and erstwhile DJ Oona King have, unusually, been rewarded for their outside interests. Miss King was also involved in promoting a Brussels club during her time as assistant to MEP Glenys Kinnock in the early 1990s.

Shaun Collins, Green party candidate for Vauxhall, runs in at number three following his involvement in the Clapham Common cannabis carnival. Collins became something of a dance culture martyr after a court appearance in December 1999, when he was charged with permitting dancing and amplified music during the May Day carnival.

Further down the list, Tony Banks is included for his repeated calls for the decriminalisation of cannabis and campaigns for animal welfare. Labour MP for Tottenham David Lammy is the youngest entrant at 28 and appears to have done his yoof credibility no harm with an appearance on Tim Westwood s Radio 1 show.

Fox hunting opponent and Liberal Democrat environmentalist Simon Hughes is also included, though his activities during the 1970s when he followed rock band Iron Maiden around the UK were no doubt appreciated rather less. Labour s Dr Phyllis Starkey, whose Door Supervisors Bill required nightclub bouncers to enter into a national register, comes in at number six.

Mo Mowlam is congratulated as the first senior politician to come clean about her use of cannabis in the past, as did Conservative Party Chief Executive David Prior who, according to Mixmag, never lets his party s politics get in the way of a good time. Mr Prior, MP for North Norfolk gained cult fame for his remark that: you can wear a pinstripe suit and be utterly conventional and still roll a joint and yes I did inhale.

Despite his low profile, 60 year-old Dr Brian Iddon (Labour, Bolton South East) won the nomination for his contribution to the campaign to legalise cannabis and attacks on the practice of nightclubs which turn off tap water in toilets, forcing clubbers to buy bottled water instead.

"I don't suppose it will swing any votes in Bolton South East but I am honoured", he said.

fields.headline: Will Milosevic escape justice?
fields.standfirst: Ian Traynor  reports on how the former Yugoslavian president has distanced himself from war crimes
fields.trailText: While Slobodan Milosevic adjusts to life in a Belgrade jail cell, he may reflect on how his old peer and partner in crime, Franjo Tudjman, the late president of Croatia, would also have been indicted for war crimes had his death in December 1999 not ushered in a new era of promise and democracy in Zagreb.
fields.body:
While Slobodan Milosevic adjusts to life in a Belgrade jail cell, he may reflect on how his old peer and partner in crime, Franjo Tudjman, the late president of Croatia, would also have been indicted for war crimes had his death in December 1999 not ushered in a new era of promise and democracy in Zagreb.

Carla del Ponte, the chief prosecutor at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, said this week that Tudjman, too, would have faced charges, probably arising from Zagreb's 1995 blitzkrieg campaign against the Serbs that won the war in Croatia and also resulting in the flight of scores of thousands of Serbs from their ancestral lands in Croatia.

While both Serbian and Croatian leaders plotted the partition of Bosnia between them and drank whisky together as the forces under their control battled one another, the contrast between the two alleged war criminals is significant.

Tudjman was an old-fashioned nationalist bigot, Milosevic a ruthless cynic who merely exploited nationalism and war to entrench himself in power for 13 years till he got his comeuppance last October and was finally arrested at the beginning of the month.

The hunt for the evidence against the two Balkan strongmen provides graphic confirmation of their fears and phobias and of their confidence.

One joke going the rounds in Belgrade has it that there is not even a copy of the Dayton agreement with Milosevic's signature on it to be found in the Serbian capital. The US-brokered agreement, signed in France in 1996, ended the Bosnia war. Milosevic, Tudjman, and Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia, ceremonially signed off on it before the television cameras.

The anecdote illustrates the lengths to which Milosevic went to avoid leaving behind any incriminating evidence, in the sure knowledge that he could be arrested and convicted either by a domestic or an international court. Serbian investigators and magistrates building the case against the imprisoned Milosevic are struggling to find any smoking guns or fingerprints.

Documentation bearing the leader's autograph is frustratingly elusive. The investigators are hoping that close aides, some of them also in jail, will eventually cave in and turn compelling testimony against Milosevic.

Things could not be different in Zagreb where the new government of Prime Minister Ivica Racan and President Stipe Mesic was astounded to find on entering office last year that Tudjman's legacy included a treasure trove of documents and recordings detailing every move the president made through the 1990s.

A locked room at the presidential palace in Zagreb contained a wealth of damning material relating to the Tudjman regime's dirty tricks, embezzlement, profiteering, and political negotiations.

Tudjman was so blissfully convinced of his own place in history, of his untouchability, and of his position as perpetual president that he clandestinely had almost every conversation in his office recorded from 1991 to 1999.

The locked room gave up some 14,000 transcripts and more than 800 cassettes, a veritable A-Z of the Tudjman years in power. The post-Tudjman authorities have been sifting through the material since coming to power in February last year and occasionally leaking juicy morsels to the press as and when it suits them.

Serbian investigators are extremely unlikely to be made such a gift in their pursuit of Milosevic.

The contrasts between Belgrade and Zagreb extend to the successors to the two warmongers. In Belgrade President Vojislav Kostunica is one of the few politicians in Serbia who had nothing, absolutely nothing, to do with Milosevic throughout the latter's 13-year rule. President Stipe Mesic in Zagreb, meanwhile, was Tudjman's tennis partner, close aide, and member of the regime party, the HDZ. But he broke with Tudjman over major policy issues, including Bosnia, and became a trenchant critic and popular rallying point for the opposition. Tudjman won his war against the Serbs, but barely a week goes by that President Mesic does not issue further withering criticism of the old regime and its cronies, its disastrous policies, and its legacy.

Mr Kostunica, on the other hand, may be clean and suffer from an acute allergy to Milosevic. But he also finds himself in the curious position of being a virtual apologist for some of the most unsavoury policies of the old regime.

He refuses to accept the legitimacy of the tribunal in The Hague. He supports the Bosnian Serbs and keeps paying the salaries of the Bosnian Serb military. He was furious when an indicted Serb war criminal was extradited to The Netherlands. He appears to have opposed arresting Milosevic.

fields.headline: Natural Environment Research Council
fields.trailText:
Funding body
Natural Environment Research Council (NERC)

Funding body

People to know

Chief Executive and Deputy Chairman: Professor John Lawton CBE FRS
Professor John Beddington - T H Huxley School of Environment, Earth Sciences and Engineering Imperial College

Chairman - Mr Richard Hardman CBE

NERC Chief Executive: Professor John Lawton CBE FRS

Aims
The Natural Environment Research Council was established by Royal Charter in 1965. It aims "to foster knowledge, understanding and prediction of the environment and its resources". The council aims to: support high quality research and technology and maintain long-term capability to understand and predict the environment, natural resources and their response to change; foster the health and vitality of the UK environmental skills base through education,training and career development . It collects, manages and supplies environmental data and provides information to meet the needs of users and aims to provide objective, independent expert scientific advice and information to underpin national and international policy and sustainable development. It provides specialist scientific facilities and services to meet the needs of UK environmental sciences and works in partnership with users and other science suppliers to promote the effective transfer of knowledge. It also encourages public understanding of environmental issues and the role of science.

Background of the Science and Technology Board
The introduction of the single Science and Technology Board (STB) has the following objectives:
 To promote much stronger multi- and inter-disciplinary earth system science within the NERC community, while retaining core activities.
 To involve NERC centres and surveys more closely in the development of NERC science strategy.
 To simplify and streamline the decision making processes, reducing the number of formal meetings and the number of small thematic programmes.
 To extend and enhance involvement of all sectors of the NERC constituency in the development of policy and provision of advice on science strategy. Greater involvement of younger scientists will be a key component.
 To clarify and simplify the reporting and assessment processes involved in the evaluation of existing science programmes.

The new board will be under the supervision of the Director of Science Programmes via the new Board Secretariat that will also be responsible for both cross research council and cross disciplinary interests, such as climate change and polar issues.

The heads of the four Science Teams are key figures in the new structure. They will continue to have management responsibilities but will put far greater emphasis on consultation and communication with the research community, government departments and agencies, industry, other users, and NGOs. Engagement will take many forms, ranging from the simple flow and exchange of information to involvement in time-limited task-focussed groups.

Budget breakdown
The breakdown of the NERC budget for 1999/00 was as follows:

Science budget income: Current expenditure £169.6m
Capital expenditure £16.7m
External funding for research £32.5m
Other income £11.9m
Total income £230.7m

In terms of people, NERC directly employs 2,608 staff across the UK in its research centres and in its Swindon headquarters. In 1999/00, 775 staff in higher education institutes were employed on NERC research grants. NERC also supported 68 research fellows, 1,058 PhD students and 334 Masters* students.

NERC's science budget can be classified in two different ways:

In terms of environmental and natural resource issues:

Issue % science budget
Biodiversity 13%
Environmental risks and hazards 10%
Global change 28%
Natural resources 32%
Pollution amd waste 16%

By scientific area:

Science area % science budget
Atmospheric 4%
Earth 20%
Marine 26%
Terrestrial and freshwater 17%
Polar 26%
Earth observation 7%

Their science budget is allocated through four different funding modes:

Thematic mode funding: Supports research in selected areas identified by NERC strategic planning and is 13% of the science budget.
Non-thematic mode funding: Supports curiosity driven research in areas identified by applicant and is 22% of the budget.
Core strategic funding: Supports strategic research of national importance and is 25% of the budget.
Infrastructure funding: Supports equipment, services and facilities for the NERC community, and is 39% of the total science budget.

Success rate
In 1999/00, success rate (by number) in the non-thematic mode was 22% and in the thematic mode, success rate (by number) was 33%.

The NERC supports basic research in all relevant disciplines, yet focuses directed research on areas where UK strengths and scientific opportunities coincide with priority environmental issues.

The NERC works with other organisations including:
 The International Geosphere- Biosphere Programme
 The World Climate Research Programme
 The International Human Dimensions Programme
 The European Space Agency and the Ocean Drilling Programme.

They are also actively involved in the European Union's Framework Programmes.

Top ten beneficiaries
The top ten university beneficiaries of NERC support in 1999/00 were:
 Southampton University
 Cambridge University
 Imperial College
 Reading University
 Oxford University
 Edinburgh University
 Bristol University
 Leeds University
 Sheffield University
 University College London

Future issues and priorities
Following the government's 2000 spending review, NERC will continue to support basic research in the environmental sciences and, in addition, will address certain priority areas including:
 Research using genomics to improve our understanding of ecology and evolution.
 Research in the area of "e-science". For example, the complexities of Earth's system mean that highly sophisticated computer models are needed to draw together the vast amounts of information on all aspects of the oceans, land, ice and the atmosphere.
 NERC will take the lead across all the research councils in developing a research agenda in the area of technology for sustainability and energy.
 NERC will launch a programme to study the behaviour of the coupled ocean - the atmosphere system of the north Atlantic - a system which keeps the UK 5-10 degrees warmer than would be expected for a country this far north.

Funding: London - 8,570, elsewhere- 6,800. Research students entering their third final year receive an enhancement of their maintenance award of £500 pa. CASE students receive an additional allowance of £350pa.
Success rate: 303 awarded.

CASE students receive an additional allowance of £350pa. Research students entering their third (final) year receive an enhancement of their maintenance award of £500 pa.

NERC also pays Mature Students Incentive, Young Dependants' Allowance and Disability Allowance.

Funding opportunities
The NERC sponsor and carry out research through four different funding modes that achieve different objectives.

Core Strategic funding, typically long-term, maintains expertise and knowledge in key areas of the environmental sciences, determined by the council. It supports relevant research, survey and monitoring, technology development, and the curation, interpretation and supply of environmental data. It meets current needs and forms a basis for meeting future priorities.

Thematic funding contributes to development through basic, strategic and applied science, technology development and training, within selected themes. The council's strategic planning identifies these themes.

Non-thematic funding supports curiosity-driven research, training and technology development in areas selected by applicants.

Infrastructure funding provides support, equipment, services and facilities to the NERC community.

More information on specific NERC Core Strategic and Infrastructure activities can be found on request from the NERC Planning and Communications Directorate: tel (01793) 411750, email: requests@nerc.ac.uk.

BNSC Earth Observation LINK
This LINK Programme supports innovative, pre-competitive research into applications of Earth observation data and derived information carried out by partnerships of academia and industry. Outline bids are now being invited.

Clouds, Water Vapour and Climate
The overall aim of the thematic programme is to improve our understanding of the physical processes responsible for the distribution of humidity and clouds, and of their influences on climate.

European Space Agency Announcements of Opportunity
"Concept for Future Visible and Infrared Imager"
"Future Earth Observation Missions: Atmospheric Chemistry 2) Consideration of a mission studying the chemistry of the upper troposhere and lower stratosphere"
"Down-linking data flow architecture for future EO missions"
"Experimental assessment of SAR/interferometric altimeter concept"

BNSC Customer Partnership Projects
The main objective of these projects is to increase the growth of the satellite value added market by establishing the operational use of EO and other satellite derived information by institutional and commercial concerns. A complimentary objective is to create "intelligent customers" for satellite based information.

Polar Science
All enquiries relating to Polar Science should be directed to:
Mrs Angela Morrison
Polar Science / Science Programmes Directorate
NERC
Polaris House
North Star Avenue
Swindon, Wilts SN2 1EU
Email: a.j.morrison@nerc.ac.uk, tel. (01793) 411794, fax. (01793) 411502.

Environmental Factors in the Chronology of Human Evolution and Dispersal (EFCHED) A concept note proposing a new thematic programme to investigate whether climate and environmental change over the last five million years were important factors in driving human evolution and dispersal. It is suggested that the proposed programme would promote cross-disciplinary interaction and build on recent investment in radiocarbon and ancient DNA laboratory facilities.

The Infrastructure Fund
Purpose: Seeks to transform the scientific research environment within UK universities. It covers:
 Life Sciences covered by the remits of NERC, the Wellcome Trust, BBSRC and MRC.
 Physical, Engineering and Social Sciences covered by the remits of NERC, EPSRC, ESRC and PPARC, and covers all elements of research infrastructure.
 The whole spectrum of research equipment and infrastructural research facilities.
 New scientific research buildings.
 Refurbishment of laboratory and research related space.
Funding: £700m available
Deadline: All applications must be submitted to NERC to be pre-registered no later than two weeks prior to any closing date. Check site for dates as they arise.

New Investigators' Competition
Purpose: Applicants must be at the outset of their scientific career and within three years of first becoming eligible for NERC funding as a Principal Investigator.
Funding: The maximum funding available has been increased to £50,000.
Deadline: Closing date: 1 February

Standard Research Grants
Purpose: An open competition for curiosity-motivated basic, strategic or applied research . The primary criterion for assessment is scientific excellence with all applications subjected to external peer review.
Funding: In excess of £35,000. Now includes the opportunity for applicants to seek support for longer than the usual three year period.
Deadline: Closing dates: 1 July; 1 December

Research Grant Schemes
The 2000/1 editions of the Grants Handbook and application form are now available on the NERC website appplication forms.

Small grants
There are now only two small grants round per year, with closing dates 1 October and 1 June.

Consortium grants
Purpose: To support focussed, coordinated, collaborative research into issues that cannot be addressed through standard non-thematic or small thematic modes.
Funding: To promote flexibility and collaboration, consortium grants will blur the boundaries between existing NERC funding modes and will reduce the number of small thematic programmes managed by NERC.
Deadline: Closing dates: 1 July; 1 December.

CONNECT Scheme
Purpose: To initiate new interactions between the science base (universities, NERC Centre/Surveys and NERC approved academic analogues) and industry, business, commerce or public sector bodies. CONNECT intends to provide opportunities not covered by other schemes such as ROPA or LINK.

CONNECT A
Of particular interest under CONNECT A are "proof of concept" proposals for research which has potential application but may have a high degree of technical risk and perhaps lack a clearly defined end user.
Funding: A maximum of £5,000 can be sought on specific applications forms available from Awards and Training.
Deadline: There are no specific closing dates and all completed applications must be sent to the NERC Awards and Training Section.

CONNECT B
Funding: A prerequisite for all applications under Scheme B is agreement and commitment from the collaborating body to fund at least 50% of the total project costs. Applications are subject to external peer review. Priority for funding will be given to new partnerships in preference to those that can be supported through other funding schemes. Deadline: Closing dates: 1 July; 1 December.

Joint MRC/NERC Scheme: Environment and Health
This joint Medical Research Council and NERC scheme supports research in the relationship between human health and the environment. Bids must be submitted jointly by environmental and medical scientists.

Realising Our Potential Awards (ROPA)
Purpose: To provide opportunity for curiosity-motivated research to applicants who already have a record of securing funds for generic research from bona fide industry, business or commerce.
Deadline: Calls for proposals, criteria and notes for guidance usually appear in January each year. Applications are submitted in September to the NERC. Prospective applicants are advised to contact Awards & Training or email here for further details and application forms.

The NERC Research Fellowship scheme
Purpose: To support a small number of outstanding environmental scientists to establish and develop a research career. There are three fellowship levels: postdoctoral, advanced and senior, each appropriate for different stages of a scientific career.
Deadline: The closing date for applications is 30 September and applicants must be able to demonstrate the support of their proposed host institution.

Studentships
Purpose: The majority are for carrying out research and training in a three-year programme leading to a PhD. The others hold one-year studentships which support them while they study for an MSc or MRes degree.
Funding: NERC only funds students through university departments. If you are intending to apply for a NERC studentship you must contact the department where you want to study.
Success rate: NERC funds nearly 1,100 postgraduate students each year.

MRC/NERC Environment and Health

It aims "to foster knowledge, understanding and prediction of the environment and its resources". The council aims to: support high quality research and technology and maintain long-term capability to understand and predict the environment, natural resources and their response to change; foster the health and vitality of the UK environmental skills base through education,training and career development . It collects, manages and supplies environmental data and provides information to meet the needs of users and aims to provide objective, independent expert scientific advice and information to underpin national and international policy and sustainable development. It provides specialist scientific facilities and services to meet the needs of UK environmental sciences and works in partnership with users and other science suppliers to promote the effective transfer of knowledge. It also encourages public understanding of environmental issues and the role of science. Background of the Science and Technology Board The introduction of the single Science and Technology Board (STB) has the following objectives:  To promote much stronger multi- and inter-disciplinary earth system science within the NERC community, while retaining core activities.  To involve NERC centres and surveys more closely in the development of NERC science strategy.  To simplify and streamline the decision making processes, reducing the number of formal meetings and the number of small thematic programmes.  To extend and enhance involvement of all sectors of the NERC constituency in the development of policy and provision of advice on science strategy. Greater involvement of younger scientists will be a key component.  To clarify and simplify the reporting and assessment processes involved in the evaluation of existing science programmes. The new board will be under the supervision of the Director of Science Programmes via the new Board Secretariat that will also be responsible for both cross research council and cross disciplinary interests, such as climate change and polar issues. The heads of the four Science Teams are key figures in the new structure. They will continue to have management responsibilities but will put far greater emphasis on consultation and communication with the research community, government departments and agencies, industry, other users, and NGOs. Engagement will take many forms, ranging from the simple flow and exchange of information to involvement in time-limited task-focussed groups. Budget breakdown The breakdown of the NERC budget for 1999/00 was as follows: Science budget income: Current expenditure £169.6m Capital expenditure £16.7m External funding for research £32.5m Other income £11.9m Total income £230.7m In terms of people, NERC directly employs 2,608 staff across the UK in its research centres and in its Swindon headquarters. In 1999/00, 775 staff in higher education institutes were employed on NERC research grants. NERC also supported 68 research fellows, 1,058 PhD students and 334 Masters* students. NERC's science budget can be classified in two different ways: In terms of environmental and natural resource issues: Issue % science budget Biodiversity 13% Environmental risks and hazards 10% Global change 28% Natural resources 32% Pollution amd waste 16% By scientific area: Science area % science budget Atmospheric 4% Earth 20% Marine 26% Terrestrial and freshwater 17% Polar 26% Earth observation 7% Their science budget is allocated through four different funding modes: Thematic mode funding: Supports research in selected areas identified by NERC strategic planning and is 13% of the science budget. Non-thematic mode funding: Supports curiosity driven research in areas identified by applicant and is 22% of the budget. Core strategic funding: Supports strategic research of national importance and is 25% of the budget. Infrastructure funding: Supports equipment, services and facilities for the NERC community, and is 39% of the total science budget. Success rate In 1999/00, success rate (by number) in the non-thematic mode was 22% and in the thematic mode, success rate (by number) was 33%. The NERC supports basic research in all relevant disciplines, yet focuses directed research on areas where UK strengths and scientific opportunities coincide with priority environmental issues. The NERC works with other organisations including:  The International Geosphere- Biosphere Programme  The World Climate Research Programme  The International Human Dimensions Programme  The European Space Agency and the Ocean Drilling Programme. They are also actively involved in the European Union's Framework Programmes. Top ten beneficiaries The top ten university beneficiaries of NERC support in 1999/00 were:  Southampton University  Cambridge University  Imperial College  Reading University  Oxford University  Edinburgh University  Bristol University  Leeds University  Sheffield University  University College London Future issues and priorities Following the government's 2000 spending review, NERC will continue to support basic research in the environmental sciences and, in addition, will address certain priority areas including:  Research using genomics to improve our understanding of ecology and evolution.  Research in the area of "e-science". For example, the complexities of Earth's system mean that highly sophisticated computer models are needed to draw together the vast amounts of information on all aspects of the oceans, land, ice and the atmosphere.  NERC will take the lead across all the research councils in developing a research agenda in the area of technology for sustainability and energy.  NERC will launch a programme to study the behaviour of the coupled ocean - the atmosphere system of the north Atlantic - a system which keeps the UK 5-10 degrees warmer than would be expected for a country this far north. fields.headline: Channel 4 takes away Right to Reply
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: Channel 4 has axed its pioneering feedback show, Right to Reply, after 18 years, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has axed its pioneering feedback show, Right to Reply, after 18 years.

Staff were told today that the long-running viewer feedback programme would not return as planned for a new series in September.

Right to Reply has been running since Channel 4 was first set up in 1982.

"The feeling is that in today's multimedia world viewers have far more interactivity that they ever used to," said a Channel 4 spokesman.

"Public access has always been a tradition on Channel 4 and that will continue on our website."

The Friday evening slot will instead be used for factual and current affairs programming.

Channel 4 said there would be no redundancies and Roger Bolton, Right to Reply's long-serving presenter, will continue to work on other projects.

Right to Reply marked out Channel 4 as the only UK broadcaster to be truly answerable to the public by giving viewers the opportunity to question and criticise programme-makers.

fields.headline: Ericsson should follow Nokia's lead
fields.standfirst:
The company must match its arch rival product for product to avoid further loss of market share, says deputy financial editor Mark Milner

20.04.2001: Ericsson axes 12,000 jobs
fields.trailText: The company must match its arch rival product for product to avoid further loss of market share, says deputy financial editor Mark Milner.
fields.body:
Ericsson is in trouble. Not only is it suffering, it is suffering in comparison to arch rival Nokia.

It is one thing for the Swedish group Ericsson to produce poor figures, massive job cuts and a gloomy outlook. Much of the telecoms equipment industry is struggling - hit by the general economic slowdown in the US and a more cautious approach to spending from a customer base where balance sheets are under pressure.

To produce such a package, however, on the same day that Nokia, based in Finland, bounces in with a good operating performance and positive projections for the immediate future, is quite another.

This is more than a question of the traditional Swedish/Finnish rivalry that extends well beyond the telecommunications sector. As Ericsson struggles to cope with sales in mobile phone handsets that have failed to come up to expectations, for example, Nokia is not just growing in line with the market, it is expanding its share of the cake, too.

Yesterday Nokia said it was already up to 32% of the world market for mobile handsets and, with its closest rivals Motorola and Ericsson struggling, its target of 40% is looking realistic.

That means Ericsson will have to do more than simply cut costs. It is not just a question of matching production to cope with slower than expected growth. It has to be able to match Nokia product for product if it is to avoid seeing the latter bite deeply into its market share.

Already Nokia is streets ahead of Ericsson's 10% share of the handset market. The current suggestion that Ericsson and Sony are forming an alliance between their mobile phone businesses, while helpful, is unlikely to mark a decisive shift in the balance of power.

Nevertheless it is possible to get too depressed - unless you are one of the thousands of Ericsson workers worldwide whose jobs are about to disappear. Yes, demand is not what most in the industry had hoped, nay expected.

Telecoms operators are, arguably, rolling out the new, third generation, mobile networks more slowly than initially expected - in part as results of the costs of the network costs themselves and the licences to run them. But build and operate them they will.

The challenge for Ericsson is to have set its house in order to be ready when the market shakes off its current bout of the blues.

Mark.Milner@theguardian.com
