fields.headline: The cream curdles
fields.standfirst: You have your say on the declining empires of Manchester United and Arsenal
fields.trailText: You have your say on the declining empires of Manchester United and Arsenal.
fields.body:
They're crap, you know, Manchester United. The so-called champions. You always knew they were, and now they're out of the European Cup, even Roy Keane has admitted it.

FMac has all you need to know about the Bayern games. "Put bluntly," he writes, "Bayern simply outclassed their opponents over both legs. It wasn't a case of Man U not playing up to standards ... they are just simply not good enough to dominate Europe."

There are shortcomings in every department (even if you seem to think that Alex Ferguson has finally solved his goalkeeping problem) but the solution according to FMac is obvious: "BUY PLAYERS!"

FMac highlights Andy Cole's deficiencies ("At the Euro level the lad looks out of his depth he just is not clinical enough") and Wes Brown and Mikael Silvestre's rawness. But MW of Cheshire knows where the true problem lies: "They've only got one midfielder who knows how to tackle and cover properly - Roy Keane."

This is, of course, a particular problem in European competition, where midfields tend to be more heavily populated. In most of their Champions League games this season, United have had only Keane and Paul Scholes in central midfield. In Munich, Ferguson brought in Nicky Butt, but the strength of the Jeremies-Effenberg-Scholl triumvirate proved conclusive.

"Both Bayern's goals were due to Paul Scholes's inability to track back and help his defence," MW claims. "And David Beckham is no better - remember last year's tie against Real Madrid? How would signing Rivaldo solve this fundamental weakness?

"As for United's defence, if Coventry's Craig Bellamy and John Hartson can rip them apart, what hope do they have against the best in Europe? In fact Man Utd's whole team seems lacking in height, power and athleticism - which is especially noticeable in European games!

"When Real Madrid won last year's Champions League they immediately went out and bought Luis Figo. Similarly, Martin Edwards should have provided the funds to strengthen Fergie's team after their 1999 triumphs - whereas now United will have to strengthen on the back of failure and not success. It's a classic complacent mistake of empires in decline."

Jez Mundy for one disagrees about the midfield. Ferguson, he says, "possesses one of the very best midfield quartets in the world" - but MW gets some support from David Coyle. "Butt and Scholes in particular were overrun and failed to give adequate cover to their defence," he writes, "while Ferguson has to take some tactical flack for the way in which he dealt with the absence of Beckham, which culminated in a void on that side of midfield. If only they had more players of the calibre of Roy Keane."

David, however, sees more obvious shortcomings at full-back. "It was glaringly obvious that Gary Neville and Silvestre are not good enough at this level. Neither defended adequately and their distribution came nowhere near to compensating for their failings at the back."

Jez Mundy makes much the same point. "Though Gary Neville excels at getting into threatening forward positions on the right he too often fails to clear the first defender with his cross," he writes. "Similarly on the left Silvestre's distribution is far too hit and miss to carry any real threat."

Jez is another who finds the strike force short of the highest standards: "Yorke and Cole have none of the menace of an Elber or Jardel or a Hakan Sukur." FMac adds that "in the Man U front line, Andy is not alone in the department of not creating or converting enough chances." And Richard Baxter asks: "Is it just me or does anyone else find the Manchester United strikers lacking when put on the big stage?"

No, Richard. It's not just you.

Naturally, most of you offer solutions. Keith Kelly of Limerick has the most forthright. "United need to buy three players and sell two if they are to become a force in Europe. The side needs a defender, midfielder and striker, and the purchases have to be Van Nistlerooy up front, Rivaldo in midfield and ... Stephen Carr at full-back.

"Sign those three players and no one in the Premeriship will have a tinker's chance of catching United next season. The three may cost some amount of money, especially the Brazilian, so to recoup some funds sell the expired Dwight Yorke and ... David Beckham. The man is a genius at crossing the ball, but he can't defend, tackle or head the ball to save his life."

The richest club in the world ought to be aiming to get the very best, of course, but Jez Mundy points out one possible limitation even to United's ambitions: "Rivaldos and Zidanes probably don't do mock Tudor."

And so on to Arsenal. Yeah, the so-called runners up. It turns out they're crap too.

Robert Williams, an Arsenal supporter for 40 years and a Guardian reader for 35, fears that "Arsenal seem to be intent on slipping away".

"It's good to see that a consensus is growing about the striker problems at Arsenal. It is absolutely time that Bergkamp was sold - he hasn't produced since the double season. Wiltord is an expensive flop with a suspect attitude. His well-documented run-in with his previous club should have put Wenger off him. Kanu is absolutely not worth it now; the club's wrangles with Nigeria over his services should preclude him for being a part of the future with Arsenal.

"The sale of Petit was an absolute blunder by Wenger and his stated resistance to re-signing a player is almost worthy of ostrich-head-in-sand status.

"Since Petit left the midfield has not been able to give the necessary cover to the Arsenal defence which, let's be realistic, is not up to much these days. If anything this would be a chance for Wenger to show his much vaunted ability to rationalise the game and its necessities by re-signing Petit. Pires may come into his own as a replacement for Overmars but there needs to be fire and commitment - dare it be said of the old-fashioned English style. Parlour at least epitomises this but more is needed. Rumours of his possible sale to Sunderland should be squashed. His loss would be deeply felt.

"Arsenal absolutely need a classic old-style centre-forward. You don't need to go back to Malcolm Macdonald - John Hartson was a Gunner in the recent past ... Henry and a harrying player would be an effective combination. The scrappy goal which Arsenal need sometimes would be back in the equation. Not all the goals have to be sublime.

"Compare the goal ratio of Hartson with Wiltord and see which is the better deal.

"Wenger has stated there will be no buying in the summer. He is surely not serious. The team has underachieved. I know other teams with the same positions over the last few seasons may disagree but now Arsenal and their fans have come to expect more. The last thing we want is a return to the dark days of the mid-70s and 80s when the team was not rebuilt after success."

Robert has some support, notably from HarrisonMedialab.

"Paul MacInnes is right about Arsenal - we need a player happy to get into the box, and Wiltord is the one to make way, but the fans would be loath to let Dennis Bergkamp go, even if his goal tally is poor.

"Losing Overmars hasn't been a big a loss as has been widely reported - Pires has had an excellent first season, and he tracks back better than the Dutchman and doesn't run up blind alleyways to the corner flag ... Arsenal now have half a dozen right-sided midfielders, none of whom have cut the mustard so far - Edu and Lauren especially. Vieira can't protect the defence on his own - Ljungberg and Parlour can't be faulted for energy and enthusiasm going forward, but they leave the defence exposed.

"Which brings us to the back four. The left-back position is the only one secure - Silvinho and Cole are simply superb - but Dixon can only have a season left in him, and Luzhny is dependable at best. In central defence, we need to splash the cash. We desperately need an imperious but mobile central defender, a good reader of the ball comfortable bringing it forward - Nowotny anyone? And bring Upson back from loan and give him a run in the team - he has great potential.

"And we need a new keeper."

Is that all? Ah, not quite. Mr Medialab alerts us to the success of Arsenal's multi-national youth set-up. He sees "excellent talent and potential in Pennant, Voltz and Barrett - we may start to see them in the first team next season".

Okay. So it seems Arsenal may not be slipping away yet.

But MW of Cheshire knows where the true problem lies: "They've only got one midfielder who knows how to tackle and cover properly - Roy Keane." This is, of course, a particular problem in European competition, where midfields tend to be more heavily populated. In most of their Champions League games this season, United have had only Keane and Paul Scholes in central midfield. In Munich, Ferguson brought in Nicky Butt, but the strength of the Jeremies-Effenberg-Scholl triumvirate proved conclusive. "Both Bayern's goals were due to Paul Scholes's inability to track back and help his defence," MW claims. "And David Beckham is no better - remember last year's tie against Real Madrid? How would signing Rivaldo solve this fundamental weakness? "As for United's defence, if Coventry's Craig Bellamy and John Hartson can rip them apart, what hope do they have against the best in Europe? In fact Man Utd's whole team seems lacking in height, power and athleticism - which is especially noticeable in European games! "When Real Madrid won last year's Champions League they immediately went out and bought Luis Figo. Similarly, Martin Edwards should have provided the funds to strengthen Fergie's team after their 1999 triumphs - whereas now United will have to strengthen on the back of failure and not success. It's a classic complacent mistake of empires in decline." Jez Mundy for one disagrees about the midfield. Ferguson, he says, "possesses one of the very best midfield quartets in the world" - but MW gets some support from David Coyle. "Butt and Scholes in particular were overrun and failed to give adequate cover to their defence," he writes, "while Ferguson has to take some tactical flack for the way in which he dealt with the absence of Beckham, which culminated in a void on that side of midfield. If only they had more players of the calibre of Roy Keane." David, however, sees more obvious shortcomings at full-back. "It was glaringly obvious that Gary Neville and Silvestre are not good enough at this level. Neither defended adequately and their distribution came nowhere near to compensating for their failings at the back." Jez Mundy makes much the same point. "Though Gary Neville excels at getting into threatening forward positions on the right he too often fails to clear the first defender with his cross," he writes. "Similarly on the left Silvestre's distribution is far too hit and miss to carry any real threat." Jez is another who finds the strike force short of the highest standards: "Yorke and Cole have none of the menace of an Elber or Jardel or a Hakan Sukur." FMac adds that "in the Man U front line, Andy is not alone in the department of not creating or converting enough chances." And Richard Baxter asks: "Is it just me or does anyone else find the Manchester United strikers lacking when put on the big stage?" No, Richard. It's not just you. Naturally, most of you offer solutions. Keith Kelly of Limerick has the most forthright. "United need to buy three players and sell two if they are to become a force in Europe. The side needs a defender, midfielder and striker, and the purchases have to be Van Nistlerooy up front, Rivaldo in midfield and ... Stephen Carr at full-back. "Sign those three players and no one in the Premeriship will have a tinker's chance of catching United next season. The three may cost some amount of money, especially the Brazilian, so to recoup some funds sell the expired Dwight Yorke and ... David Beckham. The man is a genius at crossing the ball, but he can't defend, tackle or head the ball to save his life." The richest club in the world ought to be aiming to get the very best, of course, but Jez Mundy points out one possible limitation even to United's ambitions: "Rivaldos and Zidanes probably don't do mock Tudor." And so on to Arsenal. Yeah, the so-called runners up. It turns out they're crap too. Robert Williams, an Arsenal supporter for 40 years and a Guardian reader for 35, fears that "Arsenal seem to be intent on slipping away". "It's good to see that a consensus is growing about the striker problems at Arsenal. It is absolutely time that Bergkamp was sold - he hasn't produced since the double season. Wiltord is an expensive flop with a suspect attitude. His well-documented run-in with his previous club should have put Wenger off him. Kanu is absolutely not worth it now; the club's wrangles with Nigeria over his services should preclude him for being a part of the future with Arsenal. "The sale of Petit was an absolute blunder by Wenger and his stated resistance to re-signing a player is almost worthy of ostrich-head-in-sand status. "Since Petit left the midfield has not been able to give the necessary cover to the Arsenal defence which, let's be realistic, is not up to much these days. If anything this would be a chance for Wenger to show his much vaunted ability to rationalise the game and its necessities by re-signing Petit. Pires may come into his own as a replacement for Overmars but there needs to be fire and commitment - dare it be said of the old-fashioned English style. Parlour at least epitomises this but more is needed. Rumours of his possible sale to Sunderland should be squashed. His loss would be deeply felt. "Arsenal absolutely need a classic old-style centre-forward. You don't need to go back to Malcolm Macdonald - John Hartson was a Gunner in the recent past ... Henry and a harrying player would be an effective combination. The scrappy goal which Arsenal need sometimes would be back in the equation. Not all the goals have to be sublime. "Compare the goal ratio of Hartson with Wiltord and see which is the better deal. "Wenger has stated there will be no buying in the summer. He is surely not serious. The team has underachieved. I know other teams with the same positions over the last few seasons may disagree but now Arsenal and their fans have come to expect more. The last thing we want is a return to the dark days of the mid-70s and 80s when the team was not rebuilt after success." Robert has some support, notably from HarrisonMedialab. "Paul MacInnes is right about Arsenal - we need a player happy to get into the box, and Wiltord is the one to make way, but the fans would be loath to let Dennis Bergkamp go, even if his goal tally is poor. "Losing Overmars hasn't been a big a loss as has been widely reported - Pires has had an excellent first season, and he tracks back better than the Dutchman and doesn't run up blind alleyways to the corner flag ... Arsenal now have half a dozen right-sided midfielders, none of whom have cut the mustard so far - Edu and Lauren especially. Vieira can't protect the defence on his own - Ljungberg and Parlour can't be faulted for energy and enthusiasm going forward, but they leave the defence exposed. "Which brings us to the back four. The left-back position is the only one secure - Silvinho and Cole are simply superb - but Dixon can only have a season left in him, and Luzhny is dependable at best. In central defence, we need to splash the cash. We desperately need an imperious but mobile central defender, a good reader of the ball comfortable bringing it forward - Nowotny anyone? And bring Upson back from loan and give him a run in the team - he has great potential. "And we need a new keeper." Is that all? Ah, not quite. Mr Medialab alerts us to the success of Arsenal's multi-national youth set-up. He sees "excellent talent and potential in Pennant, Voltz and Barrett - we may start to see them in the first team next season". Okay. So it seems Arsenal may not be slipping away yet.

webTitle: Unions welcome pay offer for council staff

fields.headline: Unions welcome pay offer for council staff
fields.trailText: Councils in England and Wales today appeared to have averted the threat of crippling industrial action as town hall unions welcomed a new pay offer for local government staff.
fields.body:
Councils in England and Wales today appeared to have averted the threat of crippling industrial action as town hall unions welcomed a new pay offer for local government staff.

Pay talks have been deadlocked for two months, but union leaders are predicting that their members will accept the new deal, which means a 3.5% pay increase backdated to April, with a minimum wage boost of £380.

Malcolm Wing, Unison's head of local government, said the offer was "not generous", but that it was the best that could be achieved without resorting to strikes or arbitration. "I would expect our members to accept this," he said.

The unions now have to consult their members and the final outcome of the talks will not be known until the end of May.

But the T&G's Jack Dromey also indicated that he expected the offer to be accepted: "The package which has been negotiated will actually mean a pay increase of over 4% for tens of thousands of some of the lowest paid workers in local government. We have defended the living standards of all our members."

The talks stalled in February when councils told the three major town hall unions - Unison, the T&G and the GMB - that local authorities could not afford to pay more than a 3% increase, and that anything extra might jeopardise jobs and lead to service cuts.

Mr Wing today rejected those claims: "They say that every year. The reality is that central government grant has increased in real terms again this year and we don't see any need for job losses to fund the award."

The employers have changed their position in the face of strike threats from the unions. Officials at the employers' organisation, which represents councils in the talks, said that a sizeable majority of local authorities had come out in favour of the improved offer.

The cost of the new deal is likely to total some £480m.

webTitle: Style: British designers are turning Japanese

fields.headline: When east meets west
fields.standfirst: In the beginning, there were ankle socks. Then came cartoon characters and pigtails, Hello Kitty T-shirts, fake tans and flip-flops.  Hadley Freeman on how Britain's designers and high streets are turning Japanese
fields.trailText: In the beginning, there were ankle socks. Then came cartoon characters and pigtails, Hello Kitty T-shirts, fake tans and flip-flops. Hadley Freeman on how Britain's designers and high streets are turning Japanese.
fields.body:
Ankle socks began to creep into the picture about 10 years ago. Ankle socks, striped T-shirts and, of course, Hello Kitty. Previously, western conception of contemporary Japanese fashion tended to revolve around two very different looks: head-to-toe high fashion labels (notably Louis Vuitton) or the complex styles from the rigorously intellectual native designers, such as Yohji Yamamoto and Issey Miyake, who insisted on elevating to an art form concepts such as the pleat.

But something has changed. Japanese teenagers have been overturning the country's traditions, and foreigners' ideas of Japanese style, with their clothes, which run the gamut from super-kitsch (cartoon character T-shirts and pigtails) to super-cool (low-slung baggy trousers and patterned berets). In the past decade, they have become identifiable by what could be called extreme fashion: Hello Kitty T-shirts, bleached-out skirts, ankle socks with flip-flops.

"The Japanese have always been very good at assimilating outside influences and reinterpreting them," says writer and musician Matt Edwards, who spent last year studying in Japan. "For example, one of Japan's three alphabets comes from the Chinese language, which the Japanese brought across and adapted to their own purposes. When Japan opened up to the west in the mid-19th century, it took on elements of western culture and modified them. Hello Kitty is a perfect example: it's like a reinterpreted Disney character. Japanese street fashion, though really varied, can basically be described as exaggerated western fashion."

Now western fashion, in that cyclical movement that characterises fashion as a whole, is assimilating the look itself. Clements Ribeiro's poppy-print camisoles, Boyd's slogan T-shirts and Eley Kishimoto's technicolour floral print socks, dresses and coats already look set to be among summer's biggest fashion hits.

This season's candy girl look, with sugar-sweet miniskirts, rainbow-splashed elasticated belts and, yes, ankle socks with teetering stilettos, all betray the influence of Japanese street fashion. For the whole of next month, the Selfridges stores in London and Manchester are turning themselves into Japanese superstores, stocking street labels, art and music never before available in Britain, as part of their Tokyo Life event.

"Japanese street fashion is like fashion liberation," says Anna King, a British freelance fashion writer who has lived in Tokyo for eight years. "The bright colours, the reworked traditional patterns, the little bags - these teenagers have both a rebellious attitude to fashion and a fearless one. Their style is almost confrontational. You can't help but look at them."

The contrast between what Japanese teenagers wear on the streets and what the more high-concept designers create in their studios is striking. On the one hand, we have a skirt with overlaid diagonal pleats and deconstructed stitching; on the other, we have a pink and yellow ankle sock.

"This duality is very representative of the country as a whole," says Susanne Tide-Frater, head of fashion direction at Selfridges. "While Japan is a very futuristic country, it also still relies heavily on tradition. There is a real interest in role-play, too, and this is apparent in the streetwear."

Edwards gives a more specific example. "Japan's interest in role-playing tends to infantilise women, with its veneration of cute, small girls. This continues in the way Japanese teenagers dress today, with their pigtails and cartoon colours."

More role-play is apparent among the teenagers' so-called "style tribes". Despite the apparent anarchy of Japanese street style, every element is strictly controlled and how a teenager dresses is determined by the "tribe" to which he or she belongs. Tribes such as last year's ganguro girls, with their tanned faces and platinum hair, or the ultra-kitsch Shibuya tribe, are generated and discarded at blink-and-you'll-miss-them speed.

This Day-Glo, attention-grabbing look, so different from anything Japan had seen previously, emerged in part as a reaction to the country's recent economic instability - while high-status accessories remain extremely popular, there has been a return to designers of cheaper clothing.

It can also be seen as a younger generation reaction to the sombre tone forced on their parents by the depression. "All teenagers rebel," King says, "and what better way to rebel against the solemnity of their parents than through happy-smiley, wear-and-be-damned clothing?"

After a decade of safe sportswear and demure neutrals, followed by last year's high-octane glitz, western consumers have embraced this more good-humoured approach to fashion. The high turnover of styles also attracts westerners tired of the way one trend, be it sportswear or retro 80s, infiltrates every collection, every store on the high street. The only reason Japanese style has taken so long to arrive in the west, Tide-Frater says, is that there have been practical problems exporting the clothes and adapting them to western sizes.

"Basically, Japanese street fashion is fun and this is what appeals to westerners," King says. "When I go to the UK now and go through Hoxton Square or Shoreditch, I sometimes think I'm back in Tokyo."

fields.headline: Taiwan stages war games
fields.standfirst: Special report: Taiwan
fields.trailText: Taiwan today carried out military exercises, staging a simulated Chinese invasion just days before it hopes to secure a deal to buy weapons from the US military.
fields.body:
Taiwan today carried out military exercises, staging a simulated Chinese invasion just days before it hopes to secure a deal to buy weapons from the US military.

The war games come at a sensitive time, as US and Taiwanese officials are expected to finish their annual round of arms talks next week in Washington, and China continues to defy American requests for the return of the downed US spy plane.

Taiwan hopes to purchase from the US four destroyers equipped with the missile-hunting Aegis radar system, diesel-electric submarines and an advanced Patriot anti-missile defence system. The proposed deal is a major source of friction in America's relations with China, because Beijing considers Taiwan to be a breakaway province that should not be purchasing weapons from other nations.

Although the two sides have been governed separately since splitting amid civil war in 1949, China insists reunification must occur at some point and has said any declaration of independence by Taiwan would force a war.

During the live-fire exercise on Taiwan's southern coast, Super Cobra attack helicopters and Tiger fighter jets swooped in on mock invading troops and fired rockets and bombs at targets in the sea.

A Taiwanese military spokesman, speaking on customary condition of anonymity, said that the drills were routine and planned far in advance, and that, despite the recent increase in tensions caused by the US spy plane crisis, there was no reason to cancel the exercises.

"We already discussed the drills with the Americans and they understand that the manoeuvres are routine and frequently conducted by all militaries," the spokesman said.

Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, broke with tradition by not presiding over the war games. He today told US congressmen visiting the capital, Taipei, that he hoped the US would sell defensive weapons to Taiwan because the island can only keep its democracy when its security is safeguarded.

fields.headline: Media buyers team up for online exchange
fields.trailText: 4pm: The world's three biggest marketing groups have joined forces on an internet-based media-buying venture. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The world's three biggest marketing groups have thrown their collective weight behind an internet-based media-buying tool.

Interpublic, Omnicom and WPP plan to corner the market for planning and buying advertising space electronically.

The yet-to-be named online advertising exchange will be headquartered in New York and will launch before the end of the year.

Until now, electronic trading of advertising space has failed to ignite the market, but this development should lead to widespread take-up by planners and buyers.

The move has been likened to the ongoing situation with Napster and the record industry in that the record companies have now joined forces to launch their own internet ventures after their revenues started to be threatened by online middlemen.

Between them, Interpublic, Omnicom and WPP account for the lion's share of billings in the global advertising market, and boast some of the world's biggest agencies, such as Universal McCann, Lowe Lintas, Initiative Media, J. Walter Thompson, Ogilvy & Mather, BBDO Worldwide, DDB Worldwide, and TBWA.

The three partners are also calling on other marketing groups - such as Cordiant, Dentsu and Bcom3 - to join the venture.

The venture also plans to provide buyers and sellers with the research data needed to plan media buys, so it is expected that it will be introduced as a company-wide tool on agency intranets.

Omnicom chief executive John Wren said: "We believe that technology presents a great opportunity to create a platform from which the billions of dollars now spent on media every week can be transacted much more effectively and cost-efficiently.

"We expect that the platform will both improve service and cost-efficiency to our clients and simultaneously benefit media sellers."

Interpublic's Michael Lotito, previously president and chief operating officer of Initiative Media, will serve as the venture's chief executive officer.

The development should send a warning shot through the number of online media exchanges that have emerged over the past few years.

In the UK, these include the recently merged Optimad-iMediapoint, MediaTel's MediaTrader and Adazzle which has been working to develop strong ties with advertising groups.

The problem with online ad exchanges at present is that planning and buying is, by and large, done on goodwill and often needs personal negotiation to clinch a deal.

Another problem is that so far media owners have been loathe to wholeheartedly commit to these exchanges.

Related story
12.02.2001: Online media buyers set to merge

webTitle: Councils and unions edge closer to pay settlement

fields.headline: Councils and unions edge closer to pay settlement
fields.trailText: Councils in England and Wales are considering making a fresh pay offer to staff in a bid to break the two-month deadlock in their stalled wage talks with town hall unions.
fields.body:
Councils in England and Wales are considering making a fresh pay offer to staff in a bid to break the two-month deadlock in their stalled wage talks with town hall unions.

Officials at the Employers' Organisation (EO), which represents the councils, said yesterday that a slim majority of local authorities had come out in favour of a 3.5% pay rise, combined with a minimum increase of £380, backdated to the beginning of April.

But the offer is teetering on a knife-edge. A spokeswoman said that EO staff would analyse council responses up to the last minute, and that the employer negotiating team would not take its final decision until later today.

The settlement may satisfy the three largest unions - Unison, the T&G and the GMB - which have consistently argued for a bottom-weighted pay deal to help workers at the lowest end of the wage scale.

Malcolm Wing, Unison's head of local government, said: "I'm hopeful we can conclude the negotiations today. It's not going to be easy, but local authorities have got to go that extra mile. If they don't, they run the risk of this being taken out of their hands."

Councils have been opposed to increasing the pay offer to above 3%. They claim that a higher increase could jeopardise jobs, and that bottom-weighting the settlement will not help tackle recruitment problems in management jobs.

Employers' secretary Charles Nolda has told councils that the new offer, which would cost a total of £470m, is probably the minimum the unions will accept. The only other options, according to Mr Nolda and the unions, are arbitration or strike action.

In a letter to council chief executives, Mr Nolda said a settlement at 3.5% could mean cuts in some services and the possible privatisation of others.

A spokeswoman said that EO staff would analyse council responses up to the last minute, and that the employer negotiating team would not take its final decision until later today. The settlement may satisfy the three largest unions - Unison, the T&G and the GMB - which have consistently argued for a bottom-weighted pay deal to help workers at the lowest end of the wage scale. Malcolm Wing, Unison's head of local government, said: "I'm hopeful we can conclude the negotiations today. It's not going to be easy, but local authorities have got to go that extra mile. If they don't, they run the risk of this being taken out of their hands." Councils have been opposed to increasing the pay offer to above 3%. They claim that a higher increase could jeopardise jobs, and that bottom-weighting the settlement will not help tackle recruitment problems in management jobs. Employers' secretary Charles Nolda has told councils that the new offer, which would cost a total of £470m, is probably the minimum the unions will accept. The only other options, according to Mr Nolda and the unions, are arbitration or strike action. In a letter to council chief executives, Mr Nolda said a settlement at 3.5% could mean cuts in some services and the possible privatisation of others.

fields.headline: Coke ditches 'Enjoy' for new campaign
fields.standfirst: See the new Coke ads
fields.trailText:
3.45pm: Coca-Cola has replaced its long-running 'Enjoy' slogan with a new global campaign, writes Jessica Hodgson
.See the new Coke ads
fields.body:
Coca-Cola has ditched its long-running "Enjoy" slogan in favour of a new global advertising campaign.

The campaign, under the slogan "Life tastes good", is the most ambitious to come out of Coca-Cola for years.

Thirty commercials have been shot in different locations around the world by Coke's advertising agency, McCann-Erickson.

The adverts, which have been tailored to local markets, launch this weekend in Britain and the US, and the following week in key markets including Mexico, Brazil and Spain.

"Our new celebratory campaign reclaims the Coca-Cola brand's roots, its values, its sensitivity and its rightful place in the minds and hearts of people," said Steve Jones, the chief marketing officer for Coca-Cola.

"As these commercials show, Coca-Cola belongs in stories about the true soul of everyday life. These stories express feelings of optimism, of brightness, of spirit."

The campaign will be the first fruit of a concerted push by the company to shift towards a more locally-focused branding strategy.

Coca-Cola is aware of the need to win back market share lost to new growth markets such as retail coffee outlets.

It has also faced a series of PR setbacks in recent years, from being a target of anti-globalisation campaigners to the Belgian contamination scandal.

webTitle: Decision time for Bush on Taiwan arms

fields.headline: Decision time for Bush on Taiwan arms
fields.standfirst:
China
George Bush's America
fields.trailText: President George Bush will shortly decide whether to sell some of America's most sophisticated weapons to Taiwan.
fields.body:
President George Bush will shortly decide whether to sell some of America's most sophisticated weapons to Taiwan.

But if the leaks emanating from Washington are anything to go by, Mr Bush will hold back on the sale of state of the art destroyers, equipped with the Aegis radar systems that can track more than 100 aircraft and missiles.

Mr Bush is right not to stir the pot at this delicate stage. America is trying to retrieve its spy plane that collided with a Chinese fighter and Beijing is feeling aggrieved after being promoted over a prostrate Russia as America's No1 strategic rival. Of course, China, which is adding to its 300 missiles as fast as it can, is being disingenuous in its protestations Beijing undoubtedly believes America to be its principal rival.

China has been particularly vociferous in opposing the sale of the Aegis-equipped Arleigh Burke destroyers as the system would mesh the "renegade province" ever closer into American plans for a regional defence system. Many of Taiwan's congressional sympathisers back the sale in order to buttress a fledgling democracy as it faces its predatory neighbour.

But deep disagreements exist in Taiwan, currently holding military exercises to repel a simulated Chinese attack, over the acquisition of Aegis. As a Washington Post report points out, considerable doubt exists among Taiwanese strategists over the wisdom of buying Aegis. Not only is it massively expensive, costing $3.2bn, there are also doubts over the Taiwanese navy's ability to handle such sophisticated equipment.

Taiwan's deep divisions over Aegis provide the perfect pretext for Mr Bush to finesse the issue. The Pentagon has also come up with a reasonable fallback position for all parties concerned. It favours the sale of less sophisticated Kidd-class ships that would allow Taiwan's navy to begin training on more modern radar and targeting system that it currently has. Moreover, Taiwan is trying to get to grips with recently-acquired equipment - American F-16 fighters, French Mirages 2000s and a domestic fighter. Ordering Aegis would look like arms bazaar gluttony, so postponement would make practical as well as political sense.

But if Mr Bush - as good a friend as Taiwan can have in the White House - flinches now, it is doubtful whether America will ever sell Aegis to Taiwan. America has made vague undertakings to help in the defence of Taiwan and President Bill Clinton went so far as to despatch American warships to the Taiwan straits, when China taunted Taiwan with some particularly fierce military exercises.

Any sale of Aegis would tie Taiwan more closely with the US and raises the prospect of America being dragged into any future conflict between Taipei and Beijing. America is still licking its wounds after its debacle in Vietnam and it seems inconceivable that Washington would plunge into another far-off Asian conflict, and a budding superpower at that. Taiwan can expect more American military hardware, but it should not hold out for the best that Washington can offer - not if it offends the Chinese.

fields.headline: eBay revenues up 15%
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: International internet auction house eBay has unveiled better than expected results, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
International internet auction house eBay shone some light on an otherwise gloomy dot.com market today when it unveiled better than expected results.

eBay's share price rose to around £35 on the news. Analysts also reacted warmly, projecting the share price should reach £40 within the year.

Revenues were up 15% to £108m and projections for the next two quarters are now pitched at £110m and £117m respectively.

User numbers grew to 29.7m as almost £1.4m worth of merchandise - such as baseball cards, cars, antiques and Elvis memorabilia - was bought and sold through eBay's websites.

The increased spending on eBay contrasts with the revenue downturns experienced by its rivals.

QXL's share price now stands at around 5p. Analysts said eBay was now in a class of its own.

Maynard Webb, the president of eBay Technologies, earned £350,000 in bonuses last year.

Jeffery Jordan, the senior vice-president and general manager for eBay's US business, earned £96,000 in bonus pay.

The company has now expanded successfully into six markets: the UK, Germany, Japan, Italy and Australia and Korea.

webTitle: Portillo latest Tory to veto race pledge

fields.headline: Portillo latest Tory to veto race pledge
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo has entered the row over an anti-racism pledge by dismissing it as a "bit of paper."
fields.body:
Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, today reignited the simmering political race row by refusing to sign an anti-racism pledge and dismissing it as one of many "bits of paper and questionnaires thrust in front of me."

He becomes the most senior Tory to refuse to put his name to the commission for racial equality's card, which commits candidates to avoid racist language during the election campaign.

Guardian Unlimited revealed three weeks ago how Conservative MP John Townend - who hit the headlines over a speech criticising immigrants for undermining "anglo-saxon culture" - was the first politician to refuse to sign up for the pledge.

He has since been joined by fellow Tory backbencher Eric Forth, and the Conservative whip James Cran in vetoing the commitment.

However, Mr Portillo's refusal to put his name to the CRE promises to up the stakes considerably on an issue which is becoming a major battleground ahead of the coming general election.

On a farm trip to Wales, Mr Portillo was forced to defend his position on the pledge card, rather than attack the government over its handling of the foot and mouth epidemic, the ostensible purpose of his visit.

Mr Portillo said: "No, I haven't signed it because I speak for myself and I have said that I offer equality of esteem to everyone in this country."

Mr Portillo said party leader William Hague had already signed it on behalf of all the party's candidates and he did not like "bits of paper and questionnaires thrust in front of me".

And he added: "I don't think we should be drawn into committing ourselves to sign up to every apparently well-intentioned declaration," he added.

Former Conservative minister John Gummer, who has yet to sign the pledge himself, earlier today took to the airwaves to attack the idea as "unconstitutional" and "blackmail."

And Mr Gummer said making the MPs' names public risked implying that they were racist. "The CRE seems to me to be using a measure of blackmail in this way which is unacceptable." He went on: "The problem is that at every election people ask you to sign a whole series of things of this sort. This is wholly unconstitutional because your relationship is with your constituents.

A Labour spokesman said: "Michael Portillo has refused to do that and demonstrated that the Conservatives under William Hague have no discipline, leadership or unity."

The CRE pledge states: " "The right to free political expression must not be abused in the competition for popular votes by causing, or exploiting, prejudice and discrimination on the grounds of race or nationality."

webTitle: It's time for a truce in the spin war

fields.headline: It's time for a truce in the spin war
fields.standfirst: The dust is still settling following Alastair Campbell's decision to stand down after the election.  His former deputy, Tim Allan, gives an insight into how Labour should look to manage its relations with the press after his erstwhile boss has stopped briefing.
fields.trailText: The reaction to the news that Alastair Campbell would be standing down from the spin front line was a metaphor for New Labour's relations with the media. From newspapers and Tories  there was denunciation over the way the news itself was spun, with an off the record briefing to a favoured journalist rather than a formal announcement. The government, meanwhile, criticised the media for giving more prominence to this personality story, than to a substantive policy speech by Tony Blair.
fields.body:
The reaction to the news that Alastair Campbell would be standing down from the spin front line was a metaphor for New Labour's relations with the media. From newspapers and Tories there was denunciation over the way the news itself was spun, with an off the record briefing to a favoured journalist rather than a formal announcement. The government, meanwhile, criticised the media for giving more prominence to this personality story, than to a substantive policy speech by Tony Blair.

These are pretty much the battle lines across which all Labour's disputes with the press take place. The government is portrayed as being run by spin, and, with the departure of Charlie Whelan and Peter Mandelson, that criticism was falling ever more on Campbell's shoulders. The government portrays political journalists as the real spinners - shallow, self-obsessed creatures more concerned with lobby tittle-tattle than communicating important political events to their readers. Campbell's departure from battle lines, which I manned with him for four years, provides a timely opportunity to assess the state of the war.

It is certainly true that Labour has given huge importance to media relations. Tony Blair is seared by the experience of campaigning against a highly effective Conservative communications team in the early 1980s and vowed early on in his leadership to build the most effective press team possible.

It is also true that Labour was too slow to recognise that the communication style it had developed in opposition - informal, opportunistic and lightening fast - was ill-suited to government. In opposition, words were our only weapon and we tried to use every breaking political story to communicate our central messages and cause trouble for our opponents. In government, hasty reactions communicated through off-the record briefings can be extremely dangerous.

We made mistakes. The trouble we caused ourselves by latching on to a story about director's pay at Camelot before the concrete policy implications had been thought through typified the differences between opposition and government communications. Briefing the Times on the Government's policy on the Euro, before Parliament had been told was a disaster, but also a turning point as Tony Blair made clear that such informality must end.

However, it is no longer true to characterise the government as obsessed with spin. Policy-making does dominate press relations as it should. Tony Blair himself does not even read the newspapers, as he did, obsessively, in opposition. Alastair Campbell's briefings are normally more concerned with refuting stories in the press than placing them. Yet the charge against the government remains. 'Spin' has become part of a strategic attack by the Conservatives at a time when it is used less and less.

What then of the government's claim that political journalists are dangerously obsessed with Westminster minutiae, of no interest to voters, and that they continually produce (in Campbellspeak) 'garbagic' stories? His frustration with Westminster journalists is genuine and well-founded. Perhaps the announcement of his departure will cause the Lobby to at least consider his criticisms of them.

They should address the focus and quality of their output. Too often, factual reporting of events is replaced by an obsession with the process. The interaction with the journalist becomes the story rather than the medium of communication. This only happens in Westminster, and means that many political stories in the papers are pretty incomprehensible to anybody outside the House of Commons.

And let's not beat around the bush here. Plenty of stories based around anonymous quotes are simply made up by lazy journalists, who know that nobody will ever be able to prove their invention. Of course most lobby journalists are not "make-up merchants" as Campbell calls them, but there are enough who are and their influence is corrosive. "Isn't it funny that anonymous sources always speak in short sentences to the tabloids and in long sentences to the broadsheets", Alastair used to remark dryly.

Other times the source of the quote is dressed up to make it far more important than it is. I should know, my quotes to political journalists have often become quotes from 'a senior MP' or even on one occasion a 'senior Cabinet Minister' - quite an achievement considering I was a press officer for the Opposition at the time.

This level of distortion cannot go on. With Whelan, Mandelson and Campbell all stepping down from the front lines, it is time to call a truce in the spin war. The government must ensure that its dealings with journalists are straightforward and honest. Lobby journalists must rescue their profession from the suspicions of invention which surround some of their work. After all, with so much news and information available instantly now, through TV and the internet, what the newspapers are selling is not news. It is credibility. They must not lose that.

Tim Allan was a press spokesman for Tony Blair between 1992-98

fields.headline: Running your research group
fields.trailText:
Michael Rennie explains how to juggle being a successful academic with managing a research group.
Starting a research group
fields.body:
So you're feeling very pleased with yourself. It is now 18 months since you started your research group, which is funded by two grants; one in which you piggy-backed onto the application of a well established senior figure in your department and another smaller grant which you obtained under a new lecturer scheme. Your honeymoon period of minimal teaching and administration is coming to an end and life is becoming very much more complicated, having to teach and contribute to the running of your institution as well as managing your own group. How are you going to become a successful academic juggling at least three different kinds of activities?

Firstly, make sure that whatever you do you do it to the same high standard. You are going to have to budget your time carefully. Do not fall into the trap of seeing your research as your primary interest and teaching and administration as secondary. This will only result in your life becoming more difficult. Colleagues will resent your lack of commitment to areas they regard as primary and you will not be able to fully exploit the collegiate structure to do worthwhile research.

You are also going to have to become fully independent and self sufficient. This means expanding your operation which means, in the short term, more funding problems. You are also going to have to learn to manage people - both within your group and others who provide central services, such as finance, personnel and local laboratory services. It is important that you have a considered coherent vision of how you will interact with people in your environment in order to behave consistently, productively and to avoid becoming stressed.

Personal management styles differ dramatically between individuals. However, no matter how you do it, the most important thing for your own group is to set up a framework in which everybody knows what is expected of them, what their rights are and what to do if something goes wrong. There will inevitably be personal niggles, jealousies and competition for space and resources within the group, and it is your responsibility to spot these early and sort them out. You will need a mixture of both formal and informal approaches. Getting out of your office into the lab and simply talking to your group members is invaluable. You can obtain information in a much less threatening way than hauling somebody along to your office to obtain it. However, you do also need to have regular, well organised meetings with small sections of your group, and also whole group meetings to discuss day to day activities and problems, as well as the tactics and strategy of your research. Involvement builds loyalty and loyalty builds stability, which gives you the basis on which to do new work.

Your future is very much bound up with the development of your group members, so lose no opportunities to help them acquire new skills, expertise and confidence in applying them. Give them the opportunity to present invited papers when you are too busy to do so or when you yourself are already giving a paper at the same meeting. Try to be as professional as possible in your dealings with your PhD students in particular. Remember that their entire future depends on achieving worthwhile results capable of being defended at a viva. They will be much better able to do this if they have been able to publish a couple of run of the mill papers, as well as a paper containing some first class research. Indeed, you should always maintain some pot-boiling work to enable you to satisfactorily complete end of grant reports, while at the same time continuing with a narrow strand of high class research. This will let you avoid embarrassment when things do not work out - and they often will not - and will help to maintain funding continuity. There is truth in the saying, "publish or perish", and even giants in the field need to stand on the shoulders of some dwarfs when that extra few centimetres is crucial.

Remember to delegate. The total volume of work will grow as your group grows, but you do not need to dot every i or cross every t. Once you have established that you can trust somebody, then trust them. Let them do the whole job, check it once, and let them get it out of the door.

Finally, the most important thing to remember when you are a group leader is why you got into it in the first place. If it stops being fun or is ruining your relationships, then stop it and do something else.

fields.headline: DoomWatch
fields.standfirst: Talk of recession has now permeated every sector of the media. The slump is no longer the preserve of the internet and advertising industries. Each week, our new DoomWatch service will keep you up to date on the changes in the media economy, complete with expert opinions from the US and UK.
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: News of 10,000 lay-offs at Ericsson has heightened fears of a global slump. Read our new DoomWatch survey by Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Today's news of 10,000 lay-offs at the telecoms manufacturer, Ericsson, has heightened fears of a global economic slump.

The hi-tech sector has been the source of an unprecedented, decade-long boom in the US economy but this week's events have underlined the turmoil in the technology market.

Ericsson's announcement comes just days after the Dutch electronics group, Philips, said it would be cutting 7,000 jobs.

The internet equipment maker, Cisco Systems, and PC manufacturer Hewlett Packard added to the bad news by issuing profit warnings, prompted by consumers reining in their technology spending.

The news from technology companies overshadowed a 0.5% cut in US interest rates and a massive leap in the technology-rich Nasdaq index, which rose 31% in 10 trading days.

Some UK media analysts are becoming increasingly edgy about the news coming from across the Atlantic.

A slump in the US economy will inevitably filter into UK companies and force them to cut back on the advertising spending that forms the core of media firms' revenues.

"The fundamentals are still weak and there are still advertising downgrades to come through," said one analyst.

"The media sector in the UK has a close relationship with Nasdaq, which is a key driver for the stocks. We think the Nasdaq will continue to perform very weakly."

Nicola Stewart, a media analyst at Commerzbank, said the benefits of a US interest rate cut - which will encourage businesses to borrow money - should trickle through to UK markets in the second half of the year.

But she added that lumping technology, media and telecoms stocks together was damaging for all sectors.

"The dynamics for the media industry are completely different. Technology stocks have been downgraded massively but that is not the case with media companies," she said.

Recession roulette - who's winning and who's losing

 AOL Time Warner provided a timely boost for media stocks with above-par first-quarter figures. The world's largest media company said the diversity of its operations - from America Online to Time magazine to the CNN network - protected it from the worst of a US downturn.

 Nokia, Ericsson's main rival, reported a 6% rise in pofits but said the worrying situation in the US prevented it from making firm predictions for the year.

 UK newspaper publisher Trinity Mirror cut 85 jobs from its digital operations as media companies lost patience with loss-making internet subsidiaries.

 Channel 4's chief executive, Michael Jackson, said he was glad the broadcaster was not a listed company as its internet spending would get it into big trouble with the stock market.

 The music industry reported global sales have fallen for the sixth successive year, underpinned by conditions in the US and the growth of no-fee music websites.

 Internet service provider Yahoo! attempted to inject some media savvy into its ailing business by appointing Terry Semel, the former co-head of the Warner Brothers film studio, as chief executive. The company is expected to seek content deals with blue-chip media companies.

fields.headline: Bomb scare at the White House
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Police have found a suspect package near the White House.
fields.body:
Police have found a suspect package near the White House.

Bomb scares are not uncommon but police are worried that the president, George Bush, may have been targeted ahead of a controversial trade summit in Quebec.

Pennsylvania Avenue, the road outside the White House, has been closed and the area evacuated.

Mr Bush, however, is safe inside the building. His office is in a secure area at the back of the White House, where he will stay until he leaves for Quebec later today.

fields.headline: Starting a research group
fields.trailText: Before deciding to start a research group, there are several points to consider.
fields.body:
Before deciding to start a research group, there are several points to consider. Self appraisal is the first crucial step - and one that is often ignored. A quarter to one third of all new university lecturers turn out to be unsuccessful as researchers. This needs to be recognised and the obvious question asked: am I someone who by nature, inclination and training is likely to succeed as a researcher?

Although some researchers make money from patents, win lucrative prizes, gain knighthoods and honorary directorships, most journeyman scientists will have to be content with making a modest contribution to knowledge and receiving little in return by way of status, sympathy or monetary reward. The hours are long and often unsocial. You will be under constant pressure to publish papers and write grants as well as do your fair share of serving on committees and teaching undergraduates, most of whom have little real intellectual interest in your topic. A group leader bears heavy responsibilities for identifying potentially successful research strategies, obtaining the funds to pay the salaries of research assistants and technicians and often has to stand considerable pressure to be productive in a very competitive environment. Someone who is only going through the motions of research in order to hold down a job as a lecturer will rapidly become disillusioned and unproductive.

On the plus side, however, the payoffs are: independence - you can study whatever you like, within reason - the opportunities to work with bright, enthusiastic young people and experienced older scientists and, best of all, the thrill of discovering something totally new.

If you really are determined, the best way to go about setting up your group is to first make sure you are in the best possible environment. In the UK, your chances of success if your department rates less than four in the Research Assessment Exercise will be very slim, simply because those who assess your grant applications will look at your research environment to see whether it is sufficiently supportive. In some cases, just to be able to qualify for grants, your group will have to be part of a larger group which already has funding.

Becoming a group leader is the start of your career as an independent scientist. It offers an important opportunity, rarely repeated, to radically change your area of work. Having done up to three postdoctoral fellowships before your substantive academic appointment means that you are intellectually capable and productive, but you do not need to work on the topics you researched as a postdoc. If you do you will discover your previous supervisors have suddenly become competitors. Ploughing your own furrow may be more risky, but it allows for more freedom and diminishes competition.

In deciding who to approach for funding, start modestly. It is probably reasonable to ally yourself with someone in your institution whose projects fit with yours so that there is value added in the eyes of the grant-giving body.

Try hard to negotiate a honeymoon period in which you have no teaching or administrative commitments, and try to make this as long as possible, three years if you can. Even if you did not negotiate this on your appointment, try and do it soon after arriving.

Make sure that you understand the implications of the source, size and nature of the funding. For example, from the universityÕs point of view you should ideally obtain funds from a Research Council, which will pay 40% overhead on salary costs. If you get a grant with £100,000 worth of salary costs, your institution will get £40,000 in addition. This will make you popular with the budget holder. However, if you get a grant from a medical research charity you will not get any overhead. In fact, it will cost your institution money to run your grant. Obtaining funds from commercial organisations often has less cachet, because the work is usually more applied than funds obtained from charities or research councils. But you may often be able to negotiate a higher level of overhead - say 70% on the total value of the grant - the aims and objectives are likely to be more realisable, and commercial organisations are much more likely to pay for incidentals such as travel and publication charges.

Your future success depends upon being continually innovative and efficient and you should set aside time for self development. Get as much training in research management, grant writing, PhD supervision and computer skills as you can. You will not regret it.

Once you have your grant, you will need to choose people to work with you. Be picky. Do not take the first people who apply, no matter how well qualified. Look for people who are bright, committed and who you will get along with.

Finally, be sure that your aims and objectives are realistic, that they are quantifiable so that you can tell how well you are doing, and that you identify milestones by which you can check your progress along the road to your eventual goal.

fields.headline: St Luke's founder quits to join Discovery
fields.trailText: 2pm: David Abraham is leaving to become general manager of Discovery Networks Europe, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
David Abraham, one of the founders of the St Luke's advertising agency, is leaving to become general manager of Discovery Networks Europe.

Mr Abraham, who joins Discovery in June, will be responsible for brand strategy and communication across Discovery's nine channels, which include Animal Planet, Discovery Travel and Discovery Channel.

He played a key role in the setting up of St Luke's in 1995 and has run the agency with co-owner Andy Law for the past five and a half years.

"Discovery is the most respected global TV brand and having personally moved closer to the film and broadcasting fields in recent years, the timing was absolutely right to take this unique opportunity," said Mr Abraham.

"Leaving St Luke's was a tough decision but I'm enormously excited by the fresh challenge of Discovery as it seeks to build upon impressive recent international expansion," he added.

His departure coincides with a management reorganisation at St Luke's, which is due to be announced in the near future.

fields.headline: 'Donnygate' claims third leader
fields.trailText: Scandal-hit Doncaster council is facing a fresh crisis after the arrest last night of its leader, Colin Wedd, in connection with allegations of expenses fraud.
fields.body:
Scandal-hit Doncaster council is facing a fresh crisis after the arrest last night of its leader, Colin Wedd, in connection with allegations of expenses fraud.

Mr Wedd is the third council leader at Doncaster to be arrested under Operation Danum, the long-running police investigation into corruption within the authority.

South Yorkshire police said a man had been arrested in connection with the investigation into Doncaster council, for alleged offences of false accounting, and was given police bail until April 30.

His arrest automatically triggers his suspension only days before Labour councillors were due to select a leader of the council in their annual vote.

Mr Wedd was being challenged by councillor Gerry McLister, who cited the need for a clean break from the old Labour guard in the council chamber.

Mr Wedd, 62, is the third leader of the authority to lose his position because of the "Donnygate" scandal.

He took over the reins in 1998 following the arrest of previous incumbent Malcolm Glover, who had been trumpeted as the man to turn round the authority and put it on an even keel.

Glover, 49, last year received a suspended jail sentence after admitting three charges of making false expenses claims.

He had taken over from Peter Welsh, 47, who had stood down in 1997 following a report by the district auditor which revealed widespread junketing by members and officers.

Mr Welsh was later charged with alleged expenses fraud, which he denies. He is due to appear in court next week.

It is not known at this stage if Mr McLister will be given a clear run next week and installed as unopposed leader.

Neither he nor Mr Wedd were today available for comment.

Doncaster council chief executive David Marlow said: "I have been made aware of the current situation by South Yorkshire police. For legal reasons, I am not able to comment any further.

"However I would want to assure our citizens that it is business as usual at Doncaster council and we will continue to deliver high quality services on a daily basis."

fields.headline: Farmers may face a 'bumpy ride'
fields.standfirst: The government's claim that foot and mouth is 'under control' has been met with cynicism from those covering the crisis, writes the Guardian's environment correspondent, Paul Brown
fields.trailText: The government's claim that foot and mouth is 'under control' has been met with cynicism from those covering the crisis, writes the Guardian's environment correspondent, Paul Brown.
fields.body:
After eight weeks the foot and mouth epidemic is "under control" according to the government's chief scientist, David King, just in time for Tony Blair to call the election for June 7.

The announcement was treated with jocular cynicism by the pack of reporters who have been covering the crisis and seen the news management of the crisis by Downing Street at close quarters.

At the start of the outbreak all of the information that the government had was publicly available; once Tony Blair took charge specialist correspondents were denied the facts and daily lobby briefings were substituted.

In this atmosphere rumour flourished, farmers who felt they were being kept in the dark got angry, and reporters turned on the hapless Ministry of Agriculture (Maff), which had been ordered by Downing Street to close down its website and news conferences.

But Prof King's statistics were convincing. The number of outbreaks has dropped in line with predictions, if anything slightly faster, and if all continues in the same way Mr Blair will get his trouble-free election.

Out in the shires some vets are not so sure. The problem all along has been that this strain of the disease has maverick properties that are hard to understand. While it is obvious if pigs and cattle have the disease, because of the symptoms and the suffering of the animals, sheep are a different matter.

Although they do develop blisters in the mouth and sometimes have sore feet it is easy to miss altogether. If only a few sheep out of a large flock get the disease most farmers would not notice. Not until a second wave of infection, when large numbers of animals get the disease, is it notified.

Often it is not until neighbouring herds of cattle get the disease that farmers realise their sheep have been infected all along.

It is this, plus the fact that many valuable cattle have been part protected from the disease by being kept in sheds and are now being put out to pasture that makes the course of the disease less certain.

Both factors could bring a new upsurge in cases. Prof King concedes that there may be a "bumpy ride" if all does not go according to plan. He may well be right.

The announcement was treated with jocular cynicism by the pack of reporters who have been covering the crisis and seen the news management of the crisis by Downing Street at close quarters. At the start of the outbreak all of the information that the government had was publicly available; once Tony Blair took charge specialist correspondents were denied the facts and daily lobby briefings were substituted. In this atmosphere rumour flourished, farmers who felt they were being kept in the dark got angry, and reporters turned on the hapless Ministry of Agriculture (Maff), which had been ordered by Downing Street to close down its website and news conferences. But Prof King's statistics were convincing. The number of outbreaks has dropped in line with predictions, if anything slightly faster, and if all continues in the same way Mr Blair will get his trouble-free election. Out in the shires some vets are not so sure. The problem all along has been that this strain of the disease has maverick properties that are hard to understand. While it is obvious if pigs and cattle have the disease, because of the symptoms and the suffering of the animals, sheep are a different matter. Although they do develop blisters in the mouth and sometimes have sore feet it is easy to miss altogether. If only a few sheep out of a large flock get the disease most farmers would not notice. Not until a second wave of infection, when large numbers of animals get the disease, is it notified. Often it is not until neighbouring herds of cattle get the disease that farmers realise their sheep have been infected all along. It is this, plus the fact that many valuable cattle have been part protected from the disease by being kept in sheds and are now being put out to pasture that makes the course of the disease less certain. Both factors could bring a new upsurge in cases. Prof King concedes that there may be a "bumpy ride" if all does not go according to plan. He may well be right. fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £158.04
The Prince of Punts (aka Paul MacInnes) = £55.01
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £33.46
Sean Ingle = £27.32

Scott Murray: Coventry to win at Ipswich £10 @ 7/2

"Ipswich are underrated" is fast becoming the most boring and over-used phrase of the season. Yes we all bloody know they are. Stop saying that.

So just before I'm drowned out by irritating little eejits who think they're giving us some sort of special insight by screaming "they're fourth you know" or "a glance at the table proves they're better than Leeds, Liverpool and Chelsea" at the top of their tedious voices, just let me say this.

Both these teams are in form. Both are desperate for important points. Ipswich should be favourites, of course they should, but I'll take nearly fours on a match that can easily go either way.

"That John Hartson may be a fat oaf, but he doesn't half scores some goals, you know." Please God let me hear the bores spouting this come Saturday night.

The Prince of Punts: Manchester City to be up at half-time against Manchester United £5 @ 6/1

The Prince has been in Germany recently spending a wonderful weekend with my cousin, the Baron von Wager. In between blowing each other's alpenhorns the Baron observed that while Bayern Munich are ace, Manchester United are !$*@. And who is the Prince to quibble with the Baron?

Nobody, that's who. Which is why we've plumped for spunking £5 on Manchester City to be up at half-time in this weekend's derby. City, it is to be noted, are rubbish and they stand as much chance of winning the entire game as, say, United do of winning the European Cup. But they have made a habit of starting brightly recently, scoring the first goal against Aston Villa, Everton and Leicester. Two times out of the three they went on to lose, but with United unlikely to be on top of their game from the get-go, 6-1 has to be good value for a half-way lead. So there you have it, you peasants.

Julian Lord of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: £5 double on Manchester United to beat Manchester City (4/11) and Leicester to beat Middlesbrough (6/4)

Forget Wednesday night. This is United's chance to vanquish the demons of the famous Denis Law backheel in 1974. Every United fan knows it never mattered as results went against them anyway. But the urban myth persists in Moss Side.

Nothing can be decided at Old Trafford tomorrow, but the game will have huge significance on City's Premiership status - and I expect United to be up for it.

With Coventry playing so well, Middlesbrough are looking nervously over their shoulders. Despite Leicester's dreadful run of results, Boro have one thing going against them that could decide their fate. As England and Australia fans can testify, Terry Venables is an unlucky manager.

Sean Ingle: Manchester United v Manchester City: draw half-time/United to win full-time £5 @ 4/1

In the past week, United have won the Premiership and been knocked out of Europe. With their season over, expect their motivation and morale to be a touch lower than usual.

City, on the other hand, are fighting for their Premiership lives. And while Joe Royle's men will no doubt eventually succumb to United's class, don't be surprised if they make things difficult.

I'm torn between this bet and 0-1 goals, which is priced at 7/2. But the half-time/full-time punt pays a bit more, so that's where my fiver is heading.

fields.headline: Death online
fields.standfirst: Martin Kettle asks whether the Oklahoma City bomber, Timothy McVeigh, will be the first man to be publically executed in the US in 64 years
fields.trailText: Martin Kettle asks whether the Oklahoma City bomber, Timothy McVeigh, will be the first man to be publically executed in the US in 64 years.
fields.body:
Even in today's often emotionally sheltered world it comes as something of a shock to discover that the last public execution in the US took place as recently as 1937. Somehow, public executions seem to belong to a far more distant era - the Middle Ages, say, or the French Revolution - or, in more recent times, to self-evidently barbaric societies like Pol Pot's Cambodia.

But one should never be surprised by America. And it is mark of what academics like to call this country's cultural "exceptionalism" that there is now a serious discussion going on here about what could be, to all intents, the first public execution to take place in the US since that last one in Missouri, 64 years ago.

Timothy McVeigh, the Oklahoma City mass murderer, is scheduled to die by lethal injection in a prison in Terre Haute, Indiana, on May 16. Even before the question of who would get to see him die became the major talking point that it now is, the McVeigh case was already set to break records for all kinds of reasons.

The execution will be the first federal, as distinct from state, execution since the return of the death penalty in the US in 1976. And because McVeigh committed the biggest single act of terrorism in US history - he killed 168 people in Oklahoma City in the bombing six years ago yesterday - he is arguably the worst killer in the nation's history, a grisly crown that McVeigh appears to wear with pride.

As we near May 16, debate about the McVeigh execution will probably focus attention once again on the original and fundamental question of capital punishment itself. For now, though, the American public is distracted by a different aspect.

The issue of the moment is whether McVeigh will become the first execution victim whose death will be shown on television. The question has arisen because of the convergence of two things: the sheer numbers of victims and the culture of emotional "closure".

Because McVeigh murdered so many people, the pool of victims' relatives is unprecedentedly large too. They could not possibly all be accommodated in Terre Haute to watch his execution, should they all so wish.

However, the victims' families also live in a society where individual closure, the perceived need to confront the emotions of victimhood or to complete the experience of bereavement, is accorded a reverence and a primacy that it was denied in the past.

America is a land of many public rituals, and the public rituals of loss and pain are given a rein here that they would never be given in stiff upper-lip Britain, for example.

Many of the victims' relatives have no desire to watch McVeigh die. But a lot of them do - in the sacred name of closure - and they are too numerous to be accommodated without closed circuit television.

Last week, attorney general John Ashcroft authorised the relatives and survivors, who include rescue workers, to watch the May 16 execution on TV in Oklahoma City. Ashcroft's decision was a victory for the doctrine of retribution, which the attorney general strongly supports, and also for the modern cult of victimhood, which most of his fellow conservatives despise.

If he thinks that he has drawn a line, Ashcroft is wrong. If McVeigh's execution can be seen by some Americans, why not by others? This week, a federal judge turned down a request from a group called the Entertainment Network, which wanted the right to show the killer's death on the internet.

Nevertheless, the legal challenge for the right to see McVeigh die - which McVeigh, eager to project himself as a martyr, supports - is not over. Other efforts will be made to widen the audience.

And it remains a possibility that film of the execution may somehow find its way into the public domain anyway. Which means that, if one execution is made public, what can then prevent others from being broadcast?

Yesterday afternoon, I watched the televised launch of the latest Space Shuttle from Cape Canaveral. A glorious event that was once unthinkable has now become almost routine television.

Twenty years from now, though, Americans may be able to turn on, tune in and watch the latest execution on the box with just as much ease.

fields.headline: Liverpool scores for BBC1
fields.trailText: 1pm TV overnights: More than 9m watched Liverpool squeeze past Barcelona to secure a place in the Uefa Cup final last night, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
It was BBC1's turn to score big ratings with football last night, as more than 9m watched Liverpool squeeze past Barcelona to secure a place in the Uefa Cup final.

Match of the Day Live, featuring live coverage of Liverpool's 1-0 home win over Barcelona, went out on BBC1 between 8pm and 10pm last night.

The show had 9.1m viewers and a 37% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

ITV did slightly better with its live European football on Wednesday night, with 9.3m tuning in for Manchester United's defeat and exit from the Champions League.

Last night's Match of the Day Live was up against Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? on ITV between 8pm and 9pm.

Millionaire had 9.5m viewers and a 39% audience share.

But Match of the Day Live had a higher peak audience, with 10.7m watching between 9.45pm and 10pm, than ITV's live football the previous night.

And in its second hour the BBC1 football show beat ITV medical drama A&E, which had just 7m viewers.

Channel 4 also enjoyed good ratings last night on the back of a football show.

New Channel 4 factual series Football Stories was cannily scheduled between 10pm and 11pm to pick up BBC1 soccer fans at the end of the Liverpool game.

The crowd-pleasing first instalment, which selected a team of 11 footballing bad boys, including Eric Cantona, Diego Maradona and Paul Gascoigne, drew 2.5m viewers and a 14% audience share.

Channel 5's best audience yesterday came from a repeat showing of Jean-Claude Van Damme/Dolph Lundgren movie Universal Soldier between 9pm and 10.55pm.

The futuristic action thriller took 2m viewers and a 9% audience share.
