webTitle: Labour women in line for post election promotion

fields.headline: Labour women in line for post election promotion
fields.trailText: We profile the talent pool in any female putsch for power in a second term Blair reshuffle
fields.body:
Blair's Babes FC

Tony Blair grinned like a Cheshire cat when he led Labour to power in the 1997 general election - and his smile grew even wider when he was surrounded by the 101 female Labour MPs who followed him into parliament.

Four years on, many of Labour's newest MPs look set to return to Civvy Street at the next election. But others have made their mark in parliament, and with three women leaving the cabinet after the next election and more vacancies to fill at ministerial level, Mr Blair is sure to want to promote some of his "babes". Here political correspondent Matthew Tempest profiles Blair's first 11 of Labour's brightest female prospects.

Goalkeeper
Patricia Hewitt:
They say goalies get better with age, and at 48 Patricia Hewitt has certainly got a safe pair of hands, both as Neil Kinnock's right-hand woman when Tony Blair was barely getting his feet under the desk as a new MP, and most importantly as one of the early architects of New Labour.

Now e-commerce minister, a promotion to the Cabinet for this highly-able performer seems a sure bet.

Ask Aristotle about Patricia Hewitt

Right back
Rosie Winterton:
As a member of Labour's national policy forum, this Yorkshire MP and former adviser to John Prescott will have helped shape the next manifesto.

Yet to stamp her authority on any policy specialism, but an interest in buses, bypasses and cowboy wheel clampers could see her patching up Labour's achilles heel of transport in any Blair second term.

Ask Aristotle about Ann Winterton

Left back
Lorna Fitzsimons:
This mouthy former leader of the national union of students has a style which fits uncomfortably at Westminster, but should see her playing a significant role during the election campaign trying to get the "youth vote" out for Labour.

If that succeeds, the strongly pro-European Fitzsimons could be called on again for the Euro referendum hustings in two years time.

Ask Aristotle about Lorna Fitzsimons

Centre half
Gisela Stuart:
Ms Stuart was thrust into the limelight when she became the first Labour MP to win a marginal seat on election night. Since then she has been lauded as one of Labour's potential stars, especially following her good work as a junior minister at the department of health.

While in parliament she has successfully campaigned for kerbcrawling to be made an arrestable offence.

Ask Aristotle about Gisela Stuart

Centre half
Sally Keeble:
Supremely intelligent and calm presence on the backbenches, Keeble is a rising star of the future, if not for this time around.

A former journalist, it will be interesting to see what questions she poses for Nick Brown over the handling of foot and mouth in her role on the agriculture select committee.

Ask Aristotle about Sally Keeble

Right wing
Yvette Cooper:
The granddaughter of a miner, who went to Oxford, smoked dope, and came out with a first-class degree in PPE, is now one of Labour's brightest stars.

As undersecretary of state for public health she has shone - despite a reprimand from Sir John Krebs of the Food Standards Agency after she revealed information without his permission.

Her marriage to Ed Balls, the chancellor's chief adviser, ensures that Ms Cooper benefits from the support of Gordon Brown as she rises to the top.

Ask Aristotle about Yvette Cooper

Left wing
Ruth Kelly:
This industrious former journalist is the brains behind much of the government's thinking of family-friendly working practices and welfare benefits for single mothers.

Having given birth to three children herself since winning her seat in 1997, she is certainly qualified to lead the putsch of working mothers into ministerial, or even Cabinet, level politics.

Ask Aristotle about Ruth Kelly

Central midfielder
Tessa Jowell:
Has been waiting in the wings since 1992, but recent behind the scenes lobbying for Tony Blair and Jack Straw to concede that marriage is not the only role model for society, and another big push for equal pay has seen her stock rise among progressive backbenchers from the 1997 intake.

Mocked over her scheme for a "fat summit" and idea of monitoring TV for images of female anorexia, her articulacy, charm and pure capacity for work (usually 75 hours a week) should see her promoted after a second election victory.

Ask Aristotle about Tessa Jowell

Central midfielder
Clare Ward:
The youngest female in MP in the House, was seen as a leadership stooge until she recently added to the chorus of criticism of Europe minister Keith Vaz following an internal Labour investigation into his constituency.

Keen to synchronize voting rights with other legal responsibilities at one age, be it 16 or 18, she still has a long way to go, but at 28, she has the time to do it.

Ask Aristotle about Claire Ward

Striker
Harriet Harman:
Thick-skinned enough to pick up the pieces after her brutal sacking in Tony Blair's first reshuffle, Harman has recently put herself back in the running to rejoin the Cabinet with a strong serious of proposals on how to reconnect women voters with the Labour movement.

Ask Aristotle about Harriet Harman

Striker
Oona King:
It's not her fault that she's young, female, black, jewish and good looking, but on the grey-suited benches of the Commons chamber it certainly hasn't done her any harm.

An ultra-Blairite loyalist, who escaped on a fact-finding mission to Bangladesh to avoid voting for a cut in single mothers, she is well-versed in urban renewal, the new deal, international development and third world debt. With a high media profile, Labour would be silly not to use her talents during a second term. As a former aide to Glenys Kinnock in Brussels, Keith Vaz's job as Europe minister could be on the horizon.

Ask Aristotle about Oona King

The coach
Anji Hunter:
With a friendship stretching back to the age of 15, Ms Hunter is the gatekeeper of Downing Street and one of Mr Blair's closest confidantes. If Blair has a message to get across, or needs a sounding board, she is the woman he most trusts. Ms Hunter looks set to become Mr Blair's political secretary after the next election.

Ask Aristotle about Sally Keeble Right wing Yvette Cooper: The granddaughter of a miner, who went to Oxford, smoked dope, and came out with a first-class degree in PPE, is now one of Labour's brightest stars. As undersecretary of state for public health she has shone - despite a reprimand from Sir John Krebs of the Food Standards Agency after she revealed information without his permission. Her marriage to Ed Balls, the chancellor's chief adviser, ensures that Ms Cooper benefits from the support of Gordon Brown as she rises to the top. Ask Aristotle about Yvette Cooper Left wing Ruth Kelly: This industrious former journalist is the brains behind much of the government's thinking of family-friendly working practices and welfare benefits for single mothers. Having given birth to three children herself since winning her seat in 1997, she is certainly qualified to lead the putsch of working mothers into ministerial, or even Cabinet, level politics. Ask Aristotle about Ruth Kelly Central midfielder Tessa Jowell: Has been waiting in the wings since 1992, but recent behind the scenes lobbying for Tony Blair and Jack Straw to concede that marriage is not the only role model for society, and another big push for equal pay has seen her stock rise among progressive backbenchers from the 1997 intake. Mocked over her scheme for a "fat summit" and idea of monitoring TV for images of female anorexia, her articulacy, charm and pure capacity for work (usually 75 hours a week) should see her promoted after a second election victory. Ask Aristotle about Tessa Jowell Central midfielder Clare Ward: The youngest female in MP in the House, was seen as a leadership stooge until she recently added to the chorus of criticism of Europe minister Keith Vaz following an internal Labour investigation into his constituency. Keen to synchronize voting rights with other legal responsibilities at one age, be it 16 or 18, she still has a long way to go, but at 28, she has the time to do it. Ask Aristotle about Claire Ward Striker Harriet Harman: Thick-skinned enough to pick up the pieces after her brutal sacking in Tony Blair's first reshuffle, Harman has recently put herself back in the running to rejoin the Cabinet with a strong serious of proposals on how to reconnect women voters with the Labour movement. Ask Aristotle about Harriet Harman Striker Oona King: It's not her fault that she's young, female, black, jewish and good looking, but on the grey-suited benches of the Commons chamber it certainly hasn't done her any harm. An ultra-Blairite loyalist, who escaped on a fact-finding mission to Bangladesh to avoid voting for a cut in single mothers, she is well-versed in urban renewal, the new deal, international development and third world debt. With a high media profile, Labour would be silly not to use her talents during a second term. As a former aide to Glenys Kinnock in Brussels, Keith Vaz's job as Europe minister could be on the horizon. Ask Aristotle about Oona King The coach Anji Hunter: With a friendship stretching back to the age of 15, Ms Hunter is the gatekeeper of Downing Street and one of Mr Blair's closest confidantes. If Blair has a message to get across, or needs a sounding board, she is the woman he most trusts. Ms Hunter looks set to become Mr Blair's political secretary after the next election. fields.headline: The jab of conscience
fields.standfirst:
Every few days, Guardian Unlimited views the foot and mouth crisis through the eyes of a small panel of people whose lives have been directly affected. Derek Brown takes the latest soundings in his home town of Chipping Norton in west Oxfordshire

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Derek Brown takes the latest soundings in his home town of Chipping Norton in west Oxfordshire.
fields.body:
There was a steady stream of visitors over the Easter weekend - not as many as usual, but still a relief for the many traders who depend on the passing traffic. Now the town is quieter again, though there are some signals, albeit faint ones, that business is picking up.

In the countryside, footpaths and bridleways remain closed to walkers. One of the unsurprising but noteworthy results has been a very visible increase in the amount of dog mess on the town pavements: not, perhaps, a major development; but another small example of how the wretched disease is affecting everyday life.

For farmers, such urban concerns are insignificant. West Oxfordshire remains a virtual island of freedom from foot and mouth, but the peril still lurks on all sides. That in turn lends urgency to the raging debate about vaccination.

The farmer

Marilyn Ivings cares deeply about her small herd of suckler cows, which have now given birth to 22 calves, but she is totally unconvinced by the pro-vaccination argument. "It will open up a can of worms," she says.

"A vaccinated animal will still be able to harbour the disease, and could remain infective until it dies. Instead of halting foot and mouth, it could prolong it and even make it worse. I honestly think that the main problem is that they haven't been quick enough or drastic enough in combating the virus."

But what if Marilyn was ordered to have her animals vaccinated? "I think probably, that if it came to that I would have them treated, and then keep my fingers and toes crossed, hoping for the best."

The butcher

Vaccination has already opened a can of worms in terms of consumer over-reaction, with meat traders saying that they will not deal with vaccinated animals, even though there is not the slightest evidence of danger to human health.

John Kench, the high street butcher, has not yet had any customers voicing concern. "I personally would have no problem dealing with meat from animals that have been vaccinated," he says. "The problem is that so many members of the public simply don't understand the issues. There is a lot of ignorance about."

John's shop had a bumper Easter, and demand for his high quality British meat continues to be buoyant. Recent days have also brought welcome signs of a revival in his other business: outdoor catering. "I'm getting people who have cancelled events, but are now rearranging events for later in the year," he says. "I get the impression that people are now beginning to look beyond the crisis, and hoping to get back to normal."

The restaurateur

At Stones, the bar-restaurant in the heart of the town, Easter brightened the gloom of a so-far wretched year. On Easter Sunday, 60 lunches were served; not as many as owner Brian Galbraith would have expected in normal circumstances, but a decent day's business at last.

"Some of them were definitely visitors and tourists," says Brian. "But since the weekend we have had only our normal local customers."

The supermarket manager

Managers at the Co-op have also detected a dearth of passing trade. In normal times the store would get useful extra business from self catering holidaymakers, not least those who use the popular local caravan park. But, as duty manager Mark Corbett points out, the loss is not huge: "In Chipping Norton, our main market is the town itself and the surrounding villages. In the main tourist centres like Bourton on the Water and Moreton in Marsh I believe the shops are struggling a bit."

The Co-op is preparing for a big marketing push next month for Quorn, the vegetarian meat substitute. With vegetarian groups reporting that steadily growing numbers of consumers are shunning meat, Quorn could be a nice little earner for supermarkets everywhere. It's yet another small sign of the times - and a shade more pleasant than dog dirt.

fields.headline: Law ensures organised crime pays
fields.standfirst: Nick Hopkins says that if the anti-racketeering laws are to be effective, police need more power to gather evidence against Britain's 'super-criminals'
fields.trailText: Nick Hopkins says that if the anti-racketeering laws are to be effective, police need more power to gather evidence against Britain's 'super-criminals'.
fields.body:
The 'untouchables' used to be the nickname given to police squads tackling organised crime in America. Now, the term applies to the criminals themselves.

According to security sources, between 150 and 200 crime bosses are operating in the UK. Their numbers are growing and the police are finding it impossible to get anywhere near them.

These super-criminals are too far up the chain of command, too shielded by lieutenants and foot soldiers.

It has emerged today that the country's most senior officers, including Sir David Phillips, the chief constable of Kent, have urged the Home Office to consider giving them sweeping new powers, similar to the anti-racketeering laws passed in America 30 years ago which were credited with smashing mafia families in New York, Boston and Chicago.

But though the Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organisations Act (Rico) gave federal agents giddying authority - allowing investigators to concentrate on the conspiracy behind the crime, rather than the crime itself - there are two good reasons to think similar laws would not work here.

First, the UK does not have the equivalent of the tightly knit Italian/American mafia families which, over generations, had burrowed their way into unions controlling industries like rubbish collection and construction.

Rico laws allowed investigators to seize control of public bodies suspected of being infected with mafia influence, and replace the management.

Such powers wouldn't be much use in the UK. We don't have the levels of organised, systematic corruption in similar spheres.

Secondly, Rico gave the FBI the right to use evidence gathered by phone tapping in court.

This went to the heart of being able to prove conspiracy between the men who were issuing the orders, and the underlings who followed them.

In this country, such material is inadmissible as evidence. The police use wire-tapping to gather "intelligence" on suspects, but that's all.

Recently, the Home Office, after consultation with the police, decided to keep the status quo. Detectives told ministers they didn't want the techniques they use for gathering such material being described in court, giving criminals another potential advantage.

For the laws to work, police officers would have to change their mind. Without phone-tapping evidence, Rico is a tiger without any teeth.

fields.headline: Housing regulation: the basics
fields.trailText: • The Housing Corporation regulates and funds 2,000 registered social landlords that control 1.45m homes - a figure that is set to grow as more council homes are transferred to housing associations.
fields.body:
 The Housing Corporation regulates and funds 2,000 registered social landlords that control 1.45m homes - a figure that is set to grow as more council homes are transferred to housing associations.

 The corporation's regulatory powers, which cover the largest housing associations, help to assure banks and building societies that housing associations are unlikely to default on loans. Its regulation also aims at ensuring probity and good performance among associations, as well as controlling rent levels.

 An inspection regime operates for local authority housing departments, which currently control nearly 3m homes. The housing inspectorate aims to ensure that the government is getting best value for the extra sums granted to council housing. As an incentive to improve performance, councils that impress inspectors can get access to extra funds and the chance to keep control of their housing.

 The Housing Corporation is beginning to introduce a best value regime to encourage continuous improvement in housing associations. But regulation has traditionally been based on a system of minimum standards against which associations assess themselves, before validation visits take place.

 In the long term there is likely to be increasing pressure for a single housing regulator, similar to the system planned for Scotland.

fields.headline: Royals boost tourism industry
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The royal family was today lending its support to the drive to buttress Britain's multi-billion-pound tourist industry against the damage threatened by foot and mouth disease.
fields.body:
The royal family was today lending its support to the drive to buttress Britain's multi-billion-pound tourist industry against the damage threatened by foot and mouth disease.

Following the Prince of Wales's financial efforts to support farmers hit by the outbreak, the Duke of Edinburgh was entertaining world tourism chiefs on an "open for business" tour of the countryside.

Prince Philip was hosting a pre-lunch reception at Windsor Castle for the tourism VIPs, from the US, Canada, Japan and Europe.

The tour of Britain, organised by the British Tourist Authority, British Airways and national and regional tourist boards, aims to dispel the bleak image abroad of mass killing fields where animals are being slaughtered and burned on funeral pyres.

After meeting Prince Philip, the tourism industry chiefs, seen as key opinion formers, were travelling to Chequers for lunch with the prime minister, Tony Blair, before going on to 10 Downing Street for a reception hosted by the culture secretary Chris Smith.

webTitle: Joey Ramone can show William the way to victory

fields.headline: Joey Ramone can show William the way to victory
fields.standfirst: As he awaits the start of the election David Cameron, Conservative PPC for Witney, sets out a unique path for the Tories to follow. He explains why the rock legend Joey Ramone, who died this week, could provide the inspiration for a Tory revival.
fields.trailText: There is an iconic figure from the 1970s and 80s that should inspire the Conservative party this week.  I am of course referring to the hairy godfather of punk rock who recently died of cancer, Joey Ramone.
fields.body:
There is an iconic figure from the 1970s and 80s that should inspire the Conservative party this week. I am of course referring to the hairy godfather of punk rock who recently died of cancer, Joey Ramone.

What? Has another Conservative candidate flipped his lid? Before you metaphorically cart me off to the funny farm let me explain why the lead singer of The Ramones holds the key to success for the Tories in this phoney election period.

I am not suggesting that the party's law and order stance should be toughened along the lines of the lyric much quoted in obituaries this week: "Beat on the brat, beat on the brat, beat on the brat with a baseball bat." Neither am I proposing that the only response to the current state of the opinion polls is to be found in the Ramones' memorable track "I wanna be sedated." Nor am I suggesting compulsory shoulder length hair and leather jackets for members of the shadow cabinet.

The genius of the Ramones was that their songs, like Rockaway Beach or Sheena is a Punk Rocker, were incredibly short and almost unbelievably repetitive. Verses were out, perpetual choruses were in. In most tracks three chords were seen as unnecessary; two would do. Once you could hum one tune (if tune is the right word, which it isn't), you could hum them all.

Similarly, the secret of effective political communication is to find the right tune and then repeat it endlessly until the message is driven home. I once worked for a cabinet minister who used to reject press releases because, as he put it: "I've said all this before." Eventually he agreed to persevere. It was only when he came back from one event and said that people had started repeating his own message back to him that I said it was almost time to move on to something new.

The Conservatives have more than enough messages for a Ramone-style, election-winning album. There is no need for William Hague to finish all his campaign speeches with Joey's meaningless wind up to (virtually) every Ramones song "gabba, gabba hey", but I am yet to find a voter in Witney who dissents from the two chord riff: "Your taxes are up but public services have got worse."

Some commentators complain that the Conservatives have not developed enough detailed policies. This is nonsense: the party's superb Campaign Guide for Candidates is so long that you have to read it off the intranet or a CD-ROM, as printing it would clog your ageing laserjet printer for about a week.

But the key to success is in the big picture policy statements, not the fine detail. In every area of policy the Conservatives have a clear and attractive message. On Europe, keeping the pound and opposing further transfers of sovereignty from Westminster to Brussels. On crime, 3,000 more police officers on our streets. On the economy, leaving hardworking families with more of their own money to spend. On health, treating patients in line with clinical priorities rather than centrally set waiting list targets. On education, giving head teachers wide ranging powers to run their schools. Every time a coconut.

In Oxfordshire, for example, one the biggest local issues is housing. In a county with clogged roads, overcrowded schools and public services under severe pressure, there is almost universal opposition to Labour's centrally imposed plans for 40,000 more houses. People are rightly worried that the countryside could be swallowed up in a new tide of concrete, yet they are concerned about the lack of affordable housing for local people. What is the the Conservatives' answer to this puzzling conundrum? Scrap the centrally imposed national targets and let local authorities decide how many and what sort of houses should be built. Then priority can be given to affordable housing schemes and protecting the countryside.

The problem isn't the policy, which is spot on. The real difficulty is ensuring that, in spite of all the background noise of an election campaign, the message gets home to Witney's 70,000 voters over the next six weeks. So, Ramone style - with just a few chords and catchy titles in my head - I am ready to go. Gabba gabba hey.

fields.headline: Cannes unveils Palme d'Or shortlist
fields.trailText: The organisers of the 54th Cannes Film Festival have finally announced which films will be competing for this year's Palme d'Or
fields.body:
The organisers of the 54th Cannes Film Festival have finally announced which films will be competing for this year's Palme d'Or. No British films have made it into the shortlist of 23, but actress Julia Ormond is on the feature films jury. The festival explained the lateness of its announcement by pointing out that programmers saw 1,798 films, including shorts, this year. That was up 30% on 2000.

Among those selected for the festival, which runs from May 9th to 20th, are five American films, four French, two Italian and three Japanese. Two Taiwanese films are also competing, hoping to build on the success of the Oscar-winning Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, while Bosnia is on the shortlist for the first time. Norwegian actress and director Liv Ullman is presiding over the main jury, which also includes Ormond, Terry Gilliam and Charlotte Gainsbourg.

Baz Luhrman's Moulin Rouge, starring Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor is opening the festival, while Sean Penn is offering The Pledge, (starring Jack Nicholson and Benicio del Toro) and David Lynch, who won the Palme d'Or in 1990 with Wild At Heart, is entering Mulholland Drive.

Shrek, which features the voices of Eddie Murphy, Mike Myers and Cameron Diaz, becomes the first ever Hollywood animated picture in competition.

Screen Daily call this year's festival "an intriguing clash between enfant terribles of world cinema, past and present".

webTitle: Sheringham named footballer of the year

fields.headline: Sheringham named footballer of the year
fields.trailText: Teddy Sheringham has been named footballer of the year by the Football Writers' Association.
fields.body:
Teddy Sheringham has been named footballer of the year by the Football Writers' Association.

The Manchester United striker narrowly edged out David Beckham by just two votes, with Arsenal's Patrick Vieira third and Roy Keane fourth.

Sheringham, who is the first Englishman to win the award since Alan Shearer in 1994, was just one of eight United players who received votes, reflecting their domination of the domestic game.

He said: "It's an honour to receive this award bearing in mind the illustrious names who have won it in previous years. Although I'm very down and disappointed at the moment after going out of Europe on Wednesday night, this is a very special personal highlight in my career.

"I'd like to thank my team-mates for all their help and support this season. This is an award for the club as much as myself."

Sir Alex Ferguson added: "I'm delighted Teddy has been voted Footballer of the Year by the FWA. It's a fitting tribute to a player who has contributed so much to Manchester United this season.

"It's always difficult singling out individuals amongst so many great players, but Teddy has been truly exceptional for us and thoroughly deserves the award."

Paul McCarthy, chairman of the FWA, said: "Teddy's scoring feats for United have been magnificent. He has got vital goals at vital times of the season and has proven an essential component for both his club and country."

Sheringham will be presented with his award on Thursday, May 10 at a gala dinner in London.

Meanwhile Keane, Sheringham and Ryan Giggs have been short-listed for the PFA player of the year award. The trio are joined by three strikers - Arsenal's Thierry Henry, Liverpool's Emile Heskey and Ipswich's Marcus Stewart.

fields.headline: Slaughter backlog is slashed
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Downing Street today revealed new statistics suggesting that the backlogs of animals awaiting slaughter, and of slaughtered animals awaiting disposal, are significantly smaller than previously reported.
fields.body:
Downing Street today revealed new statistics suggesting that the backlogs of animals awaiting slaughter, and of slaughtered animals awaiting disposal, are significantly smaller than previously reported.

An enhanced reporting effort was being made to ensure that the figures more accurately and promptly reflect the intensified slaughter and disposal programme. It showed that in Cumbria, where at one point 200,000 carcasses were awaiting disposal, that figure is now closer to 10,000.

Similarly, the number of animals awaiting slaughter in the county - being visited today by the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon - once at 89,000, is now close to zero.

In Scotland and the north-east there is no discernible disposal backlog; while in Worcestershire it is said to be small and reducing. In Wales, the disposal backlog has fallen from 30,000 to around 4,000, and the slaughter backlog down to 10,000 from 90,000.

The disposal backlog in Devon, however, remains significant.

A Downing Street spokesman noted that there is "no room for complacency" and added: "We will continue to bear down totally on the disease in our determination to contain and eradicate it."

The announcement came against the backdrop of encouraging news on progress in combating the disease. The government's chief scientist yesterday declared the epidemic was now "fully under control".

David King said the policy of mass culling infected animals as well as healthy livestock had been successful, that the countryside had seen a significant drop in the daily number of outbreaks, an average of 27 by last Sunday compared with 43 a fortnight previously.

In addition, Maff confirmed late last night that Northamptonshire and Leicestershire had became the first parts of the country to shed their "infected area" status. The announcement releases more than 1,000 farms from infected area restrictions.

The question of vaccination, however, still remains. Prof King has refused to rule out a vaccination programme in the worst affected areas. But the National Farmers' Union president, Ben Gill, yesterday reiterated his opposition to vaccination.

Mr Gill said he had written to his union's local offices explaining why the leadership did not think vaccination was desirable. "Remember, once you start vaccinating, you can't say 'let's stop and go back to where we were'. You are committed. Animals have been exposed to the vaccine and hence the consequent problems," he said.

fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson is ready to "ruthlessly rebuild" Manchester United, reports the Daily Mail. The paper goes on to churn out a long wish-list of players whom Fergie will be "looking at". It includes: Ruud van Nistelrooy, Rivaldo, Gaizka Mendieta, Lilian Thuram, Kieron Dyer, Emmanuel Petit and Atlanta midfielder Christian Doni. They claim the victims of Fergie's rebuilding could be Phil Neville, Nicky Butt - who's still a target for Sunderland - Phil Neville, Dwight Yorke - who's interesting Chelsea and Aston Villa - and Mikael Silvestre.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson is ready to "ruthlessly rebuild" Manchester United, reports the Daily Mail. The paper goes on to churn out a long wish-list of players whom Fergie will be "looking at". It includes: Ruud van Nistelrooy, Rivaldo, Gaizka Mendieta, Lilian Thuram, Kieron Dyer, Emmanuel Petit and Atlanta midfielder Christian Doni. They claim the victims of Fergie's rebuilding could be Phil Neville, Nicky Butt - who's still a target for Sunderland - Phil Neville, Dwight Yorke - who's interesting Chelsea and Aston Villa - and Mikael Silvestre.

However the Sun reckons Fergie will stand by his "Euro flops" - but he will put them under pressure by signing three top players. No prizes for guessing the names: Van Nistelrooy, Thuram, Rivaldo and Pavel Nedved are the men the United manager is apparently after.

Meanwhile the Star says that United are "poised to hijack" Barcelona's £17m bid for 22-year-old Boca Juniors midfielder Juan Roman Riquelme.

Dennis Wise has told Claudio Ranieri he should sign Rivaldo. "Rivaldo would be the key man at Chelsea," he says. "I dream of seeing him play alongside Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Gianfranco Zola."

Arsenal are keeping tabs on Milan's reserve keeper Christian Abbiati, reports Planet Football.

Juventus are planning a £11m move for Freddie Kanoute, reports the Star. The paper quotes West Ham manager Harry Redknapp, who admits: "I've heard about their interest and it's a worry."

Ipswich have targeted Chelsea striker Eidur Gudjohnsen as the man to lead their line if they qualify for Europe, reports the Express.

Middlesbrough are preparing a £2.4m bid for Lorenzo Amoruso. His agent Andrea D'Amico confirmed: "Middlesbrough are interested in signing him. But there are a number of clubs who would like to sign him."

Newcastle are set to follow up their interest in PSV Eindhoven's Russian international sweeper Yuri Nikforov after receiving rave reviews, reports the Star. Nikforov, we can also report, was once voted Russia's sexiest footballer.

Everton midfielder Stephen Hughes will join West Ham on a free transfer in the summer, reports the Daily Mail.

Lazio captain Alessandro Nesta has ended speculation about a move to Real Madrid by insisting: "I'm staying at Lazio for another five years."

webTitle: Organic farmers criticise NFU over vaccination

fields.headline: Organic farmers criticise NFU over vaccination
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Organic farmers today hit out at the National Farmers' Union for opposing the use of vaccination to deal with the foot and mouth outbreak.
fields.body:
Organic farmers today hit out at the National Farmers' Union for opposing the use of vaccination to deal with the foot and mouth outbreak.

The Soil Association, which represents organic farmers, accused the NFU of "letting down" its members by opposing vaccination and putting economic considerations ahead of disease control.

A spokeswoman said: "Some farmers believe retailers will not take their products [after vaccination] and we think that kind of attitude, which appears to have come from the NFU, is a bit blinkered.

"Cynically, we believe this could be because there is already a good compensation package on offer for farmers who lose animals.

"We are not saying individual farmers are guilty of this but are being let down by the NFU, particularly in the hot spots of Cumbria and Devon."

Many organic farmers feel penalised by the current policy of slaughtering animals to halt the spread of foot-and-mouth.

It takes them much longer to re-establish their livestock herds with organic status but they receive no extra help.

fields.bodyText: Organic farmers today hit out at the National Farmers' Union for opposing the use of vaccination to deal with the foot and mouth outbreak. The Soil Association, which represents organic farmers, accused the NFU of "letting down" its members by opposing vaccination and putting economic considerations ahead of disease control. A spokeswoman said: "Some farmers believe retailers will not take their products [after vaccination] and we think that kind of attitude, which appears to have come from the NFU, is a bit blinkered. "Cynically, we believe this could be because there is already a good compensation package on offer for farmers who lose animals. "We are not saying individual farmers are guilty of this but are being let down by the NFU, particularly in the hot spots of Cumbria and Devon." Many organic farmers feel penalised by the current policy of slaughtering animals to halt the spread of foot-and-mouth. It takes them much longer to re-establish their livestock herds with organic status but they receive no extra help. fields.headline: Video releases
fields.trailText: In the Mood for Love | Following | What Lies Beneath
fields.body:
In the Mood for Love
Retail (£15.99) and DVD (£19.99)
Tartan Cert PG ****

Hong Kong's great stylist Wong Kar-Wai only seems to make films about love affairs, yet each is as distinctive as it is memorable. This subtle, elusive piece about a couple drawn together when they realise their partners are having an affair has more in common with Brief Encounter than his cheeky, inventive Chungking Express or his delirious, lurid Fallen Angels. It leaves much of its story unsaid and unseen, leaving you to concentrate on its central couple, a relationship that might have flowered in another time and another place. It's languid, full of quiet, still moments, and impeccably played by Tony Leung (also in Wong's last film, Happy Together) and Maggie Cheung. Where Chungking Express was full of youthful high spirits and the Mamas and Papas' harmonies, this is a film of middle-aged regrets with a haunting score by Michael Galasso making a perfect fit. It's about stilted conversations, lost opportunities and possibilities drifting away like the smoke from Leung's countless cigarettes. Wong, the director, producer and writer, ended the film "physically and financially exhausted" but he won two awards at Cannes. Can't wait for his next, a foray into sci-fi.

Following
Retail (£15.99)
Momentum Cert 15 ****

A 70-minute, black-and-white film noir debut with a micro budget and unknown actors, Following is a little gem of subterfuge, with a twisty, pitiless, unpredictable plot, amoral characters worthy of Patricia Highsmith. The director, photographer and writer was Christopher Nolan, who made this in 1998 and went on to the highly rated Memento (out to rent on April 30). An unemployed loner starts following people for something to do and discovers his target is a burglar who steals things for obscure purposes: "You take it away, you show them what they had." Lots of violation, voyeurism and intrigue follow. In a world of bloated, vacuous star vehicles, you hope a sharp, jagged little switchblade like this will find an audience.

What Lies Beneath
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Fox Pathe Cert 15 **

It's a surprise to find Robert Zemeckis dipping a toe into the horror genre, but even more of a surprise that the Roger Rabbit/Back to the Future man brings such a dearth of imagination to it. This is sub-sub-Hitchcock or sub-De Palma. At least the latter brought some flair to his Fat Alf rip-offs but this is horribly second-hand - Rear Window with a torn shower curtain and borrowings from Hitchcock's genius composer Bernard Herrmann that get more and more blatant towards an ending that is as contrived as it is mundane. If it weren't for the A-list cast, Harrison Ford and Michelle Pfeiffer, this is the sort of thing you might stumble across blearily on a minor TV channel at 1am. Ford has been through this sort of thing before in Polanski's Frantic, which at least had the semblance of a proper plot. The only frissons of genuine chills come from Pfeiffer, paler than ever and looking authentically spooked. Her eerie, tormented performance deserves a far better film.

fields.headline: Classical CD releases
fields.trailText: Handel | Verdi | Britten | Tavener | Elgar
fields.body:
Handel: Il Trionfo del Tempo e del Disinganno
York/Bertagnolli/Mingardo/Sears/Concerto Italiano/ Alessandrini
(Naive, 2 CDs) *****
£26.99

Handel returned twice to his first oratorio, premiered in Rome in 1707. Though he had already recycled much of the music of Il Trionfo del Tempo e del Disinganno in the operas Agrippina and Rinaldo, he revised and extended it as Il Trionfo del Tempo e della Verita in London in the 1730s, and then at the very end of his life, in 1757, made an English version of it as The Triumph of Time and Truth. It was clearly a work he cherished: what had been consciously written to show off his talents on his arrival in Italy is crammed with virtuoso writing and extrovert effects. Rinaldo Alessandrini conducts that original version, and certainly conveys all its youthful exuberance. The opening Sinfonia, with its crisply articulated string playing, sets the tone for everything that follows, and both the choral and the solo singing maintain the same incisive brilliance, with the soprano Deborah York and the mezzo Sara Mingardo particularly outstanding.

Verdi: Requiem
Fleming/Borodina/Bocelli/ D'Arcangelo/Kirov Chorus & Orchestra/Gergiev
(Philips, 2 CDs) **
£21.99

There is much to admire about this new recording, but it is fatally flawed. It boasts two outstanding soloists in Renée Fleming and Olga Borodina - both on their most lustrous form, turning their every contribution into an emotionally charged statement - as well as the Kirov Chorus and Orchestra responding vividly to Valery Gergiev's typically supercharged leadership. But the choice of Andrea Bocelli as the tenor is a shameful piece of commercial opportunism that calls into question the artistic credibility of the whole undertaking. Tonally and musically he is quite out of his depth, and from his first appearance in the opening Kyrie, his sour, strained tone and clumsy phrasing are totally destructive of the poise and coherence of the whole work. It is, sadly, not that much of a surprise that a serious record company should have tried to boost sales in such a way, but it is a shock that a conductor of Gergiev's stature and integrity should have gone along with it.

Britten: Peter Grimes
Pears/Watson/Pease/Kelly/ Brannigan/ROH Chorus & Orchestra/Britten
(Decca, 2 CDs) ****
£13.99

For many, Benjamin Britten's 1958 recording of his opera, with Peter Pears in the role that was created for him, is definitive. There is distinguished competition, however, and both Richard Hickox's version for Chandos, with Philip Langridge as Grimes, and Colin Davis's for Philips, with the incomparable Jon Vickers, reveal facets of the work ignored in the composer's own reading. Yet Britten's performance is still hard to resist: he articulates all the orchestral detail with exemplary care, and besides Pears, the the cast - especially Claire Watson's Ellen Orford, James Pease's Balstrode, and Owen Brannigan's Swallow - is first-rate. The remastering is vivid: almost too clear, when previously undetectable studio noise intrudes.

Tavener: Total Eclipse; Agraphon
Rozario/Harle/Robson/ Gilchrist/New College, Oxford Choir/Academy of Ancient Music/Goodwin
(Harmonia Mundi) **
£14.99

Total Eclipse, first performed last June, is John Tavener's second work to use a period-instrument orchestra, which here is pitted against the splenetic soprano saxophone of John Harle and the far more evocative solo voices of countertenor of Christopher Robson and tenor James Gilchrist, with New College Choir. They sing a text from the gospels compiled by Tavener's regular collaborator Mother Thekla, which describes St Paul's conversion on the road to Damascus. It is music that makes great use of spatial effects and, according to the composer, should be performed in a "petrified ecstasy". In this work and in Agraphon, a 1995 setting for the soprano Patricia Rozario of a modern Greek devotional text, Tavener's admirers will no doubt find the mixture of becalmed contemplation and assertive grandeur as potent as the rest of us find it banal.

Elgar: String Quartet; Piano Quintet
Brown/Sorrel Quartet
(Chandos) ***
£14.99

The String Quartet and the Piano Quintet make a natural coupling, both composed towards the end of the first world war when Elgar retreated from London to the Sussex countryside to concentrate upon chamber music. The Brahmsian Quintet is the more direct and expansive piece, the Quartet the more personal and elusive, with the forms of its three moments drastically compressed. The Sorrel Quartet sound more at ease when partnering the pianist Ian Brown in the Quintet, and their performance is by turns affectionate and bold. In the quartet, though, they never quite get to grips with the terseness of the argument, nor find the ideal balance between maintaining the music's onward flow of invention and allowing its phrases the space to make their expressive point.

fields.headline: Renegade rhythm
fields.standfirst: Andrew Clements  praises Herbert Henck's illumination of two pianistic provocateurs
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements praises Herbert Henck's illumination of two pianistic provocateurs
fields.body:
Antheil & Nancarrow: Piano Music Herbert Henck
(ECM) *****
£14.99

As well as being a superb technician, the pianist Herbert Henck always puts together his discs with great thoughtfulness. This brilliantly executed programme of the renegade American composers Conlon Nancarrow and George Antheil may seem an unlikely juxtaposition, but it makes musical sense.

The little group of works by Nancarrow with which Henck begins his recital are all early pieces. They pre-date the great adventures in tempo and polyrhythm that came after he settled in Mexico in the wake of the McCarthy witch-hunts and began composing almost exclusively for the player piano. In both the Three 2-part Studies of around 1940 and the tiny Prelude and Blues, both from 1935, the sources of Nancarrow's inspirations are clear - the rhythmic energy and the syncopation come from jazz, while the clarity and the contrapuntal ingenuity stem from neoclassicism in general and Stravinsky in particular.

Jazz and Stravinsky had also been the main inspirations of Antheil's music more than a decade earlier, when this self-styled "bad boy of music" left the US (in 1922) to live in Europe for 11 years, touring as a pianist and scandalising his audiences with his own provocative compositions. At a recital in Paris in 1923, he played his Airplane Sonata, Sonata Sauvage and Mechanisms (all three included here by Henck, alongside the Jazz Sonata, and the Sonatina, of the same vintage, and the Sonatina for radio written six years later). The outraged reaction recalled that surrounding The Rite of Spring a decade earlier, though Erik Satie, who clearly recognised a kindred spirit, publicly supported Antheil.

Now it is hard to appreciate what it was about these pieces that generated such a fuss. Soon after they were performed their language became commonplace. It seems to have been Antheil's confrontational style of playing, with its huge extremes of dynamics and tempi, that was the main provocation.

Yet the music is still immensely attractive, full of vigour and harmonic daring - some untethered harmonies anticipate the more abandoned moments of Messiaen, other insouciant tunes sound like close cousins of the music of the Parisian Les Six, and yet other works are entirely rhythmic. Antheil was fascinated by machines, suggesting a link with the Futurists. The kinds of effects he was looking for - massive rhythmic complexity, and a complete independence between the two hands at the keyboard - are precisely those that encouraged Nancarrow, a quarter of a century later, to devote himself to the player piano.

As far as I know, the two composers never met, but had they done so, they would have found they had a lot in common, as Henck so lucidly demonstrates.

webTitle: Jazz CD of the week: Steve Slagle: New New York

fields.headline: Easy freedoms
fields.standfirst: John Fordham  hails an unpretentious alto star
fields.trailText: John Fordham hails an unpretentious alto star
fields.body:
Steve Slagle New New York
(Omnitone) ****
£14.99

Alto saxophonist Steve Slagle isn't widely known in the UK. His pedigree as a playing partner, though, is spectacular; he has collaborated with celebrity leaders such as Lionel Hampton and Woody Herman, as well as the Charlie Haden Liberation Music Orchestra via Steve Kuhn and Ray Barretto.

This disc, a tribute to Slagle's adopted home-town, reveals how much he has absorbed through thousands of improvising nights with countless contrasting partners. His biting alto tone and rugged lyricism not only drive a succession of powerful solos, but also shape some strong original pieces.

Slagle performs in a quartet of regular associates - Dave Stryker on guitar, who spans the world of Wes Montgomery and John Scofield, the sonorous Cameron Brown on bass, and a fine, clean-hitting drummer, Gene Jackson. There are no world-music diversions, passages of electronic impressionism, DJs, or classical special effects here - but there are vistas of musical space.

The strength of the original pieces sags a little half-way down the playlist, when a jaunty jazz-rhumba, a piece of Hudson-at-dawn flute impressionism and a rattly Latin feature put the thematic distinctiveness on hold. But two-thirds of the record is intelligent, co-operative and expressive contemporary jazz.

The set is bookended by two accounts of the waywardly graceful, Ornette Coleman-like theme of the album title - two accounts because guitarist Stryker, caught in New York traffic, missed the first take. Slagle cuts into the piece with his funky swing and alternately quacky and deep-thoated tone, and Jackson is a compelling splice of the fizzy energy of Billy Higgins and the bumpy, offbeat relaxation of the late Ed Blackwell.

The same sense of easy freedom is caught by Loftology, the first free-wheeling exchange between Slagle's alto and Joe Lovano's tenor. The second, Thelonious, features some chorus-swapping between the two saxophonists that makes you leap out of your chair. Between them comes a piece of sleazy, bottleneck-guitar bluesiness that could have easily fitted on a Bill Frisell or John Scofield disc.

Slagle plays soprano sax once, like a whoopier Wayne Shorter, on the initially fragmentary and then gently swinging St Mark's Shuffle: he harmonises spine-tinglingly with Stryker's clangy guitar chords. All in all, this is unpretentiously exhilarating music.

fields.headline: Jazz CD releases
fields.trailText: Chris Potter: Gratitude | Mat Maneri: Trinity | Various Artists: Slamfest
fields.body:
Chris Potter Gratitude
(Verve/Universal) ***
£13.99

American Chris Potter is one of the most original, resourceful and intelligent saxophonists on the post-bop scene, and his recent appearances in Britain with the bands of Steve Swallow, Paul Motian and Dave Holland have testified to it. But since he usually shines in appearances with other leaders, perhaps it is not so surprising that this set under his own direction isn't a total killer. Responsibility has preoccupied Potter here, and almost all the pieces are devoted to one or other of his musical heroes.

As if he were overwhelmed by their example, there are fewer instances than you might expect of Potter's remarkable ability to pack more melodic invention and tonal variety into a short sax solo than many of his contemporaries can manage all night. Also, the themes themselves are substantially slighter than Potter's spontaneous ideas, which wouldn't matter so much if they were not given quite so much lingering attention. Maybe it represents the dues-paying set that he has to get off his chest.

Mat Maneri Trinity
(ECM) ***
£14.99

This is a solo violin set from Mat Maneri, the man the sleevenotes strikingly refer to as having "played Aron to Joe Maneri's Moses" on four earlier ECM sets. The Maneris have specialised in an aspect of free improvisation not always apparent to the idiom's allies, let alone its detractors: a parallel to orthodox music's expressive lyricism and dynamic delicacy. But whereas Mat Maneri has frequently explored electronics on his father's often exhilaratingly rich and subtle works, ECM boss Manfred Eicher asked him to stay with acoustic violin and viola here. As a result, the soloist's seamless merging of jazz phrasing with the sense of space and fragile nuances of chamber music is very sympathetically presented.

Sometimes Maneri will spiral off into passages that sound like Stephane Grappelli and Billy Bang combined; at others he will echo the sax-phrasing of Eric Dolphy or the compositional atmosphere of Elliott Carter. A good deal of the music is very tranquil and slow-moving. John Coltrane's Sun Ship emphasises the contrast between Maneri's sometimes dolorously fluid intonation (like a deep sitar) and his staccato phrasing on the viola, and Eric Dolphy's Iron Man on violin skims and leaps with an unexpectedly lamb-like eagerness. Some people will find this a lot of uncompromisingly personal, single-voice, non-idiomatic music within a narrow instrumental span. But for admirers of unadulterated cutting-edge strings-improv, it is fascinating.

Various Artists Slamfest
(SLAMCD) ***

Oxford-based George Haslam is an entire jazz scene on his own. Not only is he a fine baritone saxophonist with a distinct signature, he has a unique line to the Argentinian jazz world (recently celebrated by his joint UK/Argentinian touring band), and he runs SLAM, a record label documenting the continuing work of that neglected school of influential and productive British free-jazzers including Elton Dean, Nick Evans and Keith Tippett. This double CD covers the SLAM Records festival that took place in London in July 1999, and features bands including Dean, pianists Tippett and Howard Riley, saxophonists Lol Coxhill and Harrison Smith, trombonist Paul Rutherford and many others.

Some of the music is quiet, meticulous, pulseless improv, like the slowly unfolding 20-minute conversation between Coxhill's squirmy soprano, Haslam's grainy baritone and the mobile, rubbery trombone of Rutherford. Elsewhere, it is powerfully offbeat and insistent free jazz - listen to Keith Tippett's absolutely blistering piano solo on Dreamtime's Careful Driver, driven by the furious drum undercurrents of Jim LaBaigue, for a reminder of how substantial a figure that West Country keyboard star is.

Harrison Smith's dark, liquid bass clarinet stealthily treads an undergrowth sown by the fine pianist Liam Noble among others; Elton Dean and Howard Riley confirm the virtues of a long and sympathetic dialogue; and the remarkable vocalist Phil Minton puts in a typically arresting appearance.

Three appearances by the sextet Dreamtime, featuring Tippett, anchor the collection. This kind of exploratory music-making isn't to everybody's taste - the tracks may seem pretty long - but it is a powerful blast from a pungent and characterful corner of contemporary music. (Slam Productions is at 3 Thesiger Road, Abingdon, OX14 2DX.)

fields.headline: Egg unveils robust results
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: The internet bank claims it is confident of breaking even by the end of this year, writes Amy Vickers.
19.02.2001: Egg's losses increase
14.12.2001: Egg emerges as leading independent online bank
fields.body:
Internet bank Egg raised a few smiles in the internet sector this morning when it revealed robust first-quarter results and said it was confident of breaking even by the end of this year.

Egg, the best-performing British bank stock in 2001 so far, has had a strong start to the year.

It added 224,000 customers in the first quarter - a 60% improvement on the final quarter of 2000.

Egg, which is now one of the world's biggest internet-only banks, said it now had 1.575m customers.

It posted a 14% increase in operating income to £36.5m, and first-quarter net losses narrowed as Egg increased loans to credit-card holders.

The bank reported a pre-tax loss of £37.9m, an improvement of £400,000 - or 1.1% - on the first quarter last year.

The chief executive, Paul Gratton, said: "Egg is proving attractive to a market that is becoming comfortable with using technology to manage its financial affairs."

Shares in Egg, which debuted last June at 160p, are back on an upward climb.

They are now close to the IPO price after sinking as low as 95p last year.

Related stories

webTitle: War on superbugs enlists genetic codes

fields.headline: War on superbugs enlists genetic codes
fields.trailText: Scientists hope to strike back against superbugs by unravelling the genetic codes of two of the feared organisms that have built up resistance to antibiotics.
fields.body:
Scientists hope to strike back against superbugs by unravelling the genetic codes of two of the feared organisms that have built up resistance to antibiotics.

Researchers in Japan have decoded the sequences that make up the DNA of two drug-resisting strains of staphylococcus aureus. One, methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), has become endemic in hospitals, where it infects patients who have had operations, and the other, VRSA, has developed resistance to the "last resort" antibiotic vancomycin, until recently an effective treatment against MRSA. Scientists must find new ways of fighting such bugs, including through vaccines, because even new antibiotics appear soon to lose their edge against the bugs.

The researchers from Juntendo University, Tokyo, outline their work in today's edition of the Lancet.

They found 70 new genes which could affect the bugs' infectious power and be targets for new drugs. They also found that the genes had been acquired from other living things, and that critical antibiotic-resistant genes can spread between different strains of S. aureus and between different species.

fields.headline: The tiger unleashed
fields.standfirst: Ruby gets her claws out, Janet Jackson struggles to be seductive and Mark Mulcahy does a few vocal somersaults in this week’s pop albums
fields.trailText: Ruby gets her claws out, Janet Jackson struggles to be seductive and Mark Mulcahy does a few vocal somersaults in this week’s pop albums
fields.body:
Ruby Short-Staffed at the Gene Pool
(Wichita) ***
£13.99

Despite favourable critical reaction to 1995's Salt Peter, her first album as Ruby, Lesley Rankine never lived up to the next-cool-thing status briefly conferred on her in the mid-1990s. Every ounce as bilious as sister Scot Shirley Manson, she lacks Manson's pop proclivities, so while the latter sells millions with Garbage, Rankine's trip-hoppy mutterings reach a more select audience. Short-Staffed at the Gene Pool has taken six years to materialise, during which Rankine lived in New Orleans and Seattle, adding new, mainly beats-based sounds to her portfolio. At the same time, her vocals acquired a feline sinuousness, though the feline is a tiger rather than a pussycat, claws unsheathed even at seductive moments. She titles a song Roses for the malevolent delight of whispering "I don't smell like roses", and another Sweet Is so that she can perversely claim "Sweet is the wind that brings tragedy". If Dido's too wet, try this. (CS)

Isaac Hayes The Man! The Ultimate Isaac Hayes 1967-1977
(Stax) *****
£14.99

Isaac Hayes's stock has plummeted of late, following a lacklustre mid-1990s comeback, scientology dabblings and South Park. However, from his solo debut in 1968 to his bankruptcy in 1977 with $6m of unsettled debts, he reinvented black music. For all his potential preposterousness, Hayes was a three-dimensional figure: his men openly ached. Today, rappers cover the bones of a song and build a new tale around it, but Hayes was there first. He wrestles with Walk On By for 12 minutes, while his extraordinary version of By the Time I Get to Phoenix takes 19 dignified minutes to reach its destination. Moreover, before the song itself kicks in, Hayes has narrated a harrowing back- story, recasting the saga in the ghetto. He could also up the tempo: Theme from Shaft is as taut and funky as it was nearly 30 years ago, while his finest moment was Ike's Mood 1, a symphonic instrumental which, by its climax, carries echoes of Ennio Morricone's Battle of Algiers - set, inevitably, in the ghetto. (JA)

Janet Jackson All for You
(Virgin) **
£14.99

Despite giving every outward appearance of being uninterested in her musical career, Janet has been the most popular Jackson for a decade. She has been lucky, for while she receives a co-writing credit on all tracks, she is essentially the plaything of producers and co-songwriters Terry Lewis and Jimmy "Jam" Harris III. When they are on their game, creating absorbing backgrounds - on the exhilarating Trust a Try and the feisty duet with Carly Simon, Son of a Gun - then Jackson sounds as if she is the disco queen. Alas, for the most part here, Jam and Lewis tread water, resulting in a succession of lazy, anodyne ballads such as Truth and Better Days, which leave Jackson's underpowered voice overexposed. The nadir, however, is the embarrassing Would You Mind, where Jackson attempts sexy. "I'm gonna kiss you, suck you, taste you, ride you," she claims, with laughable libidinousness. Tragically, her squeaky serenade is skin-crawlingly akin to being seduced by a member of Minipops. (JA)

Serge Gainsbourg I Love Serge: Gainsbourg Electronica
(Mercury) ****
£13.99

Ten years after his death, Serge Gainsbourg's reputation continues to precede him. Outside France, he remains better known as a lecherous old goat than a songwriter; when his songs are discussed, attention focuses on words before music. Unsurprising given Gainsbourg's lyrical preoccupation with farting and underage sex, but a shame: Gainsbourg took risks, experimenting freely with African rhythms, reggae and disco. Air and Portishead have revered his 1971 album Histoire de Melody Nelson, a fusion of tremulous orchestration and rhythmic punch. Sadly, neither grace this remix collection, and their absence is felt throughout Howie B's flat reworking of Ballade de Melody Nelson. Elsewhere, Gainsbourg's breathy growl is the perfect companion to an array of beats. Bob Sinclar remixes Marabout into joyful house and the Orb's Requiem Pour un Con surrounds slinky beats with a pervasive aura of sleaze. Gainsbourg, who once attempted to popularise a dance in which men jigged around clutching their partner's breasts, would undoubtedly approve. (AP)

Firstborn When It Hits You, Feel No Pain
(Independiente) **
£14.99

Twenty-five years after its heyday, northern soul still reverberates through British music. You hear its echoes in the tinny euphoria former northern DJ Pete Waterman constructs for Steps and the rolling pianos behind Belle and Sebastian's bedsit melancholy. Its influence continues, unaffected by fashion, because northern soul has anachronism in-built: even during its mid-1970s peak, the scene's biggest records were 10 years old, relics of a Motown-influenced sound replaced by disco, yet still worshipped in England's north-west. Accordingly, northern soul has transcended its American origins and become shorthand for a particularly British, working-class combination of perseverance and escapism. Its slogan? "Keep the faith." None of this is lost on Dublin producer Oisin Lunny, whose debut album fuses northern soul samples and pounding techno to create a grim picture of urban nightlife. But if Lunny understands northern soul's romantic image, the music's uplifting spirit has bypassed him: he unearths northern soul heroine Mary Love, then reworks her life-affirming Lay this Burden Down as a turgid dirge. Worse, Irish author Bennan Murphy rants, swears and humourlessly intones Bob Dylan lyrics throughout the album. Keeping the faith never sounded such hard work. (AP)

Lil Bow Wow Beware of Dog
(Columbia) ***
£14.99

Hip-hop's canine obsession continues apace with Lil Bow Wow, born Bryan-Michael Cox 13 years ago in Columbus, Ohio. Discovered by Snoop "Doggy" Dogg when, aged 6, he made his stage debut on Dr Dre's Chronic tour, he is already a phenomenon in the US, with a slew of hits in the rap charts and a platinum album to his name. Beware of Dog features Snoop, LL Cool J and Da Brat, but it was the involvement of Jermaine Dupri (the writer/producer behind novelty early-1990s kid-rap duo Kriss Kross) that ensured its success. The material is profanity-free - on the Timbaland-ish Puppy Love, LBW is a PG-rated playa, while This Playboy conflates G-Funk smoothie Warren G's This DJ and nursery rhyme This Old Man - but everything else, from the boy's fast-and-loose delivery to his relentless self-promotion, is for adults only. (PL)

Dion Born to Be With You / Streetheart (Ace) ****
£12.99

By 1975, even his most ardent admirers had more or less given up on Phil Spector. But then, out of the blue, he came up with two singles as extraordinary as anything he had made during his golden era. Inevitably, in a world preparing itself for the arrival of punk, both sank without trace. The first was Darlene Love's incandescent Lord, If You're a Woman; the second was Dion's Make the Woman Love Me, a masterpiece of introspection. For the occasion, Spector reassembled the Wrecking Crew - the session musicians responsible for his original Wall of Sound - and applied them to a song written by Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil, the composers of You've Lost that Lovin' Feelin'. Almost all the characteristic ingredients are present: the floating haze of acoustic guitars, the thick carpet of low-pitched horns, the filmy choral mist and, front and centre, the implacable backbeat. Only the strings are missing - in deference, surely, to Dion DiMucci, whose sinewy voice was bred on the streets of the Bronx. His highly wrought performance reminded listeners of what a wonderful singer Dion had always been, from A Teenager in Love through Runaround Sue to his superlative version of Ruby Baby in the mid-1960s. A second single, a version of the Chordettes' 1956 hit Born to Be With You, lent its title to the subsequent album and also attracted a cult following, although it is less spectacular than Make the Woman Love Me. Now reissued by Ace in tandem with Streetheart, a perfectly listenable slice of high-gloss Hollywood rock produced by Steve Barry and Michael O'Martian the following year, it offers a chance to hear the last significant flowering of an authentic pop genius. (RW)

Marcos Valle Escape
(Far Out Recordings) **
£14.99

These are tough times for Brazilian music, as Cuba's domination of the Latin scene continues. This new set by one of the key figures in the 1960s bossa-nova movement is, for the most part, merely a reminder of past glories. The production work may be exquisite (thanks to the likes of 4Hero) but take away the cool, squeaky funk effects and Valle's own classy guitar and keyboard solos, and this is still music for the Girl from Ipanema in the chill-out lounge. Most of the songs are pleasant and immaculately performed, with the expected careful balance of light, rapid percussion and jazz-funk instrumental work with laid-back vocals, both from Valle and Patricia Alvi, but they lack any real sense of surprise or innovation. Even less interesting are the soporific instrumental tracks, such as the inappropriately titled Poweride. But there is one track here that shows there could be new life in Valle's bossa nova yet. Festeira shows off his slick and funky acoustic guitar work at its best, with help from some gently impressive percussion playing. It isn't the promised "total reincarnation of bossa nova", but it's one step in the right direction. (RD)

Richard Hawley Richard Hawley
(Setanta) ***

Sheffield guitarist Richard Hawley has had a chequered career, plying his fretwork for All Saints, Pulp, Finlay Quaye and Perry Farrell while labouring for longer in his own bands Treebound Story and the Longpigs. None of these roads should lead to a sepia-tinged collection of 1950s-influenced ballads. However, with a haunting croon, a tremelo bar and an echo chamber the size of the Mersey tunnel, his first solo album effortlessly conjures up the days when all rockers were called Buddy, Gene or Eddie, and songs were listened to while perfecting a curl of the upper lip. Hawley's songs are so eerie you can almost smell the hair grease, yet strangely timeless: the religious awe of Coming Home is as much Spiritualised as Gene Vincent. As Elvis and Roy Orbison would testify, never underestimate the appeal of a leather-clad, lonely boy. (DS)

Slimm Calhoun The Skinny
(Aquemini/Elektra) ****

Slimm is the first signing to Outkast's Aquemini label and as such is already being talked of as the next big playa from Atlanta's rap game. He's certainly got the tunes. With an old-skool feel to his beats and hooks big enough to land an octopus, his southern-fried rap style packs real gusto. "The Skinny" means "street info"; in practice, this means lots of stuff about bitches, hoes and dealing. But there's poignancy here too, even though it sometimes feels like Slimm has stumbled on it accidentally. It's OK's hookline - "All these lonely girls just wanna fuck" - contains an eerie, modern bleakness more powerful that braggadocio. Calhoun may be illiberal and confused, but he knows how society made him that way. (DS)

Mark Mulcahy Smile Sunset
(Loose) ****
£11.99

Sometimes a record comes along that is so magical, you almost wish its maker would never make another - a disappointing follow-up would be unbearable. Fathering, Mark Mulcahy's 1999 debut solo, was one of those records; thankfully, so is Smile Sunset. Its wonderful songs are by turns cheeky, subtle, rinkydink, passionate and simple, and Mulcahy's voice is so velvety you want to stroke it. A Cup of Tea and Your Insights ends with him repeating the line " 'Cause I know that I could be all right" for a couple of minutes, shaking it in the air like a silk sheet. The music is beautiful, enriched with cello, mandolin and piano accompaniments, but the best songs find Mulcahy alone, singing to his plaintive guitar and tinkling glockenspiel. Wake Up Whispering is a honeyed lullaby love song; even better is The Quiet One. It starts fluttery but kicks in with the lines "What kind of drugs have you done tonight/ You've got a face like a lava light", and starts to swirl satisfyingly in sync with that image. (MC)

Reviews by Caroline Sullivan, Alexis Petridis, John Aizlewood, Robin Denselow, Paul Lester, Richard Williams, Dave Simpson and Maddy Costa.

Accordingly, northern soul has transcended its American origins and become shorthand for a particularly British, working-class combination of perseverance and escapism. Its slogan? "Keep the faith." None of this is lost on Dublin producer Oisin Lunny, whose debut album fuses northern soul samples and pounding techno to create a grim picture of urban nightlife. But if Lunny understands northern soul's romantic image, the music's uplifting spirit has bypassed him: he unearths northern soul heroine Mary Love, then reworks her life-affirming Lay this Burden Down as a turgid dirge. Worse, Irish author Bennan Murphy rants, swears and humourlessly intones Bob Dylan lyrics throughout the album. Keeping the faith never sounded such hard work. (AP) Lil Bow Wow Beware of Dog (Columbia) *** £14.99 Hip-hop's canine obsession continues apace with Lil Bow Wow, born Bryan-Michael Cox 13 years ago in Columbus, Ohio. Discovered by Snoop "Doggy" Dogg when, aged 6, he made his stage debut on Dr Dre's Chronic tour, he is already a phenomenon in the US, with a slew of hits in the rap charts and a platinum album to his name. Beware of Dog features Snoop, LL Cool J and Da Brat, but it was the involvement of Jermaine Dupri (the writer/producer behind novelty early-1990s kid-rap duo Kriss Kross) that ensured its success. The material is profanity-free - on the Timbaland-ish Puppy Love, LBW is a PG-rated playa, while This Playboy conflates G-Funk smoothie Warren G's This DJ and nursery rhyme This Old Man - but everything else, from the boy's fast-and-loose delivery to his relentless self-promotion, is for adults only. (PL) Dion Born to Be With You / Streetheart (Ace) **** £12.99 By 1975, even his most ardent admirers had more or less given up on Phil Spector. But then, out of the blue, he came up with two singles as extraordinary as anything he had made during his golden era. Inevitably, in a world preparing itself for the arrival of punk, both sank without trace. The first was Darlene Love's incandescent Lord, If You're a Woman; the second was Dion's Make the Woman Love Me, a masterpiece of introspection. For the occasion, Spector reassembled the Wrecking Crew - the session musicians responsible for his original Wall of Sound - and applied them to a song written by Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil, the composers of You've Lost that Lovin' Feelin'. Almost all the characteristic ingredients are present: the floating haze of acoustic guitars, the thick carpet of low-pitched horns, the filmy choral mist and, front and centre, the implacable backbeat. Only the strings are missing - in deference, surely, to Dion DiMucci, whose sinewy voice was bred on the streets of the Bronx. His highly wrought performance reminded listeners of what a wonderful singer Dion had always been, from A Teenager in Love through Runaround Sue to his superlative version of Ruby Baby in the mid-1960s. A second single, a version of the Chordettes' 1956 hit Born to Be With You, lent its title to the subsequent album and also attracted a cult following, although it is less spectacular than Make the Woman Love Me. Now reissued by Ace in tandem with Streetheart, a perfectly listenable slice of high-gloss Hollywood rock produced by Steve Barry and Michael O'Martian the following year, it offers a chance to hear the last significant flowering of an authentic pop genius. (RW) Marcos Valle Escape (Far Out Recordings) ** £14.99 These are tough times for Brazilian music, as Cuba's domination of the Latin scene continues. This new set by one of the key figures in the 1960s bossa-nova movement is, for the most part, merely a reminder of past glories. The production work may be exquisite (thanks to the likes of 4Hero) but take away the cool, squeaky funk effects and Valle's own classy guitar and keyboard solos, and this is still music for the Girl from Ipanema in the chill-out lounge. Most of the songs are pleasant and immaculately performed, with the expected careful balance of light, rapid percussion and jazz-funk instrumental work with laid-back vocals, both from Valle and Patricia Alvi, but they lack any real sense of surprise or innovation. Even less interesting are the soporific instrumental tracks, such as the inappropriately titled Poweride. But there is one track here that shows there could be new life in Valle's bossa nova yet. Festeira shows off his slick and funky acoustic guitar work at its best, with help from some gently impressive percussion playing. It isn't the promised "total reincarnation of bossa nova", but it's one step in the right direction. (RD) Richard Hawley Richard Hawley (Setanta) *** Sheffield guitarist Richard Hawley has had a chequered career, plying his fretwork for All Saints, Pulp, Finlay Quaye and Perry Farrell while labouring for longer in his own bands Treebound Story and the Longpigs. None of these roads should lead to a sepia-tinged collection of 1950s-influenced ballads. However, with a haunting croon, a tremelo bar and an echo chamber the size of the Mersey tunnel, his first solo album effortlessly conjures up the days when all rockers were called Buddy, Gene or Eddie, and songs were listened to while perfecting a curl of the upper lip. Hawley's songs are so eerie you can almost smell the hair grease, yet strangely timeless: the religious awe of Coming Home is as much Spiritualised as Gene Vincent. As Elvis and Roy Orbison would testify, never underestimate the appeal of a leather-clad, lonely boy. (DS) Slimm Calhoun The Skinny (Aquemini/Elektra) **** Slimm is the first signing to Outkast's Aquemini label and as such is already being talked of as the next big playa from Atlanta's rap game. He's certainly got the tunes. With an old-skool feel to his beats and hooks big enough to land an octopus, his southern-fried rap style packs real gusto. "The Skinny" means "street info"; in practice, this means lots of stuff about bitches, hoes and dealing. But there's poignancy here too, even though it sometimes feels like Slimm has stumbled on it accidentally. It's OK's hookline - "All these lonely girls just wanna fuck" - contains an eerie, modern bleakness more powerful that braggadocio. Calhoun may be illiberal and confused, but he knows how society made him that way. (DS) Mark Mulcahy Smile Sunset (Loose) **** £11.99 Sometimes a record comes along that is so magical, you almost wish its maker would never make another - a disappointing follow-up would be unbearable. Fathering, Mark Mulcahy's 1999 debut solo, was one of those records; thankfully, so is Smile Sunset. Its wonderful songs are by turns cheeky, subtle, rinkydink, passionate and simple, and Mulcahy's voice is so velvety you want to stroke it. A Cup of Tea and Your Insights ends with him repeating the line " 'Cause I know that I could be all right" for a couple of minutes, shaking it in the air like a silk sheet. The music is beautiful, enriched with cello, mandolin and piano accompaniments, but the best songs find Mulcahy alone, singing to his plaintive guitar and tinkling glockenspiel. Wake Up Whispering is a honeyed lullaby love song; even better is The Quiet One. It starts fluttery but kicks in with the lines "What kind of drugs have you done tonight/ You've got a face like a lava light", and starts to swirl satisfyingly in sync with that image. (MC) Reviews by Caroline Sullivan, Alexis Petridis, John Aizlewood, Robin Denselow, Paul Lester, Richard Williams, Dave Simpson and Maddy Costa.

fields.headline: Ericsson to cut 10,000 more jobs
fields.trailText:
11.45am: The mobile phone giant has announced the measures in response to a 90% drop in profits for the first quarter of 2001.
20.04.2001: Ericsson and Sony discuss mobile phone alliance
27.03.2001: Ericsson cuts back in the UK
fields.body:
Swedish mobile phone giant Ericsson has added to the gloom surrounding the technology sector by cutting 10,000 jobs from its workforce.

The beleaguered group made the announcement as it posted a 90% drop in profits to £41m for the first three months of the year.

Ericsson's vice-president, Roland Klein, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme the reluctance of mobile phone companies to invest in next generation wireless networks had left the company with no alternative.

"We have to react to this because our organisation is tuned into growth in the area of 30%, as we had last year," he said.

"At the moment, the market is being hit very hard by the recession but also by the reluctance of operators to invest... but we trust our operation," he added.

The cutbacks announced today are in addition to the plans Ericsson disclosed last month to cut 3,300 jobs, mostly in Sweden and Britain, which will affect staff based in Carlton, Nottinghamshire, and in Scunthorpe.

However, Finnish rival and market leader Nokia underlined the value of the mobile phone market by reporting first-quarter profits of £875m.

Nokia now has 31% of the global mobile phone market and is aiming to squeeze the likes of Ericsson further by increaseing its share to 40%.

But Nokia added the looming threat of a worldwide recession made it difficult to predict the company's prospects for the year ahead.

Despite today's news, the e-commerce minister, Patricia Hewitt, remained optimistic about the industry's future.

"We have talked to Ericsson. We are working with it to try to minimise the number of job losses here in the UK and to ensure that where people do lose their jobs we do everything possible to make sure they get new jobs fast," she said.

"Despite these very short-term difficulties, Ericsson is pretty optimistic about the longer-term prospects," Ms Hewitt added.

Ericsson's woes are reflected across the telecoms equipment sector, with Motorola, Siemens and Marconi also announcing cuts.
