webTitle: CD of the week: Ash: Free All Angels

fields.headline: Young, gifted - and back
fields.standfirst: A rejuvenated Ash have put the fun back into teenage nostalgia, says  Betty Clarke
fields.trailText: A rejuvenated Ash have put the fun back into teenage nostalgia, says Betty Clarke
fields.body:
Ash Free All Angels
(Infectious Records) ****
£13.99

Nowadays it's not cool to be young and enjoy it. Instead, adolescence is surrounded by negativity and teenagers just bemoan the fact that they have their whole lives in front of them. Fun without responsibility has been diluted by the likes of Wheatus, who celebrate the poor personal hygiene and dodgy taste in music that youth entails, by Westlife and their middle-aged, middle-of-the-road sentiments, and by dismissive declarations of "my generation" from the greying Limp Bizkit. Where are the head-spinning thrills, the heart-stopping lust, the celebration of golden summer holidays that seem to last for ever?

Step forward Ash, who (while they themselves wrestle with the complexities of mid-20s angst) have crystallised the pleasure and pain of being a teen. Back in 1996, when they kicked up some punk-pop dust with the single Kung Fu, Tim Wheeler, Mark Hamilton and Rick McMurray were the naughtiest kids in the Britpop class. Juggling a record deal with their A-levels, they hit the charts with the adrenaline-filled debut album 1977. Spawning indie classics Girl from Mars and Oh Yeah, 1977 conjured up playground longings and Kodak memories and set them to lush melodies and spiky guitars. Ash held on to their innocent exuberance, their Star Wars fixation and the knowledge that girls were an unknown but desired quantity.

Following a foray into soundtracks with A Life Less Ordinary, Ash acquired a new guitarist in Charlotte Hatherley and released their second album, Nu-Clear Sounds. But the joy had evaporated into thrash and an affection for the Jesus and Mary Chain that vanquished the optimism and fun of the past. Personally, things weren't so great either. After two years of non-stop pop, the sweetness of success turned bitter for Wheeler, who gradually retreated into depression. Cue 18 months of suffering, silence and recovery.

But with Free All Angels, Ash have rediscovered their enthusiasm, and Wheeler - not just the singer but the band's chief songwriter - has a smile on his face. From the beginning, you know it's going to be good. Walking Barefoot has that trademark sense of nostalgia for a time you're still experiencing. A great festival song, it's about relishing a perfect moment while knowing it's about to come to an end. "Remember when the sun was hot, remember when the days were long," Wheeler sings, a homage to both lazy days and golden years.

The perfect pop ethic of simple, epic singalong songs continues with Shining Star, Ash's greatest single since Girl from Mars, a celebration of someone special in sixth-form prose. World Domination is another call to arms to kids everywhere to kick off their trainers and jump up and down. With its "we don't give a fuck how we're meant to be" feelgood factor, plus count-in intro, speeding drums and rock guitars just distant enough from Status Quo to be cool, it's destined to be an Ash anthem.

But Wheeler knows life isn't all about good times, and Free All Angels has its share of sadness. New single Burn Baby Burn initially sounds joyful, but listen closer and you'll hear how the nagging guitar really captures the sound of confusion in an ode to the slow death of a relationship. "You're all I have in this teenage twilight," Wheeler sings, while admitting that the bitter words and anger characterise the death of what was once his lifeline.

The obsession with stars is still apparent in many of the songs - from There's a Star to the winsome hymn Sometimes, which blames the realignment of the stars for the loss of love - and so too are the layered harmonies and Beach Boys sound. Pacific Palisades in particular is very like the Barracudas, a fantastic melody rising like a wave before crashing into scrunched-up pop.

There's some unlikely stuff too. On Nicole, Wheeler adopts a deranged serial-killer persona as he shouts: "I said no, I killed my baby, but I love her." He gives the impression that the blood is still on his hands. The weirdness continues in Submission, which would find a suitably seedy home on Soft Cell's Non-Stop Erotic Cabaret: a wannabe homage to S&M that doesn't work because Wheeler's voice is too thin to be scary. It's like discovering your little brother's secret stash of porn mags - it just makes you giggle.

Frothy, bizarre but beautiful, Candy is the most interesting song on the album. Wheeler does Dusty as the string section from the Walker Brothers' Make It Easy on Yourself meets the sparse keyboards of Dr Dre's Next Episode in a song of sweetness and reassurance. Some unnecessary guitar messes up the ending, but it's a brave and confident fusion of genres.

Free All Angels is simply great. Sometimes introspective, a bit strange, but most of all fun, it's what being young is all about.

webTitle: Pakistan's judiciary rocked by Bhutto case

fields.headline: Pakistan's judiciary rocked by Bhutto case
fields.standfirst: The mishandling of the corruption trial against Pakistan's former prime minister has further damaged the fragile reputation of the judiciary, writes Rory McCarthy
fields.trailText: The mishandling of the corruption trial against Pakistan's former prime minister has further damaged the fragile reputation of the judiciary, writes Rory McCarthy.
fields.body:
The clumsy handling of a high-profile corruption trial against Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister, and her husband has shaken the fragile reputation of Pakistan's judiciary to its core.

Now, in an explosive 55-page ruling handed down by Pakistan's supreme court and released this week, one of the country's most senior judges has been singled out as being clearly biased in his handling of the case.

Ms Bhutto, who lives in self-imposed exile in London and Dubai, and her husband had their convictions and sentences overturned on appeal earlier this month and a retrial ordered.

With the release of the court's full ruling, pressure is mounting on the judge, Justice Malik Muhammad Qayyum, to resign. A report on Friday said that the military regime was considering filing a legal action to force the judge out of office.

Justice Qayyum, however, has been defiant. "There is no question of resignation," he said. "Nobody is pressuring me for resignation and no one could. Until I go through the detailed judgement I cannot opine on it."

In April 1999, Justice Qayyum found Ms Bhutto and her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, guilty of taking a $4.3m (£3m) commission after awarding a pre-shipment inspection contract to the Swiss firm Societe Generale de Surveillance.

Both were fined $8.6m and jailed for five years. While Mr Zardari was already in jail awaiting trial on other cases, Ms Bhutto had left Pakistan shortly before the verdict and has never returned. In its ruling this week the supreme court found a string of complaints against the judge's handling of the case and noted "bias is floating on the surface of the record."

"We are convinced that the trial in this case was not fair and on account of bias of the Ehtesab Bench (Pakistan's anti-corruption courts) the trial of the appellants stands vitiated," it said.

The court found Justice Qayyum and his wife had applied for diplomatic passports on April 17, 1998 after taking up the case. Diplomatic passports are not usually issued to judges and the foreign ministry opposed the application.

Then on April 27 Justice Qayyum issued an order freezing the properties and assets of Ms Bhutto and Mr Zardari. Three days later the then prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, a bitter rival and opponent of Ms Bhutto, granted the judge and his wife diplomatic passports.

The supreme court said that this showed the judge had "acquired a personal interest" in the case and that there was "close liaison" between the judge, Saifur Rehman, the minister in charge of the anti-corruption bureau, and Mr Sharif himself. It also said that the judge had ignored the 10 other accused in the trial and rushed the hearing.

Mr Zardari, the ruling said, was not given the chance to recall witnesses for cross-examination and the defence had been allowed to call only one witness. Finally, the supreme court noted that the verdict was written and dated April 14, one day before the trial actually ended.

Defence lawyers at the appeal hearing had also handed in evidence of taped conversations, which appeared to show the then law minister, Khalid Anwar, Mr Rehman and the judge discussing the case and the imminent verdict.

"Give them full dose," Mr Rehman told the judge. Prosecutors said the tapes were fake and the supreme court, perhaps wary of the political fallout, said that there was already enough evidence of bias in the case and therefore no need to look at the tapes.

While the military regime considers Justice Qayyum's future it must also decide if it can face a high-profile retrial in the corruption case. Ms Bhutto, who is convinced that the military will drop the trial and eager to return to politics in Pakistan, also faces several other accusations of corruption - all of which she denies.

webTitle: Internet girls go to US foster parents

fields.headline: Internet girls go to US foster parents
fields.trailText: The twin babies at the centre of the internet adoption row were last night handed to US foster parents at an undisclosed address in Missouri.
fields.body:
The twin babies at the centre of the internet adoption row were last night handed to US foster parents at an undisclosed address in Missouri.

Nine-month-old sisters Belinda and Kimberley had arrived in Britain in January after being "bought" by Alan and Judith Kilshaw, from north Wales, through an internet site run by a Californian child broker.

The case provoked outrage when the Kilshaws' claim to have adopted the girls in the US was contested by a Californian couple, who paid the broker first, and by the twins' natural mother, Tranda Wecker.

On Wednesday three social workers from Flintshire county council took the twins to St Louis, in Missouri, their original home state. The council had been caring for the girls since January 18.

Its chief executive, Philip McGreevy, said the girls had been placed in the custody of state authorities pending a decision on their future by the courts.

The high court in London last week dismissed the Kilshaws' claim to custody of the girls and ordered their return to US jurisdiction. Last month a judge in Arkansas annulled their adoption by the Kilshaws.

It emerged last night that a British television company was offering to pay for air tickets to help the Kilshaws emigrate to the US where they want to adopt again.

Mrs Kilshaw told 5 News, the Channel 5 news programme produced by ITN, that she planned to write a book to tell her side of the story. She believed America would provide the fair hearing she had been denied in Britain.

A spokeswoman for Channel 5 said the programme would fund one-way tickets for the Kilshaws to a destination of their choice. It was not able to disclose the cost since the couple had not decided on that destination.

Mr Kilshaw said he was considering opening a hotel in the US. His wife added that one of the attractions of America was that adoptions were seen to be normal. "It happens every day. It's happening now as we speak. Children are being born there, put up for adoption and it's a normal procedure."

Later, the US lawyer for Mrs Wecker said his client was looking forward to being reunited with the babies.

Bill Meehan told CNN: "The parents have been kept in the dark about the date and time of their return and that was done on purpose because they did not want any type of scene at the airport.

"There is going to be a reunification process. The parents will get a check-list of things to do and when they have done those type of things the twins will be reunited with the parents."

Mrs Wecker is in the process of divorcing her husband, Aaron, who is also seeking custody of the twins, but Mr Meehan said they were working together for the best interests of the girls.

"The parents have to redeem themselves before the court's eyes... the only way that we were going to get the children back was by a joint effort to bury the hatchet," he said.

Nine-month-old sisters Belinda and Kimberley had arrived in Britain in January after being "bought" by Alan and Judith Kilshaw, from north Wales, through an internet site run by a Californian child broker. The case provoked outrage when the Kilshaws' claim to have adopted the girls in the US was contested by a Californian couple, who paid the broker first, and by the twins' natural mother, Tranda Wecker. On Wednesday three social workers from Flintshire county council took the twins to St Louis, in Missouri, their original home state. The council had been caring for the girls since January 18. Its chief executive, Philip McGreevy, said the girls had been placed in the custody of state authorities pending a decision on their future by the courts. The high court in London last week dismissed the Kilshaws' claim to custody of the girls and ordered their return to US jurisdiction. Last month a judge in Arkansas annulled their adoption by the Kilshaws. It emerged last night that a British television company was offering to pay for air tickets to help the Kilshaws emigrate to the US where they want to adopt again. Mrs Kilshaw told 5 News, the Channel 5 news programme produced by ITN, that she planned to write a book to tell her side of the story. She believed America would provide the fair hearing she had been denied in Britain. A spokeswoman for Channel 5 said the programme would fund one-way tickets for the Kilshaws to a destination of their choice. It was not able to disclose the cost since the couple had not decided on that destination. Mr Kilshaw said he was considering opening a hotel in the US. His wife added that one of the attractions of America was that adoptions were seen to be normal. "It happens every day. It's happening now as we speak. Children are being born there, put up for adoption and it's a normal procedure." Later, the US lawyer for Mrs Wecker said his client was looking forward to being reunited with the babies. Bill Meehan told CNN: "The parents have been kept in the dark about the date and time of their return and that was done on purpose because they did not want any type of scene at the airport. "There is going to be a reunification process. The parents will get a check-list of things to do and when they have done those type of things the twins will be reunited with the parents." Mrs Wecker is in the process of divorcing her husband, Aaron, who is also seeking custody of the twins, but Mr Meehan said they were working together for the best interests of the girls. "The parents have to redeem themselves before the court's eyes... the only way that we were going to get the children back was by a joint effort to bury the hatchet," he said.

fields.headline: Hell of a halibut
fields.trailText: It is not often that the reality sounds better than the fantasy in the old tradition of the fisherman's tale.
fields.body:
It is not often that the reality sounds better than the fantasy in the old tradition of the fisherman's tale.

But James Lovie, the skipper of the trawler Enterprise, had no need to exaggerate when he hauled his latest catch from the chilly waters of the Antarctic.

Staring back at him from the Rockall trawler's nets was a giant halibut, more than 20 times the usual size of the fish caught in British waters, measuring 8ft in length.

Mr Lovie, who landed his giant catch at Kinlochbervie, on the west coast of Sutherland on Tuesday, said he was "amazed" and "impressed" to have caught the fish, which was taller than himself and weighed in at 20 stone.

The halibut was sold to King Foods, a fishmonger in Aberdeen, for an undisclosed sum and was later served up in more manageable chunks with a white wine sauce to eager diners at the city's Craighaar Hotel.

The fish, estimated to have been 35 years old, is believed to be the biggest halibut to have been landed in Britain. The previous title holder weighed in at 16st 10lb when it was landed at Dunnet Head, Scrabster, in the Highlands in 1979.

The Guinness Book of Records says a 50st common sturgeon netted off the Orkney islands in 1956 is the biggest fish caught in British waters.

fields.headline: Out of the dark
fields.standfirst: James Ellroy, the bad boy of US literature, is mellowing. He has found a 'profound' woman and banished his demons, he tells  Edward Helmore
fields.trailText: James Ellroy, the bad boy of US literature, is mellowing. He has found a 'profound' woman and banished his demons, he tells Edward Helmore.
fields.body:
If you had to identify a single defining characteristic in James Ellroy, it would be precision. Like his prose, stripped down like a hot rod, he displays no unnecessary flim-flam in his countenance - you see it in the manner he chisels cheese from the lip of his bowl of French onion soup. Even the weight of his dog, a white bull terrier named Dudley, is kept in optimum muscular form. "You gotta keep the fuckers under 50lbs," he says. "You don't let these guys become big 70lb tanks. It'll kill 'em dead."

Ellroy, 52, is not the same man who wrote My Dark Places. Nor is he the same man who wrote the LA Quartet crime novels - The Black Dahlia, The Big Nowhere, LA Confidential and White Jazz. He has moved on. His new book, The Cold Six Thousand, following 1995's American Tabloid, is the second of a planned trilogy that could be described as a semi-fictional account of American imperialism. The book extends the theme of "bad white men doing bad things in the name of authority" but Ellroy himself seems less the bad, bruising self-confident man he used to play himself as, though he still pretty sure about the value of his new book.

"I wanted to write a book that expresses a new mature ethos and I think I've done it," he says. "I just reached a point in my career where I have to quit talking about my mother's murder and all that stuff. I want to work more quietly and circumspectly, to work for some wisdom and peace of mind. Hopefully we'll be seeing a calmer, more contemplative and truth-seeking Ellroy."

The Cold Six Thousand does not betray any weariness; it is as brutal and fast-paced as its predecessor. Starting where American Tabloid left off - in Dallas on November 22 1963 - the book delves into the conspiratorial shadows of the Kennedys, J Edgar Hoover, the mob, Howard Hughes, the Klan, the civil rights movement, heroin and Vietnam, accompanied by Ellroy's own determinedly bad-ass fictional characters.

"It had to be perfect, it had to be the precisely perfect ordering of words, and it had to sound right to my ear across the board, and I didn't let it go until I thought it was perfect."

For Ellroy, run-on sentences, multiple clauses, commas and semi-colons are the enemy. "It's as stylistically pure a novel as you'll ever read. I like a period, a colon and a double-dash. There are no tricks to this style. It's propulsive, you can't blink or you'll miss things."

For a writer who was not quite 12 at the dawn of the 60s and not quite 22 at the close, that momentous decade in American history is perfect Ellroy territory. "It was that last gasp of pre-public accountability in America. These bad power-driven guys had their agendas and they got away with whatever they wanted."

Through the fog of his own drug and alcohol addictions of that time and into the 70s, he held no interest in the aspirations of the anti-establishment counterculture - "the only thing I did that they did was get bombed and try to get laid, unsuccessfully" - but he sustained an intuitive sense of the personal stories working beneath the surface of events that now inform his work.

"When you look at James Earl Ray, and learn of the horrifying and hilarious facts of his life, or Robert Kennedy, what he went through when he realised his war on organised crime - in a sense, his oedipal drama because he was the only one of the Kennedy men to see through his father - was an attack on his father once removed, it sets fire to the imagination," he enthuses. "So, I get to go back and tell the human story to those events and to rewrite history to my own specifications," he says. "And that's very seductive."

But despite the impression given by his books, Ellroy is not a conspiracist by nature. Conspiracies, such as the assassination of JFK, exist informally as consensus thinking, he holds. There was a consensus among powerful people that he had to go and a consensus among even more powerful people that the official version of how it happened was best for the country.

"I think it was an auspicious business dispute killing and nothing else. Jack betrayed some very bad people to betray, renegade CIA men, Cuban exiles, the mob. He fucked them and they killed him. Thus, by the rules he lived by, he was a traitor and he got what he deserved. He should have understood there are elements out there you don't betray. He naively trusted the power of his office, the power of his ascendancy, the power of his family name and he woefully miscalculated."

Ellroy does not buy into the posturing and projections of moral righteousness that America likes to indulge. The idea that Kennedy's assassination marked the end of innocence, or was the crime of the century, doesn't wash with him. "History is the crime of the American 20th century," he corrects. "This country was never innocent. It's a crock of shit. This country was built on racism, slavery, religious persecution, land grabs, and the genocidal slaughter of the indigenous population."

But he's also wary of being drawn into areas that are not, as a novelist, his to indulge. Readers and journalists often seek his opinion, often trying to define him by their perceived reaction to his views and anoint him as one of their own. "The guy with Irish brogue raises his hand. Oh, shit. He wants to know what you think about Northern Ireland. Or you go to San Francisco, and some androgynous human being wants to know what you think about gay rights. It's nothing to do with me. It's not my job."

Ellroy largely isolates himself from popular culture; he picks his period, immerses himself in it and does not seek contemporary parallel and metaphor. "I was obsessively self-destructive and then I became obsessively constructive in the books I write." Distractions are minimised, especially those of popular culture. "Words are my business and when I'm not putting them on paper, thinking about putting them on paper, planning to put them on paper, I don't want to be reading." His work is his passion, and the devils that once attended him have, if not departed, then are at least held at bay.

But where he once sought constant, escalating stimulation, he now seeks something else. If violence and its attendant issues was once compelling and cathartic, it is now only interesting as a social phenomenon that paints a picture of a time and a place.

Confusing the writer with his work is a dangerous game, of course, and Ellroy expresses surprise that he is often portrayed as a tough guy when, in truth, he had no stomach for serious crime or violence even as he lived a disordered and profligate life. "I was pathetic, physically weak, drug and booze debilitated, a buffoon, and scared of my own shadow. But you know what? My shadow was something to be scared of. I saw the enemy and it was me."

Nowadays, he may still push too hard, drive too hard and suffer bouts of insomnia, but the inner compulsions have been slayed by self-honesty and clarity and he now prefers to side with the forces of tenderness and calm, not the obsessive's need for constant stimulation whose only antidote is more stimulation.

"That thrill-seeking part ... the sensual part. Mental stimulation. Sex. Cultural stimulation. Sensory shit like food, a good meal. You get to a point where all that becomes such a fucking burden. Damnable temptations. After a while you want profundity in your life. I found a profound woman and that's that. Now I want to go to the next level of profundity and peace and I understand that I should step back at this point in my life."

With one more book in the current trilogy to complete, Ellroy is casting around for a change of direction. He's looking to write a historical-political novel on the life of Warren Harding, US president between 1916 and 1924. Language and style will have to be adapted and changed but the essential theme of all his books - the morally and socially corrupted, white Anglo-Saxon heterosexual American man in extremis - will remain intact.

"I write about men better than anybody since Dashiell Hammett," Ellroy says, not in boast but with the certain knowledge that he is right. "I know it in my bones. It may be time to say you've taken as far as it can go. Take an inventory. See where you've been, see where you're going and go there. Pick a direction."

 The Cold Six Thousand is published by Century, priced £16.99.

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 60: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Day 60: The government is considering giving grants to farmers to encourage less intensive farming methods.
fields.body:
The Guardian
Reports on page ten that the government is considering giving grants to farmers to become "land stewards" who will encourage less intensive farming methods and reduce the risk of foot and mouth returning. The Ministry of Agriculture has also dropped a case against an organic farm in Gloucestershire which was refusing to slaughter its animals because they were next to an infected site.

Daily Mail
On page ten, sheepdogs are being abandoned by farmers who can no longer afford to keep them and the government's chief scientist reports that the epidemic is "fully under control."

The Times
Reports on page six that ministers have put off a vaccination decision for one week, following protests from farmers. The RSPCA has saved a healthy flock of sheep stranded on an island from slaughter.

The Sun
Tory leader William Hague and shadow chancellor Michael Portillo appear on page two, visiting a farm in Essex and listening to farmers' concerns.

The Mirror
On page eight, the debate is taken to the British people, with an eight-question phone poll. Readers are asked to give their opinion on whether the election ought to be postponed and decide if vaccination should be introduced.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate | Quick bites | On the menu | On the net | Just out | The taste test
fields.body:
Cheapskate ... Where to eat out for under £15

The John Hewitt
51 Donegall Street, Belfast BT1 2FH.
Tel: 028-9023 3768

The late John Hewitt was the Leonard Cohen of Belfast. Happily the pub/restaurant named after him has completely missed the point and serves up cheerful dishes in a bright and breezy atmosphere. This is a proper pub/restaurant with a divine understanding of lunchtime pub goers' needs, with no-smoking areas, plenty of elbow room and fast service. Pan-fried calf's liver with crisp parma ham on a bed of smoked bacon mash with red wine is just (£6.50) while the spiced lamb steaks with sweet potato mash, red onion and coriander marmalade is only £6.75. Steamed mussels with lime, rocket and crusty bread are under a fiver.

Quick bites ... Where to eat out in 15 minutes

The Khyaber Restaurant
520 Saintfield Road, Carryduff. County Down.
Tel: 028-9081 3822

Tucked into a pig-ugly, roadside building which houses a petrol station, a 24-hour shop and a bottled gas centre, sits the splendidly regal Khyaber restaurant. Within this sanctuary are some of the best punjabi dishes to be found in County Down, or Northern Ireland in general come to that. Lunch prices start at £3.95 and evening dinners aren't much more expensive. Although not on the menu, the butter chicken is unmatched by any other in Belfast or Dublin and is worth asking for. Thick but not sickly sweet, the coconut and butter sauce sits happily with the barbecued tandoori chicken. The staff goes for the chicken bhuna at the end of the day, so that's another recommendation.

On the menu: Galangal

Animal, vegetable or mineral? Vegetable.

Hailing from whence? Originally Indonesia or southern China.

Or? It depends on whether you speak of the greater galangal from Indonesia or the lesser galangal, which has been used since time immemorial in China.

Do they differ markedly? Both are of the ginger family. The greater is more gingery in flavour and is used in Thai, Malay and Indonesian cooking. The lesser is more marked and is used in liqueurs, bitters and Chinese cooking.

Any relation to galingale? Yes and alternatively, no. Galingale used to be used for galangal and sedge roots for some unfathomable reason.

On the net: English Restaurants

Pizza, pasta, udon noodles ... But where's the roast beef and Yorkshire puds? You can gorge yourself on seemingly every variety of cuisine in London - but rooting out decent British grub is a tad tricky. The Earl of Bradford started Porters English Restaurant in London in 1979, and now he brings us this website, which offers reviews of the capital's finest British restaurants, such as The Greenhouse and RK Stanley's. There are recipes too - brown onion, ale and cheddar cheese soup, from Simpson's in The Strand, and roast young grouse with white boudin, confit of red cabbage, fondant potatoes and cider from Rules.

Just out: The Original Game Buckshot Bouillon

Form: Clear, peat-brown liquid.

Flavour: Very peppery; slightly caramelised gamey Oxo; with the faintest hint of sherry.

Verdict: There is sherry (0.3%); and there's game, too, all 7% of venison, pheasant and that well-known sporting bird, the pigeon. I'm not quite sure this cuts the mustard unadorned on the plate. But fortified, as suggested, with vodka or sherry then the brisk chilli levels will come into their own. Better still, it would make the basis for a blistering Bullshot.

Price: £2.49 for a 400g can. Available from Cranes of Beaminster. Tel: 01308 862226.

The taste test: extra virgin olive oil

I first looked at these two years ago. Since then, the number of oils available has proliferated; but has their quality improved?

Brand: Asda Organic
Price: £2.99/500ml
What it's like: Cracker; delicate, fruity; beautifully balanced
How it rates: *****

Brand: Morrisons Spanish
Price: £2.59/750ml
What it's like: Corker; well rounded; fat and fruity
How it rates: *****

Brand: M&S Spanish
Price: £2.99/500ml
What it's like: Rubenesque; full, fat and fruity; slightly bitter after taste
How it rates: ****

Brand: Somerfield
Price: £2.69/500ml
What it's like: Cutie; delicate, finely structured; quite plump
How it rates: ****

Brand: Waitrose
Price: £6.65/500ml
What it's like: Charmer; middleweight fruit, fat and flavour
How it rates: ***

Brand: Co-op
Price: £2.55/500ml
What it's like: Big shot; very fat; pretty peppery
How it rates: ***

webTitle: Taking sting out of Captain Corelli

fields.headline: Taking sting out of Captain Corelli
fields.standfirst: Film script strips out poignant ending, gay undertones and political controversy
fields.trailText: The British director John Madden last night defended the wholesale changes he has made to the film version of Captain Corelli's Mandolin, which had its world premiere in London
fields.body:
The British director John Madden last night defended the wholesale changes he has made to the film version of Captain Corelli's Mandolin, which had its world premiere in London.

Although the Oscar-winning maker of Mrs Brown and Shakespeare In Love resisted the temptation to change the title to Captain Corelli's Banjo, little else about Louis de Bernières's love story set during the war on the Greek island of Cephalonia remain intact.

The book's poignant ending was the first thing to go, because Madden claims "it is problematic on film although it works magnificently in the novel, as do many of the other narrative strands we had to do without".

While the homosexual overtones in the relationship between Corelli, the opera-loving Italian officer played by Nicolas Cage, and his comrade Carlo make it one of the most touching episodes in the book, it too disappears on film.

The most far-reaching change, however, is the way the film corrects the book's controversial anti-communist bias by depicting wartime Greek partisans as heroes rather than sadistic ideologues.

Mandras (Christian Bale), the fisherman whose love for Pelagia (Penelope Cruz) is forgotten when she falls for Corelli, is no longer shown as a rapist brutalised by his time in the leftwing resistance. Nor is there much reference to partisan atrocities, which landed the book in such hot water with Greek civil war veterans.

De Bernières, a former soldier and teacher who spent a fortnight on the island before writing the book, has declined to do interviews to support the film, though he did attend last night's charity premiere. Madden claimed that de Bernières was delighted with the film and had been consulted by both himself and screenwriter Shawn Slovo. She said she had cut out all reference to the civil war purely for reasons of plot and not to assuage prickly Greek sensibilities.

Joy over the likely tourist boom in Cephalonia - where the film was also shot - had been overshadowed by fears over how the thorny issue of how the vicious conflict, in which Britain played a shadowy part, would be treated. Many were angry at how de Bernières had treated the partisans, whose defeat in 1949 ushered in decades of repressive rightwing rule. The writer himself had already made concessions to the criticism by making changes to the Greek edition of the book.

"After the writing of Corelli it became clear to me that many people were offended by the portrayal of the communist resistance, or thought that it was inaccurate," he said. "I haven't changed my mind about what I think is the truth, but I had to bear in mind the possibility that I might be wrong."

Madden and the British producers Working Title, however, were much more willing to compromise, and have concentrated purely on the love triangle between Mandras, Pelagia, and Cage's Corelli.

Irene Papas, the Greek actress who plays the old woman Drosoula, said the film could not be a documentary nor remain utterly faithful to the book.

"I lived through the period the novel covers and I remember it very differently. That said, the writer has a right to tell any story he wants to."

fields.headline: BBC staff fight for free car parking
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Staff are outraged at the prospect of losing their free parking passes worth up to £5,000 a year, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
Latest BBC stories
fields.body:
Well-paid BBC staff are fighting what they believe is one of their most important battles of their careers at the corporation - maintaining the right to free car parking passes valued at up to £5,000 a year.

Under new inner city planning rules, the corporation has to lose 600 parking places in its White City headquarters in west London, a move that has outraged staff who have enjoyed the perk for years.

While most London workers, and indeed staff who work in BBC's central London offices, endure an arduous and unpleasant daily commute by tube, BBC staff insist they should be allowed to hold on to their free car park passes.

One worker, who wrote to the in-house magazine Ariel, complained she lived in the countryside and could never catch the "only bus home".

"I can't be the only one in this position and yet it seems to be a case of 'you'll have to try to make alternative arrangements, move to London or leave the BBC'," the staff member said.

But an internal survey conducted for the corporation has revealed that up to 70% of those who use the car parks live in west London.

And nearly half of those are less than a 25-minute drive away from work.

"This is a really big issue for staff here. Some people have been in tears about it," said one BBC staff member.

The BBC has a staggering 2,491 parking places at its disposal in five car parks around TV Centre and its White City headquarters, including a multistorey car-park.

Commuters in London would have to pay £20 a day or more to park in a private car park but BBC staff get this privilege free of charge.

The quantity of car park passes at the BBC has astonished Hammersmith and Fulham council and the Greater London Authority, which are campaigning to persuade Londoners to leave their cars at home.

Strict criteria for who gets to keep their parking passes are now being drawn up by a special car park committee.

Those who work night shifts, such as camera crews and journalists, are likely to keep their passes, as will staff with disabilities. Women with young children are also likely to be high up on the priority list.

And, inevitably, executives such as the heads of BBC1 and BBC2 and director-general Greg Dyke will be able to continue to use the car park. But even these criteria are causing rows.

"It has become a real hot potato. Some people, like secretaries, have got passes as a sweetener. They had otherwise threatened to leave because the BBC pays so badly," said one.

Another said: "This has raised all sorts of issues. If you work in Broadcasting House and have to bring your child to a creche, you don't get a car park pass, so why should those with children who live in Notting Hill drive to White City?" said one angry female worker.

Up to now, the BBC has argued it needs the car park space because transport is so unreliable and because Wood Lane, known as "muggers' alley", is unsafe at night.

However, as one journalist at the corporation said: "I don't think there will be any sympathy for the arguments that public transport is bad. It is bad everywhere in London. That is the price of living in the capital."

The local council has now insisted the number of places be reduced as part of its decision to grant the BBC planning permission to develop a new media centre in west London.

The BBC will start losing some of these spaces next year when building work on its new White City development begins, but it will not have to give up all its places until 2004.

A BBC spokeswoman said the BBC accepted it had to adopt a "greener" policy but was working in conjunction with the transport authorities for long-term improvements to transport and safety in the area.

It has already installed cameras along Wood Lane and it is hoping to persuade rail authorities to redevelop an old underground station on Wood Lane.

And it is hoping fewer than 600 people will be affected by the car park cutbacks.

The corporation said it was also looking at installing more spaces for bicycles and motorbikes.

webTitle: Nazi hunters condemn UK record on prosecutions

fields.headline: Nazi hunters condemn UK record on prosecutions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: Britain has one of the worst track records in hunting down and prosecuting suspected Nazi war criminals, according to a report by the Simon Wiesenthal Centre.
fields.body:
Britain has one of the worst track records in hunting down and prosecuting suspected Nazi war criminals, according to a report by the Simon Wiesenthal Centre.

The centre says Britain has had only minimal success in dealing with the perpetrators of the Holocaust and it is urging the government to take urgent steps to improve the prosecution of suspected war criminals.

Britain fares badly in the centre's new table comparing the efforts of the 18 countries which are suspected of housing the most war criminals. Britain was placed in the "minimal success" category, with countries such as Argentina, Croatia and Costa Rica.

Scotland, which following devolution deals with its own extradition requests, fares worse than the rest of Britain. The report dismisses Scotland's efforts as "insufficient or unsuccessful".

The table, which the centre's Jerusalem-based Nazi hunting operation plans to publish annually, was yesterday described as unfair by a former British army Nazi hunter. Lord Janner, former MP and secretary of the all-party war crimes group, said the idea that it was possible to rank the Nazi-hunting efforts of countries was "ludicrous".

Efraim Zuroff, director of the centre's Jerusalem office, said: "At least we can try our hardest to ensure the perpetrators do not live out their lives in peace and tranquillity. We urge every government which faces this problem to maximise its efforts to ensure that as many as possible of the criminals are forced to pay for their crimes."

Lord Janner said: "This league table makes no distinction between commitment and results, nor does it take into account the circumstances of the country assessed both during the Nazi period and after."

Dr Zuroff's study points out that Britain has prosecuted no cases since the former Belarussian policeman Anton Sawoniuk, 79, was convicted of war crimes two years ago. The retired British Rail ticket inspector was given two life sentences.

Criticism of Scotland is based on its failure to prosecute Anton Gecas, a Lithuanian living in Edinburgh, who has been accused of the murder of up to 32,000 people.

The US was the only country to be graded "highly successful" in the first Nazi War Criminals Prosecution Status Report. It was the first country to use immigration and deportation procedures, rather than criminal procedures, to deal with war criminals and the Simon Wiesenthal Centre is keen for this method to be adopted globally.

webTitle: Butterflies stand in way of white horse

fields.headline: Butterflies stand in way of white horse
fields.standfirst: Plans for a Folkestone tourist attraction could destroy habitat
fields.trailText: It is a very peculiar planning inquiry. On one side are Michael Howard, Spike Milligan, Joanna Lumley and Shepway district council. On the other is English Nature.
fields.body:
It is a very peculiar planning inquiry. On one side are Michael Howard, Spike Milligan, Joanna Lumley and Shepway district council. On the other is English Nature.

At stake are the fate of rare butterflies and orchids, and the civic pride of Folkestone.

The proposal to create a giant white horse on a grassy chalk hill overlooking the entrance to the channel tunnel has inflamed such passion that the Department of Environment deemed an inquiry was necessary. It is due to end tomorrow, although the wrangling seems certain to continue.

What began as a millennium art project has become a highly charged symbol of the town's future. Its supporters - who include Milligan and Lumley, both friends of the artist behind the scheme - say it will regenerate the resort. The council believes the 100m long galloping horse will brand Folkestone as an energetic town, attracting visitors and giving pleasure and pride to residents for generations to come.

Its detractors call the scheme a folly which will despoil a precious resource while doing little to tackle the area's underlying problems.

English Nature argues that Cheriton Hill itself is a greater treasure than anything which could be created there. Rare adonis blue butterflies and spider orchids have made the chalk escarpment their home; it is a site of special scientific interest and a candidate special area of conservation.

"We don't disagree with the need for economic regeneration, but there is no need to damage and destroy a site of national and international wildlife importance in the process," said Teresa Bennett, acting team manager for the body's Kent branch.

She fears that creating and maintaining the horse would damage the area and attract tourists who could endanger the vulnerable wildlife.

But supporters dismiss English Nature's calls for them to choose a different location.

"The site is pretty much the last view you have of England as you leave through the Channel tunnel and the first view you have as you arrive," Mr Howard, MP for Folkestone and Hythe and a former environment minister and home secretary, told the hearing yesterday.

Arguing that the potential for ecological damage had been "vastly exaggerated", he added: "The economy of Folkestone could be transformed if only a small proportion of the large numbers of people who leave or enter the country through the tunnel were to stop to enjoy the area's attractions.

"Despite all the efforts people have made we have so far made disappointing progress in attracting people to stay."

His conviction may have been fostered by a recent visitor from America, who spotted designs for the horse on a website and came to Folkestone believing it already existed.

Charles Newington, the proposed artist, says he was taken aback by the support for his design. "It's become important as an issue because the people of Folkestone want it," he said. "You can call it a lucky charm, a talisman, an icon.

"I didn't see it as a way of regenerating the area when I started, but that's what it's become."

There are around 17 chalk horses in the UK and the practice of cutting them even has its own name, leucippotomy. The best known, at Uffington in Berkshire, probably dates from between 1,400 and 600 BC, although most were created in the last three centuries.

Rather than carve a horse, Folkestone volunteers will fix panels into the soil to reduce damage from erosion and make maintenance easy. Mr Newington estimates that it will cost around £4,000, which he believes will be easily raised through donations.

John Prescott, the environment secretary, will read the inquiry's recommendations and approve or reject the scheme within the next six months.

Should he turn it down, Richard Bougie, who farms Cheriton Hill and is the scheme's foremost advocate, has warned that they may go all the way to the European courts, albeit with misgivings.

"You know what they do to horses in Brussels, don't you?" he asked the planning inspector. "They eat them."

fields.headline: America warms to Weakest Link
fields.trailText:
11am: The Weakest Link capped a triumphant first week in the US by pulling in more than 25m viewers on Wednesday, reports Jason Deans.

17.04.01: Weakest Link storms US
fields.body:
The Weakest Link capped a triumphant first week in the US by pulling in more than 25m viewers for its third outing on Wednesday night.

Anne Robinson's harsh presenting style may not have gone down well with American critics, but The Weakest Link increased its audience by more than 10m over three editions on NBC between Monday and Wednesday.

The show, which was sold to NBC by BBC Worldwide, drew 25.1m viewers from 10pm-11pm on wednesday and was the most watched programme on any US network that evening.

NBC estimates that more than 52m US viewers watched the show over its initial three-night run this week.

Executives from the network will also be pleased that The Weakest Link is rating strongly among the key 18-49 demographic much sought after by advertisers.

However, the US launch of The Weakest Link was backed by a massive NBC marketing blitz that will have boosted audience figures.

It remains to be seen whether US viewers take to Ms Robinson's abrasive style when the show settles into its regular weekly slot next week for the rest of its 13-part run.

webTitle: SAG president faces hostility over strike

fields.headline: SAG president faces hostility over strike
fields.trailText: As if tensions weren't already at boiling point in Hollywood, news now emerges that a faction within the Screen Actors Guild, which faces critical contract negotiations in May, has called on members to oust president William Daniels
fields.body:
As if tensions weren't already at boiling point in Hollywood, news now emerges that a faction within the Screen Actors Guild, which faces critical contract negotiations in May, has called on members to oust president William Daniels.

Variety reports that an email calling on Daniels not to seek a second two-year term, has been sent to members. "There's an election coming up in November that we need to win. We have a big, constant struggle on our hands and we need all the help we can get," writes the author of the "State of the Union" email.

Daniels has not yet said if he will stand again, but the message sends out a strong signal that he would face much hostility from members outside Hollywood and those loyal to former president Richard Masur. The message also indicates likely electoral battlegrounds such as Daniels' aggressive position on last year's commercials strike and the upcoming TV-film negotiations.

The author of the email, who asked not to be identified, told Variety that last year's strike was unnecessary and that he was concerned that Daniels wanted to go on strike again when the TV-film contract expires - something Daniels has denied.

Meanwhile, the mayor of Los Angeles, Richard Riordan has warned that any prolonged strike by Hollywood writers and actors could plunge the city into a recession. Reuters reports that Riordan has issued a study showing that a work stoppage could cost the city and surrounding area as many as 81,900 jobs and up to $7bn in lost income.

"We could take a huge, huge U-turn back to the days of high unemployment and business closures," said Riordan, urging union leaders and studio executives to seek compromise.

Variety reports that an email calling on Daniels not to seek a second two-year term, has been sent to members. "There's an election coming up in November that we need to win. We have a big, constant struggle on our hands and we need all the help we can get," writes the author of the "State of the Union" email. Daniels has not yet said if he will stand again, but the message sends out a strong signal that he would face much hostility from members outside Hollywood and those loyal to former president Richard Masur. The message also indicates likely electoral battlegrounds such as Daniels' aggressive position on last year's commercials strike and the upcoming TV-film negotiations. The author of the email, who asked not to be identified, told Variety that last year's strike was unnecessary and that he was concerned that Daniels wanted to go on strike again when the TV-film contract expires - something Daniels has denied. Meanwhile, the mayor of Los Angeles, Richard Riordan has warned that any prolonged strike by Hollywood writers and actors could plunge the city into a recession. Reuters reports that Riordan has issued a study showing that a work stoppage could cost the city and surrounding area as many as 81,900 jobs and up to $7bn in lost income. "We could take a huge, huge U-turn back to the days of high unemployment and business closures," said Riordan, urging union leaders and studio executives to seek compromise.

fields.headline: Kluivert hands it to the Reds
fields.standfirst: McAllister penalty takes Liverpool to their first European final in 16 years
fields.trailText: To a cock-a-hoop chorus of You'll Never Walk Alone and a carpet of scarves on the Kop Liverpool strode into their first European final in 16 years last night, ushered on their way by a helping Barcelona hand.
fields.body:
To a cock-a-hoop chorus of You'll Never Walk Alone and a carpet of scarves on the Kop Liverpool strode into their first European final in 16 years last night, ushered on their way by a helping Barcelona hand.

While Gérard Houllier's side must have expected flashes of mind-boggling skill from Barca's world-class attackers, they could never have foreseen the moment of madness from Patrick Kluivert that settled this nail-biting tie.

With two minutes remaining before half-time and Kluivert defending a Gary McAllister corner, the former Ajax forward mistimed his jump and, with Frank de Boer and Sami Hyypia lurking behind, flicked his hand at the cross. The Scot gleefully converted the penalty.

Having weathered a nerve- racking ending, which saw incessant pressure if few clear chances, Liverpool can add a Uefa Cup final against Alaves in Dortmund to their already cramped fixture list.

"Being in a European final means so much to everyone at the club," said Houllier. "That was a true team performance; we defended and attacked as a team. If you look at the two games we've not had a lot of chances even if we've had plenty of possession.

"But we've defended in a very clever way. I knew if we opened the play in the Nou Camp we wouldn't have a chance there. But I knew we had a chance here. The fans helped make it a wonderful European night."

That the second leg of this semi-final would produce more attacking pizzazz than the first was inevitable given the mind-numbing tedium of the Nou Camp stalemate a fortnight ago. Liverpool's stifling tactics that night prompted the Spanish media to round on Houllier for betraying Liverpool's traditions.

But, with Barca drawing their two previous games in La Liga 4-4 and Liverpool having notched their 100th goal of the season across Stanley Park on Monday, a repeat of the cagey jousting never looked likely.

Such optimism swelled as the home side tore into the visitors from the outset. Steven Gerrard fizzed around midfield like a man possessed. From his incisive pass Markus Babbel's cross, swirling in the wind, was palmed behind unconvincingly by Jose Manuel Reina. The goalkeeper retained an air of vulnerability as he scrambled the ball away after Vladimir Smicer slipped Michael Owen into the area.

Hyypia and Smicer both threatened with headers yet, for all Liverpool's pressure, danger was ever only one flash of Rivaldo's awesome talent away. The Brazilian - gliding between opponents, all pirouettes and majestic flicks - gathered possession on the halfway line after eight minutes, advanced and launched an Exocet from 40 yards destined for the top right-hand corner ; Sander Westerveld did well to tip it behind.

That spurred Barca on, Emmanuel Petit twice blazing horribly into the Kop while the Frenchman's former Arsenal team-mate Marc Overmars, a roadrunner up and down the left flank, terrorised Babbel. After 33 minutes the Dutch international tore to the goalline, cut back and saw Luis Enrique squirm a shot wide with Westerveld beaten.

Yet Liverpool were handed the lead through Kluivert's misdemeanour before the in terval. The striker's immediate glance at the official betrayed his guilt. A flashing drive across Westerveld's goal at the start of the second period may have been spurred by a desire to make amends.

Not that it prompted the expected barrage of chances for Barcelona. But the nerves jangling through the stands were exacerbated by Petit's innocuous punt forward that Westerveld air-kicked on the edge of his area. Kluivert gave chase but the ball ran out; with it went Barca's chance.

"We cannot underestimate Alaves," added Houllier. "I know a lot about them and they are a very good team. But this was a fantastic achievement."

Alaves cruised through to the Uefa Cup final with a 4-1 win over Kaiserslautern for a 9-2 aggregate victory . France's Youri Djorkaeff gave the home side an early lead but two goals from the substitute Jurica Vucko and one each from Ivan Alonso and Raul Ganan secured a comfortable win for the Spanish side.

Liverpool (4-4-2): Westerveld; Babbel, Hyypia, Henchoz, Carragher; Smicer (Fowler, 81min), Gerrard (Murphy, 78), Hamann, McAllister; Heskey, Owen (Berger, 63).

Barcelona (4-2-3-1): Reina; Puyol, Reiziger (Simao, 60), De Boer, Cocu; Petit, Guardiola; Luis Enrique, Rivaldo, Overmars (Dani, 74); Kluivert.

Referee : U Meier (Switzerland).

fields.headline: Fifa marketing chief sacked
fields.trailText:
10.15am: The departure of Patrick Magyer has plunged Fifa's plans for the next World Cup into chaos, writes Dan Milmo.
20.02.2001: Napster backers tackle Fifa
15.02.2001: Fifa forces Footofgod.com to close
fields.body:
Fifa's plans for the next World Cup are in chaos following the sacking of the tournament's marketing chief.

Patrick Magyer was running the competition's promotional campaign for Swiss company ISL, which owns the marketing rights to the 2002 World Cup.

It is alleged he was plotting with football's governing body against his own company, which is teetering on the brink of bankruptcy.

Fifa sold the marketing rights for the 2002 World Cup to ISL in 1996 for £1.2bn, but the deal saddled ISL with too much debt and left the company's management split over how to deal with the crisis.

An ISL spokeswoman confirmed Mr Magyer had left the company but would not give reasons for his departure.

Fifa has now created its own marketing operation, Fifa Marketing, in case ISL's £300m debt burden drags it under and the 2002 World Cup in Japan and South Korea is left without a marketing campaign.

ISL has been given three months' bankruptcy protection by a Swiss court and is counting on a rescue deal with German TV company UFA to pull it through.

Otherwise, the world's largest football tournament will be paralysed with no one to sell sponsorship packages or arrange corporate hospitality.

The ISL fiasco has added to the growing criticism of Fifa's handling of the 2002 World Cup.

German media group Kirch was sold the European TV rights to the tournament for £670m.

It has been forced to auction off the rights to pay-TV stations in order to recoup the costs, sparking a furious reaction from UK TV bosses and MPs.

Kirch is sweeping the UK auction under the carpet until the general election is over.

The media group fears the negative publicity will put off possible buyers, who include Kirch pay-TV shareholder BSkyB.

Fifa has been accused of milking the World Cup for all it is worth and restricting public access to the tournament as a result.

Fifa was unavailable for comment.

webTitle: Fatal blunders prompt new injection rules

fields.headline: Fatal blunders prompt new injection rules
fields.trailText: Rules governing the treatment of cancer patients by chemotherapy are to be drawn up by the NHS after a catalogue of blunders led to the death of an 18-year-old man with leukaemia.
fields.body:
Rules governing the treatment of cancer patients by chemotherapy are to be drawn up by the NHS after a catalogue of blunders led to the death of an 18-year-old man with leukaemia.

They will include protocols on how, where and when drugs are administered and extra training for doctors, and may even involve changes to equipment to prevent confusion between medications.

Wayne Jowett died at the Queen's medical centre, Nottingham, in February, a month after being injected with a powerful drug through the spine, where it is almost invariably fatal, rather than a vein. He was in remission when a junior doctor, supervised by a registrar who had been in the job for just two days, made the fatal error.

Doctors were powerless to reverse the devastating effects of the mistake and the teenager died nearly a month later, after his body had been slowly paralysed and he suffered heart failure.

An external inquiry yesterday blamed a system failure at the hospital, involving a combination of errors and wrong assumptions. Ward staff appeared to have been "lulled into a false sense of security", said the inquiry report's author, Brian Toft. "People had very strong tacit assumptions that everything they were doing was satisfactory."

There have been 13 similar cases in the past 15 years, five in the past 10 years, representing a mistake rate of about three in 100,000 treatments. But health officials believe there may have been hundreds of "near misses". Mistakes have also been made injecting into veins drugs which should have been administered via the spine.

The Nottingham coroner, Nigel Chapman, recorded a verdict of accidental death at Wayne's inquest yesterday. He said: "We can put a man on the moon but why can't we find a safe method to prevent these deaths?"

The NHS is looking at ways to change the design of syringes so those used for intravenous drugs do not fit the needles used for spinal injections.

Mr Jowett's father, also called Wayne, said afterwards: "I do blame the doctors. There were a lot of procedures that failed. Wayne was full of life, he was sporty and used to play football and rugby and he was also into stock car racing."

The family's solicitor, Paul Balen, said the hospital had accepted legal liability. "Wayne's family wait to see what steps the authority takes against the doctors involved. For all the failures of the hospital's systems and of the education and training of doctors highlighted by this case, nothing should disguise the fact that the doctors treating Wayne fell far short of their professional responsibilities and are to blame for his death."

David Morton and Fred Mulhem, the doctors most closely involved in the case, have been suspended and face a disciplinary investigation. They apologised in a statement issued through the Medical Defence Union. "From the outset we admitted our mistakes in Wayne's treatment. It is very important after a tragedy that all lessons are learned and safe systems put in place to ensure something like this never happens again."

The verdict coincided with the publication of three reports, by Professor Toft and Kent Woods into ways of preventing similar events, and by the University Hospital NHS Trust, responsible for the centre, which said it was following all its inquiry's recommendations on training and new procedures.

John MacDonald, chief executive at the medical centre, said: "We failed Wayne and his family and for that we are deeply sorry. There is no individual to blame. It is a combination of failures."

Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer, at the Department of Health, said the outside reports which he had commissioned "point the way forward in preventing a rare but catastrophic medical error which has repeated itself for nearly 2O years".

Professor Toft, an accident investigator, listed nearly 40 wrong assumptions by staff and pointed to breakdowns in the hospital's rules and safety culture. Professor Woods, of Leicester University and director of the NHS's health technology assessment programme, said: "This is a high-risk procedure. It should be in the hands of a small number of individuals who are fully conversant with all its impli cations." Spinal and vein injections should never be done at the same time or in the same place.

Consideration should be given to ensuring the two types of treatment could not even be given in the same way, for instance putting drugs to be administered through a vein into drip bags. Other equipment such as the connectors for syringes may also need changing.

Medical training must be improved. "Drug prescribing and administration errors occur with unacceptable frequency."

webTitle: Make MoD behave, Adams tells Blair

fields.headline: Make MoD behave, Adams tells Blair
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: Gerry Adams has written to Tony Blair, urging him to force the Ministry of Defence to disclose what the Sinn Fein president claims is information vital to the Bloody Sunday inquiry.
fields.body:
Gerry Adams has written to Tony Blair, urging him to force the Ministry of Defence to disclose what the Sinn Fein president claims is information vital to the Bloody Sunday inquiry.

Mr Adams accused Whitehall and Westminster bureaucrats of trying to undermine the inquiry into the deaths of 14 unarmed Catholic civilians, shot by paratroopers in Londonderry in January 1972, by destroying weapons and withholding documents, photographs and film footage.

"We are watching a serious attempt to subvert the Saville inquiry by those within the British military and political establishment who are intent on preventing the inquiry from getting to the whole truth," he said.

"There are serious concerns at the excuses being made by the British MoD for materials used at the time and which they claim have not been retained, or have been subsequently destroyed and cannot be traced. Relatives and lawyers have made it clear that they do not accept these excuses, particularly as other contemporaneous material that is of benefit to the soldiers' case has become available."

The prime minister set up a fresh investigation into the civil rights march in Londonderry, after a 28-year campaign by the bereaved, who were furious with Lord Widgery's 1972 inquiry, which absolved the army of any blame and cast aspersions on the dead.

Lord Saville has chaired the proceedings in the city's Guildhall since March last year. These are expected to last at least another year, hearing evidence from 1,000 witnesses.

Unionists have criticised the £100m cost of the inquiry, the biggest in British legal history, querying what it will achieve. But for many nationalists, it is an important test, post-Good Friday agreement, of the government's commitment to equality and human rights.

Mr Adams said he was particularly concerned about the destruction of most of the rifles used by soldiers on Bloody Sunday, and the failure of the MoD to provide relevant photographs, film footage and documents.

He said 29 rifles were accounted for in 1999 but only three now remained. The MoD claims some were accidentally disposed of due to a computer glitch. Police are investigating.

The MoD lawyer, Ian Burnett QC, has strenuously denied the ministry has been obstructive or uncooperative. He told the inquiry that herculean efforts had been made to locate anything of possible relevance, but most papers would have been shredded after this length of time.

But Mr Adams said it was unimaginable that Bloody Sunday material had not been considered important enough to keep and he did not believe it had been disposed of.

"If the material was destroyed, there must be a motive or reason for this, and in those circumstances those persons who gave authorisation for destruction must provide an explanation," he said.

Mr Adams's Sinn Fein colleague, Martin McGuinness, a former Provisional IRA leader in Derry, has said he will take the stand at the inquiry.

Lawyers have criticised the wall of silence surrounding IRA activity on Bloody Sunday, and five members of the Official IRA, from which the Provisionals split in the early 1970s, have asked for anonymity in return for their testimony.

fields.headline: Drug mix-up killed leukaemia sufferer
fields.trailText: Wayne Jowett had been diagnosed with leukaemia just over 18 months before his fatal visit for chemotherapy at the Queen's medical centre, Nottingham. His cancer was in remission but he needed "maintenance" treatment using five drugs.
fields.body:
Wayne Jowett had been diagnosed with leukaemia just over 18 months before his fatal visit for chemotherapy at the Queen's medical centre, Nottingham. His cancer was in remission but he needed "maintenance" treatment using five drugs.

He had to go to hospital every three months to receive Cytosine in his spine and an intravenous treatment called Vincristine, a drug that causes death or severe damage to the central nervous system if wrongly administered.

Wayne, 18, was due to receive Cytosine on January 4 and Vincristine the following day but did not arrive on the first morning. He was anxious about the lumbar puncture in his spine before the first drug was administered through a syringe. He arrived with his grandmother that afternoon.

No one informed the consultant in charge of his case. Around 5pm, David Morton - who had been on the ward for five weeks, did not know Wayne and was not aware of the dangers of Vincristine - asked Feda Mulhem, a more senior doctor who was on his third day on the ward and was meant to be shadowing other staff, to oversee him carry out Wayne's treatment.

The drugs were brought from the ward fridge. There were two transparent packages each with a syringe. Dr Mulhem assumed both were meant to be injected in the spine.

Dr Morton gave Wayne a local anaesthetic, performed the lumbar puncture and then administered the Cytosine. Dr Mulhem handed him the second syringe containing Vincristine. This surprised Dr Morton who had used just one syringe on the only other occasion he had performed the procedure under supervision.

Dr Morton told the external inquiry he had questioned whether the syringe was Vincristine and whether it should be administered via the spine. Dr Mulhem said he had it firmly in his mind that it was another drug. The fatal dose was administered.

Around 5.15pm staff realised the mistake. Within minutes specialists were preparing for emergency surgery to wash out the drug. At 6pm Wayne was taken to theatre.

He spent two days in intensive care. His condition worsened. By January 14, he was back in intensive care. On February 2, he died.

Dr Morton told the external inquiry he had questioned whether the syringe was Vincristine and whether it should be administered via the spine. Dr Mulhem said he had it firmly in his mind that it was another drug. The fatal dose was administered. Around 5.15pm staff realised the mistake. Within minutes specialists were preparing for emergency surgery to wash out the drug. At 6pm Wayne was taken to theatre. He spent two days in intensive care. His condition worsened. By January 14, he was back in intensive care. On February 2, he died.

fields.body:
Tristan Davies, the features editor of the Independent, is expected to take over from Janet Street-Porter as editor of the Sunday paper.

Mr Davies, 39, is currently executive editor (features) and has been described as "enthusiastic, confident and a smooth operator".

He is also a close friend of the Independent editor, Simon Kelner.

Mr Davies has been tipped for the role since Ms Street-Porter resigned last week.

Mr Davies the former Express deputy editor, Chris Blackhurst, and the Independent on Sunday's deputy editor, Michael Williams, were the front runners for the job.

Ms Street Porter resigned from the paper last week amid rumours she had failed to bring "fireworks" to the paper's editorial.

She will take on the new role of editor-at-large.

fields.headline: 'Shamed' charities blast commission
fields.trailText: The Charity Commission has been criticised after it 'named and shamed' six charities which it claimed had broken the law by failing to meet their financial obligations.
fields.body:
The Charity Commission has been criticised after it "named and shamed" six charities which it claimed had broken the law by failing to meet their financial obligations.

The charities regulator identified St Mary's Chorus, a church music charity, as a "persistent defaulter" because it had neglected to file annual accounts or returns for three years - but a spokesman for the charity said it was wound up two years ago.

The commission also caused ructions by sending letters to the staff of St Mary's church in Reigate threatening to report it to police - despite the the church having severed all links with the charity 15 years ago.

A second "shamed" charity also claims to have been mis-identified. Barnhill Community Association, a social welfare charity based in Hayes, Middlesex, claims it has filed its accounts, and had been told verbally by the commission that it had been mistakenly named.

The commission this week named four charities it said have broken the law by not returning annual accounts for at least two years.

In a statement the commission said: "All six charities named on our website are persistent defaulters because they have failed to submit annual returns and/or accounts in more than one of the last three years despite being given several opportunities to do so. Charities are also under an obligation to inform us if they have wound up or changed address."

Leslie Olive, who set up St Mary's chorus in 1984, said the charity's constitution was amended 15 years ago to sever all links with the church. In addition, the charity was wound up two years ago.

Mr Olive said: "The Charity Commission's letter addressed to the church caused a flurry of needless concern. The commission has taken a blunderbus approach and has not been very careful about who they contact."

The secretary of St Mary's parish received a letter from the commission threatening police prosecution for not returning accounts for the charity. Its vicar, Dan Connolly, said he was "very angry" that the church's office was named as correspondent for the charity.

The commission said it had not received an up-to-date correspondence address from the charity.

But Mr Olive, who has offered to be the point of contact for matters relating to St Mary's chorus, says he has received correspondence from the commission about the charity.

Barney O'Donnell of Barnhill Community Association said that the charity has submitted annual accounts and that it had been told verbally by the commission that a mistake has been made.

He said the charity was promised a written apology by the commission a month ago after it was threatened with being reported to the police.

Mr O'Donnell said: "I'm disappointed by what they have done. It's not true, it's unprofessional and it's unfair. I understand what they are trying to do, but we have always acted properly."

A spokeswoman for the commission admitted the charity had submitted accounts but she pointed out that it had failed to submit separate returns as it is legally obliged to do.

"Barnhill Community Association is still a persistent defaulter as it has failed to submit annual returns for 1998 and 1999. However, we did originally state that we hadn't received 'certified' accounts for 1998 which was inaccurate.

"It is unfortunate that the charity has not responded appropriately to our enforcement action as this omission could have been corrected months ago."

The commission has posted the charities' names on its website under the heading "persistent defaulters". It said each charity has an estimated income of more than £100,000.

Charities with an income of more than £10,000 are legally obliged to return accounts within 10 months of the end of the financial year and persistent failure can result in a £2,500 fine.

The commission states that its aim is "to give the public confidence in the integrity of charity".

Chief charity commissioner John Stoker said the posting of charity names on its website was "the second stage of a rolling programme of action against persistent defaulters".

He added that in future they may find themselves subject to further publicity, a formal commission inquiry, or to prosecution.

So far the commission has concentrated its efforts only on charities that have previously recorded a gross income or total expenditure of over £100,000. There are 17,000 registered charities in this category.

The commission started its campaign of shaming charities in February when it named eight other persistent defaulters on its website.

Six of these charities have now returned their accounts. Meanwhile, two have continued to ignore the commission, are still named on the website and may now face police prosecution.

A third shamed charity, the Lansdowne House Alcohol Advisory Unit reacted angrily to its treatment by the Charity Commission, claiming it had now submitted draft accounts.

Teresa Weiller, the charity's business manager, said: "I can't stop the Charity Commission publishing this information. But it gives the wrong message, it makes us look as if we can't be bothered or we have got something to hide.

"It doesn't take into the account the problems we have had. It's very complicated and is not as straightforward as it appears."

However, she refused to explain why accounts had not been submitted and added: "I think this is a private matter between ourselves and the Charity Commission."

webTitle: GPs threaten mass NHS walkout over workload

fields.headline: GPs threaten mass NHS walkout over workload
fields.trailText: The British Medical Association decided yesterday to ballot Britain's 36,000 GPs on proposals for a mass walkout from the NHS in protest at excessive workload.
fields.body:
The British Medical Association decided yesterday to ballot Britain's 36,000 GPs on proposals for a mass walkout from the NHS in protest at excessive workload.

John Chisholm, chairman of the association's GPs committee, said the first such threat for a generation could lead to the effective privatisation of the family doctor service if ministers did not agree satisfactory revision of the GP contract within 12 months.

Dr Chisholm said the results were almost certain to be known before June 7, the likely date of the general election. The threat of resignations would not be a good advertisement for the government's relationship with a key group of health service professionals. "The timing is fortuitous," he said. "It is a source of sadness that we have come to this pass."

GPs throughout the UK will be asked if they would be prepared to submit undated letters of resignation from the NHS that would be activated if the government did not agree a new GP contract and broader negotiating rights for the BMA by April next year.

The last such threat was in 1974, when 66% of GPs sent in undated resignations to pressure the government to honour a pay review body's salary recommendations. A pay increase was agreed and the threat was withdrawn.

The Department of Health said the BMA was pushing at an open door. "As we have repeatedly told GP leaders, the government also wants to see a new contract for GPs," a spokeswoman said. "Indeed, the NHS plan commits us to one. With goodwill on all sides it ought to be possible to make real progress."

But the BMA accused ministers of dragging their feet and failing to begin meaningful negotiations.

Dr Chisholm said: "We are advising doctors that patient safety and their ability to deliver safe and competent care to a high standard must be the first priority. Many of the problems that GPs are facing could be alleviated by successfully negotiating a new contract. We believe this must be achieved by this time next year if general practice is not to grind to a halt."

The threat of mass resignations is expected to come mainly from the 90% of GPs on standard contracts with the NHS.

The BMA's initiative follows weeks of mounting unrest among GPs who think the government's promises of extra NHS funds have raised patients' expectations before money comes through to expand services. They are also disgruntled that ministers are planning to concentrate recruitment of extra doctors in hospitals, with only 2,000 extra planned for the GP service by 2004.

According to the BMA, this is less than a fifth of the 10,330 extra needed to provide a satisfactory standard of service.

The BMA is to issue advice to GPs in England on steps they can take to reduce their workload, including cuts in administrative tasks, refusal to register new patients and limits on the size of patient lists.

Dr Chisholm said he did not want to see GPs following dentists out of the NHS into private practice. "A lot of people no longer go to the dentist for preventive work. If GPs were to move towards being an emergency-only service outside the NHS, we would have lost something precious. That's not what we want and not what the government wants."
