fields.headline: Internet Magazine names its top 50
fields.standfirst: Click here for full list
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Freeserve's John Pluthero and Lastminute.com's Brent Hoberman are in, and Stelios Haji-Iannou and Bob Geldof are out, writes Amy Vickers.
Top 50: click here for full list
fields.body:
Freeserve's John Pluthero and Lastminute.com's Brent Hoberman are in, and Stelios Haji-Iannou and Bob Geldof are out.

Yes, it's the top 50 internet luminaries from Emap's Internet Magazine - now an annual event that gathers together the great and the good of the UK internet scene.

This year's new entries also included Hugo Drayton from Hollinger Telegraph New Media, Michael Murphy from FT.com, Danny Kelly from 365 and Martin Turner from Peoplesound.com.

Drop-outs from last year's list included Eva Pascoe from Zoom, Evan Rudowski from Excite, Fabiola Arredondo from Yahoo!, Matthew Freud, Jim Rose from QXL and Ajaz Ahmed from AKQA.

In all, this year's list contains just 11 people with the staying power to boast two years on the list.

These true luminaries are: Simon Waldman from Guardian Unlimited; Cliff Stanford from Redbus; Roger Green from Emap; Derek Wyatt MP; Steve Frazier from Amazon; Carol Dukes from ThinkNatural; Mark Curtis, formerly of Razorfish; Jonathan Robinson from NetBenefit; Jason Drummond from Virtual Internet; and Oliver Roll from Microsoft.

webTitle: Foot and mouth fully under control, says scientist

fields.headline: Foot and mouth fully under control, says scientist
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth epidemic is "fully under control" with the number of cases expected to fall dramatically during May, David King, the government chief scientist, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth epidemic is "fully under control" with the number of cases expected to fall dramatically during May, David King, the government chief scientist, said yesterday. By June 6, the day before the expected general election date, there may be only one new case a day.

Professor King's bold prediction clears the way for an election campaign which will not be dominated by a continuing foot and mouth crisis, with its accompanying pictures of burning carcasses.

The chief scientist has been using university teams of epidemiologists from Imperial College, Cambridge and Edinburgh and Maff's own scientists to track the epidemic's course. All four groups have independently come to the conclusion that the worst is over.

Prof King said that at the peak of the epidemic there were 43 cases a day. Two weeks ago there was an average of 40 cases a day. But in the fortnight ending on Wednesday this week, the average fell to 20 a day. By May 2, it could be down to 10 cases and halve every fortnight thereafter.

He invited journalists to do their "own sums" for subsequent 14-day period but confirmed that by June 6 - the day before the country is likely to go to the polls - he would be "surprised" if there was more than one case a day.

"All the signs are hopeful. In Cumbria, the worst place, the disease is not spreading quite as rapidly as we originally thought. Devon was a potential problem but that too is improving."

The key to the calculations is the number of cases spreading from each previously confirmed case. When the disease was officially declared "out of control" in March there were two new cases spreading from each previous case. Two weeks ago it had fallen to 0.95 cases. It is now just 0.7.

Despite his upbeat attitude Professor King said there could still be "a bumpy ride." The reason he still favoured vaccination, he said, was that he wanted "as many cattle still standing at the end of the epidemic as possible".

He feared that when animals were put out to grass in Cumbria in the next few weeks more herds than was necessary would come down with the disease.

He hoped that a series of meetings between the government and cattle breeders and the National Farmers Union yesterday had won them over on the case for vaccination. A secondary reason for favouring vaccination was that it would save the logistical problems of disposing of thousands of carcasses.

In line with Professor King's predictions the number of confirmed cases on Wednesday dropped to 19 - the first time for a month that there have been fewer than 20 cases in a day. Although final figures will not be known until today Thursday's total is also expected to be below 20.

Maff said last night that as of 8.30pm, parts of Northamptonshire and Leicestershire which had been "infected areas" were no longer designated in that way. "Strict controls remain but they are no longer classed as infected areas," said a spokeswoman.

Maff this would release more than 1,000 farms from the infected area restrictions.

With almost 1,400 cases confirmed, more than 2.1m animals condemned and Maff killing 35,000 animals a day, there is still a two-week slaughtering backlog. Some 427,000 carcasses remained to be disposed of yesterday - the largest number of dead animals since the crisis began.

In addition another 1.1m animals are to be killed as a result of animal welfare problems. So far 289,165 have already gone for slaughter on these grounds.

webTitle: Redstone Telecom sheds 12% of its staff

fields.headline: Redstone Telecom sheds 12% of its staff
fields.standfirst: DSL provider scales back plans to digitise large parts of the country
fields.trailText: Redstone Telecom plans to make 85 staff redundant to reflect the City's more cautious approach to funding hi-tech companies, reports David Teather.
fields.body:
Redstone Telecom yesterday said it planned to make 85 staff redundant to reflect the City's more cautious approach to funding hi-tech companies.

Chief executive Graham Cove, who said he "very much regrets" the move, underlined the need for the company to "live within its means" in the current harsh climate.

The job losses represent 12% of the Redstone workforce and will be made at the company's head office in Borehamwood, Hertfordshire.

"We can't assume that the City will give us any more funding so we have to live with the cash and assets that we have," he said. "Our original business plan was written in very different market conditions where the City often valued growth over profitability. The City has a totally different attitude now."

Mr Cove said the job losses would save £6m a year.

Shares in Redstone have fallen dramatically from their peak of 949.5p, valuing the business at £1.1bn, in the dot.com fuelled heights of February last year. The company, which offers telecoms services to small and medium sized businesses, enjoyed a rare rally yesterday with the shares closing almost 9% higher at 69.5p.

In January, Redstone outlined plans to bring forward its forecast for reaching profitability in 2002-03 by cutting back its plans for the deployment of DSL (digital subscriber line), the technology which can upgrade old copper telephone wires for broadband uses such as high-speed internet.

The company said it would focus on only a handful of cities, including Nottingham and Cambridge, instead of earlier plans to cover large parts of the country.

Yesterday Redstone announced the launch of its first metropolitan service using DSL in Portsmouth and said it hoped to convince investors to back its more ambitious growth plans by showing the services in action.

The commercial pilot is part of the break-up of British Telecom's monopoly of the UK's local networks, otherwise known as the unbundling of the local loop.

"We want to be able to go the City and say this is technology that works and that people are prepared to pay the prices we are charging," Mr Cove said. "There is a real business opportunity in local loop unbundling. We are in discussions with banks and the City to see if there is the appetite there for further funding but we are not assuming anything."

Redstone has sidestepped much of the controversy surrounding the unbundling of the local loop. Instead of arguing over access to BT's local exchanges, the company has opted to store its equipment in adjacent street cabinets.

The cabinets are made from solid steel for security and can be installed without planning permission. Redstone argues that the cost of a street cabinet is only £18,000, compared with an upfront cost of £30,000-£100,000 of installing equipment in a BT exchange.

Last month three of Redstone's executives left abruptly led by John Carrington, non-executive chairman. The others were Glyn Thomas, chief operating officer, and Bob Cushing, group strategy and business development director.

webTitle: New laws to trap crime bosses

fields.headline: New laws to trap crime bosses
fields.standfirst: 'Untouchable' criminal masterminds could be targeted by US-style anti-mafia initiative
fields.trailText: The government is considering introducing powerful new conspiracy laws to tackle up to 200 master criminals who are effectively untouchable because current legislation does not give the police enough powers to tackle them.
fields.body:
The government is considering introducing powerful new conspiracy laws to tackle up to 200 master criminals who are effectively untouchable because current legislation does not give the police enough powers to tackle them.

Senior police officers have urged the Home Office to pursue initiatives similar to the anti-racketeering act in the US, which was credited with crushing the mafia .

The Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organisations Act (Rico) allowed federal agents to target the organising entity behind a crime, "not merely the act" itself. By concentrating on the conspiracy behind a crime, investigators were able to target mafia bosses as well as their footsoldiers.

Sir David Phillips, chairman of the Association of Chief Police Officer's policing committee, has supported the use of laws modelled on Rico in private advice to the Home Office, believing they could prove an essential crime-fighting tool.

The Guardian has learned the Home Office is now circulating a classified consultation paper titled the Prosecution of Organised Criminal Conspiracy to gauge reaction to Rico- style laws from agenciessuch as customs and excise and the crown prosecution service, before deciding what to do.

Concern in Whitehall that a premier league of criminals is prospering with impunity was bolstered last year with the findings of a confidential UK threat assessment report, compiled by the national criminal intelligence service (NCIS).

An abridged version of the report was given to the media but the full document was only presented to ministers.

An investigation into organised crime published in today's Economist newspaper claims to have uncovered further confidential details about the extent of criminality in the UK.

The Economist says it has seen classified NCIS documents that refer to a group of 150 "core nominals" - intelligence-speak for crime bosses - and around 750 lieutenants who work for them. It says the number of such criminals increases by a third every year.

NCIS yesterday denied that these figures were part of its confidential threat assessment report. Nevertheless, it has warned repeatedly about the increasing threat of organised crime in areas like drugs smuggling, illegal arms sales, and immigration rackets.

The willingness of the Home Office to consider new powers for the police became apparent yesterday when it emerged that a leading criminologist, Professor Michael Levi of Cardiff University, was asked to prepare a paper on methods used by other countries to tackle organised crime. His report highlighted the effectiveness of Rico laws in the US, but also questioned whether such laws would work in the UK.

Sir David Phillips, the chief constable of Kent, has advocated the use of similar laws to Lord Justice Auld, who is preparing a report on root and branch reform of the criminal justice system.

"The bottom line is this," said a Home Office spokes man. "We want to prosecute these top criminals and make them 'touchable'. _ At the moment, there is no real consensus on Rico-style laws, though the police are generally positive. We hope to publish the findings of the consultation later this year."

Last month the home secretary, Jack Straw, unveiled a new law to use civil powers to confiscate ill-gotten fortunes worth £220m. The draft proceeds of crime bill, to be introduced later this year, would set up a criminal assets recovery agency charged with the task of hunting down cash, houses, cars and other wealth accumulated through criminal activity.

webTitle: Hague in show of solidarity with Portillo

fields.headline: 'I agree with Michael. I have his full loyalty'
fields.trailText: William Hague was yesterday forced into an unexpected joint appearance with his shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, who in turn made an extraordinary statement of loyalty to the Conservative leader, after speculation that he would challenge Mr Hague for the leadership within days of an election defeat.
fields.body:
William Hague was yesterday forced into an unexpected joint appearance with his shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, who in turn made an extraordinary statement of loyalty to the Conservative leader, after speculation that he would challenge Mr Hague for the leadership within days of an election defeat.

With only weeks to go until the probable June 7 poll, Mr Portillo pledged "complete loyalty" to Mr Hague after the rumours grew increasingly dramatic. He declared: "Every member of the shadow cabinet, quite rightly, is behind William Hague. I think William Hague knows that he has complete loyalty from all the members of the shadow cabinet. There is no doubt about that in any of our minds, not William's, not mine and not anyone else's."

Standing beside him, the Tory leader added: "I absolutely agree with every word Michael has just said. I have the complete loyalty of the shadow cabinet. They are loyal to each other and loyal to me and we are not going to be sidetracked by media reports based on nonsense from the job of putting forward the policies on the foot and mouth crisis that we are here to put forward today."

Mr Hague's shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, also denied stories in yesterday's papers that he was to be the "chief assassin" - gathering backbenchers' signatures for a no-confidence motion - in the plot to overthrow Mr Hague. He dismissed the reports as "unadulterated rubbish" and "mischief-making".

He said: "The truth, as William Hague has said this morning, is that the shadow cabinet is and has been entirely loyal to him.

"The overwhelming majority of Conservatives - including all of its senior members - want nothing other than to get rid of this shoddy and damaging government and to replace it with a Conservative administration led by William Hague."

Tory sources privately believe that some of Mr Portillo's staff could be the source of the rumours. They are also keen to blame Downing Street, convinced that there is a deliberate Labour strategy to undermine Mr Hague by continually questioning his leadership.

The Conservative party's vice-chairman, Steven Norris, was last night also forced to declare his position on the leadership after reports suggested he would back Mr Portillo. "I don't honestly know where some of these people get this absolute rubbish," he said. "As far as I am concerned William Hague is not only the leader but the leader I support and will go on supporting."

But in a separate development, the attempt to end what one senior Tory described as the "desperately damaging" reports of plotting at the top was undermined by the revelation that a Tory whip, James Cran, and an ex-minister, Eric Forth, were both defying the leadership by refusing to sign up to the commission for racial equality's "election compact" - despite Mr Hague's commitment to it. A third Tory MP, John Townend, who is not standing again but who was at the centre of a row this month over racist remarks, has also refused to sign.

The CRE, which launched its campaign a month ago with the support of all the party leaders, released figures yesterday afternoon showing that as well as the three who specifically refused to sign, two-thirds of the Tory party's other MPs had yet to back the agreement. In contrast, nearly two-thirds of Labour MPs and almost all Liberal Democrats have signed up. The compact, while calling for robust debate on issues such as asylum, says: "The right to free expression must not be abused in the competition for popular votes by causing, or exploiting, prejudice and discrimination on the grounds of race and nationality."

The Cabinet Office minister, Ian McCartney, called on Mr Hague to sack Mr Cran from the frontbench.

The Tories insisted last night that it was unnecessary for every candidate to sign up because Mr Hague had committed all Conservatives to the terms of the compact.

Tim Butcher, the prospective Tory candidate for Gillingham, which is held by Labour with a 1,980-vote majority, added last night: "I'm not keen on all these pieces of paper, signing up to this, signing up to that. I believe in what I believe in."

Standing beside him, the Tory leader added: "I absolutely agree with every word Michael has just said. I have the complete loyalty of the shadow cabinet. They are loyal to each other and loyal to me and we are not going to be sidetracked by media reports based on nonsense from the job of putting forward the policies on the foot and mouth crisis that we are here to put forward today." Mr Hague's shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, also denied stories in yesterday's papers that he was to be the "chief assassin" - gathering backbenchers' signatures for a no-confidence motion - in the plot to overthrow Mr Hague. He dismissed the reports as "unadulterated rubbish" and "mischief-making". He said: "The truth, as William Hague has said this morning, is that the shadow cabinet is and has been entirely loyal to him. "The overwhelming majority of Conservatives - including all of its senior members - want nothing other than to get rid of this shoddy and damaging government and to replace it with a Conservative administration led by William Hague." Tory sources privately believe that some of Mr Portillo's staff could be the source of the rumours. They are also keen to blame Downing Street, convinced that there is a deliberate Labour strategy to undermine Mr Hague by continually questioning his leadership. The Conservative party's vice-chairman, Steven Norris, was last night also forced to declare his position on the leadership after reports suggested he would back Mr Portillo. "I don't honestly know where some of these people get this absolute rubbish," he said. "As far as I am concerned William Hague is not only the leader but the leader I support and will go on supporting." But in a separate development, the attempt to end what one senior Tory described as the "desperately damaging" reports of plotting at the top was undermined by the revelation that a Tory whip, James Cran, and an ex-minister, Eric Forth, were both defying the leadership by refusing to sign up to the commission for racial equality's "election compact" - despite Mr Hague's commitment to it. A third Tory MP, John Townend, who is not standing again but who was at the centre of a row this month over racist remarks, has also refused to sign. The CRE, which launched its campaign a month ago with the support of all the party leaders, released figures yesterday afternoon showing that as well as the three who specifically refused to sign, two-thirds of the Tory party's other MPs had yet to back the agreement. In contrast, nearly two-thirds of Labour MPs and almost all Liberal Democrats have signed up. The compact, while calling for robust debate on issues such as asylum, says: "The right to free expression must not be abused in the competition for popular votes by causing, or exploiting, prejudice and discrimination on the grounds of race and nationality." The Cabinet Office minister, Ian McCartney, called on Mr Hague to sack Mr Cran from the frontbench. The Tories insisted last night that it was unnecessary for every candidate to sign up because Mr Hague had committed all Conservatives to the terms of the compact. Tim Butcher, the prospective Tory candidate for Gillingham, which is held by Labour with a 1,980-vote majority, added last night: "I'm not keen on all these pieces of paper, signing up to this, signing up to that. I believe in what I believe in."

webTitle: Tories pledge to end pupil appeals

fields.headline: Tories pledge to end pupil appeals
fields.standfirst:
Full coverage of Election 2001

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The Conservatives yesterday pledged to support teachers in restoring discipline to classrooms by announcing plans to abolish the appeals panels which have the power to send pupils expelled for violent or disruptive behaviour back to school.
fields.body:
The Conservatives yesterday pledged to support teachers in restoring discipline to classrooms by announcing plans to abolish the appeals panels which have the power to send pupils expelled for violent or disruptive behaviour back to school.

The panels were set up by the Conservative administration in the mid-80s to give parents the right to challenge their child's expulsion, but have proved deeply unpopular with teachers who complain that they have to teach unruly pupils who have previously been ejected from the classroom.

The Tories had already announced plans to abandon the government's target to reduce the number of pupils permanently excluded from school by a third by 2002. But at the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers annual conference in Jersey yesterday, the shadow education and employment secretary, Theresa May, revealed that a Conservative government would also abolish the appeals system.

"Too often schools are forced to take back violent pupils," she said to loud applause. "No school should have to take back a pupil who has attacked and injured a teacher. That means allowing heads to remove disruptive and violent pupils, not just from the classroom, but from the school."

Such pupils would be taught in full time "progress centres", while greater efforts would be made to tackle disruptive behaviour among those most at risk of expulsion.

There are 10,000 permanent exclusions each year, of which 10% are referred to the appeals panels, leading to around 2% of pupils being returned to schools against the wishes of the headteachers.

Mrs May was given a largely polite reception by the delegates, who voted earlier this week in favour of scrapping the panels - a view not shared by all the teaching unions.

She also announced plans to guarantee anonymity to teachers accused of physical or sexual abuse by pupils until charged by police. Delegates want anonymity until a court verdict is given.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT, welcomed the plans to scrap the panels. He said it would lead to a rise in the number of exclusions, "but that is no bad thing". The increase could be tenfold if the plans led to action being taken on assaults previously unreported by headteachers.

fields.headline: Emap revives Screendaily.com
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Emap's film website, Screendaily.com, has been resurrected three weeks after being killed off, writes Jason Deans.

27.03.01: Emap axes UK staff as websites close

27.03.01: Emap memo to staff
fields.body:
Emap's film industry website, Screendaily.com, has been resurrected three weeks after being killed off in a cull of the company's online businesses.

Screendaily.com, the online offshoot of film trade weekly Screen International, has gone live again this week after Screen staff lobbied Emap Digital's chief executive, Paul Keenan, to reverse his decision.

The service was one of around a dozen Emap Digital websites shut down in wide-ranging cutbacks in the internet division in late March.

In the intervening weeks a holding page replaced Screendaily.com's regular service.

The Screen International publisher, Anne-Marie Flynn, and her staff are understood to have successfully argued that the website was a vital part of the weekly title's strategy to compete more effectively with its daily US rivals, Variety and Hollywood Reporter.

Screendaily.com gives the British title a daily presence in the offices of Hollywood studio executives for the first time.

Staff from the film title are also said to have argued that closing down Screendaily.com, which is maintained by only one full-time journalist, would save a relatively small amount of money.

Screen insiders were particularly incensed that having launched the website off their own backs in early 2000, it was taken over by Emap Digital and closed down without any consultation.

Ms Flynn said she was not able to comment when contacted by MediaGuardian.co.uk.

webTitle: Sir Humphrey moves to India in a BBC first

fields.headline: Sir Humphrey moves to India in a BBC first
fields.standfirst: Yes Minister remade in Hindi to try to conquer Bollywood market
fields.trailText: Yes Minister remade in Hindi to try to conquer Bollywood market
fields.body:
Given the similarities between British and Indian bureaucracy, it had to happen sooner or later. Yesterday one of India's leading TV channels launched a Hindi version of the classic 80s political comedy Yes Minister following a unique collaboration with the BBC.

The adaptation, Ji Mantriji, faithfully follows all 38 episodes of the much-loved series, starring Sir Nigel Hawthorne and the late Paul Eddington, but with Indian actors.

Gone is Jim Hacker, the flappable minister advised - rarely to his advantage - by his suave permanent secretary Sir Humphrey Appleby. In their places are characters Surya Prakash Singh, who eventually rises to become prime minister, like his sometimes naive British counterpart, and Rajnath Mathur.

While the scripts are almost identical to the original series, a few references have been tweaked to place them in an Indian context. Football becomes cricket, the European community the Commonwealth, and Russia becomes Pakistan - India's perennial foe.

A memorable episode in which the minister's daughter threatens to strip naked unless he stops the demolition of a badger sanctuary features monkeys instead.

"This is the first time the BBC has completely recreated a series for the Indian market or for anyone else in the world," said Mark Young, the BBC's India managing director. The experiment would be repeated if Ji Mantriji was a success, he added.

Ji Mantriji, which is being screened by the Star TV channel from next week, stars a comedy actor, Farooque Sheikh, in the Jim Hacker role, with Jayant Kripalani as Sir Humphrey. Paritosh Sand plays the role of Bernard, the minister's private secretary. The series, like its predecessor, has a sequel, Ji Pradhanmantriji, or Yes Prime Minister.

"When I saw Yes Minister 20 years ago I thought the part was written for me - except I was Indian, brown and in the wrong country," Mr Kripalani said yesterday. "It came as a joyous surprise when I was offered the role.

"All the long, convoluted sentences Sir Humphrey used to speak work beautifully in Hindi," he added. "The series adapts very well because the systems of democracy and the bureaucracies in Britain and India are pretty much the same."

To ensure authenticity, Ji Mantriji's director Smeeta Chakrabati called in on several Indian ministers before filming began last summer. An office decorated with pot plants, a portrait of Gandhi and an Indian flag resulted, replacing Jim Hacker's wood-panelled inner sanctum. Some of the scenes are shot in India's monumental parliament building.

Surya Prakash Singh is driven round in a white Ambassador car with blue curtains- rather than a Rover. When he becomes prime minister he gets a Honda. "My favourite episode is when the minister gets a death threat. We had to make very few changes, because if anything security is even tighter here than in the UK," Ms Chakrabati said.

The original Yes Minister series, first screened in 1980 on BBC2, gained a huge following among India's English-speaking middle class after it was shown on Doordashan, the state-run channel.

Most TV pundits expect Ji Mantriji to be a runaway hit - though a few sceptics have questioned whether it will work. "Both Yes Minister and Yes Prime Minister are so typically British that having them performed in any other language would be akin to murder," columnist V Gangadhar declared recently in the Hindustan Times.

"How can the Hindiwallas recreate immortal characters such as James Hacker and Humphrey Appleby?" he asked.

Indian audiences have long grown used to watching foreign imports - most Bollywood films borrow their plots from Hollywood blockbusters.

They are still glued to Kaun Banega Crorepati?, India's gripping version of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? There have even been Hindi versions of Pride and Prejudice and Wuthering Heights. The BBC is so confident of success it is sending a boxed set of Ji Mantriji to India's elderly prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, and his cabinet as a "gesture".

"He has a sense of humour. I'm not so sure about his party," Mr Kripalani said.

fields.headline: Restrictions to be lifted
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: More than 1,000 farms in parts of Northamptonshire and Leicestershire are to be released from infected area restrictions, the Ministry of Agriculture said last night.
fields.body:
More than 1,000 farms in parts of Northamptonshire and Leicestershire are to be released from infected area restrictions, the Ministry of Agriculture said last night.

They are the first infected areas where this has happened, although "strict controls remain but they are no longer classed as infected areas", a Maff spokeswoman said.

The countryside minister, Elliot Morley, said: "Whilst our number one priority remains combating the disease in the most heavily infected areas, it is right that in areas where there have been few or no new cases we do what we can to lift restrictions."

Regulations require that 3km protection zones and 10km surveillance zones are placed around infected premises, but the lifting of the infected area restrictions will allow farmers to apply to obtain licences to begin moving their animals. Livestock in the 3km protection zone around the premises have to be inspected regularly for the first 21 days, after which blood testing of all sheep and goat herds within the zone must be carried out to be 95% confident of detecting a 5% incidence of the disease.

After 30 days, if all inspections and blood tests prove negative, the infected area can be lifted.

webTitle: Train staff vote for two days of strikes

fields.headline: Train staff vote for two days of strikes
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Commuters face further chaos next month when guards on one of the country's busiest rail operators stage strikes over the "breakdown" of industrial relations.
fields.body:
Commuters face further chaos next month when guards on one of the country's busiest rail operators stage strikes over the "breakdown" of industrial relations.

The decision by hundreds of staff at South West Trains to walk out on May 3 and May 11 will affect more than 350,000 passengers who travel on SWT services across London, southern and south west England.

Members of the Rail Mar itime and Transport union voted by 271 to 118 in favour of industrial action yesterday. The May 3 action will coincide with a one day strike on London Underground.

The RMT's regional officer, Phil Bialyk, said: "There has been a complete breakdown in industrial relations on a number of issues."

 London Underground is to run a month's trial of an air freshener that is released by passengers walking across treated floors.

webTitle: First aider jailed for sex attacks

fields.headline: First aider jailed for sex attacks
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: A volunteer ambulanceman from Greater Manchester was jailed for 6 years yesterday for a string of assaults on boys under his supervision.
fields.body:
A volunteer ambulanceman from Greater Manchester was jailed for 6 years yesterday for a string of assaults on boys under his supervision.

Ken Whittaker, 67, from Denton, used his position as a volunteer with the St John's Ambulance Brigade to molest and rape the boys who attended the charity organisation's headquarters in Tameside to learn life saving techniques.

Whittaker was found guilty at Minshull Street crown court in Manchester of two rapes, one attempted rape, six inde cent assaults and three charges of indecency with a child. He will stay on the sex offender register for life and was disqualified from working with children.

Whittaker managed to conceal nearly 50 years of abuse from his wife Mary. It was not until one of his victims, now aged 24, came forward last year after spotting him in the street that the extent of what he had done was revealed.

Police discovered that in 1954 Mottram magistrates fined him £10 for indecently assaulting an eight-year-old boy outside a sports pavilion and in August 1957 he was put on probation for a similar assault on a 10-year-old boy.

David Lane QC, prosecuting, told the court that brigade chiefs were unaware of his past when he became a volunteer ambulanceman. There he formed friendships and gained the trust of parents who believed his pretence of offering extra tuition to spend time alone with the boys. The men who gave evidence had kept their ordeal secret for more than 15 years

Judge Peter Lakin told Whitaker: "You breached the trust placed in you."

fields.headline: Drug dealing prison officer jailed
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: A prison officer who used insider knowledge to become a drugs dealer was jailed for 7 years yesterday.
fields.body:
A prison officer who used insider knowledge to become a drugs dealer was jailed for 7 years yesterday.

Former army officer Vincent Hill, 41, from Huntington, North Yorkshire, used his position at Armley prison in Leeds to eavesdrop on conversations between inmates to "gain contact in the underground world of drug dealers".

Hill was caught trying to sell 5,000 ecstasy tablets worth £50,000 to two undercover police officers from the national crime squad who secretly taped the conversation at Doncaster railway station.

He told police after his arrest in March 1999 that he was attempting to rid the prison system of drugs by infiltrating the local gangs. He was convicted last month after a two week trial at Leeds crown court for possessing with intent to supply, and offering to supply a class A drug.

Sentencing the father of two, Judge Peter Cliffe said: "You of all people - with your experience in the prison service and your dedication to body fitness as a PE instructor - must have known the devastating effect that these drugs can have especially on young people."

Hill was a highly decorated former soldier. In 1990 he received a commendation from the then home secretary, Michael Howard, for bravery during the Strangeways prison riots.

At his trial Hill denied dealing ecstasy and told the court that he was suffering from post traumatic stress disorder in the months leading up to his arrest. He claimed that this illness was caused by his military service in Northern Ireland and his experiences of the Strangeways riots.

webTitle: BP chief fields barrage of questions on ethics

fields.headline: BP chief fields barrage of questions on ethics
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol crisis
fields.trailText: A Sudanese priest, a Tibetan exile, an American nun and a Canadian politician queued up to berate the board of BP yesterday over the firm's "unworthy" investments in politically sensitive areas of the world.
fields.body:
A Sudanese priest, a Tibetan exile, an American nun and a Canadian politician queued up to berate the board of BP yesterday over the firm's "unworthy" investments in politically sensitive areas of the world.

Chairman Peter Sutherland fielded three hours of hostile questions over BP's business ethics during the group's annual general meeting at a packed Royal Festival Hall in London.

A resolution urging BP to take a tougher line on tackling climate change attracted significant support of 7.5% of proxy voters, while just over 5% of investors voted for BP to withdraw from its £390m shareholding in Beijing-controlled PetroChina.

The group's PetroChina stake attracted the most criticism. Stephen Kretzmann, of the International Campaign for Tibet, suggested BP's new slogan "Beyond Petroleum" should be changed to "Beijing's Partners" or "Backing Persecution". He said BP was "utilising every arcane and legalistic tool to stifle debate on the matter".

PetroChina is planning to build an oil pipeline through Tibet. Opponents, including the Dalai Lama, say this threatens local culture and will lead to large-scale population transfer. Gedun Rinchen, a former political prisoner in Tibet, told Mr Sutherland: "Tibetans will be affected by BP's investment in PetroChina. And Tibetans say: 'We don't want BP involved'."

In response, Mr Sutherland said "rhetoric and emotion" were obscuring the basic facts: "Disinvesting from PetroChina means, in reality, departing from China which would be a mistake, and would be wrong."

PetroChina's parent company, CNPC, is supporting oil operations in war-ravaged Sudan. Anthony Poggo, an Anglican clergyman from Sudan, said: "Oil development continues only because of massive scorched-earth warfare conducted by the Khartoum regime against the ordinary populations of the south."

Directors arriving at the meeting were greeted by a giant inflatable caribou to remind them of the company's support for drilling in the Alaskan wilderness. One US investor said: "The Arctic natural refuge is part of America's crown jewels. It's analogous to you drilling in Westminster Abbey." He was supported by a member of the legislative assembly from Canada's Northwest Territories, who said such a move would upset the environment.

During a discussion on BP's ethical policies, directors were asked for an example of a country in which BP had chosen not to invest, because of human rights abuses. After a long pause, chief executive Sir John Browne said it would be "uncivil and inappropriate" to mention any no-go nations.

Sister Pat Daly, a Dominican nun from New Jersey, urged BP to invest more cash in renewable energy. Mr Sutherland said: "There have been calls for BP to phase out the sale of fossil fuels. We cannot accept this, and there's no point pretending we can."

webTitle: Butterflies stand in way of white horse

fields.headline: Butterflies stand in way of white horse
fields.standfirst: Plans for a Folkestone tourist attraction could destroy habitat
fields.trailText: It is a very peculiar planning inquiry. On one side are Michael Howard, Spike Milligan, Joanna Lumley and Shepway district council. On the other is English Nature.
fields.body:
It is a very peculiar planning inquiry. On one side are Michael Howard, Spike Milligan, Joanna Lumley and Shepway district council. On the other is English Nature.

At stake are the fate of rare butterflies and orchids, and the civic pride of Folkestone.

The proposal to create a giant white horse on a grassy chalk hill overlooking the entrance to the channel tunnel has inflamed such passion that the Department of Environment deemed an inquiry was necessary. It is due to end tomorrow, although the wrangling seems certain to continue.

What began as a millennium art project has become a highly charged symbol of the town's future. Its supporters - who include Milligan and Lumley, both friends of the artist behind the scheme - say it will regenerate the resort. The council believes the 100m long galloping horse will brand Folkestone as an energetic town, attracting visitors and giving pleasure and pride to residents for generations to come.

Its detractors call the scheme a folly which will despoil a precious resource while doing little to tackle the area's underlying problems.

English Nature argues that Cheriton Hill itself is a greater treasure than anything which could be created there. Rare adonis blue butterflies and spider orchids have made the chalk escarpment their home; it is a site of special scientific interest and a candidate special area of conservation.

"We don't disagree with the need for economic regeneration, but there is no need to damage and destroy a site of national and international wildlife importance in the process," said Teresa Bennett, acting team manager for the body's Kent branch.

She fears that creating and maintaining the horse would damage the area and attract tourists who could endanger the vulnerable wildlife.

But supporters dismiss English Nature's calls for them to choose a different location.

"The site is pretty much the last view you have of England as you leave through the Channel tunnel and the first view you have as you arrive," Mr Howard, MP for Folkestone and Hythe and a former environment minister and home secretary, told the hearing yesterday.

Arguing that the potential for ecological damage had been "vastly exaggerated", he added: "The economy of Folkestone could be transformed if only a small proportion of the large numbers of people who leave or enter the country through the tunnel were to stop to enjoy the area's attractions.

"Despite all the efforts people have made we have so far made disappointing progress in attracting people to stay."

His conviction may have been fostered by a recent visitor from America, who spotted designs for the horse on a website and came to Folkestone believing it already existed.

Charles Newington, the proposed artist, says he was taken aback by the support for his design. "It's become important as an issue because the people of Folkestone want it," he said. "You can call it a lucky charm, a talisman, an icon.

"I didn't see it as a way of regenerating the area when I started, but that's what it's become."

There are around 17 chalk horses in the UK and the practice of cutting them even has its own name, leucippotomy. The best known, at Uffington in Berkshire, probably dates from between 1,400 and 600 BC, although most were created in the last three centuries.

Rather than carve a horse, Folkestone volunteers will fix panels into the soil to reduce damage from erosion and make maintenance easy. Mr Newington estimates that it will cost around £4,000, which he believes will be easily raised through donations.

John Prescott, the environment secretary, will read the inquiry's recommendations and approve or reject the scheme within the next six months.

Should he turn it down, Richard Bougie, who farms Cheriton Hill and is the scheme's foremost advocate, has warned that they may go all the way to the European courts, albeit with misgivings.

"You know what they do to horses in Brussels, don't you?" he asked the planning inspector. "They eat them."

webTitle: Ministry quietly eases mass slaughter policy

fields.headline: Ministry quietly eases mass slaughter policy
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Alarm that thousands of animals were being slaughtered unnecessarily has led the Ministry of Agriculture quietly to drop its policy of killing all animals on farms next to infected premises within 48 hours.
fields.body:
Alarm that thousands of animals were being slaughtered unnecessarily has led the Ministry of Agriculture quietly to drop its policy of killing all animals on farms next to infected premises within 48 hours.

So many tests of samples taken from animals diagnosed as having foot and mouth proved negative after slaughter that ministry vets began to doubt that the original diagnoses were correct.

The change was ordered in a series of briefings to vets after the Easter weekend. Unless vets were absolutely certain of diagnosis then healthy animals should be left alive until the government's laboratory at Pirbright in Surrey had confirmed the case.

This reverses the prime minister's decision on March 23 that all animals suspected of having foot and mouth must be killed within 24 hours and animals on neighbouring farms within 48 hours. Those targets have never been met.

The problem has arisen because sheep are not seriously ill with the disease and it is difficult to diagnose.

There have been an increasing number of cases where a few sheep are believed to have the disease and as a result large numbers of healthy valuable cattle have been killed.

Yesterday the chief scientist, David King, said the culling policy remained in place although "exceptions" were being made.

The system, in place since March 23, has been modified. Previously when vets found a suspect case, they decided on instant slaughter.

This was confirmed in a telephone call to Whitehall where Maff vets are on standby to discuss symptoms. Only if there was serious doubt about the diagnosis were tests taken. Now vets have been warned that they must be certain before ordering slaughter and animals must be given "the benefit of the doubt" until confirmation comes through.

With the epidemic on the wane and a backlog of already condemned animals still to be slaughtered, this cautious approach is expected to save many pedigree animals.

webTitle: Hill farmers 'need to be land stewards'

fields.headline: Hill farmers 'need to be land stewards'
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Farmers gripped by the foot and mouth crisis should be given new government grants to become "land stewards" sensitive to the needs of the environment, an official report to the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, proposed.
fields.body:
Farmers gripped by the foot and mouth crisis should be given new government grants to become "land stewards" sensitive to the needs of the environment, an official report to the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, proposed.

The hill farms task force report, commissioned by Mr Brown, proposed a hill environment land management payment to recognise the value of hill farms to environmental protection, maintenance of the countryside and rural communities.

The report suggested the crisis "could provide an opportunity to encourage a less intensive and more environmentally friendly way of farming".

It continued: "The future could be one in which animals do not have to travel so far, local markets reduce the roles of the middle man and the big chains, and the environmental output of the hills - which underpins tourism and quality of life for society - is properly rewarded."

The proposals are likely to be central to the debate on the future of farming, and Britain's approach to the common agriculture policy following the election and the end of the foot and mouth outbreak. Ministers have already hinted at an inquiry into the future of farming following the election.

There is likely to be a contest between those in government who favour bigger, more efficient farms and those who support grants to encourage environmental land management. The report proposed shifting more of the £3.5bn spent on farming each year into supporting environmental farming.

Ministers expect large numbers of older farmers to quit the land following the crisis.

But the task force counseled: "Should land be abandoned it will profoundly change the landscape which people expect to see when they visit the uplands. We think there is an urgent need for action to sustain the landscape and wildlife which is now as valuable a product as the stock hill farmers traditionally produce."

The proposed hill environment fund would eventually replace the existing environmental enhancements included in the Ministry of Agriculture's hill farm allowance and would bring the aid back up to at least £42m a year.

Ministers are planning to cut payments to hill farmers by £20m in three years as part of a move to focus payments on acreage rather than number of animals, especially sheep.

The hills task force was chaired by David Arnold-Forster from English Nature, and included members of the National Farmers' Union.

Its report found most hill farmers, many hit by foot and mouth, were desperately short of cash, though nominally asset rich. Most hill farmers were receiving £5,500 a year.

The report warned: "Before the foot and mouth outbreak, most hill farmers had no financial cushion to withstand future shocks and many were only surviving at all because of income earned off the farm, often by the wife.

"Foot and mouth will tip more hill farmers over the brink. Some may not want to restock, even if they could ... all would need to reassess their stocking policies."

The proposed grants would be focused on issues such as animal density, the length of field boundaries and the cost of maintaining the landscape, including dry stone walls. There would also be additional payments to special areas of conservation or common land.

Payments would also be given to farmers to ensure appropriate stocking levels for the relevant land, as well as the maintenance of historic or archaeological remains.

The report also proposed extra support for moorland, so that farms with large areas of moorland are not penalised.

webTitle: Organic farm sees off Maff over cull plan

fields.headline: Organic farm sees off Maff over cull plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The government's legal case to force the slaughter of healthy animals on farms next to infected premises was last night in tatters after the Ministry of Agriculture dropped its case against one of Britain's most high profile organic farms.
fields.body:
The government's legal case to force the slaughter of healthy animals on farms next to infected premises was last night in tatters after the Ministry of Agriculture dropped its case against one of Britain's most high profile organic farms.

Oaklands Park in Gloucestershire, a Rudolf Steiner community of 115 people, 100 sheep and 60 cows, had contested the culling of its animals for almost two weeks - but with slaughtermen expected in yesterday, it unexpectedly won a reprieve.

According to Maff, the government will now not slaughter the animals or pursue the community through the courts and will only require it to monitor its animals.

It was unclear last night whether the government backed off the Oaklands animals because it was a respected care in the community centre with 50 people with learning difficulties, and because of a strong media presence.

fields.headline: Charge against Tory reduced
fields.trailText: A prosecution lawyer yesterday withdrew a firearms charge against a Conservative prospective parliamentary candidate and replaced it with a lesser allegation.
fields.body:
A prosecution lawyer yesterday withdrew a firearms charge against a Conservative prospective parliamentary candidate and replaced it with a lesser allegation.

Christian Sweeting, 33, who is standing for the Torbay seat, was originally charged with possessing a firearm with intent to cause Aaron Disley to believe that unlawful violence would be used against him.

But when Sweeting, of Torquay, appeared before the town's magistrates, prosecutor Tony Creech said that the charge, under the Firearms Act, was being withdrawn. The new charge alleges that Sweeting caused to another harassment, alarm or distress on Monday.

Sweeting denied the charge when it was put to him.

The hearing was adjourned for four weeks for a pre-trial hearing and Sweeting was granted unconditional bail.

Reporting restrictions were not lifted yesterday.

Outside court Sweeting was cheered by a crowd of about 30 supporters as he emerged.

His solicitor, Robert Newman, said outside court: "The charge that has been brought this morning is a very much reduced charge." The prosecution had reduced the charge to a public order offence, he said.

Sweeting said on the steps of the court: "I am not prepared to live in a walk-on-by society. I have always maintained the right of a homeowner to defend his own property, the right of an individual to self defence, and a son to protect his mother when a threat is perceived," he said.

Sweeting was selected in 1999 to fight Torbay, currently held by the Liberal Democrats with the smallest majority in the country - just 12 votes.

fields.headline: Bush's Britain
fields.standfirst:
There have been American radar stations at Fylingdales and Menwith Hill for years - scanning the skies for hostile missiles. They have never attracted much criticism. But recently they have changed in appearance. Surely this can only mean one thing - they will play a central role in the US president's controversial 'Star Wars' strategy. Now it is not just the people of North Yorkshire who are worrying. Andy Beckett reports

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: There have been American radar stations at Fylingdales and Menwith Hill for years - scanning the skies for hostile missiles. They have never attracted much criticism. But recently they have changed in appearance. Surely this can only mean one thing - they will play a central role in the US president's controversial 'Star Wars' strategy. Now it is not just the people of North Yorkshire who are worrying. Andy Beckett reports.
fields.body:
During the late 50s, when fears of Soviet nuclear attack began to quicken, with a certain amount of encouragement from western governments, the US Air Force proposed a controversial counter-measure: a ballistic missile early warning system should be built, involving radar stations sited as close as possible to where the attack would supposedly be launched. In other words not in America at all, but on European soil.

Suitable locations needed to be near the sea, with an unobstructed view of the horizon. They had to be high up, with enough distance and difficult terrain between them and the shoreline to deter any raiding party landed by submarine. And they had to be in a country that was used to giving America what it wanted.

In 1959, the British government was asked if Prestwick, an existing US Air Force base south of Glasgow, could be expanded to take the new radar. But there was a problem: the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament was gaining momentum, and the radar's presence near a large left-wing city would draw protesters. Moreover, they would have a point; as the American magazine Aviation Week admitted, the radar "would make the area a prime target". The British said no to Prestwick. In 1960, the Americans tried again. This time, they suggested somewhere so bleak and remote that, they successfully argued, even the most determined peace campaigners would not want to linger: Fylingdales.

Up on this bald rust-brown moor above Whitby in north Yorkshire, late spring feels like midwinter. The wind is a blast of invisible ice cubes off the North Sea. There are few trees or walls to interrupt the lowering clouds or the records collected by meteorologists.

And for most of the time since 1963, when the radar station began functioning, it has peered down on the world from its ridgetop, at first as a set of giant pale spheres, more recently as a single grey pyramid, somewhere between Aztec temple and vast Toblerone chunk, without attracting much criticism.

There have been local complaints about mysterious malfunctions by car alarms and radios. There have been small peace marches and temporary protest camps, sporadic trespasses by campaigners against American bases, chilled figures with banners and leaflets beside the A169, the only road in this empty corner of England, with its no-stopping signs and bylaws forbidding meetings where "matters of public interest are discussed".

But Fylingdales has never become unacceptable to Britons in general. Until, perhaps, the past few months. Since George Bush took office as American president in January, a previously faint suspicion about his country's strategic intentions, at least in the minds of most non-Americans, has solidified into an alarming realisation. "Star Wars", or America's long-standing and erratically pursued dream of using space as a defensive barrier against missile assault, is now a "moral" and "constitutional" priority of the new administration, rather than a mere fantasy project dogged by technical failures.

Fylingdales and another American base in north Yorkshire, Menwith Hill near Harrogate, will very likely be central elements of this new anti-missile system. Long-range radars sited in Britain, as in the American early warning scheme of the late 1950s, will be ideally positioned, thanks to the curvature of the Earth, to spot rockets from Russia or China or the Middle East early in their trajectories.

But this time there will be significant differences. America intends to shoot down enemy missiles. Exactly who this enemy might be is no longer a matter of western consensus. And unlike during the cold war, the silent American compounds of perimeter fencing and aerials on British hilltops, with their American officers and orders from and direct links to American headquarters, may extend no protection to their host nation.

"I don't know anyone in the government, including the prime minister, who thinks it is a great idea," says a Labour minister who has negotiated with the Americans over National Missile Defense (NMD), as Star Wars has revealingly long been known in Washington. "There is deep opposition within the party. People think it's mad, and people think it's dangerous." And even worse than the American cruise missiles so contentiously deployed at Greenham Common, he adds, the British parts of NMD would require local planning permission and an extension of the bases in question. "You are going to get everybody from the Women's Institute to CND on your back if this thing is built."

Yet, in the way of Anglo-American relations since the second world war, Britain is getting ready to agree. Officially, the Ministry of Defence maintains that no specific American proposals have been received. But the minister continues: "Obviously, America is our closest ally, and we would like to be helpful." He talks about "influencing" Washington into choosing "a version of NMD we can all live with".

On Menwith Hill, the results of this policy of incremental concessions may already be visible. Since last summer, a pair of smooth white globes have sprouted, mounted on white stalks like great button mushrooms, amid the older huts and domes of this long-established American listening station on the moors. These new structures are for tracking satellites. The current British line is that they are not "intended" to become part of an anti-missile system.

Lindis Percy and Anni Rainbow disagree. For the past five years, from a small terraced house a few miles south, with Gandhi's writings on civil disobedience on the shelves and their correspondence in determined piles, they have sought to expose the Americans' long-term plans for Menwith Hill. "We were up there last night," says Rainbow, who is in early middle age and uses a wheelchair. "Just looking around." Percy, who has the smiling calm of an activist who is always being arrested, adds: "As soon as we hear anything in the planning office, we will absolutely alert the world!"

Their Campaign for Accountability of American Bases has links with the campaigning television comedian Mark Thomas. Tony Benn gets their newsletter. They do not seem intimidated by the armed guards and exclusion zones around Menwith Hill: "We bring a lot of techniques that we learned at Greenham," Percy says.

But if the Americans' grand design is to be defeated, as they are sure it will be, then a broader range of people probably needs to be energised. There are a few signs of this happening. The CND website has recorded an increase in visitors since Bush took office. "I've taken calls from people who have said, 'I want to rejoin,'" says Nigel Chamberlain, who deals with inquiries about Star Wars. The North York Moors National Park Authority, which in theory at least can approve or reject any new construction at Fylingdales, will not comment in advance of any planning application, but says there is a general "incompatibility" between "military and national park activities".

Not that the people who live nearest the base have necessarily noticed, though. While Menwith Hill and its opponents are on the fringe of urban Yorkshire, with its protester networks and peace studies academics, Fylingdales is far to the north, in a more rural and conservative area. Since it was built, handfuls of local people have helped to staff it, while others have sent questioning journalists on their way with gruff statements of support for the Americans. When the original radar station was demolished in the 1980s, pieces of the spheres were eagerly collected by local residents.

Goathland is the only settlement near the new grey slab, a pretty straggle of a village on the other side of the A169. The nostalgic police series about Yorkshire in the early 1960s, Heartbeat, is filmed here; there is an immaculate little station for the local steam railway; the local shops, busy with tourists, have freshly painted period facades. You could say Goathland depends for its existence on maintaining certain illusions about an eternal, independent England. "People who think differently are not always keen to say so," says Jackie Fearnley, one of the village's few critics of Fylingdales.

She moved north from Suffolk a few years ago. Slightly unsuitable plants struggle in her front garden. She wears two oatmeal jumpers and a rainbow scarf as we sit in her living room. She speaks cautiously, at first, about opposing the radar station. "People are saying, 'Could there be another Greenham Common at Fylingdales?', but I don't think so." She looks resigned for a moment. "My children ask me now what Greenham Common was."

Instead, a few weeks after Bush took office, Fearnley drove down to Whitby on the coast and met up with three other people with experience of activism against GM food and nuclear weapons. They formed the Fylingdales Action Network, with the single aim of making any local contribution to Star Wars politically impossible. The group now has about 50 members, has held two meetings and one demonstration, and is very concerned not to seem too militant. There was considerable debate, at the start, as to whether the word "action" was too aggressive.

But the case the group makes against NMD (now being hastily renamed Ballistic Missile Defense, or plain Missile Defense as opposition swells in Europe) is a fundamental one. "How would the Americans feel," asks Fearnley, "if we put something in their national park?" She raises her quiet voice slightly: "This seems like yet another example of America wanting to have their wars fought away from their home territory."

The American embassy in London insists it is listening to such criticisms: "The concerns of our allies have to be taken into account." But in Whitby last week, at a meeting of Fearnley's fellow activists, the air was thick with suspicion of American intentions in general. The confrontation with China, the rejection of the Kyoto agreement on global warming, the international ambitions of American corporations - this was the pattern into which the eight mild, middle-class people in the borrowed living room fitted the likely expansion of Fylingdales. That Britain should remain one of Washington's "allies" at all was implicitly questioned in every polite sentence.

It is just possible that a prolonged public battle over Star Wars will finally end this unequal relationship. At the least, enough messy arrests on the North York moors could lead, ultimately, to the dismantling of America's many British bases. "If they were challenged, things would crumble rather fast," says Michael Codner of the Institute for Defence Studies. One day, "these things will seem to be rather extraordinary". Even after almost 40 years, Fylingdales and Menwith Hill do not appear on civilian maps.

Then again, America's current dominance of the world is extraordinary in itself. Near the end of the Whitby meeting, someone suggested that Star Wars was actually just the beginning of America's ambitions to dominate space. "They're going to harvest it," the young man in glasses said, looking small on the large white sofa. "Control its economics. Have absolute control of every moving object." A brief, doomy silence fell on the room before the talk returned to future protest tactics.

Afterwards, in the taxi back to Goathland, there were no lights for miles, and the moors rose black against the night sky. Then the road suddenly climbed and a great twinkling rectangle of orange lights appeared in the distance, with a pyramid of red lights at its centre. As it floated on the horizon for the rest of the journey, a thought occurred. Fylingdales is already much bigger than it appears in daylight.

Near the end of the Whitby meeting, someone suggested that Star Wars was actually just the beginning of America's ambitions to dominate space. "They're going to harvest it," the young man in glasses said, looking small on the large white sofa. "Control its economics. Have absolute control of every moving object." A brief, doomy silence fell on the room before the talk returned to future protest tactics. Afterwards, in the taxi back to Goathland, there were no lights for miles, and the moors rose black against the night sky. Then the road suddenly climbed and a great twinkling rectangle of orange lights appeared in the distance, with a pyramid of red lights at its centre. As it floated on the horizon for the rest of the journey, a thought occurred. Fylingdales is already much bigger than it appears in daylight.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Say what you will of the UK Independence party, it will be a potent doorstep presence in the weeks ahead.
fields.body:
 Say what you will of the UK Independence party, it will be a potent doorstep presence in the weeks ahead. Yesterday, while it held its pre-election rally in Westminster, an internal election guide to branch officers arrived by way of fax. Among much of interest, there is advice on fundraising. "Fashion show, flower arranging, makeover session," says one bit highlighting how hip UKIP thinking has become, "should appeal to the ladies." Also impressive is the suggestion of a 1940s theme night. "Public meetings - have members planted that will start the collection with at least a tenner." Devilishly clever. Then we come to A Few Dos and Don'ts. "Don't use the word Europe when referring to the EU," is the counsel here. "Refer instead to Brussels or the Eurozone or Euroland." Yes, such emotive words. "Do make the most of statistics," it goes on. "If you have 33% against and 34% don't knows ... always refer to this as 77% do not want the euro leaving the inference that 77% want to the keep the pound." And there we Guardian types were thinking that sort of fiendish trickery was the preserve of sneaky Johnny Foreigner. Poor show indeed.

 The new website of the month is Chegger's Bedroom, on which Keith Chegwin is now screening himself in his bedroom, round the clock, with a packed daily schedule of games, events and assorted merriment. I've already taken advantage of the email facility to send a question to Keith - "Are you mad?"- and await an answer.

 Too late for inclusion on the Turncoat list, an old friend has a startling change of heart. Tomorrow the Co-operative party national executive elections close, and some members are surprised to see Kathryn Smith standing under one member, one vote. Traditionally, as befits a New Labour stalwart, Kathryn has not been a fan of this wacky system. It was she, you will recall, who denied other members of the south London Co-operators their constitutional right to participate in Labour's London mayoral selection when she and her pals stitched up the ballot and delivered all 50,000 votes for dear old Dobbo. Odd to see her embracing OMOV now, but good luck to her all the same.

 Leader writing at the Sun continues to impress, not least yesterday's musings on the imminent death of Coronation Street character Alma Halliwell (Alma Sedgewick as was). "Why is cancer about to kill her?" is the angry enquiry. "Alma's hasty death will present a negative image of cancer." Surely not? And yet how typical of TV's trendy metro-elite that they would want to damage another much loved national institution. They did it to Baden-Powell, and now it's cancer. It'll be the Queen Mother next, you'll see.

 Strike me pink, Boris the Jackal Johnson devotes his Telegraph column to ridiculing reports (mostly in the Telegraph) on the Portillo plot to replace Mr Hague with Polly Portillo. The Jackal, Tory candidate for Henley, borrows from Macmillan to suggest it's all been got up by the press, and frankly his split loyalties - between commenting on a story that is evidently true and his desire to help the leadership - may cause him to let himself down. "The guv'nor let 'imself dahn?" splutters the Arthur Mullard figure when we call. "The only one 'e'll let down, pal, is you. Over the edge of a motorway bridge. On the end of a length of rope. Now sod orf, you slaaaaag, and stop pulling my bell end."

 Attempts to contact tank top-wearing Times managing editor George Brock on a new matter fail in the old manner. We wish to ask him how the big search is going. A fortnight or so ago, an unidentified man was heard pleasuring himself, noisily but in solo style, in a cubicle in a Times House gents. A man with gold buckles on his black shoes is being sought.

webTitle: MPs doubt fitness of landfill tax regulator

fields.headline: MPs doubt fitness of landfill tax regulator
fields.standfirst: Special report: the landfill tax scandal
fields.trailText: The government's only private regulator, Entrust, could be "unfit" to supervise a £350m programme to fund environment projects, MPs said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government's only private regulator, Entrust, could be "unfit" to supervise a £350m programme to fund environment projects, MPs said yesterday.

The Commons environment sub-committee report followed a rare contempt hearing to which Entrust's chairman, Lord Cranbrook, and its chief executive, Richard Sills, were summoned for interfering with a witness giving evidence to the committee. Both gave profuse apologies.

Entrust was set up by the Conservative government to supervise donations from waste companies to avoid paying the full amount of Britain's first "green tax" - the landfill tax - by supporting environmental and heritage projects. The landfill tax credit scheme has raised £350m paid by companies in lieu of 20% of the tax.

An investigation by the Guardian last year revealed that parts of the scheme were flawed and dominated by the waste industry.

An inquiry by the committee has criticised the scheme as "convoluted and ineffective" and benefiting the landfill companies.

The witness, Malcolm Aickin, an environmentalist, lost a £40,000 a year job offer from Entrust after he disclosed to MPs that the scheme's regulations were " inadequate and inconsistent to the point of incompetence".

In their report, MPs said: "We remain concerned about the conduct of Entrust, its chairman, chief executive and board, and its fitness for the role of regulator of the landfill tax credit scheme. In particular ... we wish to satisfy ourselves that Entrust has appreciated the need to accept constructive criticism and is responding in a more open and positive fashion."

Last night David Davis, chairman of the public accounts committee, said he would recommend that it summon Entrust as part of a larger inquiry into fraud controls and competence at customs and excise.

Yesterday Entrust said it was launching an internal inquiry into the events that led to the contempt proceedings. It blamed legal advisers for not alerting it to the dangers of contempt when it withdrew Mr Aickin's job offer.

webTitle: GPs threaten mass NHS walkout over workload

fields.headline: GPs threaten mass NHS walkout over workload
fields.trailText: The British Medical Association decided yesterday to ballot Britain's 36,000 GPs on proposals for a mass walkout from the NHS in protest at excessive workload.
fields.body:
The British Medical Association decided yesterday to ballot Britain's 36,000 GPs on proposals for a mass walkout from the NHS in protest at excessive workload.

John Chisholm, chairman of the association's GPs committee, said the first such threat for a generation could lead to the effective privatisation of the family doctor service if ministers did not agree satisfactory revision of the GP contract within 12 months.

Dr Chisholm said the results were almost certain to be known before June 7, the likely date of the general election. The threat of resignations would not be a good advertisement for the government's relationship with a key group of health service professionals. "The timing is fortuitous," he said. "It is a source of sadness that we have come to this pass."

GPs throughout the UK will be asked if they would be prepared to submit undated letters of resignation from the NHS that would be activated if the government did not agree a new GP contract and broader negotiating rights for the BMA by April next year.

The last such threat was in 1974, when 66% of GPs sent in undated resignations to pressure the government to honour a pay review body's salary recommendations. A pay increase was agreed and the threat was withdrawn.

The Department of Health said the BMA was pushing at an open door. "As we have repeatedly told GP leaders, the government also wants to see a new contract for GPs," a spokeswoman said. "Indeed, the NHS plan commits us to one. With goodwill on all sides it ought to be possible to make real progress."

But the BMA accused ministers of dragging their feet and failing to begin meaningful negotiations.

Dr Chisholm said: "We are advising doctors that patient safety and their ability to deliver safe and competent care to a high standard must be the first priority. Many of the problems that GPs are facing could be alleviated by successfully negotiating a new contract. We believe this must be achieved by this time next year if general practice is not to grind to a halt."

The threat of mass resignations is expected to come mainly from the 90% of GPs on standard contracts with the NHS.

The BMA's initiative follows weeks of mounting unrest among GPs who think the government's promises of extra NHS funds have raised patients' expectations before money comes through to expand services. They are also disgruntled that ministers are planning to concentrate recruitment of extra doctors in hospitals, with only 2,000 extra planned for the GP service by 2004.

According to the BMA, this is less than a fifth of the 10,330 extra needed to provide a satisfactory standard of service.

The BMA is to issue advice to GPs in England on steps they can take to reduce their workload, including cuts in administrative tasks, refusal to register new patients and limits on the size of patient lists.

Dr Chisholm said he did not want to see GPs following dentists out of the NHS into private practice. "A lot of people no longer go to the dentist for preventive work. If GPs were to move towards being an emergency-only service outside the NHS, we would have lost something precious. That's not what we want and not what the government wants."
