webTitle: New laws to trap top crime bosses

fields.headline: New laws to trap top crime bosses
fields.standfirst:
New laws could target UK's master criminals

Special report: crime
fields.trailText: The government is considering introducing powerful new conspiracy laws to tackle up to 200 master criminals who are effectively untouchable because current legislation does not give the police enough powers to tackle them.
fields.body:
The government is considering introducing powerful new conspiracy laws to tackle up to 200 master criminals who are effectively untouchable because current legislation does not give the police enough powers to tackle them.

Senior police officers have urged the Home Office to pursue initiatives similar to the anti-racketeering act in the US, which was credited with helping to bring the mafia to its knees in Chicago, New York, Boston and Philadelphia.

The Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organisations Act (Rico) allowed federal agents to target the organising entity behind a crime, "not merely the act" itself, giving almost unlimited powers for surveillance and allowing judges to pass discretionary sentences and fines.

By concentrating on the conspiracy behind a crime, investigators were able to target mafia bosses as well as their foot-soldiers.

Sir David Phillips, chairman of the Association of Chief Police Officer's policing committee, has supported the use of laws modelled on Rico in private advice to the Home Office, believing they could prove an essential crime-fighting tool.

The Guardian has learned the Home Office is now circulating a classified consultation paper titled the Prosecution of Organised Criminal Conspiracy to gauge reaction to Rico-style laws from agencies such as customs and excise and the crown prosecution service, before deciding what to do.

Concern in Whitehall that a premier league of criminals is prospering with impunity was bolstered last year with the findings of a confidential UK threat assessment report, compiled by the national criminal intelligence service (NCIS).

An abridged version was given to the media but the full, classified document, believed to identify Britain's 200 most influential criminals, was presented to ministers.

An investigation into organised crime published in today's Economist magazine claims to have uncovered further confidential details about the extent of criminality in the UK.

The Economist says it has seen classified NCIS documents that refer to a group of 150 "core nominals" - intelligence-speak for crime bosses - and around 750 lieutenants who work for them. The magazine says the number of such criminals increases by a third every year.

NCIS yesterday denied that these figures were part of its confidential threat assessment report. Nevertheless, it has warned repeatedly about the increasing threat of organised crime in areas like drugs smuggling, illegal arms sales, and immigration rackets.

The willingness of the Home Office to consider new powers for the police became apparent yesterday when it emerged that a leading criminologist, Professor Michael Levi of Cardiff University, was asked to prepare a confidential paper on methods used by other countries to tackle organised crime. His report highlighted the effectiveness of Rico laws in the US, but also questioned whether such laws would work well in the UK.

Sir David Phillips, the chief constable of Kent, has advocated the use of similar laws to Lord Justice Auld, who is preparing a report on root and branch reform of the criminal justice system.

The Home Office confirmed yesterday that a consultation document drawing together the key elements of Professor Levi's paper and police views was being circulated.

"The bottom line is this," said a spokesman. "We want to prosecute these top criminals and make them 'touchable'.

"We want to make the laws as effective as possible to do this ... At the moment, there is no real consensus on Rico-style laws, though the police are generally positive. We hope to publish the findings of the consultation later this year."

Last month the home secretary, Jack Straw, unveiled a new law to use civil powers to confiscate ill-gotten fortunes worth £220m from 39 gangsters who have so far escaped criminal conviction.

The draft proceeds of crime bill, to be introduced later this year, would set up a criminal assets recovery agency charged with the task of hunting down cash, houses, cars and other wealth accumulated through criminal activity.

webTitle: Martin Woollacott: Sharon steers on to the rocks

fields.headline: Sharon steers on to the rocks
fields.standfirst:
Israelis are facing more problems than solutions to their troubles

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israelis are facing more problems than solutions to their troubles.
fields.body:
It has not taken Ariel Sharon long to steer himself and his government on to the rocks. Just six weeks after he took office he has moved to occupy Palestinian territory and then been forced to withdraw because of American displeasure, thrown away what international credit he had by bombing Syrian positions in Lebanon, announced new building programmes in the West Bank in spite of earlier pledges not to do so, and rejected proposals for mutual disengagement as "a ruse." His actions have pushed Palestinians and Israelis into a more dangerous cycle of violence and raised the possibility of a wider war. The real ruse, which seems even more apparent now than it did during the election campaign, is the trick which Sharon played on Israeli voters when he assured them he had a plan which would bring them peace and security.

The Israeli commentator Amos Elon observed in one of his essays that "Over the centuries Jews have been accused of many things but not of being stupid." The unusual Jewish stupidity to which he was referring then was that of the Netanyahu government, which, in 1997, with the aggressive clumsiness which was its trademark, was stumbling into confrontation with the Palestinians. As a result, Elon wrote, "Israel found itself at the mercy of blind forces." Four years later, Binyamin Netanyahu's misjudgments pale by comparison with those of Sharon, and both Israelis and Palestinians are far more at the mercy of "blind forces" than they were at that earlier time. The stupidity which the Sharon government embodies lies in the old man's view that he can bludgeon his way toward a sort of peace, battering the Palestinians into unconditional surrender, and then awarding them less than half of the West Bank in exchange for iron-clad guarantees of good behaviour.

Such a "victory" cannot be won. It is a fantasy, and Sharon probably knows that it is a fantasy. He serves it up to justify what his instincts dictate, which is that Palestinian attacks must be countered with whatever force is necessary for them to be brought to an end. And it is conceivable, such is the desperate condition of Palestinian civilians, that Yasser Arafat may at some point feel he has no option but to agree to a ceasefire on Israeli terms. But could anyone believe that such a ceasefire would represent anything but a pause in the violence? Sharon's plan is also a fantasy because of the way in which it elevates Arafat to a position of impossible authority and strength. What leader in any country can bind a people to a settlement wholly repugnant to them, and what leader would not be weakened, perhaps terminally, by trying to do so? Peace, in the end, is between peoples as well as between leaders.

Sharon began his government with a two-track policy: he would be tougher than his predecessor, Ehud Barak, in responding to Palestinian attacks, but at the same time Shimon Peres, as his foreign minister, had a brief to re-open negotiations with the Palestinians. The contradictions were instantly obvious. The tougher military policy made it harder, not easier, for Peres to succeed in an already very difficult task, as Sharon and other members of his government undermined the foreign minister by making it clear how little they were ready to concede to the Palestinians if they laid down their arms. The contradictions in Sharon's own position also began to grind against each other. He had acted, at the beginning, with, by his lights, a degree of restraint. Yet many of those who had voted for him, and especially the settlers, had expected a dramatic escalation. He was known as a hammer of the Palestinians: when was he going to begin hammering?

You could call what has happened in recent weeks Shalhevet's war. The killing toward the end of March by Palestinian fire of this little baby girl in Hebron was one of those tragic events that tip a balance waiting to be tipped. Settlers demanded a more vigorous response and got it. Sharon explained that "The turning point will come when Arafat begins to realise - and I believe this is becoming clear to him - that my government will not negotiate under terror and violence." His home minister, Uzi Landau, explained that "The price we will extract from the Palestinians will become intolerable." This policy of relentless pressure has led the Israeli government to reject attempts by third parties to bring about a mutual disengagement. Endorsed by Jordan, Egypt, and some European countries, the scheme in question is a version of earlier American proposals under which the Israelis would withdraw from the edges of Palestinian civilian areas, lifting their various sieges, and the Palestinians would resume security cooperation. Political negotiations would follow. Whether the Palestinians would sincerely accept such a plan is moot, because the Israelis have so far refused to do so. Their public position remains that Israel will not negotiate under fire.

Yet in trying to exact Uzi Landau's price, and in going beyond the limits of military action which it had until then observed, the Israeli government has run into another set of limits. Put simply, the United States, the European Union, and the main Arab states are unlikely to tolerate a creeping reoccupation of the territory over which the Palestinians took control under the Oslo accords. Nor are they likely to sit quietly if hostilities threaten across the Lebanese or Syrian borders. The US alone of these three has a leverage which Israel can never ignore. It exerted that leverage sharply this week when it in effect ordered the Israeli army out of Beit Hanoun in Gaza. Washington had earlier condemned Israeli building plans. The Bush administration has made it clear that it will not mediate in the way its predecessor did, but that does not mean it can afford to look the other way while a Sharon government creates havoc. The Europeans have far less influence, yet they are financing the Palestinian Authority, and the trading relationship between Israel and Europe is critical. The Arabs have least influence, but exerted via America and Europe by the Arab oil states and by Egypt and Jordan, it is not inconsiderable.

This makes Sharon's game more difficult, since it had begun to depend on an escalation which has now been internationally blocked. The result is a government which has no realistic plans to negotiate and no realistic chance of escalating the conflict without itself paying a very high price. It is also an ill assorted coalition government, even by Israeli standards. Elements on the right will be enraged by the way in which Israeli actions have been stymied by other countries. Others may be regretting their decision to join. All will be preparing for the next phase in Israeli politics, in which Sharon may play no part. Only 35% of Israelis voted for him, it is worth remembering. Many of these must now know that the man who said he had a plan has not even the beginning of a solution to their problems.

The real ruse, which seems even more apparent now than it did during the election campaign, is the trick which Sharon played on Israeli voters when he assured them he had a plan which would bring them peace and security. The Israeli commentator Amos Elon observed in one of his essays that "Over the centuries Jews have been accused of many things but not of being stupid." The unusual Jewish stupidity to which he was referring then was that of the Netanyahu government, which, in 1997, with the aggressive clumsiness which was its trademark, was stumbling into confrontation with the Palestinians. As a result, Elon wrote, "Israel found itself at the mercy of blind forces." Four years later, Binyamin Netanyahu's misjudgments pale by comparison with those of Sharon, and both Israelis and Palestinians are far more at the mercy of "blind forces" than they were at that earlier time. The stupidity which the Sharon government embodies lies in the old man's view that he can bludgeon his way toward a sort of peace, battering the Palestinians into unconditional surrender, and then awarding them less than half of the West Bank in exchange for iron-clad guarantees of good behaviour. Such a "victory" cannot be won. It is a fantasy, and Sharon probably knows that it is a fantasy. He serves it up to justify what his instincts dictate, which is that Palestinian attacks must be countered with whatever force is necessary for them to be brought to an end. And it is conceivable, such is the desperate condition of Palestinian civilians, that Yasser Arafat may at some point feel he has no option but to agree to a ceasefire on Israeli terms. But could anyone believe that such a ceasefire would represent anything but a pause in the violence? Sharon's plan is also a fantasy because of the way in which it elevates Arafat to a position of impossible authority and strength. What leader in any country can bind a people to a settlement wholly repugnant to them, and what leader would not be weakened, perhaps terminally, by trying to do so? Peace, in the end, is between peoples as well as between leaders. Sharon began his government with a two-track policy: he would be tougher than his predecessor, Ehud Barak, in responding to Palestinian attacks, but at the same time Shimon Peres, as his foreign minister, had a brief to re-open negotiations with the Palestinians. The contradictions were instantly obvious. The tougher military policy made it harder, not easier, for Peres to succeed in an already very difficult task, as Sharon and other members of his government undermined the foreign minister by making it clear how little they were ready to concede to the Palestinians if they laid down their arms. The contradictions in Sharon's own position also began to grind against each other. He had acted, at the beginning, with, by his lights, a degree of restraint. Yet many of those who had voted for him, and especially the settlers, had expected a dramatic escalation. He was known as a hammer of the Palestinians: when was he going to begin hammering? You could call what has happened in recent weeks Shalhevet's war. The killing toward the end of March by Palestinian fire of this little baby girl in Hebron was one of those tragic events that tip a balance waiting to be tipped. Settlers demanded a more vigorous response and got it. Sharon explained that "The turning point will come when Arafat begins to realise - and I believe this is becoming clear to him - that my government will not negotiate under terror and violence." His home minister, Uzi Landau, explained that "The price we will extract from the Palestinians will become intolerable." This policy of relentless pressure has led the Israeli government to reject attempts by third parties to bring about a mutual disengagement. Endorsed by Jordan, Egypt, and some European countries, the scheme in question is a version of earlier American proposals under which the Israelis would withdraw from the edges of Palestinian civilian areas, lifting their various sieges, and the Palestinians would resume security cooperation. Political negotiations would follow. Whether the Palestinians would sincerely accept such a plan is moot, because the Israelis have so far refused to do so. Their public position remains that Israel will not negotiate under fire. Yet in trying to exact Uzi Landau's price, and in going beyond the limits of military action which it had until then observed, the Israeli government has run into another set of limits. Put simply, the United States, the European Union, and the main Arab states are unlikely to tolerate a creeping reoccupation of the territory over which the Palestinians took control under the Oslo accords. Nor are they likely to sit quietly if hostilities threaten across the Lebanese or Syrian borders. The US alone of these three has a leverage which Israel can never ignore. It exerted that leverage sharply this week when it in effect ordered the Israeli army out of Beit Hanoun in Gaza. Washington had earlier condemned Israeli building plans. The Bush administration has made it clear that it will not mediate in the way its predecessor did, but that does not mean it can afford to look the other way while a Sharon government creates havoc. The Europeans have far less influence, yet they are financing the Palestinian Authority, and the trading relationship between Israel and Europe is critical. The Arabs have least influence, but exerted via America and Europe by the Arab oil states and by Egypt and Jordan, it is not inconsiderable. This makes Sharon's game more difficult, since it had begun to depend on an escalation which has now been internationally blocked. The result is a government which has no realistic plans to negotiate and no realistic chance of escalating the conflict without itself paying a very high price. It is also an ill assorted coalition government, even by Israeli standards. Elements on the right will be enraged by the way in which Israeli actions have been stymied by other countries. Others may be regretting their decision to join. All will be preparing for the next phase in Israeli politics, in which Sharon may play no part. Only 35% of Israelis voted for him, it is worth remembering. Many of these must now know that the man who said he had a plan has not even the beginning of a solution to their problems. fields.headline: Judge turns down McVeigh webcast
fields.trailText: A US judge has turned down a request by an internet media company to broadcast the execution of the Oklahoma City bomber, Timothy McVeigh, live online.
fields.body:
A US judge has turned down a request by an internet media company to broadcast the execution of the Oklahoma City bomber, Timothy McVeigh, live online.

Entertainment Network Inc has vowed to appeal the ruling - by district court judge John Tinder - that its intention to show the execution is not supported by first amendment rights to free speech. Mr Tinder ruled that Bureau of Prisons was within its rights to prohibit any recording or broadcast of McVeigh's death.

US courts have traditionally allowed prisons greater leeway over questions of public access, and no execution has ever been publicly broadcast in the US.

ENI had requested permission to place a webcam in the execution chamber and had planned to use credit card payments of $1.95 (£1.25) per viewing in order to prevent children from watching. The company had promised all proceeds would be given to charities that benefit the families of victims.

The chief executive of ENI, David Marshlack, said: "As I read Judge Tinder's decision the primary reason he is denying our request is that there is no precedent for what we propose to do. With due respect to the judge, that is the whole point - the internet is a new medium and clearly we are asking for something that is unprecedented. But just because it has never been done before is not a sufficient reason to deny us the right to transmit this momentous event in a way didn't exist when the laws were written."

When McVeigh is executed by lethal injection on May 16, relatives of the victims will be able to watch the proceedings on closed circuit television feed to Oklahoma City. McVeigh killed 168 people when he placed a bomb in a federal building there in 1995.

Officials in the US fear that tapes of the CCTV broadcast will be almost impossible to keep off the internet as countless numbers of would-be internet broadcasters seek to get hold of the footage. "The constitution does not require that those who wish to record courts or executions be allowed to do so," the assistant US attorney, Gerald Coraz, said. "Executions should not be public spectacles."

webTitle: Frankly, writer's estate gives a damn about The Wind Done Gone

fields.headline: Frankly, writer's estate gives a damn about The Wind Done Gone
fields.trailText: Perhaps all the fuss could have been avoided had Alice Randall chosen another name for her novel based on Gone With The Wind. As a title for a spin-off from the romantic American Civil War tale, The Wind Done Gone may not be the most appropriate.
fields.body:
Perhaps all the fuss could have been avoided had Alice Randall chosen another name for her novel based on Gone With The Wind. As a title for a spin-off from the romantic American Civil War tale, The Wind Done Gone may not be the most appropriate.

Ms Randall, a black 41-year-old first-time novelist, calls her work "an antidote to a text that has hurt generations of African-Americans." That is not how the estate of Margaret Mitchell, author of Gone With The Wind, sees it. It sees it as a rip-off.

"She has basically taken a best-selling novel and pirated virtually all the major scenes and characters and is doing it to sell her own work," says Ralph Morrison, a lawyer for the estate.

A judge in a federal court in Atlanta is expected to rule today on an application for an injunction to prevent the publication of Randall's book next month. He must decide between the competing interests of copyright laws and the right to self-expression.

Ms Randall is supported by writers and artists such as the Nobel Prize winner Toni Morrison, Harper Lee, John Berendt, the roots rocker Steve Earle and the civil war historian Shelby Foote.

Ms Randall calls her book a political parody. References to "monkeys" and "small intelligence" have made it difficult for blacks to warm to Gone With The Wind, though she says she enjoyed the book when she first read it when 12.

"Once upon a time in America, African-Americans were forbidden by law to read and write," she says. "It saddens me and breaks my heart that there are those who would try to set up obstacles for a black woman to tell her story."

The estate says Ms Randall has borrowed so heavily from the original that she has in effect produced a sequel, something Mitchell never wanted. "If I had written a sequel to Gone With The Wind, no-one in my family would speak to me," says Ms Randall. "I think Margaret Mitchell would love my novel."

Trouble with names is not unique to Ms Randall. The original working title in 1936 of Gone With The Wind was Bugles Sang True. Scarlett, the southern belle heroine of the story, began life as Pansy O'Hara. Either way, the Mitchell estate is unlikely to embrace the final line uttered by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler in the 1939 movie version: "Frankly my dear, I don't give a damn."

fields.headline: One Night at McCool's
fields.trailText: It looks good and boasts a nimble energy but is so lightweight as to seem throwaway
fields.body:
Like Pulp Fiction or Doug Liman's Go, Harald Zwart's barfly comedy comes at the same tale from a trio of angles, sketching three conflicting portraits of Liv Tyler's grungy femme fatale. Its knowing format makes room for some genial showboating from Matt Dillon (as a strutting barman), John Goodman (baleful cop) and producer Michael Douglas, who turns in a jaw-dropping cameo as a bingo-playing hitman.

Credit where it's due: One Night at McCool's looks good and boasts a nimble energy. But it's so lightweight as to seem throwaway; so tongue-in-cheek as to be in constant danger of gagging.

fields.headline: The Hole
fields.trailText: The Hole provides a textbook example of a certain business-savvy strain of modern British movie
fields.body:
The Hole opens after the event, with poor little rich girl Liz (American Beauty star Thora Birch), staggering bloodied and hysterical up the gravel path towards her palatial public school. Liz, it transpires, is the sole survivor from an illicit weekend spent in an underground war bunker in the woods. Liz went in with three others (heart-throb, rugger-bugger, It Girl); 18 days later she comes back out. Sitting the crazed girl down in a tranquil hospital room, police psychologist Embeth Davidtz begins piecing together what went wrong.

Part-funded by the Film Council, The Hole provides a textbook example of a certain business-savvy strain of modern British movie. Certainly the set-up is intriguing, and the whole thing handled with a definite zip by director Nick Hamm. Yet in the end The Hole isn't half as smart as it thinks it is. The playing is too shrill, too strident; the plot twists not so much revelations as show-off card tricks.

fields.headline: Home entertainment
fields.standfirst: Stephen Frears reveals his home entertainment
fields.trailText:
Stephen Frears

When he's not making films such as High Fidelity, Prick Up Your Ears, Dangerous Liaisons and My Beautiful Laundrette, one of our greatest film-makers teaches at the National Film School in BeaconsfieldStephen Frears

When Stephen Frears is not making films such as High Fidelity, Prick Up Your Ears, Dangerous Liaisons and My Beautiful Laundrette, one of our greatest film-makers teaches at the National Film School in Beaconsfield
fields.body:
When he's not making films such as High Fidelity, Prick Up Your Ears, Dangerous Liaisons and My Beautiful Laundrette, one of our greatest film-makers teaches at the National Film School in Beaconsfield. Somewhat grumpy at having his mid-afternoon nap interrupted, he explains how his heart was first opened to cinema.

"Britain was a very boring place after the war. There were no restaurants because of food rationing, but you could go and see films. In Leicester, the cinemas would change their films twice a week and show different films on Sunday, and it was all to do with escape.

"There were exceptions, like The Thief of Bagdad, but generally it was destroyers being sunk, airplanes limping home or prisoners tunnelling to freedom. Then in the late 50s the world changed and you started to see films that were about a life that you recognised - films like Room at the Top."

In 1960, after working in the theatre for a while, Frears met Karel Reisz, the Czech emigre who captured the mood of changing Britain with 1960's Saturday Night and Sunday Morning. Reisz was then working on Morgan: A Suitable Case for Treatment - a film about a man obsessed with Karl Marx and gorillas in equal measure. "Reisz is the last great man in England," says Frears. "So I worked with Karel and Albert Finney and Lindsay Anderson. At that time we were to one side a bit - the mid-60s had given way to very modish, swinging-London films, such as Dick Lester's work with the Beatles. Britain had become rather fashionable."

The film that heralded the new era was Godard's A Bout de Souffle (1960). "I saw it the other day, and even Jean-Paul Belmondo's trousers are astonishing. Just the way he moved was fantastic. He was actually setting a style for my generation. Many things in that film were what we moulded ourselves on - and I suppose the film unconsciously picked up on this and anticipated it. Jean Seberg is terrible in it. The idea that a man like that would be obsessed with her is preposterous. When he says that he can't leave Paris because of her you don't believe him for an instant. He's magnificent. She's hopeless. But perhaps it's unfair to speak ill of the dead."

So can any director have more than one perfect moment? "I remember Godard's Pierrot le Fou being very good," says Frears. "But the thing is, for one moment you get it right. People have said that about me - that there was a period when I got it right. You imagine that you have some sort of control over it, but of course you don't - you're absolutely helpless. I remember working on If, and being aware that we were shooting scenes that were in the newspapers . . . "

So what of that French film that inspired If? "That French film," says Frears, in a tone that should be accompanied by puffs of smoke billowing out of his ears, "is Zéro de Conduit, which we held up as one of the great moments of cinema! So for you to call it that French film is not very impressive. What impact did If have? What do you want me to say? Mrs Thatcher came to power 10 years after it was made.

"Films have no impact, do they? Cathy Come Home caused a charity to be formed, but there was greater homelessness after it than before. But it's wonderful to touch people. I remember people being thrilled with My Beautiful Laundrette, because it was the first film to say, 'We have a very bad prime minister.' If you had written on the screen 'Mrs Thatcher is catastrophic', people would have paid to see it, because they wanted it said."

Frears is a great fan of the grandmother of the New Wave, Agnès Varda, and the brave young man of new American cinema, Paul Thomas Anderson. "Agnès Varda is fantastic. She's very wise and very vigorous." Varda is celebrated for films such as 1962's Cleo From 5 to 7 and last year's The Gleaners and I, a documentary. "Paul Thomas Anderson [Boogie Nights, 1997, and Magnolia, 1999] I admire because it's impressive to be that clear-headed that young. And I know people think highly of films like Election and Rushmore, but I'm perplexed by them. I don't quite understand them, and I think it's my fault."

The director as hero is a theme close to Frears. "John Cassavetes was a heroic figure: he really struggled. And when you're involved you really see the price people pay for that struggle. Scorsese's struggle is so heroic that I couldn't tell you about the films any longer because I'm more moved by the efforts that have gone into the making of them. And you see, over a long period of time, how someone has gone about believing in things."

webTitle: Under the Sand review - mysterious drama of denial

fields.headline: Under the Sand review - mysterious drama of denial
fields.standfirst: An intriguing film about grief and emotion, with Charlotte Rampling as an academic whose husband goes missing on holiday
fields.trailText: An intriguing film about grief and emotion, with Charlotte Rampling as an academic whose husband goes missing on holiday
fields.body:
An elegant drama of loss, bereavement and denial from François Ozon starring Charlotte Rampling, who finds her customary note of enigmatic self-possession and exemplifies a movie in which emotional life is acknowledged indirectly. Rampling plays Marie, an English literature professor now in well-preserved middle-age, happily married for over 20 years to the handsome, rumpled Jean (Bruno Cremer). On holiday, he disappears while swimming, and as the months go by, Marie refuses ever to admit that he is certainly dead, and behaves as if he is still alive, to the alarm of her friends in Paris.

In some ways, Ozon's film could almost be seen as a companion-piece to George Sluizer's The Vanishing: where Sluizer finds mystery and horror in the sudden disappearance of one half of a couple, Ozon contrives melancholy, and a meditation on the "presence" of the other in a long-standing marriage, so comfortable and companionable as to be almost invisible.

Rampling's contained performance withholds from us any ordinary expression of grief or eroticism; instead they are muted. Her emotional life is displaced into the external world: her study of Virginia Woolf's The Waves, or the song by French chanteuse Barbara, which she listens to in a supermarket. That and her fantasy of talking to a kind of wise "ghost" Jean alone in her apartment perhaps take the film uncomfortably close to Truly, Madly, Deeply territory. An intriguing piece, in which Ozon's direction preserves a mood of eerie, reticent calm.

fields.headline: Boesman and Lena
fields.trailText: Athol Fugard's 1970 stage-play is performed with intelligence and respectful passion
fields.body:
Athol Fugard's 1970 stage-play, directed for the screen by John Berry (who died in 1999, just after filming), is here performed with intelligence and respectful passion by Angela Bassett and Danny Glover. Its Beckettian influences are obvious: Boesman and Lena are the "mixed-race" couple scratching a living by foraging for deposit-bottles, endlessly quarrelling on a deserted shore. A largely wordless Xhosa tribesman appears, like Lucky in Godot, for Boesman to bully with the pseudo-apartheid attitude he has imbibed from the abusive whites.

It is a static and stagey film, though the flashbacks to the couple's earlier, happier, and above all younger existences are powerful and distinctively cinematic. In some ways Fugard's writing emerges as fiercer and more cogently human than Beckett's. webTitle: The story that inspired Ken Loach to shoot a film in LA

fields.headline: 'Why don't you just go home, you wetbacks?'
fields.standfirst: Only one thing could have inspired Hollywood-hater Ken Loach to shoot a movie in LA - the story of the Justice for Janitors campaign that exploded into violence a decade ago.  Duncan Campbell  on the Latinos who battled for union rights
fields.trailText: Only one thing could have inspired Hollywood-hater Ken Loach to shoot a movie in LA - the story of the Justice for Janitors campaign that exploded into violence a decade ago. Duncan Campbell on the Latinos who battled for union rights
fields.body:
Rocio Saenz gives a very convincing performance as a union organiser in Ken Loach's new film, Bread and Roses. She shows just the right blend of determination and controlled conviction as she addresses the people who clean the buildings of corporate Los Angeles, trying to inspire them with commitment for the battles ahead.

But if anyone should be able to play a passionate union activist, it is the 37-year-old from Mexico City in her first - and probably last - role in what is Loach's first - and probably last - film made in the United States.

Saenz, one of a family of nine, arrived as a young woman from Mexico in 1986 hoping to study. "That was the wish - and then I hit reality," she says now. She had to settle for work cleaning houses and baby-sitting and eventually decided to look for slightly better paid employment in LA's garment industry. She approached the local garment workers' union so that they could direct her to a factory that at least paid the basic rates, and they thought she was looking for work in the union itself. Through this misunderstanding she found herself making banners and gradually being drawn into the world of the unions. "Until then I only knew the horrible side of the US but when I started to go out organising with these people it was: 'Wow! Incredible!' - it was another world."

At the time, the union movement in LA was much weaker than today, when the city is regarded as the fastest-growing union city in the US, a growth mainly attributed to the large numbers of Latinos in the service industries of cleaning, catering and hotel work. One key task when Saenz first started work was the organising of the janitors, the people who clean the office buildings and who had traditionally been underpaid and exploited, not least because many of them were "undocumented" - illegally in the country and thus unable to complain. So Saenz found herself as an organiser with the Service Employees International Union in what became known as the Justice for Janitors' campaign. This hit the headlines in June 1990 when riot police attacked one of their marches in Century City and 60 marchers were hospitalised after bloody scenes. Amidst the ensuing public dismay at the violence, which was shown on television, 2,000 janitors won union recognition.

Seven years ago the Scottish writer Paul Laverty (who also scripted Loach's films My Name is Joe and Carla's Song) sought Saenz's advice for a screenplay on the theme of the immigrant worker. She met Loach the following year and in 1999 found herself playing a union organiser in the film, alongside actors Adrien Brody (The Thin Red Line, Summer of Sam) in the role of middle-class union activist Sam Shapiro, and Pilar Padilla in her debut feature role as Maya, a Mexican immigrant whose illegal entry across the border starts the film. A number of real-life janitors and union activists found themselves, like Saenz, recruited to play characters much like themselves. In the scene in which Rocio delivers her rallying speech, many of the extras were workers she had been responsible for organising in real life.

Saenz, who is now based in the Bay Area of Oakland, says it was a surprise to find that the people interested in making a film about the union battles of LA should have come all the way from Britain in order to do so. "It was always a puzzle that here he [Ken Loach] was doing a film in the middle of this big monster."

As to how well Loach has captured the life of the janitors, she adds: "I'm not objective, of course, but I think it is very accurate. The movie has got both the sad and the funny sides of it." Saenz says that few films had portrayed the experiences of the Latino immigrant worker in the US and cited El Norte, Gregory Nava's 1983 film about Guatemalans reaching the promised land of California, as the best. "What people don't realise is what the immigrant has to go through to achieve the American dream. You have to leave your family and go through a horrible experience and go through discrimination and racism. But things have changed. When I first started organising, people would say: 'Why don't you go back to your own country, you wetback.' "

Los Angeles had a reputation for being anti-union that dated back to 1910, when two labour officials were convicted of planting a bomb at the LA Times, which killed 20 people. The city now, though, seems to be smiling on union activities. During the janitors' strike the general public contributed some $2m to their fighting fund. Many of the strikers' demands were met, and their wages increased by 25% over the next few years.

Last year was a record-breaking year for recruitment in Saenz's union and she feels Loach's film will spread the message further in a country where unionisation hovers around the 13% mark in the workforce. She says that the themes in Bread and Roses - the right to organise and the conditions that people work under - are universal: "Immigration is an issue everywhere in the world, not just in LA."

Saenz is right in thinking that not many people would think of making a film about the benefits of union organisation in 2001. There have been films about unions and workers getting organised before but most seem to be from a distant age. On the Waterfront, of course, made in 1954, dealt with the issue of labour organising, and Norma Rae, which won an Oscar for its star Sally Field in 1979, painted a heroic picture of the union activist. Matewan, the 1987 John Sayles film, painted an equally heroic picture of striking miners. FIST, with Sylvester Stallone, in 1978, dealt with the rise and fall of a union boss, and Hoffa, made in 1992, tackled the life of the Teamsters' boss, Jimmy Hoffa.

In Britain, The Angry Silence (1960) portrayed unions as totalitarian and menacing, penalising the little guy, the individual, the non-conformist. ("A vicious film," Loach has called it.) I'm All Right, Jack (1959), while a comedy, carried the subtext that the union official was a humourless bureaucrat. Elsewhere in Europe, movies with union themes also seem to be from a different era: Eisenstein's Strike (1924) was about a 1912 strike; and Adalen 31, Bo Widerberg's film about a strike at a smalltown paper mill, was made in 1969.

Bread and Roses is likely to be the last movie Loach makes in the US, his experience confirming his suspicions that, for most European directors, Hollywood is not a happy experience. But he believes there are many wonderful American stories still to be explored in movies, including "some of the big historical subjects . . . Mother Jones [the turn-of-the-century American labour leader], Joe Hill [the labour organiser executed in 1915] and all the great heroic characters from the past, the history that people have been denied. History as mystery - it's the old quote of George Orwell: 'Who controls the past, controls the future. Who controls the present, controls the past.' People have no sense of the labour struggle in the US."

Ironically enough, people may soon be getting a better sense of the labour struggle in the US through the entertainment industry itself. There are potential strikes brewing for both writers and actors that could close down the industry for weeks or even months this summer and Hollywood is busily finishing off projects in anticipation.

Loach has long been back in Britain, where he is completing work on "a little comedy with a sting in the tail" called The Navigators. It's about the railway workers who check the tracks. It would be safe to assume that it is not a paean to privatisation. As for Rocio Saenz, would she like to swap her job as a union organiser for a career in the movies? "It would be OK if all films were like Ken Loach's and not Hollywood, but the union is where my blood is."

Bread and Roses is released on April 27.

fields.headline: Girlfight
fields.trailText: Karyn Kusama's film is a tough, absorbing, old-fashioned drama about a young Latino woman from the New York City projects, who channels her aggression into boxing
fields.body:
The other girl-power movie out this week actually fits the boxing term "contender" better. Karyn Kusama's film is a tough, absorbing, old-fashioned drama about Diana Guzman (Michelle Rodriguez), a young Latino woman from the New York City projects, who channels her aggression into boxing. Diana finds her way into the ring through a kind of reverse Billy Elliot situation: she stops by the gym to see her brother in training, but he's a wimp who'd rather be studying. So he quits, she persuades the trainer Hector (Jaime Tirelli) to give her a shot, and she graduates to sensational mixed bouts.

Girlfight isn't overtly concerned with political or feminist implications, and apart from a few exclamations of disgust from the sweat-soaked old-timers, there is no serious agonising about men or women thumping each other in the ring. It does not have the boxing movie's classic preoccupation with the experience of losing, or of growing old as a boxer - perhaps simply because the whole subject is so novel. In some ways it's more like a film about dancing: when Diana falls in love with Adrian (Santiago Douglas), the boy she must eventually fight, it looks like an emotionally charged rivalry on the dancefloor - Strictly Ballroom with Lonsdale sweatshirts. But in showing a woman in training and preparing for a fight, Kusama defamiliarises boxing as a subject, and makes us see afresh its drama of brutality and vulnerability.

fields.headline: Prude awakening
fields.standfirst: Puritans versus hypocrites: the US's censorship war
fields.trailText: Puritans versus hypocrites: the US's censorship war
fields.body:
The puritans are on the warpath again. In the past year, the states of Arkansas, Utah, Virginia and Massachusetts have all introduced legislation that would make it a crime for cinemas to admit under-17s to R-rated movies without a guardian. Only reactionary Virginia has succeeded in passing such an measure: for the last month in the cradle of Dixie, it's been a class one misdemeanour to admit children to movies judged "harmful" to them. Luckily for cinemas and the MPAA (the Motion Picture Producers' Association of America, Hollywood's self- regulating censorship board), the Virginia law makes no mention of R-rated material and has essentially made itself redundant by adhering to a standard so vague and legally hard to define.

Utah and Arkansas - home to Mormons and Baptists - both failed to pass similar laws last year, but new legislation is pending. Massachusetts, head-quarters of America's Irish Catholic ascendancy, has a propensity for censorship that extends back to the notorious 1934 obscenity trial against James M Cain's The Postman Always Rings Twice, and the state's medieval attitudes, towards sex in particular, seem to have persisted into the 21st century.

It's the delayed fallout from the 2000 presidential campaign's focus on evil, mind- polluting studios pimping their R-rated wares to the nation's toddlers and pubescents. "I think it's serious when you have four different state legislatures saying, 'We're going to take your voluntary ratings system and attach criminal penalties,' " John Fithian of the National Association of Theater Owners (the other Nato) told Daily Variety. "It's a scary proposition. I don't remember a year in recent history when four pieces of legislation were introduced that essentially do the same thing."

This is one of the oddities of the current kerfuffle. Legislators and politicians seem to have convinced themselves that the dictates of the MPAA are part of the law of the land. They're not. The MPAA is entirely the creature of the Hollywood studios and its ratings board is run in concert with Nato. "I think a lot of parents are shocked to find out that the rating system is totally voluntary," says Arkansas lawmaker Mark Smith. "Theatres are not required by any law to restrict ticket sales."

The MPAA has built around itself a quasi-governmental mystique. Critic Jonathan Rosenbaum notes that "the authority of its judgments is often given the sort of sanction accorded to the Food and Drug Administration, which we mentally translate into an official stamp". Yet the MPAA's umbilical links with the large studios are rarely acknowledged: it is a faux independent bulwark created to fend off precisely this kind of legislation. If it proves vulnerable to legislation, you might well ask what the point of its continued existence would be.

Censorship in Hollywood has always been a hypocritical racket. It's never really been about maintaining the moral cleanliness of younger citizens - self-censorship has always been a pre-emptive measure to keep the studios independent of government interference - but more importantly it's Hollywood's business-as-usual response to boycott threats that might undermine its own box-office receipts. It's always about the money.

And the wrong people have always been in charge. Will Hays, who created the Production Code Administration in the early 1930s, was responsible for retarding the growth - or better, the grown-upness - of Hollywood's output for nearly two decades. And just as J Edgar Hoover always downplayed organised crime in favour of communism as public enemy number one, the PCA came down much harder on sex than on violence, a situation that persists today.

One staffer at the MPAA's predecessor, the MPPDA (the D was for distributors - then still owned by the studios, of course), blamed this on the number of Irish Catholics engaged in the censorship process, particularly the prudish code administrator Joseph Breen and his predecessor, Motion Picture Herald publisher Martin Quigley. Jack Vizzard, another PCA administrator in the 1960s, had some interesting observations about mid-century Irish Catholic ideas of sex and violence. "To the Irish," he opined, "violence was not necessarily connected with the debasing of human life. It was frequently a sign of manliness . . . the Irish culture was infected with Jansenism, which dreaded sex being identified with the darker forces, but which did not fear brutality, since this wasn't as 'catching'. It contained its own remedy in that it hurt."

Such attitudes were reinforced by the Catholic Legion of Decency, a church organisation that issued its own ratings from pulpits across America and which claimed to "condemn vile and unwholesome moving pictures". The legion's high tide - and last gasp - came during the steamy ad campaign for Elia Kazan's Baby Doll in 1956. New York's Cardinal Francis Spellman - who, like J Edgar Hoover, was a total hypocrite about his own homosexuality - personally awarded the film a "C for condemned" rating, which meant that Catholics who saw it would languish in hell. John Waters says that on hearing these words, he ran all the way from the cathedral to the movie house.

Today, with that McCarthyite mind-set largely dismantled and censorship all but eradicated, the MPAA is still in the hands of Jack Valenti, who reformed the old system in 1966 and has been defending it ever since. Before that, Valenti was a personal aide to Lyndon Baines Johnson - so doggedly loyal that he was nicknamed "the Valet" - and was often heard defending the merits of the "police action" in Vietnam. Now that he's pushing 80, he has become equally shrill and mean-spirited in his defence of a system that, most observers say, seeks to pass big studio films whilst suppressing problematic independent films - or certifying them NC-17, which amounts to the same thing.

At the same time, the sex-versus-violence approach remains unchanged. NC-17 movies are usually rated thus for sex, and rarely for violence. But as MPAA lawyer Vans Stevenson says, "No ratings enforcement legislation has any traction," so it seems likely that the MPAA will continue to set the tone and the pace on censorship for the time being.

But if we add censor-happy senator Joe Lieberman to the Mormons, Baptists and Catholics mentioned above, one can envisage a multi- denominational consensus of puritanism gathering across the land, and in a week when Tom Green's new movie, Freddy Got Fingered, shows its star masturbating a stallion and an elephant, one has to ask if the blustering Valenti shouldn't stand aside and let someone younger face down the outrage that shall no doubt continue to build.

fields.headline: 'One minute I'm pushing the vacuum cleaner, the next I'm getting orchids from Giorgio Armani'
fields.standfirst: Joan Allen tells  Lanie Goodman  what a difference an Oscar nomination can make
fields.trailText: Joan Allen tells Lanie Goodman what a difference an Oscar nomination can make
fields.body:
When the phone rang at 8.30am to inform Joan Allen of her Oscar nomination for best actress, she had just stepped out of the shower with her miniature parrot and was still frantically blowdrying the shivering bird. In typical fashion, the 44-year-old star of The Contender was more concerned that the family pet might catch a cold than with fretting about what she should wear for the immediate onslaught of TV interviews. "Ordinarily my husband would have taken over," Allen says with a smile. "But he was taking our daughter to school and got delayed, so there I was."

Ordinarily, few top film actresses choose to live in a two-bedroom apartment on New York's Upper West Side, without a personal assistant hovering in the background. Then again, Allen confesses that she still has a hard time considering herself a movie star, though it has been about a decade since she joined Hollywood's ranks, leaving behind her highly acclaimed career in theatre.

On screen, Allen's commanding presence - her 5ft 10in frame, delicate features and dramatic high cheekbones - project a powerful image of dignified reserve, with a hint of turmoil in her wide-set green eyes. But as Allen curls up on her living-room sofa, dressed in a black T-shirt, jeans and minimal make-up, there's no trace of that mysterious reticence. She sits very straight, like a dancer, and talks about her sky-rocketing celebrity with candour. "People I've run into on the street tell me I look like a young Joan Allen!" she laughs.

But if the sudden fame means that strangers now approach the actress to wish her well ("I ride the subways and buses a lot," she admits), it hasn't changed her lifestyle: "Maybe it's because I grew up in the midwest, and my mother always said, 'If you want something done right, do it yourself!' I have to fight that part of my temperament, but it's kind of hilarious sometimes. One minute I'm pushing the vacuum cleaner, the next I'm getting orchids from Giorgio Armani. In her subsequent film, Pleasantville, a take-off of a 1950s sitcom, Allen's naive character experiences a sexual awakening, but it was still light years away from a chance to explore smouldering sensuality.

Which is why Allen's latest role, as the poised politician Laine Hanson in The Contender, was a welcome change. "It was nice to finally say, 'I'm not married to the senator, I am the senator,'" she quips. It isn't long before Runyon, an unscrupulous congressman played by Gary Oldman, digs up a sex scandal from the senator's college days that escalates into lurid front-page headlines. Throughout the film, Allen's character subtly balances her inner rage with a cool exterior, maintaining her dignity by refusing to comment on the malicious accusations.

I don't know if that's very . . . umm . . . movie-like," she smiles, "but it felt right. Keeping her cool was her way of fighting - never let them see you sweat!"

Echoes of Hillary? Allen had the chance to observe the former First Lady at a lawn reception at the White House at the height of the Monica Lewinsky scandal. "When Hillary got up to speak, the applause went on and on and on before she could say a word," the actress recalls. "It was quite a moment."

Most importantly, the actress wanted her character to appear comfortable with her own sexuality, even though the whole story is based on an alleged sexual issue. "If you look at high-profile female politicians like Madeleine Albright and Janet Reno, they're always dressed in conservative clothes, real no-nonsense stuff, and their sexuality is like . . . non-existent. One thing I decided about Laine's costumes was that I wouldn't wear a single pearl - no silk scarves with eagles on them, no brooches."

Allen pauses and gets up to close the door to the kitchen, where the parrot is cheerfully shrilling. "For some reason, I think it's hard to be glamorous and be taken seriously in the US," she states quietly, much in the way that Senator Hanson would have said it.

Growing up in the cornfields of the Illinois town Rochelle (population 8,700), where her father owned a gas station, Allen was an excellent student, but spent much of her time after school playing with the family dog. "In high school I was very shy but desperate to meet boys, so my sister told me to be a cheerleader. I didn't make the squad and auditioned for a play instead. After feeling like an outsider on the nerd end of the scale, I realised that I absolutely loved acting - I could cry, scream and laugh but in a controlled environment."

Allen went on to major in theatre at Eastern Illinois University and was soon approached by an older student, John Malkovich. "He wore these pearlised purple platform shoes with bell-bottoms and had a beard and long hair," Allen remembers. "And I was like, this little smalltown, goody-two-shoes kind of girl. He was so exotic that I felt like I'd arrived on another planet." Malkovich later convinced Allen to join Chicago's Steppenwolf Theatre, where he and actors like Gary Sinise and Laurie Metcalf were staging productions in a small neighbourhood church in Highland Park.

With a full-time day job as a secretary and rehearsals at night, Allen describes the early Steppenwolf days as an exhilarating time of passionate friendships, hard work, intensive partying and unexpected success. She debuted on Broadway in 1983 in And a Nightingale Sang, and five years later she won a best actress Tony award for her performance opposite Malkovich in Lanford Wilson's Burn This.

That same year, while playing Delores in Wendy Wasserman's The Heidi Chronicles, Allen met actor Peter Friedman. They were married in 1990 and now have a seven-year-old daughter, Sadie, who is the actress's top priority. "Maybe because I'm a mother now I don't have the same feeling that I must act or I'll die," Allen says. "But Sadie has also taught me a lot - a child gives you an intensity of feelings that I've never felt before and she's probably made me a better actress."

By the same token, Allen's decision to take a break from the long runs on stage and try out film was based on what she calls "a burn-out" from having to re-enact the same wrenching emotions night after night. She leans forward: "You know, the characters I was playing were really sad."

I f all goes as planned, Allen is looking forward to producing and starring in her next film, which takes place in Dublin and France. "The character is somewhat comic. She's very ballsy, drinks a lot and gets very angry when she drinks." Allen acquired a feel for Dublin after spending six and a half months there filming The Sky Is Falling, directed by John Mackenzie, based on the true story of Irish journalist Veronica Guerin, who was murdered in 1996 after investigating Dublin drugs gangs. Though Allen immersed herself in Guerin's articles and TV interviews and worked daily with a dialect coach, she acknowledges that there are difficulties attached to a biopic, as she experienced in Nixon. "You want to try to show thecomplexity - some people in Ireland feel that Veronica Guerin was very naive and foolish to have done what she did . . . especially as a mother."

This reminds her that it's nearly time to pick up Sadie from school, and Allen also has an important conference call with her stylist in LA, whom she's never actually met. "It's been a clothes nightmare," Allen laughs, "so I finally decided to hire someone. Last year, for the Golden Globe awards, I tried to do it by myself. I had a huge pile of dresses at home and I took polaroids with a self-timer to send to my publicist. Hollywood is a full-time job."

Allen maintains there wasn't any disappointment about not winning the Oscar, since for her, "being nominated was significant tribute enough". In fact, she felt equally honoured to have been chosen to present Ang Lee (who calls Allen "a director's dream") as a nominee at the Director's Guild awards.

"I'd never seen any martial arts movies before, and I thought his film Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon was unbelievable," Allen declares. Could she ever imagine herself in an intrepid-female-hero role? "I would have loved to fly around on wires, through the air, bouncing from tree to tree. Oh my God, would I ever!"

webTitle: Profile of Bob Godfrey, the godfather of British animation

fields.headline: One man and his wobbly dog
fields.standfirst: The man who brought us Roobarb and Henry the Cat also won an Oscar for a film about Isambard Kingdom Brunel. How can you top that?  Nick Smurthwaite  drops in on the godfather of British animation
fields.trailText: The man who brought us Roobarb and Henry the Cat also won an Oscar for a film about Isambard Kingdom Brunel. How can you top that? Nick Smurthwaite drops in on the godfather of British animation
fields.body:
Bob Godfrey looks as if he's been assembled by a cartoonist. Big nose, sticky-out ears, scrubby beard, hangdog expression. The thought crosses your mind that the godfather of British animation may well have invented himself.

At 80, Godfrey is still hard at it in his cramped, chaotic studio in King's Cross, London, hunched over a desk, busily turning dignity on its head and subverting conventions. He is currently working on a five-minute cartoon series called Kevin Saves the World, based on a children's book by Danny Postgate about a boy who befriends a Martian. The walls are lined with cartoons, film posters and artwork stretching back half a century. As you mount the narrow stairs of the three-storey building, you're greeted by Godfrey's gallery of grotesques, the main purpose of which, he tells me, is to save him having to decorate.

A proudly displayed Oscar and three Baftas look more than a little incongruous among the dog-eared pin-ups and creative detritus of his tiny command module. Looming over these gleaming awards, on the shelf above, is a stuffed arctic fox with a permanent snarl. "Somebody from Norway sent it to me, Christ knows why," he chuckles.

The Oscar was for Great, an animated musical about Isambard Kingdom Brunel in 1975, when he became the first British animator to receive one. The story of how he came to win it is a nice mixture of enterprise and serendipity.

"I was showing my films to some students in Leicester Square, and an American guy came up to me and asked me how much I wanted for Kama Sutra Rides Again (1971), an earlier cartoon of mine. He said he liked it so much he wanted to give it to his son as a wedding present. I had a rough old 16mm print so I sold it to him for £150. I didn't give it another thought until I heard I'd been nominated for an Oscar for Kama Sutra, which came as a complete surprise since, so far as I knew, it had never been distributed in the States.

"If I could get an Oscar nomination without even trying, why didn't I put my mind to it? I'd been reading a book about Brunel so I asked British Lion, who backed Kama Sutra, if I could have some money to make a half-hour cartoon about a Victorian engineer. Yes, they said, here's £20,000. They thought the sun shone out of my arse at the time. They'd have given me money to animate a toilet if I'd asked them." No doubt the top brass at British Lion trusted Godfrey to keep within his budget and bring in a film that marginalised engineering in favour of sex, politics and cheap laughs.

Bob Godfrey started out as a graphic artist for Lever Brothers in the 1930s, advertising "soap and sausages", before joining a Rank subsidiary that was trying to copy the success of Walt Disney. They called it Animaland.

He got his lucky break in 1950 when he was taken on by the innovative Larkin Studio, which was trying to combine the American comic strip with modern art. "They asked me what I knew about making animated films and I said 'Nothing,' and they said, 'Good, you can start Monday.' Everything was very compartmentalised then, so I just did backgrounds. I didn't like it when I saw the finished films with all these characters moving about in front of my beautiful backgrounds."

He decided to have a go at making his own films instead. He bought a handle-turned camera for £2 in Edgware Road, rigged it up on a stand, and positioned a few tin cans to light up the artwork. "It felt like I was discovering film 50 years after everyone else. I'd rush down to the developers with 27 feet of film. I was so thrilled when it came back in focus."

By the time commercial TV started in 1955, Godfrey had set up his own studio in Soho - Biographic - with two other artist-animators, and managed to produce a 15-second black-and-white animated ad for the very first night of ITV.

The flow of work from commercial TV provided the financial security he needed to start experimenting with his own flights of fantasy. "I loved music hall and The Goon Show, and all my early films looked like music-hall turns. I didn't really know what I was doing. I just used to plunge in. They were simple but effective."

Writer Colin Pearson, an occasional collaborator over 30 years, worked on The Do-It-Yourself Cartoon Kit (1962), as well as Great and, most recently, Millennium: The Musical. "Bob tramples on scripts and goes off at tangents that have nothing to do with the narrative. I took my name off Great in a fit of pique."

In the late 1950s, Godfrey's work came to the attention of influential film people such as Richard Lester and Joe McGrath, as well as Spike Milligan and Michael Bentine, who were working in television by then. "We were all doing quite innovative, avant-garde things in the comedy field, so we had a lot in common. In a sense we were getting ready for the cultural gear change of the 1960s."

His friendship with Lester and McGrath - he was a bit player in Help! and A Hard Day's Night, and an ideas man on Yellow Submarine - prompted Godfrey to suggest to John Lennon an animated version of his nonsense book, A Spaniard in the Works.

"John said he really liked the idea but I'd have to talk to Brian Epstein about the money for it. Sadly Epstein killed himself before I had a chance to see him. Anyway, John asked me to make a live action film for him and Yoko called Erection. It was about a hotel being built. He wanted to carry it around with him as a decoy to fool the customs people who always used to stop and search him for drugs."

Since Henry 9 'Til 5 in 1970, about the sexual fantasies of an outwardly respectable suburban suit, Godfrey's work has always moved along parallel lines - raunchy adult material on one track, quirky kids' stuff on the other. With the highly distinctive Henry's Cat, and Roobarb and Custard, whose cat-dog relationship was inspired by the great comedy double acts, he was one of the first animators to pioneer the idea of children's cartoons with an underlying appeal to adults. "We weren't conscious of making them sophisticated, but it's true that we thought things like Captain Pugwash and Camberwick Green were really naff."

It was his second adult short, Kama Sutra Rides Again, that changed everything in 1971. Godfrey and writer Stan Hayward both felt there was comedy mileage in a cartoon Kama Sutra. He had 12 animators working on it, each one allocated a different sexual position. Among other places, coitus was achieved by Godfrey's enterprising couple, Stanley and Ethel, in a hammock, on an escalator (going up), sliding down a bannister, and on a trapeze (without a safety net). As with all his "adult" cartoons, Godfrey simultaneously celebrated and ridiculed mankind's preoccupation with sex.

After it was finished, he was astonished to get a call from Stanley Kubrick saying he wanted it to accompany the UK general release of A Clockwork Orange. "Everyone working in films knew Kubrick only ever phoned you to give you a bollocking, so when I realised he was calling to do me a favour I nearly dropped the phone."

The studios Godfrey established successively in the 1960s and 1970s became focal points for wannabe creatives, including the young Terry Gilliam, who was refused work on the grounds that he was too good. "They were full of funny, loud and desperate people who were always getting angry and walking out," recalls Gilliam. "Bob turned me down many years ago and I have respected him ever since for his exquisite taste."

Mike Hayes likens the working atmosphere to that of "a circus, where you suddenly discover that the ringmaster is up on the high wire doing acrobatics". The Guardian's Steve Bell, a sometime collaborator (The Journalist's Tale, Maggie Thatcher: Where am I Now?), describes Godfrey's work as "deceptively simple . . . one of the things you learn working with Bob is how to avoid animation. He uses a lot of cut-outs and newsreel footage, and he's always wanting to pare everything down to the bone. He's a minimalist."

Godfrey may no longer be churning out commercials, but the drive and enthusiasm are still there. Two years ago Channel 4 commissioned him to make Millennium: The Musical, a romp through 2,000 years of British history featuring jolly songs about the Black Death and Richard III. And earlier this year he produced Will's World for Channel 4, a scurrilous account of Prince William's love life, featuring, among others Britney Spears.

Claire Kitson, his commissioning editor at Channel 4, found his approach to work unconventional. "He makes a great pretence of being chaotic. We'd have these shambolic meetings when it would appear that nothing I'd said previously had been understood. But in fact he always delivered on time and he stuck to the schedules."

As a renowned teacher of animation, Godfrey maintains his unorthodox approach. Stick to the impossible, he tells his students. Once you've learnt the rules, break them. "I teach the basics of animation, then it's up to the individual. Great illustrators don't always make great animators. I've known people who couldn't draw at all who were great animators. You can always spot the ones with real talent. They don't listen to you."

New technology has transformed the art of animation in recent years and, despite his age, Bob Godfrey refuses to languish in technophobic limbo. "I'm not what you'd call computer literate but I employ people who are. I'm not a stuckist. All the arduous stuff has gone thanks to computers. They've revolutionised the industry. The strange thing is that my computerised films look like my old trace-and- paint films."

Looking back over 60 years of animation, does he have any regrets? "I'd love to have done a full-length feature but I can't seem to stretch myself to that length. When you look at my films, they appear to be a series of 30-second commercials cut together. I'm a short distance man whether I like it or not."

Bob Godfrey presents programmes of his animated shorts at the National Film Theatre, London SE1 (0207-928 3232), on April 26 and 28.
