"It felt like I was discovering film 50 years after everyone else. I'd rush down to the developers with 27 feet of film. I was so thrilled when it came back in focus." By the time commercial TV started in 1955, Godfrey had set up his own studio in Soho - Biographic - with two other artist-animators, and managed to produce a 15-second black-and-white animated ad for the very first night of ITV. The flow of work from commercial TV provided the financial security he needed to start experimenting with his own flights of fantasy. "I loved music hall and The Goon Show, and all my early films looked like music-hall turns. I didn't really know what I was doing. I just used to plunge in. They were simple but effective." Writer Colin Pearson, an occasional collaborator over 30 years, worked on The Do-It-Yourself Cartoon Kit (1962), as well as Great and, most recently, Millennium: The Musical. "Bob tramples on scripts and goes off at tangents that have nothing to do with the narrative. I took my name off Great in a fit of pique." In the late 1950s, Godfrey's work came to the attention of influential film people such as Richard Lester and Joe McGrath, as well as Spike Milligan and Michael Bentine, who were working in television by then. "We were all doing quite innovative, avant-garde things in the comedy field, so we had a lot in common. In a sense we were getting ready for the cultural gear change of the 1960s." His friendship with Lester and McGrath - he was a bit player in Help! and A Hard Day's Night, and an ideas man on Yellow Submarine - prompted Godfrey to suggest to John Lennon an animated version of his nonsense book, A Spaniard in the Works. "John said he really liked the idea but I'd have to talk to Brian Epstein about the money for it. Sadly Epstein killed himself before I had a chance to see him. Anyway, John asked me to make a live action film for him and Yoko called Erection. It was about a hotel being built. He wanted to carry it around with him as a decoy to fool the customs people who always used to stop and search him for drugs." Since Henry 9 'Til 5 in 1970, about the sexual fantasies of an outwardly respectable suburban suit, Godfrey's work has always moved along parallel lines - raunchy adult material on one track, quirky kids' stuff on the other. With the highly distinctive Henry's Cat, and Roobarb and Custard, whose cat-dog relationship was inspired by the great comedy double acts, he was one of the first animators to pioneer the idea of children's cartoons with an underlying appeal to adults. "We weren't conscious of making them sophisticated, but it's true that we thought things like Captain Pugwash and Camberwick Green were really naff." It was his second adult short, Kama Sutra Rides Again, that changed everything in 1971. Godfrey and writer Stan Hayward both felt there was comedy mileage in a cartoon Kama Sutra. He had 12 animators working on it, each one allocated a different sexual position. Among other places, coitus was achieved by Godfrey's enterprising couple, Stanley and Ethel, in a hammock, on an escalator (going up), sliding down a bannister, and on a trapeze (without a safety net). As with all his "adult" cartoons, Godfrey simultaneously celebrated and ridiculed mankind's preoccupation with sex. After it was finished, he was astonished to get a call from Stanley Kubrick saying he wanted it to accompany the UK general release of A Clockwork Orange. "Everyone working in films knew Kubrick only ever phoned you to give you a bollocking, so when I realised he was calling to do me a favour I nearly dropped the phone." The studios Godfrey established successively in the 1960s and 1970s became focal points for wannabe creatives, including the young Terry Gilliam, who was refused work on the grounds that he was too good. "They were full of funny, loud and desperate people who were always getting angry and walking out," recalls Gilliam. "Bob turned me down many years ago and I have respected him ever since for his exquisite taste." Mike Hayes likens the working atmosphere to that of "a circus, where you suddenly discover that the ringmaster is up on the high wire doing acrobatics". The Guardian's Steve Bell, a sometime collaborator (The Journalist's Tale, Maggie Thatcher: Where am I Now?), describes Godfrey's work as "deceptively simple . . . one of the things you learn working with Bob is how to avoid animation. He uses a lot of cut-outs and newsreel footage, and he's always wanting to pare everything down to the bone. He's a minimalist." Godfrey may no longer be churning out commercials, but the drive and enthusiasm are still there. Two years ago Channel 4 commissioned him to make Millennium: The Musical, a romp through 2,000 years of British history featuring jolly songs about the Black Death and Richard III. And earlier this year he produced Will's World for Channel 4, a scurrilous account of Prince William's love life, featuring, among others Britney Spears. Claire Kitson, his commissioning editor at Channel 4, found his approach to work unconventional. "He makes a great pretence of being chaotic. We'd have these shambolic meetings when it would appear that nothing I'd said previously had been understood. But in fact he always delivered on time and he stuck to the schedules." As a renowned teacher of animation, Godfrey maintains his unorthodox approach. Stick to the impossible, he tells his students. Once you've learnt the rules, break them. "I teach the basics of animation, then it's up to the individual. Great illustrators don't always make great animators. I've known people who couldn't draw at all who were great animators. You can always spot the ones with real talent. They don't listen to you." New technology has transformed the art of animation in recent years and, despite his age, Bob Godfrey refuses to languish in technophobic limbo. "I'm not what you'd call computer literate but I employ people who are. I'm not a stuckist. All the arduous stuff has gone thanks to computers. They've revolutionised the industry. The strange thing is that my computerised films look like my old trace-and- paint films." Looking back over 60 years of animation, does he have any regrets? "I'd love to have done a full-length feature but I can't seem to stretch myself to that length. When you look at my films, they appear to be a series of 30-second commercials cut together. I'm a short distance man whether I like it or not." Bob Godfrey presents programmes of his animated shorts at the National Film Theatre, London SE1 (0207-928 3232), on April 26 and 28.

fields.headline: The Contender
fields.standfirst: Can the feisty feminist beat the bald misogynist? Peter Bradshaw  couldn't care less by the end of the latest White House thriller
fields.trailText: Can the feisty feminist beat the bald misogynist? Peter Bradshaw couldn't care less by the end of the latest White House thriller
fields.body:
This must be the last Washington film from the Clinton era to come gurgling out of the pipeline: an era in which an ostensibly liberal Hollywood elite backed Bill not merely with cash and cachet, but remarkably with actual movies featuring Clinton-alikes in more or less flattering romantic/action hero roles: Michael Douglas in The American President, Harrison Ford in Air Force One, Bill Pullman in Independence Day, John Travolta in Primary Colors and Martin Sheen in TV's cutesy The West Wing.

The Contender has another quasi-Bill in the form of Jeff Bridges, a middle-aged but credibly fanciable and dishy Democratic president coming to the end of his second term. (The script refers to the real Clinton's impeachment, so the film is presumably set around 2007 or 2008; writer-director Rod Lurie clearly conceived his movie at a time when a Democratic successor to Clinton was considered a shoo-in.) Anyway, the prez is looking around for a "swan song", a progressive achievement to bookend his administration. He hits on appointing a woman vice-president when the male incumbent dies; his choice is Senator Laine Hanson - played with steely poise and presence by Joan Allen.

But her appointment is undermined by the villainous politician Sheldon Runyon, played by Gary Oldman, also the picture's executive producer. Where Bridges is a noble soul with a full head of glossy hair, Oldman plays a balding misogynist and dirty-trick specialist who thinks nothing of dragging up Laine's supposed sexual past to destroy her. (As a woman-hating slaphead, Sheldon is like Richard Dreyfuss's nasty Republican in The American President. As an all-round bad guy, he is like the Russian terrorist in Air Force One, played by Gary Oldman.)

Runyon displays his villainy by chairing the Congressional committee instituted to ratify Senator Hanson; he feeds stories to the press about her alleged group-sex gang-bang orgies as an 18-year-old co-ed. Then he ferociously questions her about them. Before our very eyes, he turns into Joe McCarthy, while Joan Allen turns into Paul Scofield in A Man for All Seasons. Instead of denying the stories, she refuses to dignify this filth with a response - and all the president's men look like leaving her to twist in the wind.

Lurie's film is watchable enough, with kangaroo-court witch trial scenes that owe a good deal to John Frankenheimer's The Manchurian Candidate. There's a top-notch performance from Allen, and Bridges is great as the president who visibly adores charming, intimidating and discomfiting people with the trappings of office: particularly in one scene in which he meets an idealistic young congressman, played by Christian Slater, and insists he shares some of his (symbolic) lunch - shark-steak sandwich.

But this isn't a tough, wised-up political thriller; this is a movie puffed up with chest-busting sentimental pride at its own heroic liberalism. It actually has some extremely quaint and conservative assumptions about modern sexual politics. Moreover, its key plot denouement is the silliest cop-out I have seen in years. It is so lame that I at first thought it was a devilishly cynical fabrication to be itself unmasked in some post-credit twist.

But no. The Contender is a movie in which we are invited to applaud, as a feminist breakthrough, a powerful man being so good as to give a woman a job: the vice-presidency. She is not shown earning this job at the ballot-box, still less on the basis of winning anything so boring as a political argument. And in the political landscape shown here, Joan Allen is weirdly the only important woman. Senator Hillary Clinton isn't mentioned; neither is Madeleine Albright.

One powerful woman who does get a couple of name-checks, however, is our very own Margaret Thatcher, a woman whom Hanson piously rejects as a role model in favour of Thomas Jefferson. Nasty old Sheldon Runyon disses Maggie as well: the world accepted her, he sneers, "because she was answerable to Ronald Reagan". Well, yes, she (and we) certainly crawled to Ron very humiliatingly indeed. But the British voters and the parliamentary Conservative Party who put her in office were not, as it happens, answerable to Ronald Reagan. So how naive and parochial is that remark supposed to be?

What sinks The Contender in the end is its mealy mouthed spirit of bipartisanship. Allen's martyred heroine is supposed to be a one-time Republican (though we never hear the least thing about any former rightwing views) and Lurie hasn't even got the guts to make Oldman an out-and-out reactionary bad guy. Apparently nervous of admitting the existence of straightforward evil, Lurie gives Oldman a tearful scene in which his wife reminds him how he once introduced legislation against "hate crime" - a deeply unconvincing hint that his actions are some kind of tragic character flaw.

The dead hand of reassuring consensus settles on the movie long before the end. For a really sabre-toothed account of political misogyny and the war-zone in sexual politics, you have to go to Neil LaBute's In the Company of Men or Alexander Payne's Election. This is just affirmative action for liberals.

fields.headline: The London marathon
fields.standfirst: The sweaty hordes of professional athletes and fundraisers in bizarre costumes are back for the London marathon. Here's our guide to the best sites on those 26 miles
fields.trailText: The sweaty hordes of professional athletes and fundraisers in bizarre costumes are back for the London marathon. Here's our guide to the best sites on those 26 miles.
fields.body:
1. From the comfort of your armchair, or from a viewing point in the capital, you can watch the London marathon on Sunday.

2. Over 26.2 miles (which takes 30 minutes to drive at 60mph but longer at rush hour), the competitors will run from Greenwich Park to Tower Bridge, do a circuit of the Isle of Dogs and then head to St James's Park.

3. The distance more or less commemorates the legendary feat of a Greek soldier who ran 25 miles from Marathon to Athens in 490BC to bring news of the Athenian victory over the Persians.

4. Sounds a long way? Well, try doing it 200 times - that is the challenge Jerry Dunn set for himself in 2000 (and completed).

5. It is too late to enter this year's London marathon but - if the idea appeals to you - now is a good time to begin thinking about 2002. You need to work up to a 26-week preparation programme.

6. And it's not just the running you have to be ready for - you have to drink plenty of water, eat the right food and decide if you are the right kind of person to go the distance.

7. The first modern marathon was held at the 1896 Olympic Games in Athens, and the first annual race the following year in Boston, Massachusetts.

8. If you can't make the London event, there are plenty more around the world - in cities such as New York, Rotterdam and Berlin.

9. Just remember that training is essential. Without it, you risk seriously injuring yourself. (The Greek soldier did, after all, die of exhaustion.)

10. But there are those who do not need it - the Olympic record holder, Emil Zátopek, had never run the race before when he finished in 2 hours and 23 minutes.

fields.headline: 'Missing art' feud taints auction
fields.trailText: Italy's art world was convulsed yesterday by stories of theft, feuding and scandal over the auction planned last night of one of the greatest private collections of Renaissance artworks.
fields.body:
Italy's art world was convulsed yesterday by stories of theft, feuding and scandal over the auction planned last night of one of the greatest private collections of Renaissance artworks.

The wife, housekeeper, mistress and self-proclaimed illegitimate daughter of the late Carlo De Carlo were locked in battle for an estate said to be priceless.

Some of the most valuable works, including two 14th-century paintings by Giotto, were missing from the lots due to be sold in Florence. What remained was expected to raise more than £10m.

Mr De Carlo's collection has tainted establishment figures since his unexpected death from a stroke in August 1999, aged 68. A Florentine businessman and art dealer, who kept some of the best pieces for himself, he left no will.

Giotto portraits of St John the Baptist and St Francis, worth more than £13m, are reported to have vanished from a bank vault the day after his death. A holy water container embossed with the seal of Pope Clement VII and a panel from a 15th-century polyptych by Lorenzo Monaco also disappeared.

Police traced other missing treasures to the dealer's employees and friends. Among those charged with theft were his mistress, Mara Masini; their alleged daughter Lisa Zecchi and her husband. Mr De Carlo's housekeeper and her son were also charged.

Leonardo Mondadori, the chairman of Italy's biggest publishing house, was charged with receiving stolen goods after nine works were found and confiscated at his home.

Mr Mondadori said he arranged to buy them from the dealer before he died and completed the transaction with Mrs Zecchi, who he assumed was a legal heir.

A member of the board of Sotheby's Italia, he told Italy Daily he would not participate in last night's auction: "I wouldn't dream of it, so much dust has been raised over these works that I prefer to remain out of everything."

De Carlo's brother and widow, from whom he was estranged for 15 years, took possession of the remaining works and decided to auction them.

Florentine museums were dismayed; they had expected a will to make generous donations. As compensation they were given a 16th-century bust of Christ by Tullio Lombardo and a painting of the Virgin enthroned with saints by Duccio di Buoninsegna.

Antonio Paolucci, Florence's supervisor for fine arts, was accused of intentionally inflating the auction's prices by exhibiting 38 works at the Galleria dell'Accademia.

"It creates an instant pedigree for the works which are no longer just the property of a dealer but objects that have been shown in a museum setting," the art critic Paolo Vagheggi told Italy Daily.

Mr Paolucci said his intention was to pressure the state into bidding at the auction.

webTitle: A farmer's diary during foot and mouth

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
As the weather closes in, the long, hard lambing season grinds by on our diarist's farm

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: As the weather closes in, the long, hard lambing season grinds by on our diarist's farm.
fields.body:
It remains bitterly cold here. Meal times and coffee breaks, huddling round the Aga, offer welcome respite from the unrelenting icy wind outside. As I type this entry I am wearing two jumpers: the office is far from warm and chilly draughts howl under the door.

The trees remain stubbornly leafless and the grass in the pastures is still sparse, but not everywhere is like this. In County Durham around Tow Law, and for mile upon mile along the A68, there is hardly a sheep to be seen and it is easy for passers by to recognise this fact because the empty fields stand out as vibrant squares of shocking green. The Eden valley in Cumbria is almost completely without livestock, and I am told by those who have done the drive from Hartside to Penrith (and beyond) that passing through this eerie scene - of an empty, utterly silent landscape - is a truly shocking experience.

Yesterday our census form arrived in the post, and so did further instruction from Northumberland county council about footpath closures. New guidelines have been issued and in some areas footpaths will re-open, but only under a strict code of conduct. Footpaths across non-agricultural land, woodland, arable and set-aside will re-open, but footpaths will remain closed within 3km of infected premises, within all premises under foot and mouth restrictions, and elsewhere where rights of way cross areas grazed by livestock.

The code of practice for everyone wanting to use the re-opened paths seems to be quite sensible. Anyone who keeps or handles livestock must not cross any farmland at all. All visitors to the countryside must comply with the notices that are displayed. And they are asked to keep dogs on a lead (at all times) and not to take dogs on to land with cows, sheep, goats or pigs. Everyone is asked to use disinfectant where provided and never to leave behind waste food or litter and to clean their boots and their vehicles after each walk or visit to the countryside.

The sheep are hungry all the time now, and it is not a good sign. Every time the quad bike enters the field they lift their heads expectantly and some even come running up, whatever the time of day, in the hope that they will be fed with compound food at the trough or receive more hay. Although this is not uncommon with a late spring, it is rather dispiriting this year as we do not know what the future holds and all this extra feed is very expensive. Archie, our lambing shepherd, said an inch of grass in the fields would make all the difference, and we all agree.

This shortage of new grass and the consequential shortage of milk among the ewes is leading to problems in the twin fields. Every evening Peter and Graham check different fields of ewes with twin lambs to make sure that each pair of lambs is "mothered up" with its own mother. Because the ewes are so ravenous they are rushing up to the troughs and leaving their lambs behind so it is impossible to make sure each family unit is safe for the night.

This is an added worry as the cold nights are always a risk for abandoned and hungry lambs and we do also have predators. A strong recently born Cheviot cross lamb was found on Wednesday morning with its head bitten off by either a fox or a badger, and the crowds of crows often peck out the eye or even a tongue of a lamb if it is left alone.

Another cow calved on Tuesday night, during a brief but fierce snowstorm. This particular cow was thankfully beside the back door into the shed so it was easy to bring them both into the warm and dry. We have had six live calves so far this spring, and there are hopefully a few more due soon.

Only 19 Mule sheep are left to lamb but there are still too many Scottish Blackface ewes left to count, but by next week there should be a lot fewer. We are well over half way through the lambing, but we're not quite able to see the end of the interminable lambing tunnel where work is the only order of the day and a few hours off is an unobtainable luxury.

At least we have no pet lambs - yet. Melanie, Roly's wife, from the next door farm, has 16 lambs on the bottle receiving powdered milk and she also has 25 or more on an automatic milk feeder. All these hassles are the normal trials and tribulations of spring, of course. And at least we still have our livestock to worry about.

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. Her diary will return next Wednesday.

fields.bodyText: It remains bitterly cold here. Meal times and coffee breaks, huddling round the Aga, offer welcome respite from the unrelenting icy wind outside. As I type this entry I am wearing two jumpers: the office is far from warm and chilly draughts howl under the door. The trees remain stubbornly leafless and the grass in the pastures is still sparse, but not everywhere is like this. In County Durham around Tow Law, and for mile upon mile along the A68, there is hardly a sheep to be seen and it is easy for passers by to recognise this fact because the empty fields stand out as vibrant squares of shocking green. The Eden valley in Cumbria is almost completely without livestock, and I am told by those who have done the drive from Hartside to Penrith (and beyond) that passing through this eerie scene - of an empty, utterly silent landscape - is a truly shocking experience. Yesterday our census form arrived in the post, and so did further instruction from Northumberland county council about footpath closures. New guidelines have been issued and in some areas footpaths will re-open, but only under a strict code of conduct. Footpaths across non-agricultural land, woodland, arable and set-aside will re-open, but footpaths will remain closed within 3km of infected premises, within all premises under foot and mouth restrictions, and elsewhere where rights of way cross areas grazed by livestock. The code of practice for everyone wanting to use the re-opened paths seems to be quite sensible. Anyone who keeps or handles livestock must not cross any farmland at all. All visitors to the countryside must comply with the notices that are displayed. And they are asked to keep dogs on a lead (at all times) and not to take dogs on to land with cows, sheep, goats or pigs. Everyone is asked to use disinfectant where provided and never to leave behind waste food or litter and to clean their boots and their vehicles after each walk or visit to the countryside. The sheep are hungry all the time now, and it is not a good sign. Every time the quad bike enters the field they lift their heads expectantly and some even come running up, whatever the time of day, in the hope that they will be fed with compound food at the trough or receive more hay. Although this is not uncommon with a late spring, it is rather dispiriting this year as we do not know what the future holds and all this extra feed is very expensive. Archie, our lambing shepherd, said an inch of grass in the fields would make all the difference, and we all agree. This shortage of new grass and the consequential shortage of milk among the ewes is leading to problems in the twin fields. Every evening Peter and Graham check different fields of ewes with twin lambs to make sure that each pair of lambs is "mothered up" with its own mother. Because the ewes are so ravenous they are rushing up to the troughs and leaving their lambs behind so it is impossible to make sure each family unit is safe for the night. This is an added worry as the cold nights are always a risk for abandoned and hungry lambs and we do also have predators. A strong recently born Cheviot cross lamb was found on Wednesday morning with its head bitten off by either a fox or a badger, and the crowds of crows often peck out the eye or even a tongue of a lamb if it is left alone. Another cow calved on Tuesday night, during a brief but fierce snowstorm. This particular cow was thankfully beside the back door into the shed so it was easy to bring them both into the warm and dry. We have had six live calves so far this spring, and there are hopefully a few more due soon. Only 19 Mule sheep are left to lamb but there are still too many Scottish Blackface ewes left to count, but by next week there should be a lot fewer. We are well over half way through the lambing, but we're not quite able to see the end of the interminable lambing tunnel where work is the only order of the day and a few hours off is an unobtainable luxury. At least we have no pet lambs - yet. Melanie, Roly's wife, from the next door farm, has 16 lambs on the bottle receiving powdered milk and she also has 25 or more on an automatic milk feeder. All these hassles are the normal trials and tribulations of spring, of course. And at least we still have our livestock to worry about.  The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. Her diary will return next Wednesday. webTitle: Internet girls go to US foster parents

fields.headline: Internet girls go to US foster parents
fields.standfirst: Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The twin babies at the centre of the internet adoption row were last night handed to US foster parents at an undisclosed address in Missouri.
fields.body:
The twin babies at the centre of the internet adoption row were last night handed to US foster parents at an undisclosed address in Missouri.

Nine-month-old sisters Belinda and Kimberley had arrived in Britain in January after being "bought" by Alan and Judith Kilshaw, from north Wales, through an internet site run by a Californian child broker.

The case provoked outrage when the Kilshaws' claim to have adopted the girls in the US was contested by a Californian couple, who paid the broker first, and by the twins' natural mother, Tranda Wecker.

On Wednesday three social workers from Flintshire county council took the twins to St Louis, in Missouri, their original home state. The council had been caring for the girls since January 18.

Its chief executive, Philip McGreevy, said the girls had been placed in the custody of state authorities pending a decision on their future by the courts.

The high court in London last week dismissed the Kilshaws' claim to custody of the girls and ordered their return to US jurisdiction. Last month a judge in Arkansas annulled their adoption by the Kilshaws.

It emerged last night that a British television company was offering to pay for air tickets to help the Kilshaws emigrate to the US where they want to adopt again.

Mrs Kilshaw told 5 News, the Channel 5 news programme produced by ITN, that she planned to write a book to tell her side of the story. She believed America would provide the fair hearing she had been denied in Britain.

A spokeswoman for Channel 5 said the programme would fund one-way tickets for the Kilshaws to a destination of their choice. It was not able to disclose the cost since the couple had not decided on that destination.

Mr Kilshaw said he was considering opening a hotel in the US. His wife added that one of the attractions of America was that adoptions were seen to be normal. "It happens every day. It's happening now as we speak. Children are being born there, put up for adoption and it's a normal procedure."

Later, the US lawyer for Mrs Wecker said his client was looking forward to being reunited with the babies.

Bill Meehan told CNN: "The parents have been kept in the dark about the date and time of their return and that was done on purpose because they did not want any type of scene at the airport.

"There is going to be a reunification process. The parents will get a check-list of things to do and when they have done those type of things the twins will be reunited with the parents."

Mrs Wecker is in the process of divorcing her husband, Aaron, who is also seeking custody of the twins, but Mr Meehan said they were working together for the best interests of the girls.

"The parents have to redeem themselves before the court's eyes... the only way that we were going to get the children back was by a joint effort to bury the hatchet," he said.

webTitle: Bush accelerates US return to Middle East u-turn

fields.headline: Bush accelerates US return to Middle East u-turn
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Bush administration, reversing efforts to extricate itself from the Middle East, is poised to appoint a peace envoy to the region, US and Israeli officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
The Bush administration, reversing efforts to extricate itself from the Middle East, is poised to appoint a peace envoy to the region, US and Israeli officials said yesterday.

A likely candidate is Edward Djerjian, a veteran diplomat who has served as ambassador to Israel and Syria. Richard Haas, a former analyst at the Brookings Institution thinktank in Washington, has also been mentioned.

But it is thought that whoever is appointed will not have the sweeping independence or the staff of Dennis Ross, who was a significant player in peacemaking for the best part of 10 years.

The appointment is the latest in a series of events which suggest that Washington, concerned about the growing violence of the Palestinian revolt against Israeli occupation, may have given up its goal of disengaging from day-to-day involvement in the Middle East, because of the gravity of the crisis.

Earlier this month the CIA held a meeting of Israeli and Palestinian security officials near Tel Aviv, reversing the agency's decision to end its mediatory role.

Reports of an imminent appointment surfaced less than 48 hours after Washington made an unexpected intervention in the uprising by rebuking Israel for re-occupying a square mile of the Gaza Strip.

Within hours of it condemning the seizure of Palestinian-ruled land as "excessive and disproportionate", Israeli tanks were on their way out.

The hasty withdrawal proved hugely embarrassing to the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, who has been forced to fend off the accusation of far-right allies that he succumbed to US pressure.

The episode also led to squabbling in Israeli military and political circles, and yesterday parliament opened an investigation into the affair.

Analysts said Washington's rebuke and the expected appointment of a peace envoy heralded the renewal of US involvement in the Middle East crisis which could result in it placing limits on Mr Sharon's campaign to snuff out the Palestinian revolt.

Mr Sharon spoke to President George Bush during thee night. His spokesman said he told Mr Bush that Israel would continue to retaliate harshly against mortar attacks on Jewish settlements in Gaza.

But after this week's rebuke it seems clear that the US will tolerate the incursions that have become routine under Mr Sharon, but not his reoccupation of Palestinian territory.

"They pretty clearly set out a line that Israel should not reoccupy parts of Palestinian Authority, that if it is going to go in, it should come out right away," said Joseph Alpher, an independent analyst who was an adviser to the former prime minister Ehud Barak at the failed Camp David summit last summer.

The US is getting itself more involved as Mr Sharon steps up his efforts to end the revolt and thereby accelerates the cycle of attack and retaliation.

In the the West Bank city of Ramallah an explosion ripped through the roof of a building used by Yasser Arafat's elite Force 17 security unit yesterday. It was unclear what caused the blast.

Israel has repeatedly bombed buildings belonging to Force 17, which it accuses of leading Palestinian attacks on soldiers and illegal Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza.

It has also assassinated more than a dozen Palestinian activists. But an Israeli army spokesman denied that it was involved in this incident.

In public Israeli officials support Mr Djerjian's appointment, though Mr Sharon has said he has no intention of negotiating with the Palestinians until they end their uprising. He also opposes efforts to reach a final peace deal.

His spokesman Raanan Gissin insisted that the appointment of a Middle East envoy did not mean that Washington would begin pushing the government to the negotiating table.

"It is not going to be a negotiator at this stage. Right now it is someone who can report on what is going on, who can pass messages and who can report to the secretary of state."

fields.headline: Quebec steels itself for violence
fields.standfirst:
Thousands to protest at controversial trade summit

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: A three metre-high fence and thousands of police officers sealed off the heart of Quebec City last night as the leaders of 34 American countries began to arrive for a controversial free trade summit.
fields.body:
A three metre-high fence and thousands of police officers sealed off the heart of Quebec City last night as the leaders of 34 American countries began to arrive for a controversial free trade summit.

Hundreds of women staged the first of many protests against the Summit of the Americas, which is taking place in the Canadian city this weekend, when they attached weavings and banners to the perimeter fence. Lisa Fithian of the Direct Action Network, an organising group, said that they were trying to highlight the injustice of the proceedings.

Police yesterday charged seven Canadians with conspiring to commit dangerous acts and to break through the security fence.

In a specially held press conference after the arrests, the police displayed weapons they had seized during the arrests, including military thunder flash explosives, smoke bombs, baseball bats, and slingshots.

Clac, an anarchistic anti-capitalist group; Gomm, a coalition against globalisation; and the pagan River Action group are all expected to stage separate demonstrations today.

The Canadian authorities expect a total of between 10,000 and 40,000 people to protest against the free trade agreement being discussed at the summit.

The protests, which follow those held in Seattle two years ago and Washington and Prague last year, are expected to be among the largest held in Canada in recent memory.

Disparate groups from across the Americas believe that the aim of the summit - to push towards the creation of a huge free trade bloc from the tip of South America to north of the Arctic Circle encompassing 800m people and with a combined output of $11 trillion in goods and services - will harm poorer countries and damage the environment. The summit has been criticised for being anti-democratic.

Aides to George Bush, who will travel to the summit tomorrow, have said that members of his cabinet will meet with representatives of the anti-globalisation, environmental and human rights groups as part of the "good neighbour" policy the US president wants to expound at the meeting.

But more than 7,000 police officers from four different Canadian forces have been trained in special anti-protest control measures in an attempt to prevent a re-run of the clashes that turned Seattle into a battleground. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police force is co-ordinating the effort, which also includes 1,400 members of the Canadian armed forces.

One police officer who earned the nickname Sergeant Pepper at the Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation summit four years ago for repeatedly spraying protesters with pepper spray will also be on the frontlines.

The 6ft tall chainlink fence, mounted on concrete posts, is six kilometres long (3.7 miles) and covers the downtown area of Old Quebec, enclosing summit venues and hotels.

Some of the protesters believe that the heavy border controls and police presence may have deterred some potential participants.

Philippe Duhamel, an organiser for Salami, a leading Canadian protest groups, said that several people had been prevented from entering Canada and many were worried by threats of police brutality: "People are scared. They are really scared."

Ms Fithian added that many first aiders had been prevented from entering the country by border police.

"People are only being let in if they don't identify themselves with the protest and don't have any equipment with them," she said.

Over the weekend, when the summit proper starts with a series of meetings to discuss increasing hemispheric trade, a larger march is expected to be held and organised by labour unions in Canada.

One Canadian citizen tried to have the fence taken down as an affront to democratic freedom but a superior court judge ruled that it should stand because of the risk of violence during the summit.

webTitle: Analysis: The third summit of the Americas

fields.headline: Free trade free-for-all
fields.standfirst:
As Quebec hosts the third summit of the Americas this weekend, divisions within the conference may overshadow the protests on the outside

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: As Quebec hosts the third summit of the Americas this weekend, divisions within the conference may overshadow the protests on the outside.
fields.body:
Forget May Day. The anti-globalisation lobby's first big outing of the year is happening this weekend in Quebec City. Representatives of 34 nations, Antigua and Barbuda to Venezuela with the United States and Canada towering over them as the chart shows, are gathering for the third summit of the Americas, which is discussing a free trade area to cover the entire western hemisphere.

Also expected are between 10,000 and 40,000 protesters. The Canadian authorities have built a 3m high, 5km long wall around the old quarter of the city to prevent a repeat of the demonstrations which have disrupted international financial meetings in Seattle, Washington and Prague.

On both sides of the barricades the gatherings face major challenges. The goal of a free trade zone stretching from the Arctic Circle to Cape Horn was first mooted seven years ago but lay dormant after the Clinton administration lost so called "fast track" negotiating authority in 1994.

The new president has declared the Free Trade Area of the Americas to be a priority but George Bush's fellow leaders are rightly sceptical about what the United States is prepared to bring to the table. Brazil, the most powerful Latin American economy, doubts that the US will offer many concessions on market access for steel and agriculture, its two priorities.

Also crucial will be whether the new administration can win fast-track negotiating authority from congress. Without this, which the Bush administration calls trade promotion authority, Washington's partners fear prospective deals may be rewritten by a Congress dominated by producer lobbies.

Prospects for the global economy have darkened since the leaders made the Quebec date in their diaries. This week's decision by Alan Greenspan, the world's most powerful central banker, to cut interest rates, is an indication of how worried the authorities are.

Trade deals are often easier to clinch when the economic outlook becomes uncertain. Negotiators' minds become concentrated on the dangers of a breakdown in trading relationships. As Mike Moore, the head of the World Trade Organisation asked recently: "When do you fix the roof? When the sun shines or when it rains?"

But history shows that the opposite can also be true. During the depression of the 1930s, countries rushed to erect tariff walls around their economies, and exacerbated the downturn with beggar-thy-neighbour devaluations. In an uncomfortable reminder of that past, Argentina, the most storm-tossed economy in the Americas, has recently slapped higher tariffs on range of imports, in defiance of its obligations under Mercosur, the four-country Latin American trade agreement.

Argentina also angered its neighbour Brazil by signalling it may break ranks with the rest of Mercosur and negotiate bilateral trade agreements with the European Union and the US. This is the equivalent of Britain declaring that it wished to leave the EU and become a member of the European Free Trade Area instead. It would severely dent Mercosur's status as a customs union with a common external tariff.

This weekend's gathering is supposed only to rubber stamp the declaration on the Free Trade Area of the Americas agreed by officials last week in Buenos Aires. The hard bargaining comes next, over the 300-page agreement which is the basis for negotiations between now and January 2005 when the FTAA* - Area de Libre Comercio de las Americas in Spanish - is supposed to be formally launched.

Outside the conference rooms, the protesters also have problems. Having propelled trade negotiations into the public consciousness 18 months ago, by contributing to the collapse of the Seattle summit of the World Trade Organisation, the disparate groups opposed to further liberalisation in the global economy face a conundrum. Non-governmental organisations know that mass protests outside trade meetings bring headlines while thoughtful policy papers on the impact of liberalisation on developing economies disappear into the ether. But they are uncomfortable with the increasingly violent trend in the protest movement.

Supporters of direct action are also in a quandary. To keep the media interested they need to up the ante each time. But having started off with a bang by helping to derail Seattle, the law of diminishing media returns applies. Seattle collapsed mostly because of the fights inside the conference room, although the battles on streets did not help improve the atmosphere. Protest groups have since failed to stop any of the meetings they have targeted.

And without breakdown in the negotiating room, vio lence outside has become the story. Demos get hijacked by hardliners whose interest is more in having a rumble with the local police than contributing to a debate on globalisation. This in turn has dissuaded many non- violent supporters of direct action from turning up to protest. It does not help gain wider support for their cause among the public either - many Quebec residents have decided to leave town for the weekend rather than face the chaos.

Somebody has already sprayed "Berlin" on the Quebec wall. It is not going to be around as long as the wall that used to divide the German capital, but the ideological division it represents is becoming as entrenched.

 Charlotte Denny is the Guardian's economics correspondent.

Prospects for the global economy have darkened since the leaders made the Quebec date in their diaries. This week's decision by Alan Greenspan, the world's most powerful central banker, to cut interest rates, is an indication of how worried the authorities are. Trade deals are often easier to clinch when the economic outlook becomes uncertain. Negotiators' minds become concentrated on the dangers of a breakdown in trading relationships. As Mike Moore, the head of the World Trade Organisation asked recently: "When do you fix the roof? When the sun shines or when it rains?" But history shows that the opposite can also be true. During the depression of the 1930s, countries rushed to erect tariff walls around their economies, and exacerbated the downturn with beggar-thy-neighbour devaluations. In an uncomfortable reminder of that past, Argentina, the most storm-tossed economy in the Americas, has recently slapped higher tariffs on range of imports, in defiance of its obligations under Mercosur, the four-country Latin American trade agreement. Argentina also angered its neighbour Brazil by signalling it may break ranks with the rest of Mercosur and negotiate bilateral trade agreements with the European Union and the US. This is the equivalent of Britain declaring that it wished to leave the EU and become a member of the European Free Trade Area instead. It would severely dent Mercosur's status as a customs union with a common external tariff. This weekend's gathering is supposed only to rubber stamp the declaration on the Free Trade Area of the Americas agreed by officials last week in Buenos Aires. The hard bargaining comes next, over the 300-page agreement which is the basis for negotiations between now and January 2005 when the FTAA* - Area de Libre Comercio de las Americas in Spanish - is supposed to be formally launched. Outside the conference rooms, the protesters also have problems. Having propelled trade negotiations into the public consciousness 18 months ago, by contributing to the collapse of the Seattle summit of the World Trade Organisation, the disparate groups opposed to further liberalisation in the global economy face a conundrum. Non-governmental organisations know that mass protests outside trade meetings bring headlines while thoughtful policy papers on the impact of liberalisation on developing economies disappear into the ether. But they are uncomfortable with the increasingly violent trend in the protest movement. Supporters of direct action are also in a quandary. To keep the media interested they need to up the ante each time. But having started off with a bang by helping to derail Seattle, the law of diminishing media returns applies. Seattle collapsed mostly because of the fights inside the conference room, although the battles on streets did not help improve the atmosphere. Protest groups have since failed to stop any of the meetings they have targeted. And without breakdown in the negotiating room, vio lence outside has become the story. Demos get hijacked by hardliners whose interest is more in having a rumble with the local police than contributing to a debate on globalisation. This in turn has dissuaded many non- violent supporters of direct action from turning up to protest. It does not help gain wider support for their cause among the public either - many Quebec residents have decided to leave town for the weekend rather than face the chaos. Somebody has already sprayed "Berlin" on the Quebec wall. It is not going to be around as long as the wall that used to divide the German capital, but the ideological division it represents is becoming as entrenched.  Charlotte Denny is the Guardian's economics correspondent. charlotte.denny@theguardian.com

webTitle: Legal roadshow rolls on to Brazil

fields.headline: Legal roadshow rolls on to Brazil
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The collapse of the drug companies' court case against the South African government is likely to be just the first victory in the battle for cheaper medicines in developing countries.
fields.body:
The collapse of the drug companies' court case against the South African government is likely to be just the first victory in the battle for cheaper medicines in developing countries.

Although the spotlight is on Pretoria, which has not yet shown any inclination to use the Aids drugs which it can now legally obtain at lower prices, a second legal front has already been opened in Brazil, a country hailed as a shining example of Aids treatment in the developing world.

It is richer than South Africa and has 500,000 fewer HIV-positive patients, but that does not diminish its achievement in distributing life-saving anti-retroviral drugs to the vast majority of patients who need them.

It has done so by making cheap generic copies of some drugs and buying others from generic manufacturers in India. Since 1996, when it began to provide free anti-retroviral drugs, it has halved the Aids death rate and reduced the number confined to hospital by 80%.

But now Brazil is coming under serious attack.

Washington, at the behest of the pharmaceuticals companies, is taking it to a disciplinary tribunal of the World Trade Organisation.

It alleges that Brazil is in breach of the Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (Trips) agreement, which enshrines patent protection for 20 years.

If Brazil loses the case it will be forced to change its laws or face trade sanctions.

Brazil has made or imported 10 types of drugs quite legally, because they were patented before Brazil's Trips-compliant law came into force in 1997. Its battle is for drug patented since then.

The action lodged by the US at the WTO in January takes issue with Article 68 of Brazil's 1996 Industrial Property Act, which says it can legally make or import a generic version of a drug if the patent-holding company fails to manufacture it in Brazil - local production making it cheaper - within three years.

The clause has not yet been used. Campaigners say that the companies and their allies are picking a fight with local legislation to intimidate developing countries into buying medicines at prices set by the big companies.

Michael Bailey, a senior policy adviser to Oxfam, said: "It is part of the systematic intimidation of Brazil and developing countries to say if you step out of what we define as the line on intellectual property, we will clobber you in the courts."

Developing countries are supposed to endorse Trips by 2005, and Oxfam sees the Brazilian case as a clear signal to Argentina and India, both of which make generic drugs and are preparing their own Trips-compliant law.

Brazil recently won a battle with Merck, manufacturers of efavirenz, one of the two patented drugs on which Brazil spends a third of its Aids drugs budget.

The state pharmaceutical company imported efavirenz made in India, saying it wanted to research the possibility of making its own copy.

Merck threatened legal action, but it has now reduced the price of its brand of efavirenz, Stocrin, by more than half.

Brazil is trying the same tactics on Roche, producers of the second drug, nelfinavir.

Despite the publicity disaster in Pretoria, the US will be reluctant to withdraw its case against Brazil.

The biggest nightmare for the pharmaceutical industry is the possibility that cheap generic versions of their new drugs may end up in the US.

webTitle: Cellnet starts consumer GPRS service next month

fields.headline: Cellnet starts consumer GPRS service next month
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: BT Cellnet yesterday took a step closer to rolling out its advanced third-generation mobile services by announcing it will launch its consumer GPRS service in May.
fields.body:
BT Cellnet yesterday took a step closer to rolling out its advanced third-generation mobile services by announcing it will launch its consumer GPRS service in May.

The GPRS - general packet radio service - heralded as the next move forward from WAP, is supposed to provide permanent access to the internet and will give users cheaper and faster access to, for instance, email via mobile phones.

"This is an improved service and it takes WAP to the next stage", said Stuart Newstead, BT Cellnet's wireless data general manager.

BT Cellnet - Britain's sec ond largest mobile operator after Vodafone - launched the world's first GPRS service for businesses last June. It has 500 users at 35 companies, including Cisco and Oracle. The service for consumers will be available from May 18.

"With GPRS the mobile internet has become faster, cheaper and more accessible. We are delighted to be the first UK operator delivering always connected and always on, data services to UK consumers", Mr Newstead said.

The service will initially run on Motorola handsets, costing £199. Cellnet customers will have to pay a monthly subscription of £7.99 to download up to one megabyte of data, equivalent to 1,000 WAP pages or 400 emails. They can also opt to pay £3.99 plus 2p per kilobyte, equal to one WAP page.

GPRS is seen as a test bed for 3G mobiles, which operate at much faster speeds and will be put out for trials next year. Take-up of GPRS will be closely watched by an industry that has gambled its future on expensive 3G licences. BT Cellnet paid £4bn for its licence last April and there is speculation revenues from wireless internet devices will not be as high as first anticipated.

Mr Newstead would not comment on the expected take-up of GPRS but said the company is targeting customers who use their phones for more than 100 minutes every month.

fields.trailText: A table of reported sex cases involving Roman Catholic priests (Theraputic hideaway for wayward priests, page 8, April 18) included the name of Fr David Martin of London Oratory School, who had been posthumously, and anonymously, accused of child abuse.
fields.body:
 A table of reported sex cases involving Roman Catholic priests (Theraputic hideaway for wayward priests, page 8, April 18) included the name of Fr David Martin of London Oratory School, who had been posthumously, and anonymously, accused of child abuse. A joint police and social services inquiry reported on March 30 2001 that the allegations were unfounded. A statement released by Hammersmith and Fulham Council on behalf of the investigating team said they had, "fully investigated the original complaint, painstakingly followed every possible lead and linked up with other similar inquiries to compare notes". We apologise for any distress caused to Fr Martin's family, friends, or colleagues.

 Star of the definitive 1952 western, High Noon, was Gary Cooper, not Cary Grant (Godfather bows out of Lloyds after 49 years, page 24, April 19).

 In our piece about the National Theatre's announcement that Trevor Nunn will stand down as artistic director (Exit Nunn pursued by critics, page 3, April 18), we gave the impression that he worked with Andrew Lloyd Webber on the musical Les Miserables. Impresario Cameron Mackintosh and Nunn cooperated on this production.

 Yossi Beilin (Sharon's breach of Oslo was step too far, page 4, April 18) was described as a Labour member of Israel's Knesset. He is no longer an MK. He stood down shortly after being made minister for justice in the last parliament. At the time of the Oslo agreement he was deputy foreign minister and, although not officially part of the Israeli delegation, is seen as one of the chief architects of the deal.

webTitle: US slowdown takes toll on Ford profit

fields.headline: US slowdown takes toll on Ford profit
fields.trailText: The US economic downturn yesterday took its toll on Ford, the world's No 2 carmaker, whose profits fell 41% in the first quarter on the back of production cutbacks and a drop in sales.
fields.body:
The US economic downturn yesterday took its toll on Ford, the world's No 2 carmaker, whose profits fell 41% in the first quarter on the back of production cutbacks and a drop in sales.

Ford said earnings fell to $1.13bn (£790m), compared with $1.93bn in the first three months of last year but company executives shrugged off the decline.

Its profits decline follows an even steeper slump at General Motors, its bigger rival, which made $225m net, down from $1.82bn a year ago. Both performances came in ahead of market expectations, however.

Their problems were dwarfed by South Korea's Daewoo, whose net loss tripled last year to $10.43bn - the country's biggest corporate loss. GM is due to take over the company.

Ford Europe, including its main UK operations, Jaguar, Land Rover, Aston Martin and Volvo, returned to profit - making $88m against a loss of $3m in the first quarter of 2000.

Its British arm, which is closing its main Dagenham assembly plant early next year, is due to report its annual earnings at the end of June. Land Rover, bought last year from BMW, is scheduled to return to profitability next year.

Ford's chief financial officer, Henry Wallace, said the group's profits should rise in the current quarter even with a "softening" of the North American vehicle market.

But he admitted that Ford has made little or no progress towards its goal of cutting $1bn from its overheads this year, with the onus now on the second half to deliver.

Amid concerns that GM, meanwhile, is demanding tax breaks to take over Daewoo, the Korean group's losses were 50% higher than its own forecasts.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: 3 more years for BCCI man
fields.body:
3 more years for BCCI man

Abbas Gokal, convicted for his role in the collapse of BCCI - the world's largest banking fraud - was yesterday sentenced to a further three years in jail because of his refusal to release £3m the serious fraud office believes he has hidden away.

The decision in the City of London magistrates court yesterday means that the earliest Mr Gokal can now expect to be released is July 2004 or November 2006 if he is not granted parole.

The former head of Gulf Group which received millions of dollars from BCCI, he was sentenced to 14 years in 1997 but was backdated to the period he spent in custody after being arrested in 1994.

Sega lays out revival plan

Japanese video game maker Sega, hit by four consecutive years of losses, said yesterday it aims to get back into the black on a group operating basis during the business year that started this month.

It hopes to boost return on equity to 15% or more in the 2003-04 business year, up from an expected 2% in 2001-02. It will trim its workforce by 300, nearly 30%, by the end of this business year while cutting interest-carrying debt by 65bn yen (£370m) over the next three years.

Strike vote for steelworkers

Steelworkers are to be balloted on industrial action after Corus was accused of "industrial sabotage" by pressing ahead with thousands of job losses and turning down union proposals aimed at saving some of the 6,000 jobs being axed over the next year.

A plan to safeguard the future of the Llanwern factory in south Wales was rejected yesterday following a similar decision affecting a Corus plant on Teesside.

The main steel union, the ISTC said it would back requests for an industrial action ballot among Llanwern workers.

A mass meeting will be held at Teesside today when workers will decide their next move.

Armani sales rise 20%

Armani, the Italian fashion house whose interests range from exclusive perfumes to designer houseware, yesterday posted a 20% rise in sales for 2000.

Publishing its final results for last year, the unlisted Milanese company said it had almost completed its metamorphosis from a brand whose products were largely manufactured under licence to a group which owns and controls most of its own output.

Sales for the year came in at almost exactly two trillion lire (£641m), with operating profit running at 374bn lire and consolidated net profit rising 11% to 235bn lire.

DFS warns of modest profits

DFS, Britain's largest sofa retailer, reported an 11% rise in first-half profits yesterday but warned that growth would be more modest for the full year in less than buoyant trading conditions.

Pre-tax profits rose to £24.4m for the six months to January 27, on sales up 13.7% at £192.6m and like-for-like sales up 8.5%.

fields.headline: GKN-Brambles alliance agreed
fields.trailText: British engineering leader GKN and the Australian group Brambles have overcome the last of the snags in the way of the £6.9bn merger of their industrial services businesses.
fields.body:
British engineering leader GKN and the Australian group Brambles have overcome the last of the snags in the way of the £6.9bn merger of their industrial services businesses.

News of the negotiations broke earlier this year and yesterday the two companies were able to announce the terms of the merger which will give GKN shareholders 43% of the new company.

"After years of trying to do this, even if there was the smallest hint of a premium, even if there was the smallest hint there was a winner or a loser, we would not have had the agreement of both boards," according to Brambles chief executive John Fletcher.

The new Brambles will comprise the group's existing operations plus GKN's share of the Chep transport pallets and Cleanaway waste management joint ventures plus the Interlake conveyor belt company and the Meineke retail business in the US.

The merger will mean a series of top management changes at GKN which will now be centred on the automotive and aerospace businesses.

Its chief executive, Sir CK Chow, will move over to head the enlarged Brambles business, which will be listed in both Sydney and London but based in Australia, and he will take finance director David Turner with him.

They will be replaced by Marcus Beresford, currently managing director of GKN industrial services, and Nigel Stein, chief financial officer at the GKN Sinter metals division.

Yesterday Sir CK said that while GKN would be a smaller company as a result of the deal "on the other hand, the engineering businesses are very much cash-generating and the balance sheet of GKN will be extraordinarily strong with a lot of capacity".

Analysts said that there was little to surprise in the deal and on the stock market GKN shares were down 1.5p at 775p.

webTitle: Foot and mouth saves Eddie's bacon

fields.headline: Foot and mouth saves Eddie's bacon
fields.standfirst: High meat prices counter budget
fields.trailText: At least one person has cause to be grateful for foot and mouth. Sir Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, has higher meat prices to thank for saving him the embarrassment of writing a letter to the chancellor explaining why inflation has drastically undershot the government's target.
fields.body:
At least one person has cause to be grateful for foot and mouth. Sir Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, has higher meat prices to thank for saving him the embarrassment of writing a letter to the chancellor explaining why inflation has drastically undershot the government's target.

Underlying inflation was unchanged in March at 1.9% - marking two years now that it has been below the Bank's 2.5% target. Gordon Brown set the Bank a particular challenge by keeping excise duty on fuel on hold in his March budget. Because in previous years the fuel escalator has raised duties faster than inflation, the impact of no change this time around would have been to push inflation down by around 0.3 percentage points - taking it perilously close to the 1.5% threshold which requires Sir Eddie to sharpen his quill pen.

Instead, foot and mouth intervened, sending meat prices soaring and cancelling out the disinflationary impact of Mr Brown's budget.

Next month, however, will be a different story. Further budget measures are likely to knock a further 0.4 percentage points off the underlying rate and could require Sir Eddie to start composing his letter. He will undoubtedly tell Mr Brown what he told MPs last month - that the Bank, like other forecasters, has been wrong-footed by sterling's unexpected strength. This has kept inflation in check, at the expense of squeezing the export sector.

Influenced by the arrival of Sushil Wadhwani on to the monetary policy committee, the Bank has reformed its forecasting model to take a more realistic view about the direction of the exchange rate. This has contributed to the MPC's decision to cut rates twice since January. After its most recent meeting, the Bank left the door open for further moves. Sooner rather than later might be advisable.

If they cut in May, Sir Eddie could then point to that rate cut as evidence of what the Bank is doing to raise inflation. If they choose to delay - the following month's meeting coincides with the expected date of the general election - and a cut on that day could be interpreted as politically driven. Threadneedle Street may be officially above the political process, but discretion is the better part of being a central banker.

Merger relief

The idea of the merger of the Brambles/GKN industrial services businesses has been around for so long that there was a sense of relief when the deal was finally done. Certainly it looks a sensible solution and will allow GKN to concentrate on its engineering operations with a strong balance sheet. Nevertheless, there are questions that shareholders will want to ponder. The divestment of industrial services increases GKN's dependence on automotives at a time when the industry in the US is not having an easy time. Then there is the question of whether the group can hang on to its membership of the FTSE-100. In these days of tracker funds, size matters.

From the Bramble side the acquisition of GKN's chief executive and finance director means that it is getting people who know the business without the risk of top management turf wars which often bedevil post-merger companies.

GKN is promoting from within to fill the gaps and sensibly opting for continuity - but its new top team will be under few illusions about the need to impress.

Scare tactics

The Institute of Directors yesterday produced a piece of research suggesting the cost of the foot and mouth outbreak could have already reached £20bn (or 2% of GDP). By the end of July, it added, that figure could be £40bn.

These are sky-high numbers designed to generate scary headlines. The survey was conducted on the internet. Some 600 members replied, saying they had suffered an average loss of £50,000 so far, which could be £125,000 by the end of July.

The IoD's number crunchers, led by economist Ruth Lea, grossed up the numbers to produce findings for the whole economy and to wheel out its usual demands for compensation, tax rebates, interest free loans etc.

But this research is so badly flawed it should never have been released. The businesses which replied - mostly in hotels, catering, and transport and distribution - were concentrated in areas hit hardest by the outbreak. The losses they anticipate were their own estimates and could be wildly exaggerated. The IoD admits its numbers are "crude grossed-up estimates" and that the real cost is probably only a quarter of its suggestions.

Many businesses other than farming are being badly hit by the outbreak, but the IoD's tactic of generating scary numbers from what they admit is a self-selecting sample to back their financial demands is at best misleading, at worst dishonest and ultimately self-defeating.

fields.headline: Pub rebels are given brush-off
fields.trailText: Whitbread's rebel landlords have suffered a shattering blow in the fight to buy their pubs, with new owner Morgan Grenfell dismissing the demands as "inconceivable".
fields.body:
Whitbread's rebel landlords have suffered a shattering blow in the fight to buy their pubs, with new owner Morgan Grenfell dismissing the demands as "inconceivable".

The private equity firm scornfully rejected the splinter group's campaign on the eve of Whitbread's extraordinary general meeting at which angry publicans will call for the dismissal of chief executive David Thomas.

Morgan Grenfell is paying £1.625bn for Whitbread's pubs, which include the Hogshead and Dme chains. The German-owned finance corporation has lined up Ian Payne, a former Ladbroke casinos boss, to run the 3,000-strong estate.

In an interview published yesterday in the pub industry's Morning Advertiser, Mr Payne said: "It's inconceivable that we're going to set about selling off pubs to individuals."

He insisted Morgan Grenfell had no plans to offload any of the 1,700 tenanted pubs in the estate: "We've got no plans to sell anything from Whitbread pub partnerships - on the contrary, our plans are to strengthen WPP."

Several hundred landlords claim Whitbread has a moral and legal obligation to allow them to buy their pubs. They are worried that the new owner could change the terms on which they buy their beer, and take a hostile attitude when their leases are due for renewal.

Mr Payne said: "I hope we can work together to resolve this and make their pubs more successful. I'm looking forward to meeting some of these guys."

Cumbrian landlord Gary McClure, who organised the right-to-buy campaign, has queried Morgan Grenfell's competence to run pubs. He has pledged to stop selling the German beer Beck's in protest at the estate's new ownership.

Mr McClure, who runs The Old King's Head in Broughton-in-Furness, travelled to London to confront Whitbread today."I shall be asking whether they shouldn't be keeping the inns and pubs and getting rid of the board and the mismanagement."

Whitbread's chairman, Sir John Banham, has pledged to use his "best endeavour" to pass on the concerns of the rebel landlords to Morgan Grenfell. However, this is likely to amount to little more than giving Morgan Grenfell a list of the pubs involved.

Mr McClure is taking his campaign to the European court, which will decide next week whether the terms of Whitbread's lease agreements are illegal.

He said that a benefactor had provided him with a nine-seat limousine in which to travel to Luxembourg for the hearing.

The rebel landlords have been backed by former Whitbread chairman Sir Charles Tidbury, who has called on the company to respect "the principles of fair play".

webTitle: Hi-tech Asia suffers from US fallout

fields.headline: Hi-tech Asia suffers from US fallout
fields.trailText: Asian economies dependent on hi-tech exports will suffer the worst effects of the economic slowdown prompted by a weak US economy, according to a report out yesterday.
fields.body:
Asian economies dependent on hi-tech exports will suffer the worst effects of the economic slowdown prompted by a weak US economy, according to a report out yesterday.

After rebounding from a financial crisis four years ago, growth in most Asian economies will slow to 5.3% this year from 7.1% last year, largely because of weakness in the US economy, the Asian Development Bank said.

The sharpest slowdown will be felt most by Asia's industrialised economies and south-east Asian countries heavily dependent on technology exports and the US market, the Manila-based bank said in its annual report, Asian Development Outlook 2001.

It said the very strong performance of the global economy as a whole in 2000 masked a significant downshift in the second half as the US reached a cyclical peak and slowed down.

The report saw growth declining from 4.8% last year to 3.5% in 2001, then recovering to 4% next year.

The 5.3% figure did not include Japan, Australia and New Zealand. It said the rest of the region, "developing Asia", would see one of its "sharpest slowdowns, but would rebound to grow by 6.1% next year.

The forecast for Japan is continued growth of 1-2% next year, after some weakness early this year. The growth would be sustained by restructuring and by fiscal and monetary support. Unemployment should remain steady as restructuring continued, the report said.

Growth in the industrialised Asian economies - Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan - was forecast to drop from 8.4% last year to 4.3% this year before rising to 5.6% next year. China's economic expansion was seen as slowing from last year's 8% to 7.3% this year and 7.5% next year.

The economies of countries most affected by the region's 1997-98 financial crisis - Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines and Thailand - saw 6.8% growth last year, forecast to decline to 3.9% for this year before recovering to 5.1%.

India's economy, largely immune from the financial crisis, is expected to grow 6.2% this year and 7% in 2002.

fields.headline: Accenture braves flotation waters
fields.trailText: Accenture, the management consultancy firm formerly known as Andersen Consulting, is to press ahead with a flotation of its shares despite the rocky stock market conditions.
fields.body:
Accenture, the management consultancy firm formerly known as Andersen Consulting, is to press ahead with a flotation of its shares despite the rocky stock market conditions.

The decision will release millions of pounds for the 2,500 partners of the firm, including chief executive Joe Forehand and Ian Watmore, the managing partner in Britain, following last year's acrimonious split from Arthur Andersen.

However, under the terms of the planned share sale announced in the United States yesterday, the partners will be locked into the firm for at least eight years and they will not be able to sell more than 10% of the shares within the first year of the flotation.

The timing of the shares sale in the United States is not clear but the partners reached an agreement at a meeting held late on Wednesday in Dallas, Texas, to press ahead with the flotation.

Like other partnerships to list shares on the stock market, such as the investment bank Goldman Sachs, Accenture will have to endure closer public scrutiny of its finances.

Accenture is expected to sell shares worth around 10% of the overall value of the group, according to the documentation filed with US regulator the securities and exchange commission yesterday.

The filing shows that Accenture expects to raise up to $1bn (£700m) in an initial public offering which was expected to take place in June, before the emergence of widespread speculation recently that the partners had decided to abandon their plans.

In deciding to change from their partnership status, the Accenture partners are following a route taken by the consultancy arms of other firms such as KPMG.

There had been speculation that Accenture might delay its float not only because of the stock market conditions but also because of the more difficult economic backdrop. However, Accenture said yesterday that, while it expected to made a loss in the coming three months, its revenues were growing.

fields.headline: At this price?  Bioglan Pharma
fields.trailText: A steady supply of spotty American teenagers beat a path to the doors of Bioglan Pharma last year, helping the dermatology company ooze healthy profits.
fields.body:
A steady supply of spotty American teenagers beat a path to the doors of Bioglan Pharma last year, helping the dermatology company ooze healthy profits.

The Hertfordshire-based firm notched up a 111% jump in annual earnings to £31.5m yesterday, driven by expansion in the US.

Its biggest products include treatments for psoriasis, eczema and acne. In skin care, Bioglan has found an area which tends to be ignored by bigger drugs multinationals in favour of life-threatening conditions such as heart disease and cancer.

However, the company attracted criticism for some unusual financial engineering. For the second year running, the firm concluded a spate of licensing deals shortly before the end of its financial year in January, some of which involved the receipt of hefty lump sums. Cynics wonder whether this is a last-minute ruse intended to meet analysts' profit forecasts.

In particular, the relationship with biotech firm SkyePharma is unusual. Bioglan agreed to buy the rights from SkyePharma for Soleraze, a new drug for pre-cancerous skin conditions. Then a few days later, SkyePharma paid Bioglan $9m (£6m) for a collection of drug delivery technologies. Some analysts are intrigued by this relationship, pointing out that SkyePharma is under similar pressure to meet targets, having promised to break into profits this year.

The company's turnover of £100.6m included income of £20.3m from out-licensing products, compared with just £7.4m last year.

Bioglan's core business is doing well - eczema sales jumped 78%, with steroids up 66% and psoriasis medicines up 52%.

Bioglan's shares, up 4p to 555p, have slipped more than 25% since August.

Despite the impressive growth record, investors should be wary because of the lack of visibility in Bioglan's licensing deals.
