webTitle: Faith in Fed turns to suspicion

fields.headline: Faith in Fed turns to suspicion
fields.trailText: The FTSE 100, propelled upwards by Wednesday's unexpected US interest rate cut, dropped yesterday, down 18.6 points to 5,871.6, as disappointing news from CMG, the IT consultancy company, scared investors who had tiptoed back into the sector the day before.
fields.body:
The FTSE 100, propelled upwards by Wednesday's unexpected US interest rate cut, dropped yesterday, down 18.6 points to 5,871.6, as disappointing news from CMG, the IT consultancy company, scared investors who had tiptoed back into the sector the day before.

Economic outlook worries - of "the Fed knows things are much worse than expected" variety - also eroded optimism. The market had reached a six-week high earlier in the day, but it regressed and drifted near its lows.

Technology stocks, which proved popular in late trading on Wednesday afternoon, were still favoured, helped by positive news from across the Atlantic. IBM posted a 15% rise in first quarter net income, and Apple had announced an unexpected return to profitability the night before.

The Techmark closed up 8.52 points at 1992.75, but a gloomy report from CMG threw a damper on the tech revival.

CMG tumbled 83p to 360p after warning of losses in its telecom products division. The news also weighed on Logica, which dropped 55p to 895p. Bookham Technology, a high riser in the middle of the tech boom, fell 34.5p to 318p.

ARM Holdings rose 17p to 395p and Sage Group headed higher, up 13p to 291p. Autonomy, once a FTSE 100 stock market darling, jumped 45p to 371p.

Vodafone also provided some support, up 5p to 229p.

Shares in Redstone Telecom surged 6p to 70p after the firm announced it was set to cut 85 jobs.

The company, which scaled back expansion plans earlier in the year, said it would lay off 12% of its workforce, across the board, to cut costs.

Media stocks, however, were not popular. Granada fell 4.25p to 177p and Pearson dropped 29p to 1415p. But Profile Media Group, the publishing and database company bucked the trend, edging up 2p to 36.5p, after announcing it had bought marketing group Marketlink Marketing Communications (MMC) for £13.55m.

Defensive stocks, such as pharmaceuticals, had a tough day as investors retreated from the regularly haunted safe havens and looked with more interest at some of the battered tech stocks.

GlaxoSmithKline fell 68p to 1740p and AstraZeneca dropped 155p to 3240p. The world's fourth largest drugs firm was also hit by a note is sued by Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein which repeated a "reduce" rating. The analysts forecast a modest 3% rise in pretax profit - to $1.05bn - ahead of the group's results next week.

Biocompatibles International, the medical devices firm, bucked the negative trend, however, and saw its shares rise 37p to 286p. The company's shares were buoyed by strong first quarter results from US partner Abbott Laboratories, which yesterday reported an increase in sales and earnings for the first quarter to the end of March.

Garton Engineering had a bad day. The group watched its shares drop 14.5p to 52p after posting a post exceptional, pre tax loss of £1.2m for the year to the end of December. The figures were slightly worse than the previous year.

Old school stocks, such as Imperial Tobacco, down 46p to 665p, and Cadbury Schweppes, which fell 15p to 425p, were also hit.

Retailer Daniels, a maker and distributor of chilled fresh products, saw its shares rise in early trading before closing down 1.5p at 19p. The firm announced that its profits were in line with expectations and turnover was a little ahead of last year. The company said foot and mouth has boosted the popularity of its New Covent Garden Soup but the crisis has cut demand for all its products in the catering and food service sectors.

Shares in Manchester United dropped 3p to 175p after England's premier team lost to Germany's Bayern Munich in the European Champions League quarter final.

Economic outlook worries - of "the Fed knows things are much worse than expected" variety - also eroded optimism. The market had reached a six-week high earlier in the day, but it regressed and drifted near its lows. IBM posted a 15% rise in first quarter net income, and Apple had announced an unexpected return to profitability the night before. Granada fell 4.25p to 177p and Pearson dropped 29p to 1415p. fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Our eye is drawn to an earnest research paper from PR firm Ludgate Communications, dated 1999, titled Tackling Social Exclusion in Financial Services.
fields.body:
 Our eye is drawn to an earnest research paper from PR firm Ludgate Communications, dated 1999, titled Tackling Social Exclusion in Financial Services. "Being denied access to even a modest agreed overdraft," its author, Jason Evans, contends, "prevents thousands of people from building a credit record, making future borrowing, and, therefore, makes household financial management difficult." Quite so. "With over 1,000 bank branches either closed (or due to do so) over the last six years," he goes on, "the concern is that more and more people will be left to the prey of loan sharks and deprived of mainstream financial services." Marvellously put. When we call to congratulate Mr Evans - now government affairs officer at Halifax - he suffers an inexplicable fit of rage. "That was written while I was at Ludgate," he barks. "And what I did at Ludgate has no connection at all with what I am doing at Halifax now." Halifax is almost alone in its refusal to sign up to the government's "universal banking" proposals, designed to provide accounts for the financially excluded. Overlooking this outburst, we appoint Mr Evans the City Diary's ethical consultant for next week. Readers worried about ethical dimensions to their investment decisions are invited to email them to us and we will put them to "Ethical" Evans.

 A letter arrives from Broomford Estate in Devon, home of light entertainment superstar turned entrepreneur, Noel Edmonds. "Thank you very much for the plug for Video Meeting Company in the City Diary," it begins, referring to an item in this column some weeks past by my colleague Richard Adams. Don't mention it, Noel, it was only a pleasure. "UK video communications market is an interesting story, and still a well kept secret," he goes on, before asking: "Is now the appropriate time for the Guardian to revisit this subject?" It could be, Noel. It could just be ... "I would be happy to contribute to an article about the UK's dominant position in the world of business communications ... I'd be happy to talk at length about my belief that the only way to relieve the UK's beleaguered transportation system is for business to be encouraged to embrace 'meeting without moving'..." OK, Noel, that's enough. "Or I would be simply delighted to unashamedly promote VMC..." Enough, please! We will call you in due course to discuss the matter.

 Apologies to those awaiting an extract from Harvard Business Review, the "indispensable resource for business achievers" only available to "an elite corps of top managers" (and shoppers in most high street newsagents). Due to lack of space the promised extract on the subject of corporate egos will appear next week.

 We are delighted to note Safeway taking a lead in the campaign to prepare for the euro. Since last summer, reports The Grocer magazine, the supermarket chain has rejected all IT developments that fail to meet its strict standards of euro compliancy. "We've mapped out what needs to be done, and when, depending on a number of scenarios," says Safeway's computer expert, Jeremy Wyman. Safeway chairman David Webster. Mr Webster, you will recall, is better known as one of an elite corps of rabid Europhobes and a signatory to the "No euro" advertisement campaign which last September claimed the European currency would spell "higher taxes, unemployment costs and ... a return to boom and bust."

 Our first call to Noel's Devonshire pile. No sooner have we introduced ourselves to Nicky, Noel's personal assistant, than she says. "Sorry, "I have to go. He's just buzzed me - I have to go in." With that, she is gone. We hope our promotional efforts on Mr Edmonds's behalf are better received next week.

fields.headline: FI enjoys Synergy
fields.trailText: FI Group, the IT services group run by Hilary Cropper, was one of the few companies to enjoy a rise in its shares yesterday after cementing an acquisition. The company's shares rose 2.5p to 357.5p as investors supported the firm's decision to buy out the stake in American firm Synergy that it did not already own.
fields.body:
FI Group, the IT services group run by Hilary Cropper, was one of the few companies to enjoy a rise in its shares yesterday after cementing an acquisition. The company's shares rose 2.5p to 357.5p as investors supported the firm's decision to buy out the stake in American firm Synergy that it did not already own.

FI could pay up to $40m (£30m) for 80% of Synergy which specialises in the aerospace, defence, engineering and construction sectors, with its own shares. FI inherited the other 20% of the group through the acquisition last year of Druid.

As a result, FI is bestowing riches on the founders of the Nevada-based Synergy, although they have pledged to sell no more than half their stakes for the next two years. They will then hold on to a quarter of their positions until mid 2004.

The total price being paid by FI is dependent on performance targets.

fields.headline: Japanese minister in racial blunder
fields.trailText: It is not often that the subject of race enters the debate in leadership elections in Japan, a country which claims a 99% level of "ethnic purity".
fields.body:
It is not often that the subject of race enters the debate in leadership elections in Japan, a country which claims a 99% level of "ethnic purity".

But the issue surfaced in bizarre manner yesterday, when a prime ministerial candidate said Japan should aspire to become a country that attracts "rich Jews".

"This might be arbitrary and biased, but I think the best country is one in which rich Jews feel like living," said Taro Aso, minister for economic and fiscal policy, one of four challengers for the leadership of the Liberal Democratic party and therefore the succession as prime minister when Yoshiro Mori steps down next week.

The comment is in one sense progressive: until now, LDP politicians would not have dreamed of suggesting that Japan should be for anyone but the Japanese.

But his singling out of the wealthy members of one particular group does nothing to change the impression that many Japanese leaders are guilty of racial stereotyping and averse to accepting needy immigrants.

Japan has accepted fewer than 10 economic refugees in the past decade.

Mr Aso, a rising LDP star related to the imperial family, said the presence of rich Jews was a benchmark of success, because they were attracted to countries that were free of racial discrimination and had good law and order, low taxes and a strong national defence.

fields.headline: Indonesia warned of impeachment revolt
fields.trailText: President Abdurrahman Wahid warned Indonesian MPs yesterday that he had 400,000 supporters ready to descend on the capital, Jakarta, if they went ahead with their attempt to impeach him.
fields.body:
President Abdurrahman Wahid warned Indonesian MPs yesterday that he had 400,000 supporters ready to descend on the capital, Jakarta, if they went ahead with their attempt to impeach him.

He told a conference of business people, analysts and diplomats: "You can see that it is a nationwide rebellion against the ways of the parliament, which is doing its worst now.

"My supporters ... are going to Jakarta. Yesterday the registration came to 400,000, from all over Java and from Lampung, Sumatra.

"This does not take into account the people from Jakarta."

The parliament, in which only 11% of MPs supportthe president, is expected to give him a second and final warning to mend his ways when it meets in 10 days time.

If the majority of MPs remain dissatisfied with his response to their demand for more effective government, they are entitled to begin impeachment proceedings after 30 days.

Mr Wahid, who became Indonesia's first democratically elected president in October 1999, accuses parliament of acting unconstitutionally and illegally by trying to remove him, because it did not bring the required treason charges.

"According to the constitution, the president has the right to govern to the end of his term [in such circumstances]," he said.

His five-year term ends in 2004.

While there is no evidence to corroborate Mr Wahid's claim that an army of supporters is about to descend on the capital, tens of thousands of people have joined a new movement called the Defenders of Truth Front (FPK), whose only criterion for membership is a willingness to martyr oneself to defend Mr Wahid as president.

"We exceeded all the membership targets we have set," the FPK's founder, Wiro Sugiman, said.

"This is a clear sign that the majority of people do not support the campaign to get rid of [Wahid]."

Mr Sugiman says the FPK is not about defending the president, rather it was formed to protect the constitution.

"We are ready to defend the truth, the rightful president, the constitution, to guard the nation and the state, if necessary until blood is spilled."

But it is no coincidence that the movement was set up a month ago in the heartland of Mr Wahid's support, East Java, just as his position was beginning to get precarious.

He is regarded there as an almost mythical sacred man who can do no wrong, owing to his position as a former leader of Nahdlatul Ulama, the world's biggest Muslim organisation, which has its base in the region.

In recent weeks the FPK has been giving some of its members paramilitary training and guidance on strengthening their spirit.

"If the spirit is strong enough, then the body can do anything," Mr Sugiman said.

Observers are divided about the seriousness of the threat posed by groups such as the FPK.

One diplomat at the conference described Mr Wahid as being "disingenuous in believing that he can get away with using force to save himself".

Another in the audience disagreed. "Wahid is such a master tactician, and the opposition are so confused about how to deliver the killer blow, he could well survive."

webTitle: £3bn bridge to link Sicily to toe of Italy

fields.headline: £3bn bridge to link Sicily to toe of Italy
fields.standfirst: An election promise to realise a centuries-old dream is met by delight, cynicism and scepticism
fields.trailText: The Italian government has cut through 2,000 years of yearning and dithering with an election promise to link Sicily to the mainland.
fields.body:
The Italian government has cut through 2,000 years of yearning and dithering with an election promise to link Sicily to the mainland.

A road and rail suspension bridge will be built across the Strait of Messina if the private sector agrees to pay half the £3bn cost, it said.

Work could begin within months on a project which has beguiled nationalists, mobsters and ancient Roman engineers.

Decreed a national priority 30 years ago, the project has been given the go-ahead by ministers desperate to woo the voters before next month's general election.

The design is for a bridge carrying 12 lanes of traffic on a 3,690-metre span connecting the toe of Italy to the north-east tip of Sicily's Up to 140,000 cars and 200 trains could be carried daily.

Opposition politicians mocked the promise as yet another false dawn in a saga which has inspired a Sicilian expression for procrastination: "When they build the bridge."

But Nino Calarco, who has chaired a public sector company charged with supervising the project since the early 1970s, and has been likened to the characters in Beckett's Waiting for Godot, sensed that his wait was at an end.

"The bridge will become a reality," he said.

Agazio Loiero, the minister for regional affairs, was confident that matching private capital would be found.

"We'll know soon if the bridge will be able to be realised. The state is willing to cover 50% of the cost as long as there are private investors who commit themselves to an identical cost," he said.

The centre-left government needs to galvanise support in the south to avoid defeat in the general election on May 13.

Despite cynicism, Sicilians and Calabrians are enthusiastic about the jobs and wealth which could be generated by linking two of Italy's poorest regions. Successive governments, fearing a financial and engineering fiasco, delayed a decision by commissioning one feasibility study after another.

Greens and some economists said that the 11-year construction project would damage the environment and divert resources from plugging gaps in the motorway and railway network.

Greens in the government derided the announcement as a pseudo-decision typical of Pontius Pilate. The centre-right dismissed it as empty propaganda intended to steal thunder from its own promise of massive infrastructure investment.

Whether a government formed by the present opposition would go ahead with the bridge was unclear.

Ancient Romans dreamed of bridging the strait, which was known in Greek mythology as Scylla and Charybdis, after the six-headed monster and whirlpool reputed to lie in wait for sailors on the opposite sides.

Giuseppe Garibaldi's nation alists considered building a bridge in 1860 to consolidate their unification of Italy.

In yesterday's La Repubblica, Andrea Camilleri, one of Sicily's best-known novelists, attacked those who sought to preserve the "sacredness" of the water between the island and Italy. "Finally we will succeed in eliminating this ... sense of isolation and loneliness," he said.

One source of government hesitation has been the fear that the mafia will infiltrate the process of letting construction contracts.

The bridge would unite Sicily's Cosa Nostra with Calabria's 'Ndrangheta', the Scylla and Charybdis of organised crime networks, specialists in skimming the profit off public work contracts.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Unripe fruit kills 50 in north Haiti | Fresh border clash in Assam |  Professor dies on drug flight   | Beijing in talks on US spy plane | Cancer link to war babies |
fields.body:
Unripe fruit kills 50 in north Haiti

Fifty people, mostly children, have died in northern Haiti in the past two months after eating the fruit ackee.

Widespread flooding which ruined crops and killed livestock near Haiti's second city, Cap-Haitien, prompted many to eat the popular pear-shaped yellow fruit while still unripe, a known hazard. Reuters, Port-au-Prince

Fresh border clash in Assam

Fighting erupted again on the Bangladeshi-Indian border yesterday soon after both sides voiced regret for 18 troops killed in Wednesday's clashes.

Officials in the north-eastern Indian state of Assam said the fighting was in Dhubri, 180 miles west of the capital, Guwahati. Sixteen Indian troops and two Bangladeshis are reported to have died on Wednesday in the worst fighting for 30 years. AFP, Guwahati

Professor dies on drug flight

A law professor who died in Canada after being taken ill on a transatlantic flight later had 12 cocaine-filled balloons removed from his stomach, police said.

Prof Gennady Danilenko, 45, was flying from Amsterdam to Detroit, where he taught at Wayne State University, when the plane diverted to Newfoundland to treat him for a suspected heart attack. AP, Detroit

Beijing in talks on US spy plane

China has agreed to discuss with American diplomats the future of the EP-3E spy plane being held on Hainan island. US diplomats had threatened to end talks if Beijing did not put it on the agenda. AP, Washington

Cancer link to war babies

The children of veterans exposed to herbicides such as Agent Orange during the Vietnam war may have a greater chance of suffering from a certain type of leukaemia, a study by the Institute of Medicine in the US suggests. The analysis stops short of saying that the link is conclusive. AP, Washington

fields.headline: Report points to EgyptAir co-pilot
fields.trailText: US-Egyptian relations cooled again yesterday after American investigators concluded that mechanical problems were not responsible for the crash of EgyptAir flight 990 two years ago.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington and  Khaled Dawoud  in Cairo
fields.body:
US-Egyptian relations cooled again yesterday after American investigators concluded that mechanical problems were not responsible for the crash of EgyptAir flight 990 two years ago.

The official draft finding of the national transportation safety board (NTSB) once again pointed the finger of responsibility at one of the co-pilots, Gameel el-Batouti.

There was outrage in Egypt when it was suggested shortly after the crash in October 1999 that Batouti had put the plane into a dive to kill himself.

All 217 people on board the Boeing-767 were killed when the plane, which was flying from New York to Cairo, plunged from 10,000 metres into the Atlantic.

The report was due to be presented to the Egyptian authorities yesterday. It is understood not to use the word "suicide", partly because there is no clue to why the pilot might have forced the plane into a fatal dive, and partly because earlier suggestions that Batouti was responsible caused such indignation in Egypt, a key American ally.

EgyptAir 990 had not reported any technical problems before its autopilot suddenly shut off, its throttles cut back and its elevators initiated a steep descent. The plane recovered, rose, and then fell again into the ocean.

A year ago the NTSB released transcripts from the flight's black box recorder in which Batouti is heard repeatedly saying: "I rely on God."

The voice of the captain then says: "What's happening, Gameel, what's happening?"

EgyptAir has 60 days to prepare a response to the draft report before a final set of conclusions are issued.

A statement issued earlier this week by the airline called on the Americans to make fresh tests of the 767's flight control system.

It urged US aviation and safety authorities to "consider the possibility that there might be an inherent flaw in the design and/or maintenance procedures of the Boeing 767 flight control system".

Central to the Egyptian's case is the experience of an American Airlines 767-300 which experienced problems with its flight controls while landing at Paris on March 27.

The plane lost altitude and experienced "pitch control difficulties" which were not caused by the pilots as it tried to land.

EgyptAir cited two previous incidents, in Bahrain and Mexico, in which rivets in the flight control system was found to have been damaged.

webTitle: French ask US for Caroline suspect

fields.headline: French ask US for Caroline suspect
fields.trailText: French authorities yesterday began formal extradition proceedings against Francisco Arce Montez, the Spaniard held in a US jail who is suspected of raping and murdering the British schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson in a Brittany youth hostel five years ago.
fields.body:
French authorities yesterday began formal extradition proceedings against Francisco Arce Montez, the Spaniard held in a US jail who is suspected of raping and murdering the British schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson in a Brittany youth hostel five years ago.

A spokesman for Rennes appeal court in northern France said an international arrest warrant, pending a request for extradition from the French justice ministry, had been sent to the American authorities yesterday.

He added that the paperwork included an English translation of the Paris police laboratory report that found 18 matches between the suspect's DNA and traces found on 13-year-old Caroline's body after she was raped and suffocated in Pleine-Fougères hostel in July 1996.

Since his arrest in Miami, French police have learned that that Arce Montez, an itinerant restaurant and bar worker, had been convicted or was suspected of a variety of sex offences in Germany, France and Spain over a 20-year period starting in 1980. He may also be linked to unsolved offences in Britain, where he lived from 1994 to 1996, and the Netherlands.

The bungled French investigation eventually led to DNA tests being performed on some 3,600 men, and a former girlfriend of the suspect has confirmed to police that he was staying with her at her home some 30 miles from Pleine-Fougères at the time of Caroline's murder.

When Arce Montez, 51, might appear in a French courtroom will depend on whether the US authorities opt for an accelerated extradition procedure.

He is due to be tried in Miami on July 2 after his arrest on March 3 for breaking into the room of a young woman while she was asleep and cutting her underwear with scissors. Before extradition, under the standard procedure Arce Montez would first have to stand trial on charges of breaking and entering and lewd behaviour.

If France asks for an accelerated procedure, however, Florida authorities may decide the Miami case should be dropped and the suspect put on a plane to Paris.

Brian McDonald, Arce Montez's American lawyer, has said he is "convinced that the US authorities will at the very least consider" such a request, and that his client - deemed a high suicide risk - could exchange his bed in the psychiatric wing of Dade County jail for a French prison cell before the summer.

webTitle: No court martial for US sub captain

fields.headline: No court martial for sub captain
fields.trailText: The captain of the US submarine Greeneville, which sank a Japanese trawler off Hawaii on February 9 with the loss of nine lives, will leave the navy with an honourable discharge, according to navy sources.
fields.body:
The captain of the US submarine Greeneville, which sank a Japanese trawler off Hawaii on February 9 with the loss of nine lives, will leave the navy with an honourable discharge, according to navy sources.

A navy investigation has found that Commander Scott Waddle showed "unprofessional conduct" in his acts leading up to the collision but he will not face a court martial and criminal charges, according to reports.

The decision, due to be announced shortly, is likely to dismay Japan. There has been anger there that the collision occurred in the course of a public relations exercise, when the control room was crowded with civilians. Some crew members have since complained that they were unable to do their jobs properly because of the presence of visitors.

Admiral Thomas Fargo, the head of the inquiry into the collision, has concluded that Cmdr Waddle and his sonar analyst, Petty Officer Patrick Seacrest, showed "unprofessional conduct" on the day of the accident. Cmdr Waddle was deemed to have made only a cursory periscope check before the rapid ascent.

The inquiry has found that Waddle bears the ultimate responsibility for the accident, partly because of the "command climate" on the submarine which made his crew unwilling to tell him when they thought something was wrong.

However, Cmdr Waddle will be allowed to leave the service with an honourable discharge and will not face a court martial, according to navy sources quoted in the Los Angeles Times.

Cmdr Waddle had already indicated through his lawyer that he accepted that his career was over and was willing to leave the service voluntarily if he was not charged with criminal offences and was allowed to keep his pension.

Nine crew members and schoolchildren on board the Japanese vessel Ehime Maru died when the submarine executed an emergency surfacing procedure for the benefit of a group of 16 visiting civilians, including businessmen and supporters of navy charities.

Adm Fargo's investigation, which took evidence from both Greeneville and Ehime Maru crews in Pearl Harbour, has concluded that the 16 civilians were not responsible for the collision.

However, the inquiry will make recommendations about future "distinguished visitors" programmes, which have become common as the navy fights potential cuts. Civilians will not be allowed to operate controls as they did on the Greeneville, nor will trips take place purely as public relations exercises.

The decision not to hold a court martial was made because it was felt that no new facts would emerge and that Cmdr Waddle might not be convicted, which would further damage relations with Japan. Two other officers are to receive reprimands.

Cmdr Waddle and Adm Fargo, both of whom grew up in service families in Japan, are due to visit the country to apologise to the families of those who died.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: I love my husband but fantasise about a female friend. What should I do?
fields.trailText: I love my husband but fantasise about a female friend. What should I do?.
fields.body:
"I am a woman in my mid-40s with three teenage children. I am happily married to a man I love and who cares about the children. We have a satisfactory sex life. I have, however, fallen in love with a close female friend and have started to have sexual fantasies about her. She would, I'm sure, be horrified about this, as would my husband. I cannot bear the thought of cheating on my husband. However, having felt emotionally flat for a long time due to bringing up a family and working, I now feel better and am a much more sexual person. I have always thought of myself as heterosexual so am bewildered at my feelings. Where should I proceed, if anywhere?"

Tell him how you feel

Firstly, explain how you feel to your husband. The feelings you have are one of the most popular male fantasies and even if the discussion leads no further, you will probably have some amazing sex afterwards.

Make it clear to him that you have no intention of ever cheating on him (and be wary about saying you love your female friend). If it is true, explain that it is his influence that has allowed you to open up sexually (he will be flattered). If you discuss it with him openly and get him to express his own fantasies, then you should be able to get a measure of how he feels about the issue.

An important caveat is that fantasies are always much more fun in your imagination because they are perfect encounters but in reality they will be imperfect. If this does go any further then you will find that it will not be as much fun as it was discussing it with your husband.

Finally, bear in mind that most other men reading your letter will be wishing that their wives were having the same feelings.
Ed Singleton, London

Don't risk your marriage

I am exasperated with your self-indulgence. Fantasise away to your heart's content - indeed, why not introduce your fantasies into your "satisfactory sex life", but keep your fantasies as just that. What do you hope to achieve by taking them further? You claim to love your husband - have you no sense of loyalty or commitment? Marriages don't just happen - both partners have to work hard - and there are always plenty of temptations which have to be kept in check in order for the relationship to stand a chance.

Considering this attraction further is not a constructive way to deal with your flat emotions. You say that you have a happy marriage; surely it's better that you invest energy into revitalising what you have and spice up your sex life rather than pursuing a course which will inevitably lead to the breakdown of your marriage and cause much unhappiness within your family.
Beryl Docherty, London

Consider the effects

Having recently had an affair with a female friend who has both children and a husband, there are some points I would urge you to consider. Firstly, how sure are you of your feelings? Do you have someone you could talk to? Do you have any inkling about your friend's feelings? If you are sure that she would be uninterested, then do not say or do a thing - your friendship may never be the same.

If, on the other hand, you think she may be receptive, an affair with her could be one of the most thrilling events of your life. The problem is, however, that affairs are never problem free. Could you and your friend live with the guilt and the deception? How would your husband/children react if they found out? Having a heterosexual affair is shocking enough, but a homosexual one brings with it a lot more prejudice, and pressure. What would happen if one of you later discovered that it had all been a horrible mistake?

I would try to ascertain the true nature of your feelings for this friend. Is this a passing thing? Or could you be looking at a lifestyle change? Above all proceed cautiously, and see if there is someone you could confide in who will not judge you.
Name and address withheld

Feelings are hard to deny

You are far from alone in your dilemma. I too thought I was happily married but chose to explore a relationship with a female friend. The result was eventually a complete transformation of my life. Lesbian feelings, once aroused, were impossible to suppress. After several years of struggling to resolve the situation with my husband we eventually separated. I am now happily established in a lesbian relationship, and sharing parentage of my children with my ex-husband.

However, it was a terrible shock for him and a very difficult process to go through. You need to be aware of the potentially huge implications of following your feelings.
Name and address withheld

Next week

I bought my own flat nine years ago and live alone with two cats. At 46 I'm getting used to the idea that I will probably never meet a man who wants to settle down. The relationships I've had in the past have always been stormy, with no likelihood of becoming long term. I have a few good friends, plenty of interests, a responsible job and wonderful nephews and nieces, so I don't feel my life is empty without a partner. What really makes me unhappy is living on my own.

The idea of spending my retirement years living alone fills me with dread. Should I have another try at meeting "Mr Right", or is there another way of sharing my life and my home?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020-7239 9935, or email private.lives@theguardian.com.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on the twelfth man

fields.headline: No 1,863
fields.standfirst: The twelfth man
fields.trailText: The twelfth man.
fields.body:
Who he? The imposter who found his way in to the Manchester United team line-up for the pre-match photo in Munich.

What, you mean Gary Neville? That's right, kick a team when they're down.

Gee, thanks. Is it true the interloper is rumoured to be a fanatical United fan who never misses a match, and police are now making house-to-house enquiries? In Bournemouth. That old chestnut. No, as a matter of fact the first thought was that he was a German.

Why? The efficiency with which he carried out his subterfuge. The split-second timing. Also, he reserved his place in the photo by leaving his towel there.

And look, he's standing there right next to Andy Cole. Surely, Cole couldn't have missed him? Why not, he missed everything else?

I detect a touch of bitterness. How do we know this guy isn't a genuine United fan anyway? No prawn sandwich.

So is he just some hopeless inadequate man who gets his kicks being photographed near famous people? What, you mean like William Hague? Interesting, by the way, that United seem to be pursuing a similar policy to his on withdrawal from Europe. No, actually he is called Carl Power, also known as "fat neck". And he really is from Manchester - friend of Manchester main man Shaun Ryder, in fact.

So why did he do it? For a magazine called Front. The idea was that he get as far as he could without a ticket. So he didn't do too badly.

Watch out for Carl Power on: Celebrity Big Brother, Joan Collins's arm, or, possibly, in the real Man U team when they totally restructure.

fields.headline: Spring arrivals
fields.standfirst: Western Highlands
fields.trailText: Western Highlands.
fields.body:
Most things went according to plan. Molly, our eighth grandchild arrived on Good Friday in Glasgow only marginally behind schedule. Small but perfectly formed, sleeps a lot but not necessarily at the right times. Partick Thistle achieved promotion as champions on Saturday at Forfar.

So on Monday evening I set off northwards to Onich at the upper end of Loch Linnhe in the hope of seeing some of Elizabeth's thriving population of pine martens. Well before Crianlarich that most evocative of smells, peat reek, reached my nostrils and started a chain of thought that lasted long enough for me to get across Rannoch Moor without noticing its total bleakness and to drop down to sea level through the Pass of Glencoe.

Elizabeth had done her best to ensure some martens appeared - raspberry jam-loaded slices of bread were on a plank outside the kitchen window and she showed me the well-worn track down the bank by which the martens arrive. The blackbirds always recognise a predator, their sudden alarm calls indicate an approach.

Over her 24 years in the house, the visiting population has increased significantly. As we chatted, one piece of bread disappeared but its fast-moving consumer did not stay to be identified. The local martens are numerous enough to be pests. Martens are still shot and snared, despite enjoying legal protection. Before the light faded, a fluttering host of finches brought colour to the steep bank behind the house. I waited until the light had almost gone but no martens appeared. Elizabeth shared my disappointment but gave a consolation camcorder video of the visitors taken on a summer evening.

Well before Crianlarich that most evocative of smells, peat reek, reached my nostrils and started a chain of thought that lasted long enough for me to get across Rannoch Moor without noticing its total bleakness and to drop down to sea level through the Pass of Glencoe. Elizabeth had done her best to ensure some martens appeared - raspberry jam-loaded slices of bread were on a plank outside the kitchen window and she showed me the well-worn track down the bank by which the martens arrive. The blackbirds always recognise a predator, their sudden alarm calls indicate an approach. Over her 24 years in the house, the visiting population has increased significantly. As we chatted, one piece of bread disappeared but its fast-moving consumer did not stay to be identified. The local martens are numerous enough to be pests. Martens are still shot and snared, despite enjoying legal protection. Before the light faded, a fluttering host of finches brought colour to the steep bank behind the house. I waited until the light had almost gone but no martens appeared. Elizabeth shared my disappointment but gave a consolation camcorder video of the visitors taken on a summer evening.

fields.headline: Bringing home the bacon
fields.standfirst: The idea came to him during a bad hangover - wouldn't it be great to have breakfast in bed brought to your door? Now Jonathan Stibbs is delivering fry-ups and smoked salmon to hungry households every morning.  Merope Mills calls him up
fields.trailText: The idea came to him during a bad hangover - wouldn't it be great to have breakfast in bed brought to your door? Now Jonathan Stibbs is delivering fry-ups and smoked salmon to hungry households every morning. Merope Mills calls him up.
fields.body:
Jonathan, the little angel, has promised me breakfast in bed. Not just a token cup of tea and a slice of cold toast, but the whole shebang. I'm looking forward to scrambled eggs, crispy bacon and pork and leek sausages, alongside mushrooms fried in butter and tomatoes with balsamic vinegar. I'm getting fresh, crusty bread and golden hash browns, as well as a pain au chocolat, a croissant and a generous portion of fruit salad. And, because he's such a darling, Jonathan is even serving up a newspaper. I think I'm in love. The only problem is that we haven't yet met.

To Jonathan, you see, I am no one special. Just one of many hundreds of women for whom he has slaved over a hot stove to bring breakfast to over the past year. A fair amount of men have profited from his culinary hand, too. That's because Jonathan is the brains behind Breakfast with Jonathan, a breakfast and brunch delivery service charged with feeding the ravenous but sleepy-eyed population of north London and beyond.

Breakfast with Jonathan was conceived when 26-year-old Jonathan Stibbs woke up one morning with a stonking hangover wishing that someone - anyone - would deliver him breakfast in bed. "It was then that I realised that you can get almost anything delivered to your door these days, but that there was nobody out there doing a breakfast run." After that, it was a matter of months before Stibbs left a well-paid sales job to venture into the early morning food delivery business.

The transition was not an easy one. He was passed around the houses in his quest for permits and licences. "It was a long, complicated and tortuous process and I got a lot of blank looks," he says. But after the health and safety and hygiene courses were secured, he was able to occupy himself with "the really important stuff". "There was a lot of practice, eating full English breakfasts and testing out sausages. It was really difficult work," he says, with some earnest nodding. I am not convinced.

I fit into Jonathan's core customer demographic. I am a young woman. I would like a young man to bring me breakfast in bed. I am resigned to the fact that no young man is going to do that. If I want my breakfast in bed I am going to have to pay for it. "I always assumed the business was going to attract people like me - hungover blokes who really didn't fancy cooking," says Stibbs. "But it turns out I was all wrong. The customers are nearly all female. They're in their late 20s, early 30s and without kids and I think what they would like is their boyfriends to order it for them. Their boyfriends, of course, are never going to get it together, so the girlfriends do it for themselves in a 'well-I-suppose-I'll-have-to-then' kind of way."

It was also his female followers who forced him to rethink his designs on calling the business The Morning After Pill. "I thought it was fantastic, but every woman I told it to gave me a terrible stare, so I couldn't go ahead with it. The guys I told thought it was funny but the girls were like 'that doesn't make me want to have breakfast'."

When I told colleagues about Breakfast with Jonathan several were convinced it was "perfect for one-night stands where you could still stand each other the next day". My own suspicions were that laying on a pre-ordered, romantic morning meal for two might be more of a spoiler than a seducer that early in a relationship. But maybe I'm wrong. The Breakfast with Jonathan menu offers up a washbag replacement kit (£7), complete with toothbrush, paste, deodorant, socks and pants. The "Other items to make your weekend a little more pleasant" section also includes Durex condoms (£5), king-size Rizlas (£1) and Nurofen (£3).

For my breakfast, I settle for the comparatively boring, but more than ample Classic Continental (£10) and Fully Jonty (£10) options - the latter being the fried, artery-clogging English breakfast and the most popular item on the menu. There is also Kedgeree (£7), eggs benedict (£10) and smoked salmon specials (£4-£12) and for special occasions there's the £50 luxury Morning Glory breakfast complete with a chilled bottle of Perrier-Jouet. Given notice, he can also personalise an order to accommodate any individual requests.

Stibbs prepares your breakfast outside in a van before delivering the end result in brown paper bags to your door. He is now more than accustomed to greeting his customers half-clothed and half-conscious and admits to seeing "the odd nude person streak across in the background". Most of the time though, "it's just an arm and a head poking around the door". "But what's best is when one partner doesn't know it's coming and they get very pleased. Amorous occasionally," he says, quickly adding, "but not with me. Not yet."

At lunatic speed, Jonathan can satiate the appetites of 15 households in Maida Vale and St Johns Wood in one morning. His short-term plan is to stretch the business south so he can cover from Islington to Clapham and all the areas in between. "Assuming it works and I think it will catch on," he adds, "I'd then like to start it up in other major cities like Manchester and Bristol."

It is simply a matter of time before the nation's early morning munchies and Nurofen needs are in safe hands.

fields.headline: Bean there, done that
fields.trailText: Costing The Earth | The Very World Of Milton Jones | Night Waves
fields.body:
Most of us, after a spot of grocery shopping, unpack the bags and have some tea. Not so Larry Proctor, an American seed merchant. After Larry went to market in Mexico, Costing The Earth (Radio 4) reported, he decided to patent one of the things he'd bought - the humble yellow bean - back at home.

Now, wanting to import the bean to the US is one thing; the very same one thing, in fact, that Mexican farmers were trying to do, turning huge areas of farming land over to the crop. But Proctor secured a patent for the bean, renaming it Enola after his wife ("no really, you shouldn't have," we can only hope Enola said), despite failing to meet any of the patenting criteria, most notably the one about it being something, er, new.

"I did not try to patent outside the US," Proctor said. "I am not interested in taking over the world." This might work with patent applications within the borders of Liechtenstein, but given America's size and wealth, the Mexican farmers were not convinced. "Maybe tomorrow they're going to patent our tortilla," one fumed. Don't give them any ideas, man.

The Very World Of Milton Jones (Radio 4) would be very funny about tortillas, one imagines, but its comedy axis never really leaves Swansea. Back for a second series, it retains its endearing mix of stinkingly bad gags (a scientist mixes up cabbage, carrot and mayonnaise to prove "Coles Law") and oddball charmers that pull you into his weird world. Milton meets Shania Twain (her dialogue is snippets from That Don't Impress Me Much), and we visit the Russian Orthodontist Church. You do sort of have to be there.

Philip Dodd maybe wished he wasn't there for his interview with James Ellroy on Night Waves (Radio 3). Dodd was all enthusiastic affability as always; Ellroy was not, volleying every question back with a snarl. Is the new book really about Clinton? "I despise Bill Clinton." Do you see yourself as doing in fiction what Martin Scorsese does on film? Ellroy thinks Scorsese "a stylist who burned out long ago." But Ellroy did share his philosophy: if you are not "pissing some people off", you are not working at the height of your powers. Ellroy is working at the height of his powers.

Presenting this week's Fantasy Evening Concert (Classic FM) Nicholas Tresilian was lucky the tune-picker, 10 year-old Daniel Timms, wasn't there. He sounded something of a handful, with his 10 choices including the whole of Aida and an extra choice, because ten just isn't enough, is it?: Wagner's Ride Of The Valkyries. His family listen "to other radio stations" and his younger sister likes Aerosmith. No wonder the poor boy slips into fantasy.

fields.headline: If you can't eat 'em, join 'em
fields.trailText: The People Detective | The Real Cracker
fields.body:
"Eating people is wrong."

- Flanders and Swan

There are few things more calculated to lift the spirits than hearing that a relative has been eaten by cannibals. As opposed, of course, to being eaten by a lion, as Albert was.

The People Detective (BBC 2) went out to Papua New Guinea with Charlotte Sainsbury to see the place where her distant relative, the Rev James Chalmers, was eaten by the locals. (Do you think we could persuade Judith Chalmers to visit Papua New Guinea?)

When applying to the London Missionary Society, Chalmers quoted Saint Mark: "Go ye into all the world and preach the gospel to every creature." Unfortunately, through pressure of space, Mark omitted this proviso: "Personally though I'd give New Guinea a miss. Try New Jersey."

The natives were known to be cannibals and clustered skulls hung outside their huts like dead white flowers. However, Chalmers flourished there for 30 years. Admittedly his wife died but he went home and got another. As the happily-named Dr Stanley said "It was fairly common for missionaries to be kitted out with a wife."

New Guinea looks like an iguana swimming above Australia. Chalmers started at the tip of the tail and worked his way up. When he reached Goaribari Island at the root of the tail, his inexperienced curate, Tomkins, insisted on going ashore. They were taken into one of the huge huts, which look like gaping whales. There Chalmers was struck with a stone axe and Tomkins speared as he made a run for it. Their bodies were given to the women to cook.

Papuans have long memories. At the name of Chalmers, the village of Ero offered Charlotte all they possessed. A head man said "You are standing on his place. The land here belongs to him and the people. You are now standing on your own land. Your coming here is very important to us. Because of his coming, we are civilised."

But at Goaribari Island they were refused admittance.

Charlotte is one of those well-bred women of superb composure and strong principles, who wouldn't put a foot wrong if she were a centipede. She spoke warmly of wherever she happened to be. She shook a couple of hundred hands. A couple of hundred hands waved her farewell. It was a royal progress and you can see why Chalmers found it preferable to Aberdeen.

When Charlotte met Andrew, a descendant of the man who had killed Chalmers, she made an exceptionally deft speech. "I think my ancestor was wrong to come in and try to change you. So I am very sorry for that but I will go away with very, very happy memories of Papua New Guinea and the people because you have been most kind." Andrew's eyes shone. "I appreciate that and I honour your great ancestor."

Her ancestor is still great in Papua New Guinea. As Daru Rooke, the presenter, said "He's been absorbed into them." You could put it that way.

The Real Cracker (Channel 4) ended, taking with it the curious Dr Boon ("My name is Boon, Julian Boon") whose self-deprecating jokiness is 50 years too old for his face.

This was the case of an unknown man tormenting air hostesses at Gatwick with sadistic, pornographic letters. If they ignored him, he said, their punishment would be based on a roll of the dice. A high score was acid in the face. A consistently touching thing about this series has been the courage of the victims, who agreed to tell us about it.

A psychological profile strikes me as fluffy compared to solid police work. See what you make of these clues. Putting the content of the letters aside, this man used Gatwick's internal mail, wrote in very neat capitals, used diagrams to an unusual degree, gave precise and detailed instructions and liked working out the rules of a board game. What do you think?

He was a senior BA engineer at Gatwick.

Boon believed he was an ugly bastard without a life. As the investigating officer said tactfully "Julian was very useful but probably not for the right reasons."

Directed by Patrick Forbes, the beautiful and evocative look of the thing disinfected the subject. On the runway at Gatwick the big bodied jets taxied like sharks in the dark.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Jazz Legends | The Great Mancini | Twenty Minutes
fields.body:
When the jazz promoter Norman Granz arranged recording sessions for Art Tatum he was stunned at the limited studio time they needed. Of the 69 tracks issued, all but three were completed in one take, a startling tribute not only to the pianist's technical prowess but to the clarity of his musical vision. Small wonder that Julian Joseph adds Tatum to his list of Jazz Legends (4.0pm, Radio 3).

Writing prat-fall music for an Abbot and Costello film doesn't seem a particularly sure route to fame and fortune but there is always an exception. In this case it was The Great Mancini (7.0pm, Radio 2) whose story is narrated by the lyricist Don Black. Young Henry started life as Enrico in the grimy steel town of Cleveland, Ohio. He was gifted enough as a child to master several musical instruments. This talent, honed at the Juillard School, soon secured him work as an arranger and, eventually, 20 Grammy awards.

In what must rate as one of the century's most daunting assignments Peter Holland has been asked to write Shakespeare's entry for the new Dictionary of National Biography. The editors have allotted it more space than any other but, as Holland muses in Twenty Minutes (8.20pm, Radio 3), how is he actually to fill it? There is the daughter's birth six months after Will's marriage. Beyond that Holland has to rummage through four centuries of unsourced mythology.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Dirty Harry | Trainspotting | Live Rugby League
fields.body:
Films

Butterfield Eight
(Daniel Mann, 1960)
9pm, TCM

Dame Elizabeth Taylor won an Oscar for her performance as Gloria Wandrous, "the most desirable woman in town, and the easiest to find!" as the publicity coyly explained. A call-girl haunted by a bad past, she is undone when she falls for two men - Laurence Harvey's sharp businessman and Eddie Fisher's more sensitive musician. Taylor is fine; skirting the edge of tragedy, she hardly needs to act. It was a role made for her.

Dirty Harry
(Don Siegel, 1971)
10pm, Sky Cinema

The first appearance of Clint Eastwood's semi-psychotic San Francisco cop Harry Callahan set a new yardstick for the detective movie, and few measure up to his .44 Magnum. He gives a performance of steely minimalism, dispatching "punks" while munching a hotdog; yet he is a man at the end of his tether. His methods of catching Andy Robinson's revolting Scorpio killer inspired wide debate about the film's supposed fascist stance. Siegel's direction, tight and tough, is exemplary.

Trainspotting
(Danny Boyle, 1996)
10pm, FilmFour

Heroin addicts are the subject, but this is a film on speed. The story of four Edinburgh junkies, adapted from Irvine Welsh's cult novel by the Shallow Grave and A Life Less Ordinary team, is shot full of manic invention and wit. Performances are inspired, from Robert Carlyle's bantam bruiser Begbie to Ewan McGregor's half-comatose hero Renton, mulling over the possibility of going straight. Hilarious and harrowing, it shows the highs and lows (to the very bottom of the toilet bowl) of addiction.

Cube
(Vincenzo Natali, 1997)
11.05pm, Sky MovieMax

Six people wake up inside a blank-walled cube: doors lead off into other cubes where, they soon learn, perils lie. This small-scale Canadian production, performed by a cast of unknowns, builds a captivating tension not through action but through the interplay of its mystified and panicky characters: enigmatic and unsettling, it is sci-fi in the Tarkovsky mode.

Under The Skin
(Carine Adler, 1997)
2.15am, FilmFour

A raw and uncompromising study of grief and its emotional twists and turns. Samantha Morton plays Iris, who on the death of her mother (Rita Tushingham), dumps her boyfriend (Matthew Delamere), picks an argument over mum's ashes with her pregnant sister Rose (Claire Rushbrook) and launches into a series of self-abusive one-night stands. This is hard and harrowing material, performed with real conviction: the film beat The Full Monty to an Edinburgh film festival prize.

Sports

Live Rugby League
7.30pm, Sky Sports 3

Warrington Wolves will be hoping that St Helens have half an eye on next week's Challenge Cup final, as that seem the likeliest way for them to steal the points against the Super League champions. The Wolves may have won their last two matches, but they have already lost five times this season and the sides are separated by virtually the entire length of the table.

The story of four Edinburgh junkies, adapted from Irvine Welsh's cult novel by the Shallow Grave and A Life Less Ordinary team, is shot full of manic invention and wit. Performances are inspired, from Robert Carlyle's bantam bruiser Begbie to Ewan McGregor's half-comatose hero Renton, mulling over the possibility of going straight. Hilarious and harrowing, it shows the highs and lows (to the very bottom of the toilet bowl) of addiction. Cube (Vincenzo Natali, 1997) 11.05pm, Sky MovieMax Six people wake up inside a blank-walled cube: doors lead off into other cubes where, they soon learn, perils lie. This small-scale Canadian production, performed by a cast of unknowns, builds a captivating tension not through action but through the interplay of its mystified and panicky characters: enigmatic and unsettling, it is sci-fi in the Tarkovsky mode. Under The Skin (Carine Adler, 1997) 2.15am, FilmFour A raw and uncompromising study of grief and its emotional twists and turns. Samantha Morton plays Iris, who on the death of her mother (Rita Tushingham), dumps her boyfriend (Matthew Delamere), picks an argument over mum's ashes with her pregnant sister Rose (Claire Rushbrook) and launches into a series of self-abusive one-night stands. This is hard and harrowing material, performed with real conviction: the film beat The Full Monty to an Edinburgh film festival prize. Sports Live Rugby League 7.30pm, Sky Sports 3 Warrington Wolves will be hoping that St Helens have half an eye on next week's Challenge Cup final, as that seem the likeliest way for them to steal the points against the Super League champions. The Wolves may have won their last two matches, but they have already lost five times this season and the sides are separated by virtually the entire length of the table.

fields.headline: Peggie Dear
fields.standfirst: Pioneering stage manager for Noël Coward
fields.trailText: The death of Peggie Dear at 93 closes just one part of the vast book on the light romantic plays of British theatre that were so typical of the 20th century.
fields.body:
The death of Peggie Dear at 93 closes just one part of the vast book on the light romantic plays of British theatre that were so typical of the 20th century. She was also a member of a remarkable family which contributed much to the world of entertainment.

Peggie Dear was not someone the public ever saw, but she was hugely influential as a stage manager - a ground-breaking role in the development of the West End theatre, particularly for a woman. She was certainly in the right place at the right time, developing professionally in the vibrant HM Tennant empire, in the guiding hands of impresario Binkie Beaumont, and working on some of Noël Coward's most famous productions.

Peggie Dear was a sturdy woman, a necessary asset with such physically demanding work, and was connected with 57 productions in the 1930s. During the second world war, she was notably involved in Noël Coward's presentations of Blithe Spirit (1941), Present Laughter (1942), This Happy Breed (1942) and Sigh No More (1945).

In 1952, she worked on Coward's Quadrille, which starred leading Broadway actors Alfred Lunt and his wife Lynn Fontane. Peggie had met them earlier, in 1944, when they played in Love In Idleness at London's Lyric Theatre, and they persuaded her to go back with them to America. A longstanding working relationship with the Lunts was established.

Peggie obtained her green card in 1955, and lived in New York on 82nd Street where the 1961 hit Breakfast At Tiffany's was filmed. Although her hopes of becoming a director did not materialise, she was a pioneer, and almost certainly the first woman stage manager on 42nd Street.

Marjorie Beaufort Dear was born the fourth child of Charles and Florence Dear of Brighton, and the older sister of brothers Basil and Peter. In 1918, her father drowned while attempting to save someone who had fallen overboard from a cross-Channel ferry, and the family found itself in severe financial difficulties.

Her two elder brothers (Howard and Kenneth) were sent to earn their living (a third, Ian, was put in the care of a guardian) to support their mother. To help out, the very young Peggie, Basil and Peter chose an entrepreneurial route.

They put on plays and skits at the weekend for the public at Brighton. Here Peter was spotted by "a famous artist of the legitimate stage" (according to a report in the Cardiff Daily News) who persuaded his mother to allow her son to try for the screen. Peter signed for a starring role in the 1922 film The Grass Orphan, which was a huge success.

Dubbed the "British Jackie Coogan", he was besieged wherever he went to promote the film. After too many newspaper reports called him "dear little Peter Dear", he changed his surname to Dearing and had a career as an actor, director and teacher.

As the only daughter, Peggie would have been expected to remain at home with her dominating mother, but she had been influenced by the man who was rumoured to have spotted her brother, Sir Philip Ben Greet, who started the London Shakespeare for Schools movement, and was manager-actor of the Ben Greet Players.

In 1932, calling herself Marjorie Beaufort, she became assistant stage manager of the Kingsway Theatre, London, where the Ben Greet Players were in repertory with a number of Shakespeare's works, and where Basil and Peter took on an incredible number of roles.

Years later, Basil's career veered towards film, beginning during the second world war with the propaganda film The Goose Steps Out (1942), in which he is credited as co-director with Will Hay. Later, in partnership with Michael Relph, he was behind a range of British classics, from The Blue Lamp (1950) to The League Of Gentlemen (1959).

To prevent confusion with another contemporary film maker, Basil Dean, he changed his name to Dearden. The story goes that Dean complained of getting Dear's love letters, while Dear complained of getting Dean's bills.

In 1969, Peggie returned to Britain in time to attend Sir Noël Coward's 70th birthday celebration, A Talent To Amuse, at the Phoenix Theatre in London. Her eyesight started to deteriorate not long after this, and she decided that she could no longer physically handle stage management.

She retired, living first in Hove, then later in London, where she died. She never married.

 Marjorie Beaufort Dear, stage manager, born February 12 1908; died April 13 2001

fields.headline: Jeanette Kimball
fields.standfirst: New Orleans pianist who played Dixieland jazz with key bands for 70 years
fields.trailText: New Orleans pianist who played Dixieland jazz with key bands for 70 years.
fields.body:
Early jazz bands in New Orleans would often select women pianists to play for them during the music's formative years. A skilled reader who could provide the correct harmonic foundation for the other (male) instrumentalists, yet still be clearly heard, was a definite asset. Jeanette Kimball, who has died aged 94, fitted this description perfectly, her excellent musicianship and solo capability kick-starting a remarkable career, which spanned 70 years and took in some of the formative names of the New Orleans circuit.

Jeanette Salvant was born in Pass Christian, a small town near New Orleans, into a family with strong French Creole ties. She took piano lessons at the age of seven, and played in church and at school events. She said later that she "lived at the piano - my teacher couldn't keep me in lessons". Classically trained yet adept at improvisation, when she was only 11 she was teaching other children and adults.

She went on to perform professionally at weekends with a local string band, but was drawn to jazz when she heard visiting groups from New Orleans in the streets of her home town. In 1926, she joined Celestin's Tuxedo Orchestra (so-called because its members always wore evening dress), travelling throughout the Southern states, playing prestigious white dance jobs and carnival balls. The orchestra's style secured it a position as a "society" orchestra suited to "polite" occasions - worlds away from the rough-and-ready jazz bands who performed in the Crescent City's dives and clubs.

Celestin specialised in well-structured arrangements, clean execution and a danceable beat, with room for "hot" solo extemporisations. Commended for her "ladylike presence", the demure Salvant thought it all "wonderful". She stayed on when Celestin turned his nine-piece into a touring big band, participating effectively in the band's recordings.

In 1929, she met and married the banjoist and guitarist Narvin Kimball while both were playing with Celestin, and in 1935 came off the road to raise her daughters. When the marriage foundered, she retained her married name, devoting herself to her family and to her continuing musical career.

At home in New Orleans, she began to teach again and then moved into local club work in the mid-1940s, playing at the Dew Drop Inn with the Buddy Charles band, which often included trumpeter Dave Bartholomew, best known as the musical mentor of bluesman Fats Domino. She was also hired to play with the city's best big bands, run by trumpeters Herb Leary and Sidney Desvignes, and commenced a long association with the Holy Ghost Catholic Church as organist and choir director.

When the traditional jazz revival got under way in the 1950s, Papa Celestin re-emerged to head a popular jazz group (still called the Tuxedo Band although the dress code had changed) and Jeanette Kimball was reunited with her old leader. She continued to play Dixieland jazz throughout the ensuing decades, staying with Celestin's unit and its successor, run by Papa French, before playing for the tourists with the famed Preservation Hall Jazz Band.

In her latter years, she was a member of expatriate British trumpeter Clive Wilson's Original Camellia Jazz Band, and recorded reward ingly for his New Orleans label. "Her style of syncopation would really drive the band," Wilson said. In 1998, she was given the Black Men of Labor Jazz Legacy Award.

Prompted by her daughters, she left New Orleans for good in the late 1990s, sharing her time with them in Ohio and South Carolina. She is survived by her former husband, her daughters and their extended families.

 Jeanette Salvant Kimball, jazz pianist, born December 18 1906; died March 29 2001

webTitle: Ripper's jeering letter goes on show

fields.headline: Ripper's jeering letter goes on show
fields.trailText: A letter from Jack the Ripper jeering at the authorities for their failure to capture him and warning that he would be "on the job soon" is to be made public for the first time today.
fields.body:
A letter from Jack the Ripper jeering at the authorities for their failure to capture him and warning that he would be "on the job soon" is to be made public for the first time today.

The letter has been passed by the Metropolitan police to the public record office at Kew where it is to go on exhibition. It is expected to fuel the controversy over the unsolved vicious murders of five women in Whitechapel, in the east end of London in the autumn of 1888.

Arguments over the true identity of Jack the Ripper have raged between the impossible and the improbable for more than a century and include the claim that Prince Albert, the grandson of Queen Victoria, was indirectly involved.

Metropolitan police archivists said the newly released letter sent at the height of the police hunt for the Ripper to Dr Thomas Openshaw, the curator of the pathological museum at the London hospital, Whitechapel, was directly linked to the best known letter in the case which was sent to the authorities along with half a human kidney.

The Openshaw letter was sent to the doctor who carried out the police examination on the kidney to establish whether or not it was genuine. Signed by Jack the Ripper it jeers at the results of the doctor's examination which had been widely reported in the newspapers. He had found that it was in a similar state to the kidney that had been left in the body of the last victim of the Ripper. It was a "ginny" kidney of the sort found in an alcoholic, it belonged to a woman of about 45 and had been removed within the previous three weeks, he reported.

The letter jeered at the doctor in mock cockney tones: "Old boss you was rite it was the left kidney I was goin to hoperate agin close to your ospitle just as I was going to dror mi nife along of er bloomin throte them cusses of coppers spoilt the game but I guess I wil be on the job soon and will send you another bit of innerds

Jack the ripper

O have you seen the devle with his mikerscope and scalpul a lookin at a Kidney with a slide cocked up."

The envelope in which the letter was received is postmarked 'London E. OC29 88'.

The Metropolitan police said that the debate was still going on whether the original kidney letter was from the genuine killer or not with many arguing it was the work of a hoaxer, possibly a medical student. The letter that accompanied the piece of kidney was sent to George Lusk the chairman of the Whitechapel Vigilance Committee which had been formed to help the police hunt the serial killer. It began: "From hell, Mr Lusk, Sor, I send you half the Kidne I took from one woman prasarved it for you ... signed Catch me when you can Mishter Lusk."

The famous nickname, Jack the Ripper, first appeared as the signature on two letters sent to the Central News Agency at the beginning of October 1888.

Stewart Evans, the author of a forthcoming book, Jack the Ripper, Letters From Hell, said there were around 220 letters sent to the authorities at the time of murders, but the Openshaw letter had a better claim than many to be genuine.

He said that some experts believed it was from the murderer but that handwriting specialists had found no common hand or theme with only some including deliberate misspellings. The Openshaw letter had been written as though it was imitating a cockney accent.

A new Hollywood film of the Whitechapel murders is to come out this autumn. Starring Johnny Depp it is called "From Hell" - the opening words of the Lusk letter.

fields.headline: Grandmothers keep elephant families going
fields.trailText: For elephants in Africa an old social truth lives on: it is the grandmothers who keep the family going.
fields.body:
For elephants in Africa an old social truth lives on: it is the grandmothers who keep the family going. British researchers combed 30 years of elephant family history in Amboseli national park, Kenya, to discover that the most successful families were led by the oldest matriarchs.

They taped and then broadcast elephant recognition calls to prove the point. When the elephants heard a call from a group they did not know well, they went into a defensive huddle. When they heard calls from a more familiar herd, they carried on grazing.

But in either case, the older the matriarch, the more sure the group's behaviour. The research could have implications for conservation.

Elephants live almost human lifespans, cover huge distances and spend all day feeding. Females stay in family groups, led by the oldest female, to protect and rear their calves. Each group encounters around 25 other groups a year. Some groups - often related - see each other frequently, others meet occasionally. And occasionally, groups get into conflict and threaten each other.

Karen McComb of Sussex University and colleagues report in Science today that they recorded the low, rumbling elephant identity calls and played them from the back of a Land Rover, to watch the behaviour of elephant groups.

"What we found was that it all boiled down to what age the matriarch was. Families with older matriarchs were massively better at picking out genuine strangers. When faced with more familiar individuals, they would remain relaxed. But they pinpointed the ones that would have constituted a genuine threat."

The payoff was that the older the matriarch, the greater the number of calves produced by the family each female reproductive year. "We believe this to be the first statistical link between social knowledge and reproductive success in any species," Dr McComb said.

"The results highlight the disproportionate effect the hunting and poaching of mature animals might have. Other large mammals, such as whales, dolphins and chimpanzees, also live in fluid social systems where an ability to recognise friends among many acquaintances might be expected to have an impact on reproductive success."

But the oldest female in a herd will have the biggest tusks and be most likely to face danger, making her most vulnerable to poachers.

webTitle: Fatal blunders prompt new injection rules

fields.headline: Fatal blunders prompt new injection rules
fields.trailText: Rules governing the treatment of cancer patients by chemotherapy are to be drawn up by the NHS after a catalogue of blunders led to the death of an 18-year-old man with leukaemia.
fields.body:
Rules governing the treatment of cancer patients by chemotherapy are to be drawn up by the NHS after a catalogue of blunders led to the death of an 18-year-old man with leukaemia.

They will include protocols on how, where and when drugs are administered and extra training for doctors, and may even involve changes to equipment to prevent confusion between medications.

Wayne Jowett died at the Queen's medical centre, Nottingham, in February, a month after being injected with a powerful drug through the spine, where it is almost invariably fatal, rather than a vein. He was in remission when a junior doctor, supervised by a registrar who had been in the job for just two days, made the fatal error.

Doctors were powerless to reverse the devastating effects of the mistake and the teenager died nearly a month later, after his body had been slowly paralysed and he suffered heart failure.

An external inquiry yesterday blamed a system failure at the hospital, involving a combination of errors and wrong assumptions. Ward staff appeared to have been "lulled into a false sense of security", said the inquiry report's author, Brian Toft. "People had very strong tacit assumptions that everything they were doing was satisfactory."

There have been 13 similar cases in the past 15 years, five in the past 10 years, representing a mistake rate of about three in 100,000 treatments. But health officials believe there may have been hundreds of "near misses". Mistakes have also been made injecting into veins drugs which should have been administered via the spine.

The Nottingham coroner, Nigel Chapman, recorded a verdict of accidental death at Wayne's inquest yesterday. He said: "We can put a man on the moon but why can't we find a safe method to prevent these deaths?"

The NHS is looking at ways to change the design of syringes so those used for intravenous drugs do not fit the needles used for spinal injections.

Mr Jowett's father, also called Wayne, said afterwards: "I do blame the doctors. There were a lot of procedures that failed. Wayne was full of life, he was sporty and used to play football and rugby and he was also into stock car racing."

The family's solicitor, Paul Balen, said the hospital had accepted legal liability. "Wayne's family wait to see what steps the authority takes against the doctors involved. For all the failures of the hospital's systems and of the education and training of doctors highlighted by this case, nothing should disguise the fact that the doctors treating Wayne fell far short of their professional responsibilities and are to blame for his death."

David Morton and Fred Mulhem, the doctors most closely involved in the case, have been suspended and face a disciplinary investigation. They apologised in a statement issued through the Medical Defence Union. "From the outset we admitted our mistakes in Wayne's treatment. It is very important after a tragedy that all lessons are learned and safe systems put in place to ensure something like this never happens again."

The verdict coincided with the publication of three reports, by Professor Toft and Kent Woods into ways of preventing similar events, and by the University Hospital NHS Trust, responsible for the centre, which said it was following all its inquiry's recommendations on training and new procedures.

John MacDonald, chief executive at the medical centre, said: "We failed Wayne and his family and for that we are deeply sorry. There is no individual to blame. It is a combination of failures."

Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer, at the Department of Health, said the outside reports which he had commissioned "point the way forward in preventing a rare but catastrophic medical error which has repeated itself for nearly 2O years".

Professor Toft, an accident investigator, listed nearly 40 wrong assumptions by staff and pointed to breakdowns in the hospital's rules and safety culture. Professor Woods, of Leicester University and director of the NHS's health technology assessment programme, said: "This is a high-risk procedure. It should be in the hands of a small number of individuals who are fully conversant with all its impli cations." Spinal and vein injections should never be done at the same time or in the same place.
