fields.bodyText: Rules governing the treatment of cancer patients by chemotherapy are to be drawn up by the NHS after a catalogue of blunders led to the death of an 18-year-old man with leukaemia. They will include protocols on how, where and when drugs are administered and extra training for doctors, and may even involve changes to equipment to prevent confusion between medications. Wayne Jowett died at the Queen's medical centre, Nottingham, in February, a month after being injected with a powerful drug through the spine, where it is almost invariably fatal, rather than a vein. He was in remission when a junior doctor, supervised by a registrar who had been in the job for just two days, made the fatal error. Doctors were powerless to reverse the devastating effects of the mistake and the teenager died nearly a month later, after his body had been slowly paralysed and he suffered heart failure. An external inquiry yesterday blamed a system failure at the hospital, involving a combination of errors and wrong assumptions. Ward staff appeared to have been "lulled into a false sense of security", said the inquiry report's author, Brian Toft. "People had very strong tacit assumptions that everything they were doing was satisfactory." There have been 13 similar cases in the past 15 years, five in the past 10 years, representing a mistake rate of about three in 100,000 treatments. But health officials believe there may have been hundreds of "near misses". Mistakes have also been made injecting into veins drugs which should have been administered via the spine. The Nottingham coroner, Nigel Chapman, recorded a verdict of accidental death at Wayne's inquest yesterday. He said: "We can put a man on the moon but why can't we find a safe method to prevent these deaths?" The NHS is looking at ways to change the design of syringes so those used for intravenous drugs do not fit the needles used for spinal injections. Mr Jowett's father, also called Wayne, said afterwards: "I do blame the doctors. There were a lot of procedures that failed. Wayne was full of life, he was sporty and used to play football and rugby and he was also into stock car racing." The family's solicitor, Paul Balen, said the hospital had accepted legal liability. "Wayne's family wait to see what steps the authority takes against the doctors involved. For all the failures of the hospital's systems and of the education and training of doctors highlighted by this case, nothing should disguise the fact that the doctors treating Wayne fell far short of their professional responsibilities and are to blame for his death." David Morton and Fred Mulhem, the doctors most closely involved in the case, have been suspended and face a disciplinary investigation. They apologised in a statement issued through the Medical Defence Union. "From the outset we admitted our mistakes in Wayne's treatment. It is very important after a tragedy that all lessons are learned and safe systems put in place to ensure something like this never happens again." The verdict coincided with the publication of three reports, by Professor Toft and Kent Woods into ways of preventing similar events, and by the University Hospital NHS Trust, responsible for the centre, which said it was following all its inquiry's recommendations on training and new procedures. John MacDonald, chief executive at the medical centre, said: "We failed Wayne and his family and for that we are deeply sorry. There is no individual to blame. It is a combination of failures." Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer, at the Department of Health, said the outside reports which he had commissioned "point the way forward in preventing a rare but catastrophic medical error which has repeated itself for nearly 2O years". Professor Toft, an accident investigator, listed nearly 40 wrong assumptions by staff and pointed to breakdowns in the hospital's rules and safety culture. Professor Woods, of Leicester University and director of the NHS's health technology assessment programme, said: "This is a high-risk procedure. It should be in the hands of a small number of individuals who are fully conversant with all its impli cations." Spinal and vein injections should never be done at the same time or in the same place. Consideration should be given to ensuring the two types of treatment could not even be given in the same way, for instance putting drugs to be administered through a vein into drip bags. Other equipment such as the connectors for syringes may also need changing. Medical training must be improved. "Drug prescribing and administration errors occur with unacceptable frequency."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Boy, 13, charged over child porn
fields.body:
Boy, 13, charged over child porn

A 13-year-old boy has been charged with 10 offences of possessing indecent photographs of children following a nationwide police operation against alleged internet paedophiles which resulted in 33 arrests. The boy will appear at Teesside juvenile court on April 23.

Tate to open arts library

The Tate is to establish a library for the arts, showcasing previously unseen papers and sketches from leading figures from the past century. A £2.2m donation from the Kreitman Foundation has funded the research centre at Tate Britain, in London, to be opened in spring 2002.

Nightclub wins back licence

Home nightclub, in the West End of London, has had its licence to open restored by Westminster council after agreeing measures to combat drug dealing. It lost its entertainments licence 21 days ago when police discovered dealing in hard drugs was rife at the venue.

Speed cameras monitor salmon

Speed cameras are monitoring the number of salmon in British streams, the environment agency revealed yesterday. The cameras, similar to those used to catch speeding motorists, are being employed underwater to take digital photographs of endangered Atlantic salmon.

Blue Peter dog Bonnie dies

Bonnie, the former Blue Peter dog, has died, the BBC announced yesterday. The golden retriever, who first appeared on the long-running children's show in 1986 at six weeks old, retired two years ago.

fields.headline: Drug mix-up killed leukaemia sufferer
fields.trailText: Wayne Jowett had been diagnosed with leukaemia just over 18 months before his fatal visit for chemotherapy at the Queen's medical centre, Nottingham. His cancer was in remission but he needed "maintenance" treatment using five drugs.
fields.body:
Wayne Jowett had been diagnosed with leukaemia just over 18 months before his fatal visit for chemotherapy at the Queen's medical centre, Nottingham. His cancer was in remission but he needed "maintenance" treatment using five drugs.

He had to go to hospital every three months to receive Cytosine in his spine and an intravenous treatment called Vincristine, a drug that causes death or severe damage to the central nervous system if wrongly administered.

Wayne, 18, was due to receive Cytosine on January 4 and Vincristine the following day but did not arrive on the first morning. He was anxious about the lumbar puncture in his spine before the first drug was administered through a syringe. He arrived with his grandmother that afternoon.

No one informed the consultant in charge of his case. Around 5pm, David Morton - who had been on the ward for five weeks, did not know Wayne and was not aware of the dangers of Vincristine - asked Feda Mulhem, a more senior doctor who was on his third day on the ward and was meant to be shadowing other staff, to oversee him carry out Wayne's treatment.

The drugs were brought from the ward fridge. There were two transparent packages each with a syringe. Dr Mulhem assumed both were meant to be injected in the spine.

Dr Morton gave Wayne a local anaesthetic, performed the lumbar puncture and then administered the Cytosine. Dr Mulhem handed him the second syringe containing Vincristine. This surprised Dr Morton who had used just one syringe on the only other occasion he had performed the procedure under supervision.

Dr Morton told the external inquiry he had questioned whether the syringe was Vincristine and whether it should be administered via the spine. Dr Mulhem said he had it firmly in his mind that it was another drug. The fatal dose was administered.

Around 5.15pm staff realised the mistake. Within minutes specialists were preparing for emergency surgery to wash out the drug. At 6pm Wayne was taken to theatre.

He spent two days in intensive care. His condition worsened. By January 14, he was back in intensive care. On February 2, he died.

webTitle: Two held on bag snatch killing

fields.headline: Two held on bag snatch killing
fields.trailText: Police yesterday arrested a man and a woman in connection with the murder of Liz Sherlock, the costume designer who was run over on Monday while chasing two people who stole her handbag.
fields.body:
Police yesterday arrested a man and a woman in connection with the murder of Liz Sherlock, the costume designer who was run over on Monday while chasing two people who stole her handbag.

A 35-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in an early morning raid on a property in West Hampstead, north-west London. Yesterday the pair were being questioned in a north London police station.

The arrests came after an intelligence tipoff and surveillance operation, a spokesman said. Dozens of people had responded to an appeal for witnesses to the incident.

Mrs Sherlock was killed after being run over by the thieves' getaway vehicle. She had been with her husband in a coffee shop at Euston station, central London, when her handbag, containing just £20, was snatched.

The 42-year-old from Chiswick, west London, chased the thieves into the street, but was hit by their car and swept on to the bonnet, before slipping under its wheels. She died later of multiple injuries.

Police also released a photograph of the vehicle believed to have been used in the getaway, a white E-reg Ford Fiesta. It was found abandoned nearby shortly afterwards.

Detectives would have to charge the two suspects within 24 hours, a spokesman said, unless an extension was granted by a police superintendent. Suspects can be held for up to 96 hours without charge, with the permission of a magistrate.

The designer, who had worked for the BBC on programmes including Last of the Summer Wine, It's a Knockout and the Royal Variety Performance, had been on the way to Bolton, Lancashire, to celebrate her father's 79th birthday.

Mrs Sherlock's husband Peter, 48, a computer programmer, said yesterday that his wife's parents, Joseph and Doris Nicholls, had travelled to London to be with him.

It was also revealed yesterday that street robberies in London have soared by almost a fifth in the past year, according to Scotland Yard figures.

Metropolitan police commissioner Sir John Stevens said that tackling such offences remained a "major challenge" for the force. "There will be absolutely no let-up in our efforts to get on top of street robbery across the capital."

webTitle: Museum director's stress led to suicide

fields.headline: Museum director's stress led to suicide
fields.trailText: A brilliant museum director with a strong sense of public service, who was found drowned on a Dorset beach last month, took his own life because of stress compounded by impossibly exacting personal standards.
fields.body:
A brilliant museum director with a strong sense of public service, who was found drowned on a Dorset beach last month, took his own life because of stress compounded by impossibly exacting personal standards.

Despite praise from colleagues and rivals, Sir Richard Foster did not feel on top of his demanding position as head of the National Museums and Galleries on Merseyside, an inquest heard yesterday.

The Bournemouth coroner recorded a verdict of suicide after hearing that Sir Richard, knighted in the millennium honours list of January 2000, had drunk a bottle of whisky after going alone to the deserted seafront at Swanage. His body was found on the resort's North Beach on March 8, his pockets filled with sand in an apparent attempt to ensure that he would drown.

Lady Mary Foster, widow of the 59-year-old director, said that her husband's "very special character" included a strong sense of public service and the obligations it imposed. She said after the inquest: "His achievements were enormous to the rest of us but not to him. He was a modest man who worked far too hard and always thought he should do better."

Lady Mary told the inquest that her husband, who had melded eight separate museums and galleries into one of the main cultural attractions of the north, had been in excellent spirits at a function held only days before he took his life.

She said: "He was very happy and the people at the reception I have spoken to have been as amazed as I was that there was anything the matter."

But the last time she had spoken to Sir Richard, who was a father of three, he had seemed stressed. In spite of the museums and galleries' success, she said, "he was desperately overworked and he was worried that he was not in control of everything."

Sir Richard was within sight of retirement from his post, which he was due to leave next year after 35 years in the business. His work had brought his galleries a host of awards and buoyant visitor numbers, and his death shocked staff.

The inquest heard that he had been due to return to his home on Merseyside after a function in London, but instead had hired a car and driven to Swanage the day before his body was found. He left a note for his wife which paid tribute to his family but said that he was depressed and concerned about his work.

The coroner said: "The early part of the note shows that he thought there was a weakness in the leadership he had been carrying out in his duties. The rest of the note is praise for the support and love given to him by his wife and family."

PC Steve Wood, who helped to recover Sir Richard's body said that an empty whisky bottle had been found on the steps of a hotel overlooking North Beach. Sir Richard had 20 units of alcohol in his blood at the time of death, more than four times the legal driving limit.

Tributes at the time of Sir Richard's death emphasised his modesty and self-deprecation as well as praising his vision and achievements. All eight Merseyside museums and galleries, including the award-winning Conservation Centre which won his attention as much as the more showy exhibitions, closed simultaneously as a mark of respect.

Sir Richard was the second much praised arts figure in the north-west to take his life this year. A month earlier, the head of arts at the new Lowry Centre in Salford, Lea Parkinson, threw himself off the top of the building. His partner, Maria Foran, told an inquest last week that the 32-year-old had been over-stressed at work and had suffered from a lack of management support.

webTitle: Letters: What's cooking with the census

fields.headline: What's cooking with the census
fields.trailText: A census form has just been delivered to our house. We are 90 and nearly 86 and took it, but the young woman refused an invitation to come in and help us fill it up as she had so many forms to deliver (Letters, April 18).
fields.body:
A census form has just been delivered to our house. We are 90 and nearly 86 and took it, but the young woman refused an invitation to come in and help us fill it up as she had so many forms to deliver (Letters, April 18).

"Can't you get someone to help you?" she said. At the last census, when we were only 80 and 75, a young man helped us. This time we really need help. The questions are well-printed in black and legible. The explanations are printed in red on pink paper and very difficult to read for people with poor sight and cataracts. Whoever passed that design?
Name and address supplied

 Well I've done it! My religion on the form is Jedi. But then it seemed inappropriate to put school teacher on Q27, so I have put Jedi Master, thus lifting my lowly status in one fell swoop. This could be the answer to recruiting for my beleaguered profession. May the Force be with us.
Kath Thompson
Sheffield

 Robin Cook is clear that "Britain is not a single Anglo-Saxon race, but a gathering of races" (Chicken tikka Britain is new Cook recipe, April 19). Perhaps he should have told the authors of the census form. Under the heading "What is your ethnic group?", designed we are told to "indicate your cultural background", the choices confuse colour, race and nationality; for example: "White and British" or "Asian British and Indian". If I want to record my ethnic group as "English/Irish", I have to settle for "any other white background".
Mike Levon
Wakefield mike@Holyground.co.uk

 In an Indian restaurant in Edinburgh a few years ago I discovered from the waiter that Robin Cook was a regular customer. "What does he order?" I inquired. "Lamb pasanda," came the reply. So no chicken tikka masala for our foreign secretary, but a dish far more in keeping with his personality and attributes - mild on the surface, creamy even, but also chewy, substantial, and profoundly satisfying to people of good taste.
Stefan Stern
London

fields.headline: Knee-jerk liberals
fields.trailText: "South Africa is desperately short of educated and cultured people" (Stranger than fiction, April 19). That'll be white education and culture, will it? And as for Nadime Gordimer being "dragged down" from her "lofty heights" ... hmm.
fields.body:
"South Africa is desperately short of educated and cultured people" (Stranger than fiction, April 19). That'll be white education and culture, will it? And as for Nadime Gordimer being "dragged down" from her "lofty heights" ... hmm.

Just because people like Gordimer courageously opposed the racist regime of old, does not mean their work and thinking is not, itself, on occasion, racist. Given the culture in which Gordimer learned to think and speak, it is almost certain to be there, consciously or unconsciously, and to be evident in passages of their writing.

Perhaps it is a shame that the committee at Gauteng proposed to ban Gordimer, rather than placing on the syllabus deconstruction of the racist assumptions still present in liberation literature (and one could have a field day with the sexism in Coetzee, while one was about it). But this knee-jerk defence of some sacred (white) liberal cows against "a functionary" - presumably black ... well, aren't there some unconscious assumptions here too?
Kate de Selincourt
Lydney, Glos

 So the new education authorities have banned Shakespeare's Julius Caesar because it "elevates men". They ought to know that one of their most elevated men, Nelson Mandela, chose a passage from that play (Caesar's response to Calpurnia when she tries to dissuade him from going to his doom - "Cowards die many times before their deaths ...") to represent his views while surviving imprisonment on Robben Island; and that he and his fellow political prisoners used to circulate and treasure a copy of Shakespeare's complete works as a source of inspiration.
Prof Dennis Walder
London

webTitle: Letters: We want it all and we want it now

fields.headline: We want it all and we want it now
fields.trailText: Zac Goldsmith (Comment, April 18) reports that 89% of respondents in an opinion poll "would prefer to buy British food if it were available". It is available, but a glance at people's behaviour in a supermarket will show that despite what they might answer to an opinion poll, large numbers of people will choose foreign food over the British equivalent.
fields.body:
Zac Goldsmith (Comment, April 18) reports that 89% of respondents in an opinion poll "would prefer to buy British food if it were available". It is available, but a glance at people's behaviour in a supermarket will show that despite what they might answer to an opinion poll, large numbers of people will choose foreign food over the British equivalent.

How many of the 61% who "believe our money should be spent on alternatives to roads" were amongst those cheering on the fuel protestors' pro-road movement?

How many of the 49% reported to be against advances in science and technology have mobile phones or personal computers? And how many would refuse better medical treatment gained by scientific research?

Those with real political responsibilities have to deal with contradictory popular demands, an electorate which will call for things requiring more state spending when asked in opinion polls, but then vote for parties promising less taxation.

It is not "healthy scepticism" if people are misled by shallow-thinking people like Zac Goldsmith into thinking it is the fault of democracy if conflicting demands cannot be immediately met. It is part of the consumerist anti-ecological mindset that people cannot think through the consequences of their short-term political choices.
Matthew Huntbach
London mhuntbach@hotmail.com

 I have recently been diagnosed with diabetes. The insulin I use is of the type known as "precursor yeast recombinant". Using a very clever piece of biotechnology, those corporations that Zac Goldsmith decries have engineered a yeast that produces pure human insulin. As such it is a genetically modified product yet far preferable to insulin extracted from pigs or cattle which, until recently, was the only choice.

With his attack on "the government's obsession with technological progress" Goldsmith contributes to a dangerously misplaced public view of science and technology as uncontrollable bogeymen leading us to our doom. Certainly we need serious and informed debate on the issues Goldsmith raises. This was nothing like it.
Adam Newey
London

It is part of the consumerist anti-ecological mindset that people cannot think through the consequences of their short-term political choices. Matthew Huntbach London mhuntbach@hotmail.com  I have recently been diagnosed with diabetes. The insulin I use is of the type known as "precursor yeast recombinant". Using a very clever piece of biotechnology, those corporations that Zac Goldsmith decries have engineered a yeast that produces pure human insulin. As such it is a genetically modified product yet far preferable to insulin extracted from pigs or cattle which, until recently, was the only choice. With his attack on "the government's obsession with technological progress" Goldsmith contributes to a dangerously misplaced public view of science and technology as uncontrollable bogeymen leading us to our doom. Certainly we need serious and informed debate on the issues Goldsmith raises. This was nothing like it. Adam Newey London

fields.headline: No holiday for teachers
fields.trailText: There I was, pleased (for once) with your leader on schools (April 19), until I came upon the old myth of 13 weeks "holiday".
fields.body:
There I was, pleased (for once) with your leader on schools (April 19), until I came upon the old myth of 13 weeks "holiday".

Pray, when do we holidaymakers find time to plan a term's lessons, covering all the subjects in the national curriculum, plus a couple more, visit museums etc to prepare class visits, troll round bookshops and historic sites buying resources and books to bolster up a flagging system? When can we set individual targets for our children, class targets for our classes, write letters to parents informing them of said targets? When can we level our children, so that the DfEE can keep a tab on our performance? Who puts up the displays necessary to provide a "stimulating and welcoming environment" so beloved of Ofsted inspectors?

Oh, I forgot the dental visits, doctor's appointments, visits to vet, hairdresser etc that has to be undertaken in my own time. Last, but certainly not least, when do I talk to my own children, who constantly remind me they feel neglected because both mum and dad are teachers? Please think again before you perpetrate the myth still further. I love the teaching bit; I know much of the paper work helps me do my job - but 13 weeks holiday is a joke or even an insult.

Pam Darby

London

darbys@waitrose.com

 The current round of teacher union carping is a moan too far. Most of us work in excess of the 35-hour week being wrangled over by teachers. I am a director of a software company where the majority of staff works in excess of 45 hours. Many of us work 50-60 hours regularly. Of the 23 members of staff, only three are non-graduates so we are vaguely comparable to teachers. The salaries of new members of staff are on a par with new teachers.

The difference comes later on; our staff start work early, finish late to complete work, work in teams and ultimately get promotion for ownership of projects. "So," all you teachers chorus, "do we." Ahh, but here's the rub, we do it all for 25 days holiday a year (some of which we don't get to take because of deadlines). So darling teachers, "wake up and smell the coffee" - live in the real world. It's all about endless paperwork, governance and, as some of you are learing to your cost "accountability". As you argue "you just want to teach the kids", so our programmers say "I just wanted to write code". Unfortunately we don't get the choice to spend a six-week break with our kids.

Name and address withheld


 So Estelle Morris is accusing teachers of lack of "professionalism" in seeking a 35-hour week. I was a teacher for 10 years; I worked in industry for 13, and now I'm a university lecturer. In none of those jobs have I ever felt the need to consider myself a member of a "profession". The reality is that in all of those jobs I've been selling my labour for a wage. The daft notion that teaching is a "profession" serves only to guilt-trip teachers. There is only one way for the government to show that it holds teachers in the same esteem as doctors and lawyers - and that's to pay them the same wages.

Alan Harrison

West Drayton, Middx

 After a fairly limp and underfunded attempt at an appraisal system (introduced by the last government), for the first time ever, teachers now have an entitlement to in-service training and can match their personal and professional targets to a school improvement plan. This can only be good news for teachers and pupils. For the NUT to attempt to link the issue to workload and hours is an error of judgment.

Martin Tibbetts

Headteacher, Cheslyn Hay Primary School

• This article was amended on 29 July 2014 to remove personal details of a letter writer
